sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 What is the matter?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: She could not give order face to face, for what was fit
To be done to one in child-bed; but after ſhe is come forth, ſhe calls out
From the ſtrect-way to them that are within-doors. O Davus, am I ſo ſlighted by you?
Or do I ſeem at laſt to be ſo fit a man for you, as that you ſhould begin ſo openly
To put tricks upon me? You might at leaſt have carried it more handſomly,
line 15 That I might ſeem to be had in ſome awe. Certainly, had I but known.—

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Certainly forſooth
This man now coſens himſelf, not I.

sp.speaker: S,
sp.l: Did not I tell you?
I charged you, you ſhould not do it. Did you ſtand in awe of me? What good hath it done thee?
Do I now believe thee this, that this womon is brought in bed of a child by Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I perceive wherein he is miſtaken, and I know what to do.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Why do you not ſpeak?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 20 What ſhould you believe? as if theſe things were not told you that they would be ſo?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Did any body tell me?

sp.speaker: D,
sp.l: What then, did you your ſelf find out that this was feigned?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Am I made a fool on?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Some body told you, for how could you come to ſuſpect it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How? becauſe I knew thee.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: As if he ſhould ſay that was done by my device.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: For I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Simo, You do not ſufficiently know me yet what a man I am.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 25 Do not I know you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But if I begin to tell you any thing, you preſently
Suppoſe I go about to coſen you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Unjuſtly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And therefore I dare not open my lips.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: This one thing I am ſure on, that no woman is brought abed here.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Have you underſtood ſo much?
Yet nevertheleſs they will bring a childe hither before the door.
Maſter, I now tell you that it will come to paſs, that you may know it,
line 30 That you may not hereafter ſay to me, that this was done by Davus's counſel or craft,
I would have this ill opinion which you have of me to be quite taken away.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How do you know it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I heard it, and I beleeve it. Many things withal concur, which cauſe me to gueſs thus. Shee now hath ſaid firſt that ſhe was with childe
By Pamphilus; it is a falſe thing invented; and now after that ſhe ſeeth
line 35 That preparation was for the wedding at home, preſently a maid
Was ſent to fetch a Midwife to her, and to bring a childe withall.
Ʋnleſs it come to paſs that you ſee the childe, the marriage is not hindred.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What ſay you? when you perceived they plotted ſuch a thing, why did you not forthwith tell

l.hi: Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why then who elſe withdrew him from her; but I?
line 40 For truly we all know how dearly he loved her.
Now he deſires he may have a wife; to conclude, let me alone with the matter, and do you nevertheleſs
Go on to make up this match as you do, and hope God will proſper you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Well then, go thou in a door, and there tarry for me, and provide what is fitting to be provided.
He hath not inforced me wholly to beleeve theſe things, & yet I know not
line 45 Whether all he told me be true or not, but I make no great matter of it; That is the main thing to me,
Which my ſon hath promiſed me. Now will I meet Chremes, and intreat
For a wife for my ſon; if I prevail; what ſhould I deſire elſe, but
That the marriage may be to day? for if my ſon will not do what
He hath promiſed, I make no queſtion but I can force him to it;
And look where Chremes himſelf comes toward me in the very nick of time.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l:
ADhuc, Archillis, quae adſolent, quae
que oportent
Signa eſſe ad ſalutem, omnia huic eſſe video.
Nunc primùm fac iſtaec ut lavet: poſt deinde
Quod juſſi, ei date bibere, & quantum imperavi, date.
line 5 Mox ego huc revertar. Perecaſtor ſcitus puer natus eſt
Pamphilo. Deos quaeſo, ut ſit ſuperſtes, quandoquidem

Ipſe eſt ingenio bono, cùm
que huic veritus eſt
Optumae adoleſcenti facere injuriam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Vel hoc quis non credat, quite nôrit, abs te eſſe ortum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Quidnam eſt id?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non imperabat coràm quid opus facto eſſet
Puerperae; ſed poſtquam egreſſa eſt, illis, quae ſunt intus clamat
De viâ. O Dave, itáne contemnor abs te, aut itáne
Tandem idoneus tibi videar eſſe, quem tu apertè
Fallere incipias dolis? Saltem accuratè, ut metui
line 15 Videar; certè ſi reſciverim—.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Certè hercle
Nunc ipſus ſe fallit, haud ego.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Dixin'tibi?
Interminatus ſum, ne faceres: num veritus? quid retulit?
Credon' tibi hoc nunc, peperiſſe hanc è Pamphilo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Teneo quid erret; & quid agam, habeo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid taces?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 20 Quid credas? quaſi non renunciata tibi ſint haec ſic fore?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Mihin' quiſquam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eho, an tute intellêxti hoc adſimularier?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Irrideor?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Renunciatum eſt; nam quî iſtaec incidit tibi ſuſpitio?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quî? quia te nôram.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quaſi tu dicas, factum id conſilio meo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Certè enim ſcio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non ſatis me pernôſti etiam qualis ſim, Simo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 25 Egóne te?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sed ſi quid tibi narrare cepi, continuò dari
Tibi verba cenſes.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Falsò.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l:
Ira
que hercle nihil mutire jam. audeo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hoc ego ſcio unum, neminem peperiſſe hîc.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Intellextin'?
Sed nihilo ſecius puerum deferent huc ante oſtium.
Id ego nunc tibi, here, renuncio futurum, ut ſis ſciens:
line 30 Ne tu hoc mihi poſterius dicas, Davi factum conſilio aut dolis.
Prorſus à me opinionem tuam eſſe ego amotam volo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Unde id ſcis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Audivi & credo. Multa concurrunt ſimul,
Qui conjecturam nunc hanc facio. Jam priùs haec ſe è Pamphilo
Gravidam dixit eſſe; inventum eſt falſum: nunc poſtquam videt
line 35 Nuptias domi apparari, miſſa eſt ancilla illico
Obſtetricem accerſitum ad eam, & puerum ut aſſerat ſimul:
Hoc niſi fit, puerum ut tu videas, nihil moventur nuptiae.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid ais? cùm intellexeras id conſilii capere, cur non dixti extemplo
Pamphilo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quis igitur eum ab illa abſtraxit niſi ego?
line 40 Nam omnes nos quidem ſcimus quâm miſerè hanc amârit, nunc ſibi
Uxorem expetit; poſtremò id mihi da negotii, tu tamen has
Nuptias perge facere, ita ut facis, & id ſpero adjuturos deos.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Imò, abi intro; ibi me operire, & quod parato opus eſt, para.

Non impulit me haec omnino ut crederem, at
que haud ſcio
line 45 An quae dixit ſint vera omnia, ſed parvi pendo. Illud mihi maximum eſt,
Quod mihi pollicitus eſt ipſe gnatus. Nunc Chremetem co •• eniam, orabo
Gnato uxorem ſi impetro, quid aliâs malim, quàm hodie fiori
Has nuptias? nam gnatus quod pollicitus eſt, haud dubium id mihi;
Si nolit, quin eum meritò poſſim cogere;
line 50 Atque adeò ipſo tempore eccum ipſum obviam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I Bid you good marrow Chremes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: O you are the man I ſought for.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: And I for you.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: You come at a wiſh: There were ſome came to me
Who ſaid they heard it from you, that my daughter ſhould be married
To your ſon to day; I come to ſee whether you or they be out of your wits.
line 5 Hear me in a few words, and you ſhall know what I would have you do, and what you enquire after.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I hear you. Speak what you have a minde to ſay.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I intreat you for Gods ſake, and for our friendſhip, Chremes,
Which begun when we were little ones, and hath grown up together with our age;
And for your only daughters ſake, and my ſons ſake,
line 10 The ſaving of whom lieth chiefly in your power,
That you would help me in this matter, and like as
The marriage ſhould have been, ſo that it may be made.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ah, do not intreat me;
As though you muſt obtain this of me by intreating.
You take me to be another kind of man now, then heretofore, when I promiſed her.
line 15 If it be good for both parties that the marriage be made, bid her be fetcht,
But if there be more harm then good in this matter
To both, I intreat you to conſult for the good of all parties,
As if ſhe were your daughter, and I Pamphilus's father.

sp.speaker: S▪
sp.l: Yea Chremes ſo I mean, and deſire that it may be ſo effected.
line 20 Neither would I deſire it of you, if the matter it ſelf did not give occaſion.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: There is a falling out betwixt Glycerie and my ſon.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I hear you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: So great that I hope they may be parted.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Theſe are but tales.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Truly it is ſo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: So indeed as I will tell you,
The falling out of lovers is the renewing of love.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 25 Alas, I entreat you, that we may prevent it, whilſt time ſuffereth,
And whilſt his hot love is ſtopt by their bitter ſpeeches,
Before theſe womens rogueries and tears feigned through wiles
Work his weak minde again to compaſſion of them.
Let us give him a wife; I hope Chremes, that he being engaged by uſe of company and honeſt wedlock,
line 30 Will afterwards eaſily winde himſelf out of thoſe miſchiefs.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: It ſeemeth ſo to you; but I think it cannot be,
That either he ſhould continue with her, or that I ſhould abide it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How then do you know that, before you have made triall?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 35 But it is an hard caſe to make that trial in my daughter.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Verily, all the worſt that can be cometh but to this at laſt,
If it ſhould come to paſs, which God forbid, a divorce;
But if he ſhall be reformed, ſee how many good things come of it;
Firſt and foremoſt, you ſhall reſtore his ſon to your friend,
line 40 You ſhall get a ſure ſon in law to your ſelf, and a husband to your daughter.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What ſay you ſo? if you be perſwaded that this is ſo expedient,
I ſhould be loth to hinder you of any good turn I can do you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Chremes, I have for good reaſon always loved you more then any man

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: But what ſay you?

sp.speaker: S,
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: How know you that they are now fallen out
line 45 Amongſt themſelves?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Davus himſelf who is very privie
To their counſels, told me, and he perſwadeth me
To haſten on the marriage as faſt as I can. Do you think
He would do it, except be knew my ſon deſire theſe ſame things?
Beſides you ſhall hear what he ſaith. Ho,
line 50 Call Davus forth hither. But l • I ſee him coming out of doors.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: IUbeo Chremetem.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: O, teipſum quaerebam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Et ego te.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Optato advenis. Aliquot adierunt me
Exte auditum, qui aiebant hodie filiam meam
Nubere gnato tuo; id viſo, tun' an illi inſaniant.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 5 Auſculta paucis, & quid ego te velim, & tu quid quaeris
Scies.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Auſculto, loquere quid velis.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Per ego te Deos oro, & noſtram amicitiam, Chreme,
Quae incepta à parvis cum aetate accrevit ſimul,
Perque unicam gnatam tuam & gnatum meum,
line 10 Cujus tibi poteſtas ſumma ſervandi datur,
Ut me adjuves in hâc re, atque ita, ut nuptiae
Fuerant futurae, fiant.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ah, ne me obſecra,
Quaſi hoc te orando imperare à me oporteat.

Alium eſſe cenſes nunc me at
que olim cùm dabam?

line 15 Si in rem eſt utri
que ut fiant, accerſi jube.
Sed ſi ex eâ re plus mali eſt quàm commodi

Utri
que ; id te oro in commune ut conſulas,

Quaſi illa tua ſit, Pamphili
que ego ſim pater.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Immò ita volo, itá
que poſtulo ut fiat, Cheme,

line 20 Ne
que poſtulem abs te, niſi ipſa resmoneat.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: S,
sp.l: Irae ſunt inter Glycerium & gnatum.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Audio,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ita magnae ut ſperem poſſe avelli.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Fabulae.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Profectò ſic eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sic hercle ut dicam tibi,
Amantium itae amoris integratio eſt..
line 25 Hem, id te oro, ut antè eamus dum tempus datur,

Dum
que ejus libido occluſa eſt contumeliis,
Priùs quàm harum ſcelera & lachrymae confictae dolis▪
Reducant animum aegrotum ad miſericordiam;
Uxorem demus; ſpero confuetudine &
line 30 Conjugio liberali devinctum, Chreme,
Dein facilè ex illis ſeſe emerſurum malis.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Tibi ita hoc videtur; at ego non poſſe arbitror,
Neque illum hanc perpetuò habere, neque me perpeti.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quî ſcis ergò iſtuc, niſi periculum feceris?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 35 At iſtuc periculum in filiâ fieri grave eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Nempe incommoditas deni
que huc omnis redit,
Si eveniat, quod dii prohibeant, diſceſſio.
At ſi corrigetur, quot commoditates vide.
Principio, amico filium reſtitueris,
line 40 Tibi generum firmum, & filiae invenies virum.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc? ſi ita iſtuc animum indûxti eſſe utile,
Nolo tibi ullum commodum in me claudier.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Meritò te ſemper maxumi feci, Chreme.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sed quid ais?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Qui ſcis eos nunc inter ſe
line 45 Diſcordare?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ipſus mihi Davus, qui intimus eſt
Eorum conſiliis, dixit, & is mihi perſuadet
Nuptias quantum queam ut maturem. Num cenſes
Faceret, filium niſi ſciret eadem haec velle?
Túte adeò jam ejus audies verba. Heus,
line 50 Evocate huc Davum. Atque eccum video foras exire.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I Was coming to you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why is not the Bride ſent for?
It draweth towards night already.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do you hear him, Davus! I was erewhile
Something afraid of you, leſt you ſhould do as the common ſort of ſervants
Are wont, that you deceive me by knaviſh tricks, becauſe my ſon is in love.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Should I do ſo?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I thought ſo, and therefore fearing it
I concealed from you, that which I will now tell you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: You ſhall know, for I dare now
Almoſt truſt you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you know at laſt what a man I am?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: This marriage was not to have been.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What not?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But I diſsembled for this reaſon, that I might try you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It is juſt ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 See, I could never perceive ſo much. O not able piece of policies!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hear me this, As ſoon as I bade you go in hence, this man
Met me very fitly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What are we quite undone?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I told him thoſe things
Which you told me erewhile.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I intreat him
To beſtow his daughter, and with much ado I prevailed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How now, what ſaid you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 I ſay it is very well done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Now there is no ſtop in him.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I will go home now, and bid things be got ready, and bring word hither again.
Now Davus, I intreat you, ſeeing thou alone haſt brought this marriage to paſs for me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I alone indeed.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Endeavour a little further to reform my ſon.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Truly I will do the beſt I can.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: You may do it now, whilſt he is netled.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 20 Set your heart at reſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do it then; where is be now?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: It is a marvel if he be not at home.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I will go to him, and tell him theſe ſame things juſt as I told you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am an undone man. What ſhall hinder me from going ſtraightway
Hence into the houſe of correction? No intreaty will ſerve. I have ſet all out order.
I have deceived my maſter, I have thrown my maſters ſon on a marriage,
line 25 I cauſed that the wedding ſhould be to day, this man not dreaming of it, and againſt Pamphilus's minde. Fie upon
Craft! But if I could have been quiet, no harm had happened; but
Lo I ſee him himſelf; I wiſh I had ſome place here, whence I might throw my ſelf headlong.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: A Dre •… ibam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quidnam eſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cur non uxor accerſitur?
Jam ad veſperaſcit.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Audin' tu illum? Ego dudum nonnihil
Veritus ſum, Dave, abste, ne faceres idem quod vulgus ſervorum
Solet, dolis ut me deluderes, propterea quod amat filius.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Egon' iſtuc f • cerem?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l:
Credidi, id
que adeo metuens
Vos celavi, quod nunc dicam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Scies, nam propemodum
Habeo tibi jam fidem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tandem cognoviſti qui ſiem?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non fuerunt nuptiae futurae.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid non?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sed eâ gratiâ
Simulavi, vos ut pertentarem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sic res eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Vide, nunquam iſtuc quivi ego intelligēre. Vah conſilium
Callidum!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hoc audi. Ut hinc te introire juſſi, opportunè
Hic fit mihi obviam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, numnam perimus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Narro huic quae tu
Dudum narrâſti mihi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quidnam audio?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Gnatam ut det,

Oro, vix
que id exoro.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Occidi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hem, quid dixiſti?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Optume inquam factum.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nunc per hunc nulla eſt mora.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l:
Domum modò ibo; ut apparentur dicam, at
que huc renuncio

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nunce te oro, Dave, quum ſolus mihi effeciſti has nuptias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ego verò ſolus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Corrigere mihi gnatum pot • ò enitere.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Faciam hercle ſeduló.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Potes nune dum animus irritatus eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 20 Quieſcas.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Age igitur: ubi nunc eſt ipſus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mirum, ni domi eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ibo ad eum, atque eadem haec quae tibi dixi, dicam itidem illi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nullus ſum. Quid cauſae eſt, quin hinc in piſtrinum rectâ
Proficiſcar viâ? Nihil preci loci relictum eſt. Jam perturbavi omnia.
Herum fefelli, in nuptias conjeci herilem filium, Feci hodiè

line 25 Ut fierent, inſperante hoc, at
que invito Pamphilo. Hem
Aſtutias! quod ſi quieſſem, nihil eveniſſet mihi; ſed eccum ipſum
Video, video; utinam mihi eſſet aliquid hic, quo nunc me praecipitem darem.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: WHere is that Varlet, that hath undone me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Yet I confeſs,
This hath juſtly befallen me, becauſe I am ſo ſottiſh, and ſo void
Of counſel: O that I ſhould commit my fortunes to a prating ſlave!
There am I rightly ſerved for my folly: but he ſhall never go ſcot-free with it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 I am ſure I ſhall be ſafe hereafter; if I but now eſcape this ſcouring.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: For what ſhall I now ſay to my father? ſhall I ſay I will not marry her, who have but lately promiſed to do ſo?
With what confidence ſhould I dare to do it? Neither do I know
What I ſhould now do with my ſelf.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nor I with my ſelf, and yet I do what I can about it.
I will tell him I will finde out ſome remedy by and by, that I may make this puniſhment be delayed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 10 Oh.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am ſeen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Come hither good Sir, what ſay you?
Do you not ſee how I poor man am intangled by your advice?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But I will rid you by and by.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Will you rid me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Yes indeed, Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Forſooth as you did lately.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nay, better I hope.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Oh, how ſhould I credit you, you rogue? will you recover a matter
Full of trouble, and paſt help? Alas, what a fellow have I relyed on,
line 15 Who haſt thrown me to day upon a match, when all was quiet with me?
Did not I tell you that this would come to paſs?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You told me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What have you deſerved?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: The gallows.
But if I may but come to my ſelf a little, I will preſently find ſome remedy.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Wo is me,
That I have no ſpace to puniſh thee as I deſire,
For this time permitteth me to look to my ſelf, not to be revenged on you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: UBi illie eſt ſcelus, qui me perdidit?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Perii.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Atque hoc
Confiteor jure mihi obtigiſſe, quandoquidem tam iners, tam nullius
Conſilii ſum. Servon' fortunas meas me commiſiſſe futili:
Ergo pretium ob ſtultitiam fero; ſed in ultum id nunquam auferet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Poſthaec incolumem ſat ſcio fore me, nunc ſi devito hoc malum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: N • m quid ego nunc dicam patri? negabon' velle me, modò qui ſum
Pollicitus ducere? Quâ fiduciâ facere id audeam? nec quid me
Nunc faciam ſcio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nec quid de me, atque id ago ſedulò.
Dicam aliquid me jam inventurum, ut huic malo aliquam producam
line 10 Moram.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ohe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Viſus ſum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ehodum bone vir, quid ais?
Viden' me tuis conſiliis miſerum impeditum eſſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At jam expediam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Expedies?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Certè, Pamphile.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nempe ut modo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Immò melius
Spero.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Oh, tibi ego ut credam, furcifer? Tu rem impeditam
Et perditam reſtitues? hem, quo fretus ſim, qui me hodie
line 15 Ex tranquilliſſima re conjeciſti in nuptias? annon
Dixi eſſe hoc futurum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dixti.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid meritus es?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: • rucem.
Sed ſi paululùm ad me redeam, jam aliquid deſpiciam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Hei mihi,
Cùm non habeo ſpatium ut de te ſumam ſuppilcium ut volo:

Nam
que hoc tempus praecavere mihi, haud te ulciſci ſinit.

l.hi: IS this a thing to be believed or mentioned, that ſo mach peeviſhneſs

Should be bred in any man, as to delight in miſchief, and ſeek to get His own commodity by anothers diſcommodity? Alas, is it true? Yea, That is the worſt kind of men, who have a little ſhame now aad then in denying;

l.label: line 5
l.hi: Afterwards when it is time that their promiſes ſhould be performed, then
Being forced they have no way but to lay open themſelves, and they are loth, yet the matter drives them to deny.
Then is their ſpeech moſt ſhameleleſs; Who are you? What are you to me?
Why ſhould you deſire to have my ſweetheart? Do you hear Sir, I am my own next neighbour: Yet for all this, if you ask,
Where is faith? they are aſhamed of nothing. Here where there is need, they are not afraid; there where is no

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Need, they are afraid: But what ſhould I do? Should I go to him
And take him up for this injury? I ſhall give him many ſhrewd words, But may ſome body ſay,
You will do no good: I ſhall be ſure to trouble him ſufficiently
And eaſe my own minde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Charinus, I have undone you and my ſelf unawares,

l.hi: Except God look upon us.
Yes, forſooth, unawares.

l.label: line 15
l.hi: You have got an excuſe now at laſt, you have broke your promiſe.
What now at laſt?
Yea you deſire to deceive me now with theſe words.
What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: After I told you that I was in love with Philumena, ſhe pleaſed you. Wo is me poor man,

l.hi: Who eſteemed your minde by my own.
You are miſtaken.
Did not this
Joy ſeem to you ſolid enough, except you muſt call me on being in love, 〈◊〉 . And draw me on with vain hope? You may take her.
I take her? 〈…〉 as you know not in what troubles I am, and what cares this bangman •… mine hath wrought me by his projects.
What is that •… ſuch ſtrange matter, he takes example by you?
You would not 〈◊〉 ſo,
If you either underſtood me, or my love.
I know you chid with your father

l.label: line 25
l.hi: Erewhile, and he is angry with you for it, neither could he force you to day
To marry her.
Nay indeed, whereby you do not ſo well apprehend my grief,
This marriage was not intended for me, nor did any man deſire now
To give me a wife.
I know you are compelled by your own will.
Tarry,
You do not yet know.
I know certainly, that you will marry her.
Why do you kill me?

l.label: line 30
l.hi: Hear me this; he never gave over to urge, to perſwade,
And intreat me to tell my father I would marry her, and ſo far untill he enforced me to it.
What fellow did that?
Davus.
Davus?
He ſets all on heaps.
Why did he ſo?
I know not, except I think God was offended with me;
Becauſe I gave ear to him.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Did you do this, Davus?

l.hi: I did it.

l.label: line 35
l.hi: Ha, what do you ſay, you rogue? But God give thee an ill end anſwerable to thy doings.
Come on, tell me if all his enemies would have thrown upon a marriage,
What other advice then this, could they give him?
I am deceived, but not diſcouraged.
I know it.
It hath no ſucceſs this way, we will try another way; unleſs you think this,
Becauſe it ſucceeded not well at the firſt, this miſchief cannot

l.label: line 40
l.hi: Be remedied.
Yes indeed, for I verily beleeve, if you ſet your ſelf to it,
You will make me two marriages of one.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I, Pamphilus,

l.hi: Ow you this, as I am your ſervant, to ſtrive with might and main, night
And day to adventure my life to do you good. It is your part
To pardon me if any thing have hapned beſides what we looked for. That which I did, had no good ſucceſs; yet I do

l.label: line 45
l.hi: The beſt that I can. Or do you finde a better remedy, and let me alone.
I am content. Set me again in what condition you found me:
I will do it.
But it muſt be done preſently.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ho, whiſt, ſtay a little, Glyceries door creaks.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: That is nothing to you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am deviſing a way.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What now at the laſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But I will find a device for you by and by.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: HOccine eſt credibile aut memorabile, tanta vecordia cuiquam
Innata ut ſiet, ut malis gaudeat, atque ex incommodis
Alterius ſua ut comparet? Ah, idne eſt verum? Immó
Id eſt genus hominum peſſimum, in denegando modò quis pudor
line 5 Paululum adeſt: pòſt ubi tempus eſt promiſſa jam perfici, cum coacti
Neceſſariò ſe aperiunt, & timent: & tamen res premit eos denegare.
Ibi tum eorum impudentiſſima oratio eſt. Quis tu es? quis mihi es?
Cur meam tibi? Heus, Proximus ſum egomet mihi. Attamen ubi fidis
Si roges? nihil pudet. Hic ubi opus eſt non verentur: illîc ubi nihil
line 10 Opus eſt verentur. Sed quid agam? adeàmne ad eum, & cum eo
Injuriam hanc expoſtulem: ingeram multa mala, atque aliquis
Dicat, nihil promoveris. Multùm moleſtus certè ei fuero,

At
que animo morem geſſero.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Charine, & te & me imprudens
Perdidi, niſi quid dii reſpiciunt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Itáne imprudens?
line 15 Tandem inventa eſt cauſa, ſolviſti fidem.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid tandem?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Etiam nunc me ducere his dictis poſtulas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Poſtquam me amare dixi, complacita eſt tibi. H • u me miſerum,
Qui tuum animum ſpectavi ex animo meo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Falſus es.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nonne tibi
Satis eſſe hoc viſum ſolidum eſt gaudium, niſi me lact aſſes amantem,
line 20 Et falſâ ſpe produceres? Habeas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Habeam? ah neſcis quantis

In malis verſer miſer; quantá •
que hic ſuis conſiliis mihi
Confecit ſoilic tudines meus carnifex.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc
Tam mitum eſt, de te ſi exemplum capit?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Haud iſtuc dicas,
Si cognôris vel me, vel amorem meum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scio cum patre altercâſti.
line 25 Dudum & is propterea tibi ſuccenſet, nec te quivit hodie cogere
Illam ut duceres.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Immò etiam, quò tu minus ſcis aerumnas meas,
Hae nuptiae non apparabantur mihi, nec poſtulabat nunc quiſquam
Uxorem dare.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scio tu coactus tuâ voluntate es.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Mane.
Nondum ſcis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scio equidem illam ducturum eſſe te.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Cur me enecas?
line 30 Hoc audi; nunquam deſtitit inſtare, ut dicerem me eſſe ducturum
Patri, ſuadere, orare; uſque adeò donec perpulit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quis homo
Iſtuc?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Davus.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Davus?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Interturbat omnia.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quamobrem?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Neſcio niſi mihi D •• s ſatis ſcio fuiſſe iratos
Quia auſcultaverim.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Factum hoc eſt, Dave?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Factum.
line 35 Hem, quid ais, ſcelus? At tibi dii dignum factis exitium duint,
Eho, dic mihi, ſi omnes hunc conjectum in nuptias inimici vellent,
Quod niſi hoc, conſilium darent?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Deceptus ſum, at non defatigatus.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hâc non ſuccedit; aliâ aggrediemur viâ: niſi id putas.
Quia primò proceſſit parùm, non poſſe jam ad ſalutem converti
line 40 Hoc malum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Immò etiam: nam ſatis credo, fi advigilaveris,
Ex unis geminas mihi conficies nuptias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ego, Pamphile,

Hoc tibi pro ſervitio debeo, conari pedibus & manibus, nocteſ
que &
Dies, capitis periculum adire, dum proſim tibi. Tuum eſt ſiquid praeter
S • em evenit, mihi ignoſcere. Parùm ſuccedit quod ago: at facio
line 45 Sedulô; vel melius tute aliud reperi, me miſſum face.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Cupio. Reſtitue quem à me accepiſti locum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Faciam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: At jam hoc opus eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, 'ſt, manc: concrepuit à Glycerio oſtium.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nihil ad te.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quaero.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nunccine demum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At jam hoc tibi inventum dabo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: WHere ever he ſhall be, I will take care to find out your Pamphilus
For you, and bring him with me preſently; onely my dear, do not vex your ſelf.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Myſis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Pamphilus, you meet me in very good time.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: My Miſtriſs
Bade me intreat you, to come to her, if you love her. She ſaith ſhe hath a deſire to ſee you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 5 Alas, I am undone, this miſchief begins afreſh. That I, and ſhe poor ſouls
Should be thus diſquieted now by thy means? For I am therefore ſent for, becauſe ſhe perceiveth that I am abont to be married. Which indeed how eaſily might it have paſſed quietly,
If this fellow had been quiet?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Go to, if he be not mad enough of himſelf, ſet him on.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: And truly that is the cauſe why the poor woman is in ſorrow.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 10 Myſis, I ſwear to you by all the Gods, that I will never forſake her, no not if I wiſt
I ſhould ma • e all men living my enemies. I have deſired to have her, ſee it is fallen to my lot.
Our diſpoſitions are alike; let them be jogging that would make diſcord betwixt us.
None but death ſhall part her from me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I begin to come to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Apollo's anſwer is not
More true than this I ſay, if it may be ſo carried, that my Father may not
line 15 Think, that I was a means to hinder the marriage, I am content; but if that
Cannot be, I will go the readieſt way to work, though he think I was the cauſe to hinder it.
What a man do I ſeem to be?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: As a very a wretch as my ſelf.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am deviſing a Plot.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In other mens matters.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I know what you would fain do.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Truly, I will be ſure to diſpatch this for you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: This muſt now be done.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But I have it now.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I have it for this man, and not for thee:
line 20 Do not miſtake your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I have enough.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What will you do? tell me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am afraid this day will
Scarce be enough for me to do my buſineſs, Do not think I am now at leiſure to tell you.
And therefore get you away hence, for you do but hinder me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I will go ſee her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What do you? whither do you go, hence?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Would you have me ſay the truth?

sp.speaker: D,
sp.l: Nay forſooth, he begins to tell me a tale of a tub.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 25 What will become of me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why you ſhameleſs fellow: have you not enough that I gave you
A ſmall dayes reſpite, in that I prolong the marriage for him?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yet for all this, Davus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What then.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That I may marry her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: See
You come hither to me, if you can do any thing.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What ſhould I come for? I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nevertheleſs, if you can do any thing,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Well, I will come.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: If you can do any thing I will be at home.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Myſis, do you tarry here a little, whileſt I come forth again.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You muſt needs do ſo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Make haſte.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will be here, I ſay, by and by.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I Am ubi ubi erit, inventum tibi curabo, & mecum adductum
Tuum Pamphilum: tu modò, anime mi, noli te macerare.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Myſis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid eſt? hem Pamphile, optumè mihi te offers.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Orare
Juſſit, ſi ſe ames, heta, ut ad ſeſe venias. Videre ait te cupere.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 5 Vah, perii, hoc malum integraſcit. Siccine me atque illam tuâ operâ
Nunc miſeros ſollicitariet? Nam idcirco accerſor, nuptias quia mihi
Apparari ſenſit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quibus quidem quàm facilè poterat quieſci,
Si hic qui êſſet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Age, ſi hic non inſanit ſatis ſuâ ſponte, inſt • ga.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l:
Atque aedipol ea res eſt, propterea
que miſera in maerore eſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 10 Myſis Per omnes tibi adjuro deos, nunquam eam me deſerturum; non ſi capiundos
Mihi ſciam eſſe inimicos omnes homines. Hanc mihi expetivi, contigit,
Conveniunt mores, valeant qui inter nos diſſidium volunt.
Hanc niſi mors mihi adimet nemo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Reſipiſco.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Non Apollinis
Magis verum atque hoc reſponſum eſt. Si poterit fieri ut ne pater pro me
line 15 Stetiſſe credat, quò minùs hae fierent nuptiae, volo; ſed ſi id non
Poterit, id faciam in proclive quod eſt, per me ſtetiſſe ut credat.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quis videor!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Miſeraequè atque ego.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Conſilium quaero.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Foras.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Scio quid conere.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hoc ego tibi profectò effectum reddam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Jam hoc opus eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quin jam habeo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Huic, non tibi, habeo.
line 20 Ne erres.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sat habeo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid facies, cedó?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dies hic mihi
Ut ſatis ſit vereor ad agendum, ne vacuum eſſe nunc me ad narrandum,
Credas. Proinde, hinc vos amolimini. Nam impedimento eſtis.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ego hanc viſam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid tu? quò hinc te agis?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Verum vis
Dicam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Immo etiam, narrationis incipit mihi initium,

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 25 Qui me fiet?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eho tu impudens non ſatis habes quod tibi
Dieculam addo, quantum huic promoveo nuptias.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Dave, attamen.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ergo?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ut ducam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ridiculum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hoc fac •
Ad me ut venias, ſi quid poteris.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid veniam? nihil habeo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Attamen ſi quid.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Age, ego veniam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Si quid, domi ere.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Tu Myſis, dum exeo, parumper me operire hîc.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quapropter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ita facto opus eſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Matura.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Jam, inquam, adero hîc.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: IS there nothing that one can be ſure on? O wonderful ſtrange!
I thought this Pamphilus was my Mistreſſes greateſt comfort,
As being her friend, ſweetheart, husband, and one ready to ſerve her
Ʋpon all occaſions: but what pain doth the poor woman endure becauſe of him!
line 5 Certainly there is more harm in this, then good in that:
But Davus cometh forth; my good friend, what is that I pray you?
Whither do you carry the childe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: NIhilne eſſe proprium cuiquam? Dii veſtram fidem!
Summum bonum eſſe herae putavi hunc Pamphilum,
Amicum, amatorem, virum in quovis loco
Paratum: verùm ex eo miſera quem capit
line 5 Laborem! facilè hic plus mali eſt, quàm illic boni.
Sed Davus exit; mi homo, quid iſtuc obſecro eſt?
Quò portas puerum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: MYſis, I have now need
Of your ready feat and cunning for this matter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What are you going to do?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Take this child of me quickly,
And lay it before our gate.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What I pray you,
line 5 On the ground?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Take thee ſome ſtrewing-herbs hence from off this altar,
Amd ſtraw them under it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why do you not do it your ſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Becauſe, if perhaps I be driven to ſwear to my Maſter,
Thal I laid it not there, that I may do it ſafely.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I underſtand you:
But tell me, how came you to be ſo very ſcrupulous?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 10 Beſtir your ſelf quickly, that you may know further, what I would do.
O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: The Brides farther preventeth me;
I leave off the purpoſe which I firſt entended.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I know not what you ſay.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will make as though I came
Here hence on the right hand thee; do you ſee that you hold up
line 15 My diſcourſe, in all points as it ſhall be needfull.
I do not at all underſtand what you mean to do; but if there be any thing
Wherein you may ſtand in need of my help, or you ſee more then I,
I will tarry, that I may not hinder you in any thing that may do you good.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: —MYſis, nunc opus eſt tuâ

Mihi ad hanc rem expromptâ militiâ at
que aſtutiâ.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quidnam incepturus es?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Accipe à me hunc ocyus,

At
que ante noſtram januam appone.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Obſecro,
line 5 Humine?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ex arâ hinc ſume verbenas tibi,

At
que eas ſubſterne.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quamobrem id tute non facis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quia ſi fortè opus ſit ad herum jusjurandum mihi,
Non appoſuiſſe, ut liquidò poſſim.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Intelligo.
Nova nunc religio in te iſtaec inceſſit, cedo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Move te ocyùs, ut, quid agam, porrò intelligas.
Pro Jupiter!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sponſae pater intervenit;
Repudio conſilium quod primùm intenderam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Neſcio quid narres.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ego quoque hinc ab dextra
Venire me adſimulabo; tu, ut ſubſervias
line 15 Orationi utcunque opus ſit verbis, vide;
Ego, quid agas, nihil intelligo: ſed ſi quid eſt
Quod meâ operâ opus ſit vobis, aut tu plus vides,
Manebo, ne quid veſtrum remorer commodum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: NOw I come back again, after I have provided what was fitting
For my daughters wedding, that I may bid her be ſent for. But what is this? Verily it is a child.
Woman, did you lay this child here?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Where is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Doeſt thou not
Anſwer me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Alas, he is nowhere to be ſeen: Wo is me, poor woman!

line 5
The man hath left me, and is gone away.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O wondrous ſtrange!
What an hurly-burly there is in the market? what a ſort of men are brabling there?
Beſides proviſion is dear, I know not what I ſhould ſay.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why do you leave me here alone, I pray you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How now, what tale is this?
Ey but Myſis, whoſe is this childe? or who brought it hither?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 10 Art thou well in thy wits, to ask me that queſtion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whom elſe ſhould I ask?
That ſee no body elſe here.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I wonder whoſe it ſhould be!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Will you tell me what I ask you, or not?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ah,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Come hither on my right hand.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You dote; did not you your ſelf lay it there? you had beſt take heed
You do not ſpeak one word beſides thoſe that I ask you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 15 You rail.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whence iſt? ſpeak aloud.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: From us.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
It is a wonder indeed if a woman that is a whore deal ſhameleſly.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: This maid belongeth to the woman of Andros, as far as I can perceive.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do we ſeem to be ſo fit perſons for you to play upon?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I came in time.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Make haſte withal to take away the childe hence from the gate;
line 20 Tarry. Take heed you ſtir not any whither out of that place.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: A miſchief light on thee, thou doeſt ſo terrifie me poor woman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do I ſpeak to you or no?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you yet ſtand to ask?
Deal plainly, whoſe childe have you laid here? tell me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Do not you know?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Let what I know alone, and tell me what I ask.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 25 Yours.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whoſe yours?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Pamphilus's.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How now, what? Pamphilus's?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why, is it not?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I did well always to avoid this marriage.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O villain, that deſerves to be puniſhed!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why do you exclaim?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Which childe? was not it brought to you yeſternight in the evening?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: O thou bold-faced fellow!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But I ſaw Canthara
line 30 With her coats tuckt up about her.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Truly, I thank God
That ſome free-women were at her delivery.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Truly, ſhe doth not well know him, for whoſe cauſe ſhe begins theſe things.
If Chremes (thinks ſhe) ſhall ſee a childe laid before the door,
He will not give his daughter: but he will the rather give her.

l.label: line 35
l.hi: Truly he will not.
Moreover, now that you may know my mind,
Unleſs you take away the child, I will tumble him into the middle of the way,
And I will tumble you there in the dirt.
Truly thou art not a man in thy wits.

sp.speaker: D.

l.hi: One piece of knavery Diſcovereth another. I hear it whiſpered now amongſt them

sp.l: line 40 That this Glycerie is a Citizen of Athens.

l.hi: What now?
He ſhall
Be forced by the Law to marry her.
Why I pray you, is ſhe not a Citizen?
I was almoſt fallen upon a merry miſchief at unawares.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Who talks here? O Chremes, you come in very good time;

l.hi: Do you hearken?
I have heard all.
Have you heard all theſe things?

l.label: line 45
l.hi: I have heard all I ſay from the beginning.

sp.speaker: D.

l.hi: Have you heard I pray you?
O the rogueries! It is fit this woman ſhould be had hence to the houſe of correction.

sp.l: This is he: do not think that you make a fool of Davus.

l.hi: Wo is me, poor woman! my old Maſter, I have ſpoken nothing untrue.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I know the whole matter. But is Simo within?

l.hi: He is.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 50 You villain, do not meddle with me; If I do not tell Glycerie all theſe things—

l.hi: Away, you ſilly woman, you perceive not what is done.
How ſhould I perceive?
This is the Brides Father, it could not otherwiſe be brought about
That he ſhould know th • ſe things we would have him.
You ſhould have told me before-hand.
Do you think there is but ſmall difference whether you do all by hab nab,

l.label: line 55
l.hi: As the nature of them requires, or meerly for the nonce?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: REvertor jam ego poſtquam quae opus fuêre ad nuptias gnatae,
Paravi, ut jubeam accerſi. Sed quid hoc? Puer hercle eſt.
Mulier, tun' poſuiſti hunc?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ubi hic eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non
Mihi reſpondes?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Hem, nuſquam eſt: Vae miſerae mihi?

line 5
Reliquit me homo at
que abiit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dſi voſtram fidem!
Quid turbae eſt apud forum? Quid illic hominum litigant?
Tum annona chara eſt; quid dicam, aliud neſcio.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Cur tu, obſecro, hîc me ſolam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, quae eſt haec fabula?
Eho, Myſis, puer hic unde eſt? quiſve huc attulit?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 10 Satin' ſanus es, qui id rogites?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quem ego igitur rogem?
Qui hic neminem alium video.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Miror unde ſit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dicturan' es quod rogo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Concede ad dextram.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Deliras; non tute ipſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Verbum ſi mihi ullum
Praeterea quàm quod rogo, faxis cave.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 15 Maledicis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Unde eſt? dic clarè.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: à nobis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Mirum verò impudenter mulier ſi facit meretrix.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ab Andria eſt ancilla haec, quantum intelligo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Adeon'
Videmur vobis eſſe idonei, in quibus ſic illudatis?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Veni in tempore.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Propera adeò puerum tollere hinc ab janua.
line 20 Mane. Cave quoquam ex iſtoc excêſſis loco.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Dii te te eradicent, ita me miſeram territas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tibi ego dico, an non?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid vis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At etiam rogas?
Cedo, cujum puerum hîc appoſuiſti? dic mihi.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Tu neſcis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mitte quod ſcio; dic quod rogo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 25 Veſtri.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cujus veſtri?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Pamphili.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, quid? Pamphili?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Eho, Annon eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Rectè ego ſemper fugi has nuptias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O facinus animadvertendum!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid clamitas?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quémne ego vidi heri ad vos deferri veſperi?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: O hominem audacem!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Verùm vidi Cantharam
• 0. Subfarcinatam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Diis pol habeo gratias,
Cùm in pariundo aliquae adfuerunt liberae.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nae illa illum haud novit, cujus cauſa hoc incipit.
Chremes ſi puerum poſitum ante aedes viderit,
Non dabit: tantò herele magis dabit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 35 Non hercle faciet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nunc adeò, ut tu ſis ſciens,
Niſi puerum tollis, jam ego hunc in mediam viam

Pervolvam, té
que ibidem pervolvam in luto.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Tu pol homo non es ſobrius.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fallacia
Alia aliam trudit. Jam ſuſurrari audio
line 40 Civem Atticam eſſe hanc.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hem!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Coactus legibus
Eam uxorem ducet.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Obſecro, eho, annon civis eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Jocularium in malum inſciens penè incidi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quis hic loquitur? O Chremes, per tempus advenis.
Auſculta.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Audivi omnia.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: An haec tu omnia?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 45 Audivi, inquam à principio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Audiſtin', obſecro? Hem
Scelera! hanc jam oportet in cruciatum hinc abripi.
Hic eſt ille: non te credas Davum ludere.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Me miſ: ram, nihil pol falſi dixi, mi ſenex.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Novi omnem rem. Sed eſt Simo intus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 50 Ne me attingas, ſceleſte; ſi pol Glycerio non omnia haec.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eho, inepta, neſcis quid ſit actum.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Qui ſciam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hic ſocer eſt, alio pacto haud poterat fi • ri,
Ut ſciret haec quae volumus.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Praediceres.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Paululum intereſſe cenſes, ex animo omn ••
line 55 Ut fert natura, facias, an de induſtriâ?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I Was told, that Chryſis lived in this ſtreet,

l.hi: Who choſe rather to get wealth here diſhoneſtly,
Then to live poor and honeſtly in her own country,
Her goods are fallen to me by her death.

l.label: line 5
l.hi: But I ſee ſome of whom I may ask. God ſave you.

sp.speaker: M.

l.hi: I pray you,

sp.l: Whom do I ſee? Is not this Crito, Chryſis her full coſin?

l.hi: It is he.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: O Myſis, God ſave you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: God ſave you, Crito.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Is it ſo, is Chryſis dead? Ha!

l.hi: Shee hath undone us poor women.
How do you? How do you live? Is all well with you?
What we?

l.label: line 10
l.hi: We do as we can, as they ſay, when we cannot do as we would.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: What doth Glycerie? hath ſhe yet found out her parents here?

l.hi: I would ſhe had.

sp.speaker: Cr.

l.hi: What not yet? I came hither unluckily;
For truly had I known that, I would never have ſet foot hither;
For ſhe was always reported and held to be her ſiſter,

sp.l: line 15 Shee is in poſſeſſion of what was Chryſis's. Now for me that am but a ſtranger to follow ſuits here,

l.hi: How eaſie and profitable it is likely to be, other mens examples forewarn me.
Beſides I ſuppoſe ſhe hath now ſome friend or guardian,
For ſhe was almoſt a grown woman when ſhe went thence, They may cry out on me,
That I like a petty-fogging knave do hunt after another bodies eſtate, that I am a beggerly raſcal and beſides

l.label: line 20
l.hi: I may not bereave her of all.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: O moſt honeſt ſtranger Crito, indeed you keep your old wont.

l.hi: Bring me to her, and ſeeing I am come hither, let me ſee her.
Yes.
I will follow theſe folks; I am loth the old man ſhould ſee me at this time.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: IN hac habitaſſe platea dictum eſt Chryſidem,
Quae ſeſe inhoneſtè optavit parare hîc divitias,
Potius quàm in patriâ honeſtè pauper vivere.
Ejus morte ad me lege redierunt bona.
line 5 Sed quos percuncter, video. Salvete.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Obſecro,
Quem video? Eſtné hic ſobrinus Chryſidis?
Is eſt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: O Myſis, ſalve.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Salvus ſis, Crito.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Itan' Chryſis? Hem.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nos quidem pol miſeras perdidit.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Quî vos? quo pacto? ſatin' rectè?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nóſne?
line 10 Sic ut quimus, aiunt, quando ut volumus, non licet?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Quid Glycerium? jam hîc ſuos parentes repperit?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Utinam.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: An nondum etiam? haud auſpicatò huc me appuli:
Nam pol ſi id ſciſſem, nunquam huc tetuliſſem pedem.
Semper enim dicta eſt eſſe haec, atque habita eſt ſoror.
line 15 Quae illius fuêre poſſidet. Nunc me hoſpitem lites ſequi, quàm hîc mihi ſit
Facile atque utile, aliorum exempla commonent.
Simul arbitror jam aliquem eſſe amicum & defenſorem ei;
Nam ferè grandiuſcula jam profecta eſt illinc, clamitent me
Sycophantem haereditatem perſequi, mendicum: tum ipſam deſpoliare
line 20 Non licet.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Optume hoſpes, pol, Crito, antiquum tenes.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Duc me ad eam, & quando huc veni, ut videam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Maxumè.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sequar hos, nolo ut me tempore hoc videat ſenex.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: NOw, Simo, my friendſhip towards you hath appeared ſufficiently,

l.hi: I began to undergo danger enough. Now ceaſe your intreating;
Whilſt I ſtrive to humour you, I have almoſt befool'd away my daughters life.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nay rather Chremes, I moſt earneſtly requeſt and deſire you,

l.label: line 5
l.hi: That you would really perform the kindneſs erewhile begun.
See how unreaſonable you are through earneſtneſs; ſo you may effect what you have a minde to,
You neither conſider any mean in courteſies, nor what you intreat me.
For if you did conſider, you would forbear to burden me with your unreaſonableneſs.
What, what?
Alas, do you ask? You have forced me

l.label: line 10
l.hi: To beſtow my daughter on a yong man intangled in loue with another,
Not enduring to hear of a wife, for diſcord, and uncertainty of wedlock;
That by her trouble and grief I may cure your ſon;
You obtained your deſire, I began to do it, whilſt the matter ſuffered; and now it doth not ſuffer, you muſt bear with me.
They ſay ſhe is a Citizen herehence, there a child born, let us alone.

l.label: line 15
l.hi: I intreat you for Gods ſake, that you would not give your mind to beleeve them,
For whom it is moſt advantagious that he be as bad as bad can be;
All theſe things are done and undertaken becauſe of the marriage;
When that cauſe why they do theſe things ſhall be taken away, they will be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You are miſtaken, I my ſelf ſaw a maid chiding with Davus.

l.hi: I know it.

l.label: line 20
l.hi: But in good earneſt, when neither of them knew before-hand that I was there.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I beleeve it, and Davus told me a while before that the women would do it.

l.hi: I know not what I have forgot to ſay to you to day, as I had intended.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: SAtis jam ſatis, Simo, ſpectata erga te amicitia eſt mea,
Satis periculi incepi adire; orandi jam finem face.
Dum ſtudeo obſequi tibi, pene illuſi vitam filiae.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Immo enim quàm maximè abs te oro at
que poſtulo, Chremes,

line 5
Ut beneficium initum dudum re comprobes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Vide quàm iniquus ſis prae ſtudio; dum id effici • s quod cupis,

Ne
que modum benignitatis, ne
que quid me ores, cogitas.
Nam ſi cogites, remittas jam me onerare injuriis.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quibus?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ah rogitas? perpuliſti me ut homini adoleſcentulo
line 10 In alio occupato amore, abhorrenti ab re uxoriâ
Filiam darem in ſeditionem; atque in incertas nuptias;

Ejus labore at
que dolore gnato ut medicarer tuo.
Impetrâſti, incepi dum res tetulit, nunc non fert, feras.
Illam hinc civem eſſe aiunt, puer eſt gnatus, nos miſſos face.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: line 15 Per ego te Deos oro, ut ne illis animum inducas credere,
Quibus id maximè utile eſt, illum eſſe quàm deterrimum.

Nuptiarum gratiâ haec ſunt facta at
que incepta omnia.
Ubi ea cauſa, quamobrem haec faciunt, erit adempta his, deſinent.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Erras: cum Davo egomet vidi jurgantem ancillam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 20 At vero vultu, cùm ibi me adeſſe neuter tum praeſenſerat:

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Credo, & id facturas Davus dudum praedixit mihi.
Et neſcio quid tibi ſum oblitus hodie ac volui dicere.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I Charge you preſently to ſet your heart at reſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: See where Davus is for you.

l.hi: Whence cometh he forth?
By my means and the ſtrangers.
What miſchief is that?
I never ſaw a fitter man,
A more ſeaſonable coming, nor a better time.
Whom doth the rogue commend here?

l.label: line 5
l.hi: Now all is cock-ſure.
Do I linger to ſpeak to him?
Here is my Maſter, what ſhall I do?
God ſave you, good Sir.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What now? O our Chremes, all things are ready

l.hi: Now within.
You have looked to them very well.
Send for the Bride when you will.
Very well indeed:
That is the reaſon forſooth he is now abſent therehence. Withal, do you anſwer me this; What buſineſs
Have you there?
Who, I?
Yes, you.
I?
I ſpeak to you.

l.label: line 10
l.hi: I went but in juſt now.
As though I asked you how long ago?
With your ſon.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What is Pamphilus within? I am tormented, poor man.

l.hi: Why, you rogue, did not you tell me there was a falling out betwixt them?
So there is.
Why is he here then?
What do you think he is doing? he is chiding with her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nay, but indeed Chremes you ſhall hear me tell you a notable ſtrange matter;

l.label: line 15
l.hi: I know not what old man is come even now; but to look on, he is a ſubſtantial, underſtanding man: if you ſaw his face,
You would deem him a very honeſt man; there is a ſetled gravity in his countenance,
And truth in what he ſaith.
What news do you bring us?
Nothing indeed
But what I have heard him ſay.
What ſaith he then?

sp.speaker: D.

l.hi: That he is ſure

sp.l: That Glycerie is a Citizen of Athens.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ho, Dromo, Dromo!

l.hi: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Dromo?

l.hi: Do but hear me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: If thou ſpeakeſt a word, Dromo.

l.hi: I pray you, hear me.
What would you have?
Take up this fellow
A good heighth in a doors, as faſt as you can.
Whom?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Davus.

l.hi: Why ſo?
Becauſe I liſt. Take him up, I ſay.
What have I done?
Take him up.
If you find I have told you any lie, kill me.
I do not hear you.

l.label: line 25
l.hi: I will now vex your patience.
Although this be true.
Yea for all that, do you take care to keep him fettered. And do you hear,
Tie the beaſt neck and heels together. Go to now, I will ſhew you if I live to day,
What danger it is for you to deceive your Maſter, and him his Father.
Ah, be not in ſuch a paſſion.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Chremes, do you not pity me, to ſee my ſons dutifulneſs towards me,
line 30 That I ſhould take ſo much pains for ſuch a ſon? Well, Pamphilus; come out here Pamphilus, are you no whit aſhamed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: ANimo nunc jam otioſo eſſe impero.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hem Davum tibi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Unde egred • tur?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Meo praeſidio atque hoſpitis.

sp.speaker: S,
sp.l: Quid illud eſt mali?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ego commodiorem hominem,
Adventum, tempus non vidi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Scelus, quemnam hîc laudat?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Omnis res eſt jam in vado.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ceſſo alloqui?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Herus eſt, quid agam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Salve, bone vir.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ehem, O noſter Chremes, omnia apparata ſunt
Jam intus.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Curaſti probè.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ubi voles, accerſe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Bene ſané.
Id enimverò hinc nunc abeſt. Etiam tu hoc reſponde, quid iſtic tibi
Negotii eſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mihin'?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mihine?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Tibi ego.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Modò introii.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quaſi ego quam dudum rogem?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cum tuo
Gnato uná.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Anne eſt intus Pamphilus? crucior miſer.
Eho, num tu dixtin' eſſe inter eos inimicitias, carnifex?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sunt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Cur igitur hîc eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid illum cenſes? cum illâ litigat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Imò verò indignum, Chremes, jam facinus faxo ex me audies.
line 15 Neſcio qui ſenex modò venit; ellum! confidens, catus, cùm faciem videas,
Videtur eſſe quantivis pretii; triſtis ſeveritas ineſt in voltu,
Atque in verbis ſides.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quidnam adportas?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nihil equidem,
Niſi quod illum audivi dicere.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid ait tandem?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Glycerium
Se ſcire civem eſſe Atticam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hem, Dromo, Dromo!

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Dromo!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Audi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Verbum ſi addideris, Dromo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Audi, obſecro.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quid vis?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sublimem int • ò hunc
Rape, quantum potes.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quem?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Davum.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quamobrem?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quia lubet. Rape, inquam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid feci?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Rape.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Si quicquam invenies mentitum, occidito.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nihil audio.

line 25
Ege jam te commotum reddam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tametſi hoc verum eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Tamen, tu cura adſervandum vinctum. At
que audin quadrupedem
Conſtringito. Age nunc jam, ego pol hodie ſi vivo, tibi oſtendam
Herum quid ſit pericli fallere, & illi patrem.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ah ne ſaevi tantopere.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Chremes, pietatem gnati! nonne te miſeret mei? Tantum
line 30 Laborem capere ob talem filium? Age Pamphile, exi Pamphile, ecquid te pudet?

l.hi: VVHo would ſpeak with me? I am undone, it is my Father.
What ſayeſt thou of all knaves the worſt?
Ah Speak rather to the matter, and forbear to give ill language.

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: As though any thing can be ſpoken too ill againſt this fellow.

sp.l: Do you ſay it forſooth, Is Glycerie a Citizen?

l.hi: So they report.

l.label: line 5
l.hi: So they report! O his huge confidence!
Doth he conſider what he ſaith? Is he ſorry for what he hath don • .
See whether his colour doth ſhew any ſign of baſhfulneſs?
That he ſhould be ſo weak minded, as contrary to the cuſtom
Of Citizens, and the law, and the mind of his own Father,

l.label: line 10
l.hi: He ſhould yet deſire to have her to his utter diſgrace?
Wo is me, poor man!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Oh Pamphilus, are you now ſenſible of it at laſt?

l.hi: You ſhould have ſaid that long agoe, I ſay long agoe, when you ſo ſet your mind,
As you muſt by any means effect what you had a deſire to:
On that very day, that word was truly ſaid of you.

l.label: line 15
l.hi: But what do I do? why do I diſquiet my ſelf? why do I chaſe my ſelf?
Why do I trouble my old age with his madneſs?
Is it that I ſhould undergo the puniſhment for his faults?
Nay, let him take her, and fare him well; let him live with her.
My Father!
Why my Father? as if you had need of this father.

l.label: line 20
l.hi: You have got a houſe, a wife and children, whether your Father will or no.
There he thoſe brought that may ſay ſhe is a Citizen: you ſhall have the victory.
Father, may I ſpeak a few words?
What will you ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yet, Simo, hear him.

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: I hear him? What ſhould I hear him,

sp.l: Chremes?

l.hi: Yet let him ſpeak.
Well, let him ſpeak, I give him leave.

l.label: line 25
l.hi: I confeſs I love this woman, and if that be an offence, I confeſs it too;
Father, I ſubmit my ſelf to you, lay what charge you will upon me, command me.
Will you have me marry, and let this woman go? I will bear it as well as I can:
Onely this I beſeech you, that you would not think this old man was brought by me.
Give me leave to clear my ſelf, and bring him hither before you.
You bring him?

l.label: line 30
l.hi: Suffer me, Father.
He deſires but what is reaſon; give him leave.
Let me over-treat you.

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: I give you leave.

sp.l: I could be content to yield to any thing, Chremes, ſo I may not find my ſelf to be coſened by this ſon of mine.

l.hi: A little puniſhment is ſatisfaction to a father for a great offence.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: QUis me vult? perii, pater eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid ais, omnium?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ah,
Rem potius ipſam dic; ac mitte malè loqui.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quaſi quicquam in hunc gravius dici poſſit.
Ain' tandem, civis Glycerium eſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ita praedicant.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Ita praedicant, ò ingentem confidentiam!
Num cogitat, quid dicat? num facti piget?
Vide num ejus color pudoris ſignum uſquam indicat?
Adeon' impotenti eſſe animo, ut praeter civium

Morem at
que legem, & ſui voluntatem patris,
line 10 Tamen hanc habere cupiat cum ſummo probro?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Me miſerum!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hem: modóne id demum ſenſiſtj, Pamphile?
Olim iſtuc olim cùm ita animum induxiſti tuum,
Quod cuperes aliquo pacto efficiundum tibi;
Eodem die iſtuc verbum vere in te accidit.
line 15 Sed quid ago? cur me excrucio? cur me macero?
Cur meam ſenectam hujus ſolicito amentiâ?
An ut pro hujus peccatis ego ſupplicium ſufferam?
Immò habeat; valeat; vivat cum illâ.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Mi pater?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid, mi pater? quaſi tu hujus indige as patris.

line 20
Demus, uxor, liberi inventi, invito patre.
Adducti qui illam civem hinc dicant: viceris.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Pater, licétne pauca?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid dices mihi?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tamèn, Simo, audi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ego audiam? Quid ego audiam,
Chreme?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Attamen, dicat, fine.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Age, dicat, ſino.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 25 Ego me amare hanc fateor; ſi id peccare eſt, fateor id quoque;
Tibi, pater, me dedo; quidvis oneris impende, impera.
Viſne uxorem ducere, hanc vis amittere? ut potero, feram:
Hoc modò te obſecro, ut ne credas à me allegatum hunc ſenem.
Sine me expurgem, atque illum huc coràm adducam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Adducas?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 30 Sine, pater.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Aequum poſtulat, da veniam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Sine te exorem.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sino.
Quidvis cupio, dum ne ab hoc me falli comperiam, Chreme.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Pro peccato magno paululum ſupplicii ſatis eſt patri.

sp.speaker: Cr.

l.hi: FOrbear to intreat me; any one of theſe reaſons perſwade me to do it.

sp.l: Either you, or becauſe it is true, or becauſe I wiſh well to Glycerie.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do I ſee Crito of Andria? truly it is he.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: God ſave you Chremes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: what do you at Athens, that are here ſo ſeldom?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: It is ſo fallen out. But is this Simo?

l.label: line 5
l.hi: This is he.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do you ask for me? Why, do you ſay Glycerie is a Citizen of this place?

l.hi: Do you deny it?
Do you come hither ſo well provided?
Why ſo?
Do you ask?
Do you think to do theſe things and go unpuniſhed? Do you trapan
Young men here, that are unexperienced in the world, and honeſtly brought up?
Do you feed their fancies by enticing them on, and giving them fair words?

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Are you well in your wits? and do you take them, and their whores together?
I am undone. I am afraid the ſtranger cannot abide it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Simo, if you knew this man ſufficiently,

l.hi: You would not judg ſo. He is an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: Can this be an honeſt man?
Comes he ſo very jump to day upon the very nick of the marriage,

sp.l: That he could never come before now? Muſt we believe him, Chremes?

l.label: line 15
l.hi: B • t that I am afraid of my Father; I have ſomething I could tell him very well how to anſwer that matter.
You petty-fogging knave.
What now!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He is as you ſee, Crito, forbear him.

sp.speaker: Cr.

l.hi: Let him conſider who he is.
If he proceed to ſay what be liſt to me, he ſhall hear what he liſt not.
Do I meddle with thoſe things, or care for them? Will not you bear your own grief patiently?
For as concerning what I ſaid, it may be quickly known, whether what you heard, be true, or falſe.

sp.l: line 20 An Athenian a good while ago having ſuffered Shipwrack, was caſt a ſhore at Andros,

l.hi: And that little girle with him; Then he being in want by chance,

sp.l: Firſt betook himſelf to Chryſis Father.

l.hi: He begins to tell a tale of a tub.
Let him go on.
Doth he ſo interrupt me indeed?
Go on.

sp.speaker: Cr.

l.hi: Beſide,
He that entertained him was my Couſin. There I heard it of the man himſelf,

sp.l: line 25 That he was an Athenian. He died there.

l.hi: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Muſt I tell you his name ſo quickly? Phania.

l.hi: Ah, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Cr.

l.hi: But truly

sp.l: I think it was Phania. This I am ſure of, he ſaid he was one of Rhamnus.

l.hi: O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: O Chremes, many others in Andros heard

l.hi: Theſe ſame words then.
I wiſh it were as I hope it is, Well tell me

l.label: line 30
l.hi: What did he ſay ſhe was? Did he ſay ſhe was his daughter?
Whoſe then?
His brothers daughter:
Surely ſhe is mine.
What ſay you?
What
Is that you ſay?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Liſten, Pamphilus.

l.hi: How, do you beleeve it?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That Phania was my brother.

l.hi: I knew the man, and know it was ſo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He flying hen • e to avoid the war, and thinking to follow me into Aſia,

l.label: line 35
l.hi: Made a journey after me, he was then afraid to leave her here.
After thoſe things, this is the firſt time I • ear what was become of him.
I am ſcarce my own man, my minde is ſo toſſed with fear,
And joy, and hope, and wondring at this ſo great and ſo ſ • dden a good hap.
Truly I am glad that ſhe is ſo many ways found to be your daughter,

l.label: line 40
l.hi: I bele • ve it, Father.
But one ſcruple yet remains with me.
Which doth very much trouble me.
You deſerve to be ſhent with your 〈◊〉 ,
You ſeek a knot in a bull-ruſh.
What is that?
Her name
Doth not accord.
Sh • e had another name truly when ſhe was a little girl.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What, Crito? Do you remember it.

l.hi: I am calling it to minde.

sp.speaker: P.

l.label: line 45
l.hi: Should I ſuffer this mans memory to hinder my pleaſure,
Seeing I can eaſily help my ſelf in this matter?

sp.l: I will not ſuffer it. O Chremes, the name is Paſibula which you enquire after.

l.hi: That is ſhe.
That is juſt ſhe.
I heard it of her a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Chremes, I think you beleeve that we are all glad at this.

l.label: line 50
l.hi: In g •… earneſt; I beleve it.
Father, what remains more to be done?
The matter it ſelf hath reconciled me towards you a good while ago.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: O fine father! Chremes altereth nothing about my wife,

l.hi: But that I may have her ſo as I have had.
Very good reaſon, except your father
Say otherwiſe.
As for the portion forſooth.
That indeed is to be looked after.

sp.speaker: Ch.

l.hi: Her portion.

sp.l: line 55 Pamphilus, is five hundred pounds.

l.hi: I accept it.

sp.speaker: Ch.

l.hi: I haſte to my daughter.

sp.l:
〈◊〉
Crito, go along with me, for I beleeve ſhe ſcarce knoweth me.

l.hi: Why do you not give order ſhe ſhould be brought over hither?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: You do well to put us in mind, I will now Commit that buſineſs to Davus.

l.hi: He cannot do it.
Why can he not?
Becauſe he hath another thing which more concerns him, and a greater matter then that.
What is it?

l.label: line 60
l.hi: He is faſt in Priſon.
Father, he is wrongfully impriſoned.
Not ſo, I commanded it.
I pray you bid him be ſet at liberty.
Well, be it ſo.
But make h • ſte.
I am going in.
O what a joyfull and happy day is this!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: MI • te orare▪ una harum quaevis cauſa me, ut faciam, monet.
Vel tu, vel quod verum eſt, vel quod ipſi cup • o Glycerio.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Andrium ego Critonem video? certè is eſt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Salvus ſis, Chreme.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid tu Athenas inſolens?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Even it. Sed hiccine eſt Simo?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 5 Hic eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Men' quaeris? Eho, tu Glycerium hinc civem ais eſſe?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Tu negas?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Itáne huc paratus advenis?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Quare?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Rogas?
Túne impune haec facias? túne hîc homines adoleſcentulos
Imperitos rerum, eductos liberè, in fraudem illicis?
Sollicitando & pollicitando eorum animos lactas?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: line 10 Sanun' es?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ac meretricios amores nuptiis conglutinas?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Perii; metuo, ut ſubſtet hoſpes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Si, Simo, hunc nôris ſatis,
Non ita arbitrere. Bonus eſt hic vir.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hic vi • ſit bonus?
Itáne adtemperatè evenit hodie in ipſis nuptiis,
Ut veniret antehac nunquam? eſt verò huic credendum, Chremes?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 15 Ni metuam patrem, habeo pro illâ re quod illum moneam probé.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sycophan • a.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Hem!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sic Crito eſt hic; mitte.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Videat
Qui ſiet. Si mihi pergat quae vult dicere, ea quae non vult audiet.
Ego iſtaec moveo aut curo? non tu tuum malum aequo animo feres?
Nam ego quae dixi, vera an fal • â audieris, jam ſciri poteſt.
line 20 Atticus quidam olim nave fractâ apud Andrum ejectus eſt,
Et iſtaec unà parva virgo; tum ille egens fortè applicat
Primùm ad Chryſidis patrem ſe.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fabulam inceptar.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sine.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Itáne veró obturbat?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Perge.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Tum is mihi
Cognatus fuit, qui eum recepit. Ibi ego audivi ex illo ſeſe
line 25 Atticum eſſe. Is ibi mortuus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ejus nomen?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Nomen.
Tam citò tibi? Phania.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hem, perii.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Verùm hercle
Opinor fuiſſe Phaniam. Hoc certò ſcio, Ramnuſium ſe aiebat eſſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Eadem haec, O Chreme, multi alii in Andro
Tum audivere.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Utinam id ſit quod ſpero. Eho, dic mihi

line 30
Quid eam tum? Suámne eſſe aiebat.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Cujam igitur?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Fratris filiam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Certè mea eſt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid
T •… s?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Arrige aures▪ Pam •… hile.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quî credis?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Phania ille frater meus fait.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nòram & ſcio.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Is hinc bellum fugiens, méque in Aſiam pe • ſequens
line 35 Proficiſcitur; tum illam relinquere hie eſt veritus.
Poſt illa, nunc primum audio quid illo fit factum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: V x ſum ap •… , ita animus commotus eſt metu,
Spe, gaudio, mirando hoc tanto, tam repentino bono.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Sanè iſtam multis modis, tuam inveniri gaudeo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 40 Credo pater.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: At mihi unus ſcrupulus etiam reſtar
Qui me malè habet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Dignus es cum tuâ religione odio;
Nodum in ſc • rpo quaeris.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nomen
Non convenit.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Fuit hercle huic aliud parvae.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid, Crito? Nunquid meminiſti?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Id quaero.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 45 Egó ehujus memor • am patiar meae voluptati obſtare,
Cum ego poſſim in h • c re medicari mihi?
Non patia▪ Heus Chreme, quod quaeris Paſibula eſt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Ipſa eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: E •… eſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ex ipsâ millies aud • vi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Onnes nos ga • dere hoc, Chreme, te credo credere.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 50 Ita me D •… bene ament, credo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid reſtat, parer?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l:
〈◊〉
〈◊〉 res reduxit me ipſa in gratiam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: O 〈…〉 de ux • re, 〈◊〉 p •… ſſedi, nihil
Mutat Chremes.

sp.speaker: C • .
sp.l: Cauſa o • tima eſt, niſi quid pater
Aliud ait.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nempe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Id ſcilicet.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do •
line 55 Pamphile, eſt decem talenta

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Acc • p • o.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Propero ad filiam.
Eho, Crito mecum, nam illam me credo haud noſſe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Cur non
Illam huc transferri jubes?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Rectè admones, Davo ego
Iſtuc dedam jam negotii.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non poteſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Qui non poteſt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quia habet aliud magis ex ſeſe, & majus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quidnam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 60 Vinctus eſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Peter, non rectè vinctus eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Haud ita, juſſi.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Jube ſolvi, obſecro.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Agè, fiat.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: At matura.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Eo intrò.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: O fauſtum & felicem hunc diem!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I Am going to ſee what Pamphilus doth, and lo where he is.

l.hi: Some body perhaps
May-think I do not believe this to be true; but I have a good mind that it be thus true.
I ſuppoſe the life of the Gods is therefore everlaſting,
Becauſe pleaſures do properly belong to them, for I am immortal

l.label: line 5
l.hi: Already, if no grief at all intermingle with this joy.
What, whom ſhould I chiefly deſire now to be offered me, to whom I may tell theſe things?
What joy is that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I ſee Davus: There is no man that I had rather have

l.hi: Of all men living. For I know that he alone will be hearti'y glad of any thing that rejoyceth me.

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.l:
PRoviſo quid agat Pamphilus, at
que eccum!

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Aliquis forſitan
Me putet non putare hoc verum: at mihi nunc ſic eſſe hoc verum lubet.
Ego vitam Deorum propterea ſempiternam eſſe arbitror,
Quod voluptates eorum propriae ſunt; nam mihi immortalitas
line 5 Parta eſt, ſi nulla aegritudo interceſſerit huic gaudio.
Sed quem ego potiſſimum mihi exoptem nunc, cui haec narrem, dari?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid illud gaudii eſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Davum video: nemo eſt, quem mallem
Omnium. Nam hunc ſcio mea ſolidè ſolum gaviſurum gaudia.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: WHere is this Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Davus!

l.hi: What man is that, that calls me?
It is 1.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Pamphilus!

l.hi: You do not know what hath befallen me.
True indeed: But I know what hath befallen my ſelf.
And ſo do I too.
The faſhion of the world goeth, that you ſhould firſt know what harm I have got,

l.label: line 5
l.hi: 5. Then I know what good hath befallen you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: My Glycerie hath found

l.hi: Her Father and Mother.
That is well.
What now?
Her Father is
An eſpecial friend of ours.
Who is that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Chremes.

l.hi: You ſay well.
and there is no delay, but I muſt marry her.
Doth he dream
On thoſe things which his mind ran upon when he was awake?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: And as for the child, Dâvus.

l.hi: Tuſh, ſay no more.

l.label: line 10
l.hi: He is the onely child whom the Gods love.
I am well, if theſe things be true;
I will go to him, and ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What man is this? O Charinus, you come

l.hi: In the very nick of time.
It is well done.
What, have you heard the matter?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I have heard all; well, think of me in your proſperity. Now Chremes is yours,

l.hi: I know he will do all things that you would have him do.

sp.speaker: P.

l.hi: I know it:

l.label: line 15
l.hi: But it would be too long for us to tarry for him till he come forth; follow me this way.

sp.l: He is within with Glycerie. Do you Davus go quickly home,

l.hi: Fetch ſome body to lead her away hence: why do you ſtand ſtill? why do you loyter?
I am going.
Do not ye tarry till they come out hither; ſhe will be married within:
It will be diſpatched within doors, if there be any thing remaining to be done. Clap your hands.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Pamphilus ubinam hic eſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Dave.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quis homo eſt qui me?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ego ſum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Pamphile.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Neſcis quid mihi obtigerit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Certè, ſed quid mihi obtigerit, ſcio.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Et quidem ego.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: More
Hominum evenit, ut quid ſim nactus mali, priùs reſciſceres tu,
