line 5 Qúàm ego illud quod tibi evenit boni.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Mea Glycerium ſuos
Parentes repperit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O factum bene.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hem!

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Pater amicus
Summus nobis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quis?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Chremes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Narras probè.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nec
Mora ulla eſt, quin eam uxorem ducam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Num ille ſomniat ea quae
Vigilans voluit?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Tum de puero, Dave.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ah, deſine,
line 10 Solus eſt quem diligant Dii.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Salvus ſum, ſi haec vera ſunt.
Adibo & colloquar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quis homo eſt? O Charine, in tempore
Ipſo mihi advenis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Bene factum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Hem, audiſtin?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Omnia: age, me in tuis ſecundis rebus reſpice: Tuus eſt nunc Chremes:
Facturum quae voles ſcio eſſe omnia.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l:
Memini, at
que adeo
line 15 Longum eſt nos illum expectare dum exeat. Sequere hâc me.
Intus apud Glycerium eſt. Tu, Dave, abi domum properè,
Accerſe, hinc qui auferant eam: quid ſtas? quid ceſſas?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eo,
Nè expectetis, dum exeant huc; intus deſpondebitur;
Intns tranſigetur, ſi quid eſt quod reſtat. Plaudite.

div.p: TERENCE'S EUNUCHUS ENGLISH AND LATINE.

div.head: EUNUCHUS A COMEDIE Of Publius Terentius An African of Carthage.
div.p: Acted At the Megaleſian games, When Lucius Poſthumius Albinus And Lucius Cornelius Merula were Aediles Curules. Lucius Ambivius Turpio and Lucius Attilius Preneſtinus acted it.
Flaccus the Son of Claudius tuned it with two Pipes held on the right ſide of the mouth. It is a Greek Comedie of Menanders, Acted the ſecond time.
Publiſhed when Marcus Valerius Meſſala, and Cneius Fannius Strabo were Conſuls.
In the Year Since the City Rome was built, DLXXXXIII. Before Chriſt was born, CLIIII.

div.head: EUNUCHUS PUBLII TERENTII Carthaginienſis Afri.
div.p: Acta Ludis Megalenſibus, L. Poſthumio Albino & L. Cornelio Merula Aed libus Curulibus. Egerunt L. Ambivius Turpio & L. Attilius Praeneſtinus.
Mod • s fecit Flaccus Claudii Filius, tibiis duabus dextris.
Graeca eſt Menandri. Acta II.
Edita M. Valerio Meſſala & Cn. Fann • o Strabone Conſulibus.
Anno Ab Urbe conditâ, DLXXXXIII. Ante Chriſtum natum, CLIIII.

div.head: The Actors or Speakers in this Comedy.
The Argument, or Plot of Eunuchus, by C. Sulpitius Apollinaris.
div.l: THe Souldier Thraſo, not knowing ſo much, brought
With him a Maid which was falſly reported to be Thais's Siſter,
And beſtowed her on her. This Maid was a Citizen of Athens.
Phaedria a ſweet-heart of Thais, gives command, that an Eunuch
Which he had bought, ſhould be delivered to her; and goeth himſelf into the Countrey,
Being intreated to give place to Thraſo for two days.
A young ſtripling Phaedrias's brother (foraſmuch as he dearly loved
The little girle which was ſent for a preſent to Thais)
Is clad in the Eunuchs habit. Parmeno perſwadeth him to it.
He went in, he defloureth the Maid. But his brother
Being found to be a Citizen of Athens, beſtoweth her
When ſhe was deſtoured on the ſtripling. Thraſo over-intreateth Phaedria.

div.head: Eunuchi Argumentum. C. Sulpitio Apollonari authore.
div.l: SOrorem falſò dictitatam Thaidis,
Id ipſum ignorans miles advext Thraſo,

Ipſi
que donat. Erat haec civis Attica.
Eidem Eunuchum, quem emerat, tradi jubet
Thaidis amator Phaedria, acirus ipſe abit,
Thraſoni oratus biduum concederet.
Ephebus frater Phaedriae (puellulam
Cùm deperiret dono miſſam Thaidi,)
Ornatu Eunuchi induitur, ſuadet Parmeno.
Introiit, vitiat virginem. Sed Atticus
Civis repertus frater ejus, conlocat
Vitiatam ephebo: Phaedriam exorat Thraſo.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: IF there be any that ſetteth himſelf to pleaſe
All good men and to be offenſive to few:
This Poet profeſſeth himſelf to be one of them.
Again if there be any that thinketh he is too ſharply
Spoken againſt, let him thus think,
That an Apologie, and not an Invection is made, becauſe he did the firſt wrong,
Who by tranſlating well, but ordering them badly.
Hath made bad Latine Comedies of good Greek ones.
The ſame man hath now lately ſet out Menanders Phaſma,
And in his Theſaurus he hath ſet down that the defendant pleaded,
Of whom it was demanded why the gold ſhould be his,
Before the Plaintiff who demandeth it, declared how the treaſure came to be his,
And how it came into his fathers monument.
From henceforth let him not deceive himſelf, or think thus,
I have now given over, he hath nothing to ſay to me.
I adviſe him not to miſtake himſelf, and to leave off provoking me.
I have many other things, which ſhall now be forgiven,
Which ſhall be produced afterwards, if he go on to offend me,
So as he hath begun to do. As for this Menanders Eunuchus
Which we are now to act, he obtained, after the Aediles
Had bought it, that he might have liberty to ſee it;
It began to be acted when the Magiſtrate was there.
He cry • th out that a thief, not a Poet had ſet out a Comedie,
And yet bad added no words of his own to it;
That Colax was an old Comedie of Naevius and Plautus,
That the Paraſites and Souldiers part were taken thence.
If that be an off nee, it is an offence committed through the Poets ignorance
Who did not purpoſe to play the thief:
That it is ſo you may now judge:
Colax is a Comedie of Menanders, in it is Colax the Paraſite;
And the braggadocian Souldier he doth not deny
That he hath tranſlated thoſe parts into his Eunuchus,
Out of the Greek Comedy; but that he knew that thoſe Comedies
Were tranſlated before into Latine, he utterly denieth it.
But if it be not lawfull for diverſe men to uſe the ſame parts,
How is it more lawfull to introduce running ſervants
To feign grave matrons, naughty drabs,
A greedy paraſite, a b • aggadocian ſoldier,
A child to be ſuborned, an old man to be couſened by his ſervant,
And that folks love, hate, or ſuſpect? To conclude,
There is nothing now ſaid, which hath not been ſaid heretofore.
Wherefore it is fitting that you ſhould underſtand, and paſs it by,
If new Comedians do, what the old have uſed to do.
Do you endeavour, and give ſilent attention,
That you may fully know what Eunuchus meaneth.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: SI quiſquam eſt qui placere ſe ſtudeat bonis
Quamplurimis, & minimè multos laedere,
In his Poeta hic nomen profitetur ſuum.
Tum ſi quis eſt qui dictum in ſe inclementiùs
Exiſtimavit eſſe, ſic exiſtimet,
Reſponſum, non dictum eſſe, quia laeſit priùs,
Qui bene vertendo, & eas deſcribendo malè
Ex Graecis bonis, Latinas fecit non bonas.
Idem Menandri Phaſma nunc nuper dedit,

At
que in Theſauris ſcripſit cauſam dicere,
Priùs unde petitur aurum quare ſit ſuum,
Quàm illum qui petit, unde is Theſaurus ſit ſibi;
Aut unde in patrium monimentum pervenerit.
Dehinc ne fraudetur ipſe ſe, aut ſic cogitet,
Defunctus jam ſum, nihil eſt quod dicat mihi,
Is ne erret moneo, & deſinat laceſſere.
Habeo alia multa nunc quae condonabuntur;
Quae proferentur pòſt, ſi pergat laedere,
Ita ut facere inſtituit. Quam nunc ſumus acturi
Menandri Eunuchum, poſtquam aediles emerunt,
Perfecit, ſibi ut inſpiciund • eſſet cop • a.
Magiſtratus cùm ibi adeſſet, occoepta eſt agi.
Exclamat furem, non Poetam, fabulam
Dediſſe, & nihil dediſſe verborum tamen;
Colacem eſſe Naevi, & Plauti veterem fabulam,
Paraſiti perſonam inde ablatam & militis.
Si id peccatum eſt, peccatum imprudentiâ eſt
Poetae, qui non furtum facere ſtuduerit.
Id ita eſſe vos jam judicare poteritis.
Colax Menandri eſt, in ea eſt paraſitus colax,
Et miles glorioſus, eas ſe non negat
Perſonas tranſtuliſſe in Eunuchum ſuam
Ex Graecâ: ſed eas fabulas factas priùs
Latinas ſciſſe ſe, id verò pernegat.
Quod ſi perſonis iiſdem uti aliis non licet,
Quî magis licet currentes ſervos ſcribere,
Bonas matronas facere, meretrices malas,
Paraſitum edacem, glorioſum militem,
Puerum ſupponi, falli per ſervum ſenem,
Amare, odiſſe, ſuſpicari? Denique
Nullum eſt jam dictum, quod non dictum ſit priús,
Quare aequum eſt vos cognoſcere, atque ignoſcere,
Quae veteres factitârunt, ſi faciunt novi.
Date operam, & cum ſilentio animadvertite,
Ut pernoſcatis quid ſibi Eunuchus velit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: WHat then ſhall I do? Should I not go? no, not now
When I am ſent for by her of her own accord? or ſhould I rather ſo behave my ſelf,
As to let her ſee I cannot put up the abuſes of Whores?
Shee hath ſhut me out of: door, ſhe calls me back again, ſhould I go back again? no, though ſhe ſhould intreat me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 5 If you can do ſo indeed, there is no better or braver part,
But if you once begin, and not perform it gallantly,
And when you cannot endure, when no body ſhall deſire you,
Before you have made peace, you ſhall come to her, and tell her
That you love her, and cannot abide without her, all is daſht, you may go fiddle,
line 10 You are utterly loſt; ſhe will make an Aſs of you, when ſhe ſeeth you vanquiſhed.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Therefore do you conſider well of it, while time ſerveth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Maſter, you cannot rule that thing by advice,
Which is neither capable of any advice, nor obſerves any mean.
All theſe vices are in love; Injuries,
line 15 Suſpitions, fallings out, truce,
War, and peace again. If you deſire to make theſe uncertain things
Certain by reaſon, you ſhould do no more good,
Then if you ſhould endeavour to be mad with reaſon.
And that which you now in your angry mood think with your ſelf,
line 20 Should not I be even with her, which hath entertained him, which excluded me, which would not admit me? let me but alone,
I would die rather: ſhe ſhall know what a fellow I am.
Verily, one counterfeit tear, which ſhe hath with much ado wrung from her eyes
By rubbing them pittifully, will cool theſe words,
And you will accuſe your ſelf of your own accord, and ſuffer her
line 25 Of your own accord to puniſh you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O abominable act!
I now perceive her to be an errant quean, and that I am a wretched man.
It irketh me that I had any thing to do with her, and I burn in love, and wittingly and willingly,
Being ſenſible and ſeeing it, I am undone, neither do I know what to do.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What ſhould you do? but ranſome your ſelf being a Priſoner, for as little
line 30 As you can; if you cannot for a little, yet for ſo much as you can;
And do not torment your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do you perſwade me ſo?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: If you be wiſe:
And beſides thoſe troubles which love it ſelf hath
Do not you add more, and bear thoſe patiently which it hath,
But look where ſhe is, the very deſtruction of our eſtate,
line 35 For what we ought to have, ſhe getteth it before us.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: QUid igitur faciam? non eam? ne nunc quidem
Cum accerſor ultrò? an potiùs ita me comparem,
Non perpeti meretricum contumelias?
Excluſit, revocat, redeam? non ſi me obſecr • t.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Verùm ſi incipies, neque perficies gnaviter,
Atque ubi pati non poteris, cùm nemo expetet,
Infectâ pace, ultro ad eam venies; indicans
Te amare, & ferre non poſſe, actum eſt, illicet,
line 10 Perîſti: eludet, ubi re victum! ſenſerit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Proin tu, dum eſt tempus, etiam atque etiam cogita.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here, quae res in ſe neque conſilium neque modum
Habet ullum, eam conſilio regere non potes.
In amore haec omnia inſunt vitia; injuriae,
line 15 Suſpitiones, inimicitiae, induciae,
Bellum, pax rurſum. Incera haec ſi poſtules
Ratione cercâ facere, nihilo plus agas,
Quàm ſi des operam ut cum ratione inſanias.
Et quod nunc tute tecum iratus cogitas,
line 20 Egóne illam? quae illum, quae me, quae non? ſine modò,
Mori me malim; ſentiet qui vir ſiem.
Haec verba una mehercule falſa lachrymula,
Quam oculos terendo miſerè vix vi expreſſerit,
Reſtinguet, & te ultro accuſabis, & dabis
line 25 Ei ultro ſupplicium.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O indignum facinus! nunc ego
Et illam ſceleſtam eſſe, & me miſerum ſentio.
Et taedet & amore ardeo, & prudens ſciens,

Vivus vidénſ
que pereo, nec quid agam, ſcio.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid agas? niſi ut te redimas captum quàm queas
line 30 Minimo; ſi nequeas paululo, at quantiqueas,
Et ne te afflictes.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Itáne ſuades?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Si ſapis,
Neque praeterquam quas ipſe amor moleſtias habet,
Addas, & illas quas habet rectè feras.
Sed ecca, ipſa egreditur noſtri fundi calamitas;
line 35 Nam quod nos capere oportet, haec intercipit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: AH me poor woman, I am afraid leſt Phaedria
Should take that more heavily, or otherwiſe then I did it,
Becauſe he was not admitted yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Parmeno,
I tremble every joynt of me, I am in a fright ſince I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Have a good heart,
line 5 Come neer to this fire; you will be hot enough by and by.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Who talks here? Alas, was it you here, my Phaedria?
Why ſtood you here? Why did you not come in ſtraight?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But
Here is not a word of ſhutting out.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Why do you not ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Forſooth, becauſe indeed theſe doors ſtand always open for me,
line 10 Or becauſe I am in the greateſt favour with you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Let theſe complements paſs.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What let them paſs? O Thais, Thais, I wiſh I had
A like ſhare of your love as you have of mine, and that it might come to paſs in like manner,
That this might either grieve you, juſt as it doth me;
Or that I could value that doing of yours as nothing.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 15 I pray you do not vex your ſelf, my dear heart, my Phaedria,
I did not do it truly therefore becauſe I loved or affected any man more then you,
But ſo the caſe ſtood, it muſt needs be done.

sp.speaker: Par
sp.l: I beleeve, as it fell out, the poor woman ſhut him out of doors for love.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Say you ſo Parmeno? Well go to: But hear for what cauſe
line 20 I bade you to be fetcht hither.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Be it ſo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Firſt • elt me
This, can this man hold his peace?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What, I? very well:
But do you hear, I aſsure you faithfully on this condition;
What I hear that is true, I conceal, and keep in very well;
But if any thing be falſe, or forged, it is all abroad preſently.
line 25 I am full of riſters; I leak out this way and that way;
And therefore if you would have it concealed, ſpeak what is true.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: My mother was born at Samos, ſhe dwelt at Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This may be concealed.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Moreover a Merchant there
Gave my mother a little gire for a preſent,
line 30 Stoln hence out of Athens.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: A Citizen, or no?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I think ſhe was one,
I am not ſure; ſhe told us the name of her Mother and Father,
But her Country, and other marks ſhe neither knew,
Nor indeed could ſhe by reaſon of her age.
The Merchant told us this moreover, that he had heard
line 35 Of the Pyrates of whom he had bought her, that ſhe was ſtoln from Sunium.
My mother as ſoon as ſhe had her, began to teach her
All things carefully, and to bring her up ſo, as if ſhe had been her daughter;
Moſt folks thought that ſhe was my ſiſter:
I went thence hither with that ſtranger, with whom alone I had to do,
line 40 Who left me all theſe goods which I have.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Both theſe are falſe, out it goeeth.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do you ask?
Becauſe you was neither content with one, neither did alone give them:
For this man hath alſo brought you a good, and a great ſhare.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: It is ſo; but let me come to my tales end, as I deſire.
line 45 In the mean time, a ſoldier that began to be a ſuiter to me,
Went a journey into Caria; in the mean ſpace
I became acquainted with you; you your ſelf know after theſe things, how tenderly
I loved you, and how I made you privy to all my counſels.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Parmeno will not conceal this.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh, is there any doubt of that?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 50 Mind me this, I pray you: My Mother died there;
But a while ago, her brother was ſomewhat covetous;
He, when he ſaw this maid to be of a lovely beauty,
And skilled on an inſtrument, hoping to get a ſumme of money,
Brought her out preſently, and ſold her; By meer fortune this friend of mine

l.label: line 55
l.hi: Was there preſent; he bought her for a preſent for me,
Unwitting and ignorant of all theſe matters:
I came hither, and after he perceived that I had dealing with you too,
He made all the excuſes he could, that he might not give me her.
He ſaid, if he might be ſure that he ſhould be preferred with you

l.label: line 60
l.hi: Before me, and might not fear, leſt when I had got her,
I ſhould forſake him, he could find in heart to beſtow her on me,
But he was afraid of that. But as far as I can gather,
He hath a mind to the maid.
Was there any more betwixt them?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Nothing; for I enquired: Now my Phaedria,

l.label: line 65
l.hi: There are many reaſons, why I ſhould deſire to get her from him:
Firſt, Becauſe ſhe is reported to be my ſiſter: and beſides, that I may
Reſtore and deliver her to her friends. I am a lone woman, I have no body here,

sp.l: Neither friend, nor kindſman. Wherefore; my Phaedria,

l.hi: I deſirt to get me ſome friends by my good office;

l.label: line 70
l.hi: I pray you help me about it, that it may be done more eaſily.
Give him leave to have the greater reſpect from me
For theſe few day • s. Do you make me no anſwer?
Thou naughty queane,
Should I anſwer you any thing with your ſuch doings?
O brave Maſter of ours, I commend you. She is very ſorry at laſt, you play the man.

l.label: line 75
l.hi: But I did not know what your ſpeech tended to: There was a little girle
Stoln away hence, my mother brought her up for her own:
She is reported to be my ſiſter: I deſire to get her from him, that I may reſtore her to her friends.
Forſooth all theſe words come to this; in ſhort,
I am ſhut out, he is entertained. For what cauſe?

l.label: line 80
l.hi: But that you love him better than me; i and you now fear that wench
Which is brought hither, leſt ſhe ſhould get him ſuch a man as he is from you.
Am I afraid of that?

sp.speaker: Ph.

l.hi: What elſe then troubles you?
Tell me, doth he alone give you gifts? did you ever find
My bounty to be reſtrained towards you?

l.label: line 85
l.hi: Did not I, when you told me that you deſired to have a little maid

sp.l: From Aethiopia, leaving all my buſineſs,

l.hi: Get you one? Beſides you ſaid, you deſired to have an Eunuch,
Becauſe none but great Ladyes uſe ſuch▪ I got you one▪
I gave twenty pounds yeſterday for them both.

l.label: line 90
l.hi: For all this I am ſlighted by you. I have not forgot theſe things.
For theſe good turns I am ſcorned by you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: What is this you ſay, Phaedria?

l.hi: Although I deſire to get her away from him, and I ſuppoſe by this means
It may beſt of all be done, yet nevertheleſs
Rather then I ſhould have your diſ-favour, I will do as you would have me.

l.label: line 95
l.hi: I would to God you ſpake that word from your heart and really,
Rather then I ſhould have your diſ-favour, if I thought
It was ſincerely ſpoken, I could away with any thing.
How ſoon doth he begin to falter, being overcome with one word?
Do not I poor woman ſpeak from my heart? what thing

l.label: line 100
l.hi: Did you deſire of me in jeſt, but you obtained at laſt▪
Can not I obtain this of you, that you would but go aſide
Two days onely?
If it be but two dayes;
But let them not be made twenty days.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Truly not above two days, or—

l.hi: O •… I matter not.

l.label: line 105
l.hi: It ſhall not be, onely let me intreat you this.
Yes forſooth,
I muſt do, what will you have me do.
I love you becauſe you deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Ph.

l.hi: You do well.
I will go into the countrey, there will I pine my ſelf this two dayes,

sp.l: I am reſolved to do it, I muſt ſatisfie Thais minde.
Do you, Parmeno, ſee they be brought hither.

l.hi: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 110 Thais, farewel for theſe two days.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: My Phaedria,

l.hi: Fare you well too; would you have any thing elſe?
Would I have any thing elſe?
I deſire that you may be abſent from the ſouldier, when you are preſent with him,
That you would love me night and day, and long for me,
That you would dream on me, look for me, think on me,

l.label: line 115
l.hi: Hope for me, delight your ſelf with me, and be wholly with me.
Laſtly, ſee that you be my ſweet-heart, for aſmuch as
I am yours.

sp.speaker: Th.

l.hi: Wo is me poor woman, this man perhaps
Gives little credit to me, and now judges me by other womens diſpoſitions,
But I indeed, who am privie to my ſelf, am ſure of this,

l.label: line 120
l.hi: That I have not forged any lie, neither is any man

sp.l: More dear to my heart then this Phaedria is.

l.hi: And whatever I have done in this matter, I did it

sp.l: For the maids ſake; for I hope I have now in a manner
Found out her brother, a very noble yong gentleman;
line 125 And he hath appointed to come to me to day in my houſe;
I will go in hence, and tarry looking for him till he come.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: MIſeram me! vereor ne illud graviùs Phaedria
Tulerit, neve aliorſum, atquc ego feci, acceperit,
Quòd heri intromiſſus non eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Totus tremo
Parmeno, horr •• , poſtquàm aſpexi hanc.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Bono animo es.
line 5 Accede ad hunc ignem; jam caleſces plus ſatis.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quis hic loquitur? Ehem, tun' hîc eras, mi Phaedria!
Quid ſtabas hic? Cur non rectè introibas?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Caeterum De excluſione verbum nullum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid taces?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Sanè quia verô hae mihi patent ſemper fores,
line 10 Aut quia ſum apud te primus.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Miſſa iſtaec face.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid miſſa? O Thais, Thais, utinam eſſet mihi
Pars aequa amoris tecum: ac pariter fieret
Ut aut hoc tibi doleret, itidem ut mihi dolet;
Aut ego iſtuc abs te factnm nihili penderem.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 15 Ne crucia te obſecro, anime mi, mi Phaedria.
Non pol quò quenquam plùs amem, aut plùs diligam
Eò feci: ſed ita erat res; faciundum fuit.

sp.speaker: Par,
sp.l: Credo, ut fit, miſera prae amore excluſit hunc foras.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Siccine ais, Parmeno? age; Sed, huc quâ gratiâ
line 20 Te accerſi juſſi, auſculta.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Fiat.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Dic mihi
Hoc primùm, potin' eſt hic tacere?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Egóne? optúme,
Verùm heus tu, lege hâc tibi meam aſtringo fidem:
Quae vera audiv, taceo, & contineo optimè;
Sin falſum, aut vanum, aut fictum eſt, cont • nuò palàm eſt.
line 25 Plénus timarum ſum: hâc atque illâc perfluo.
Proin tu taceri ſi vis, vera dicito.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Samia mihi mater fuit, ear habitabat Rhodi.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Poteſt taceri hoc.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Tum ibi matri parvulam
Puellam dono quidam mercator dedit,
line 30 Ex Atticâ hinc abreptam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Civémne?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Arbitror.
Certum non ſcimus: matris nomen & patris
Dic • bat ipſa: patriam & ſigna caecera

N •
que ſciebat, ne
que per aetatem etiam potuerat.
Mercator hoc addebat, è praedonibus
line 35 Unde emerat ſe and viſſe, arreptam è Sunio,
Mater ubi accepit, cepit ſtudioſè omnia
Docere, educare, ita ut ſi eſſet filia.
Sororem plerique eſſe credebant meam.
Ego cum illo, quocum tum uno rem habebam, hoſpite,
line 40 Abii huc: qui mihi reliquit haec quae habeo omnia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: U • rumque hoc falſum eſt: efluit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quî iſtuc?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Rogas?

Quia neque uno eras content • , ne
que ſolus dedit:

Nam hic quoq bonam magnám
que partem ad te attulit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Ita ſt: ſed ſine me pervenire quò volo.
line 45 Inte ea miles qui me amare occeperat,
In Cariam profectus eſt: te interea loci
Cognovi tute ſcis poſt illa quàm intimum
Te habeam, & mea conſilia ut tibi credam omnia.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ne hoc quidem •… ebit Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh, dubiúmne id eſt?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 50 Hoc agite amabò. Mater mea illic mortua eſt.
Nuper, ejus frater aliquantùm ad rem eſt avidior;
Is ubi hanc formâ videt honeſtâ virginem,
Et fid • bus ſcire, pretium ſperans, ill • co
Producit, vendit. Fortè fortuna affuit

line 55
Hic meus amicus; emit eam dono mihi,
Imprudens harum rerum ignaruſque omnium:
Is venit, poſtquam ſenſie me tecum quoque
Rem habere, fingit cauſas, ne det, ſedulò.
Ait, ſi fidem habeat ſe iri praepoſitum tibi
line 60 Apud me, ac non id metuat, ne ubi acceperim,
Seſe relinquam, velle ſeſe mihi dare,
Verùm id vereri; ſed, ego quantum ſuſpicor,
Ad virginem animum adjecit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Etiamne amplius?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Nihil: nam quoeſivi; Nunc ego eam, mi Phaedria,
line 65 Multae ſunt cauſae quamobrem cupiam abducere;
Primùm quod ſoror dicta eſt; praeterea ut ſuis
Reſtituam ac reddam. Sola ſum, habeo hîc neminem
Neque amicum neque cognatum: Quemobrem, mi Phaedria.
Cupio aliquos praeparare amicos beneficio meo.
line 70 Id amabò adjuta me, quo id fiat facilius.
Sine illum priores partes hoſce aliquot dies
Apud me habere; nihil reſpondes?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Peſſuma,
Egon' quicquam cum iſtis factis reſpondeam?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Heu noſter, laudo. Tandem perdoluit: vir es.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 75 At ego neſciebam, quorſum tu ires; parvola
Hinc eſt abrepta; eduxit mater pro ſuâ:
Soror dicta eſt; cupio abducere ut reddam ſuis.
Nempe omnia haec verba huc redeunt denique,
Excludor ego, ille recipitur: quâ gratiâ?
line 80 Niſi illum plus amas quàm me, & iſtam nunc times,
Quae advecta eſt, ne illum talem praeripiat tibi?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Egon' id timeo?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid ergo aliud ſollicitat?
Cedò, num ille ſolus dona dat? nunc ubi meam
Benignitatem ſenſiſti in te claudier?
line 85 Nonne-ubi mihi dîxſti cupere te ex Aethiopiâ
Ancillulam, relictis rebus omnibus
Quaeſivi? porrò Eunuchum dîxti velle te,
Quia ſolae utuntur his reginae; repperi.
Heri minas viginti pro ambobus dedi,
line 90 Tamen contemptus abs te: haec habui in memoriâ.
Ob haec facta abs te ſpernor.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc, Phaedria?
Quanquam illam cupio abducere, atque hac re arbitror
Id fieri poſſe maximè, veruntamen
Potiùs quàm te inimicum habeam, faciam ut juſſeris.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 95 Utinam iſtuc verbum ex animo ac verè diceres,
POTIUS quàm te inimicum habeam; ſi iſtuc crederem
Sincerè dici, quidvis poſſem perpeti.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Labaſcit, victus uno verbo, quàm citó?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Ego non ex animo miſera dico? quam joco
line 100 Rem voluiſti à me, tandem quin perfeceris?
Ego impetrare nequeo hoc abs te, biduum,
Saltem ut concedas ſolúm.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Siquidem biduum
Verùm nè fiant iſti viginti dies.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Profectò non plus biduum, aut.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Aut? nihil moror.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 105 Non fiet; hoc modò ſine te exorem.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Scilicet,
Faciundum eſt quod vis.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Meritò te amo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Bene facis.
Rus ibo, ibi hoc me macerabo biduum,
Ita facere certum eſt, mos gerundus eſt Thaidi.
Tu, Parmeno, huc fac illi adducantur.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Maxumé.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 110 In hoc biduum, Thais, Vale.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Mi Phadria,
Et tu, nunquid vis aliud?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Egóne quid velim?
Cum milite iſto praeſens, abſens ut ſies,

Dies noctéſ
que ames me, me deſideres,
Me ſomnies: me expectes, de me cogites:
line 115 Me ſperes: me te oblectes: mecum tota ſis.
Meus fac ſis poſtren ò animus, quandoquidem
Ego ſum tuus.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Me miſeram, forſitan mihi hic

Parvam habeat fidem, at
que ex aliarum ingeniis me nunc judicet.
Ego pol, quae mihi ſum conſcia, hoc certò ſcio,

line 120 Ne
que me finxiſſe quicquam falſi, ne
que meo
Cordi eſſe quenquam chariorem hoc Phaedriâ,
Et quicquid hujus feci, causâ virginis
Feci; nam me ejus fratrem ſpero propemodum
Jam repperiſſe, adoleſcentem adeò nobilem:
line 125 Et is hodie venturum ad me conſtituit domum;
Concedam hinc intro: expectabo dum venit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do as I bade you, let thoſe be brought away.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But diligently.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But quickly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Have I not
Given you ſufficient commands?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do you go on to ask, as though i • were ſuch a hard matter?
Phaedria, I wiſh you could as eaſily get any thing,
line 5 As this is ſure to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I am like to be loſt my ſelf too, which is a thing more precious to me;
Do not you take that ſo impatiently.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No.
But would you have any thing elſe, and I will diſpatch it for you?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Set out my preſent with words as well as you can, and thruſt away
T •… copeſ-mate from her as far as you can.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I remember it, though
line 10 You ſhould ſay nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I will go into the country, and tarry there.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But do you bear?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do you think that I can
Settle my ſelf, and abide, ſo as not to come back again in the mean time?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What you?
Truly I think not; for either you will return by and by, or your dreams after a while,
Will drive you hitherway.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I will do ſome work, until I be weary,
line 15 That I may ſleep whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: You will lie waking, when you are weary,
And then you will do this the rather.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Alas, Parmeno, you talk to no purpoſe truly;
This niceneſs of minde muſt be caſt away. I pamper my ſelf too much.
Can I not be without her, if need be, for three days together?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Whoo, whole three days? beware what you do.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I am reſolved upon it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 20 O wonderful what diſeaſe is this? that men ſhould be ſo altered
By love, that you cannot know one to be the ſame he was? There was no man alive
Leſs given to folly, nor any one more ſtayed, or that could better bridle his affections, than this man.
But who is this that comes on hither? Ah, Ah, this indeed is Gnatho
The Soldiers Parafite; he brings with him a Virgin for a preſent to her. O ſtrange!
line 25 Of a beautifull countenance. It is a wonder, but I ſhall come baſely off

With this decrepit Eunuch of mine▪ She ſurpaſſeth Thai •
〈◊〉 ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: FAc ita ut juſſi; deducantur iſti.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Faciam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: At diligenter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Fiet

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Maturé.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Fiet.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Satin' hoc
Mandatum eſt tibi?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ah, rogitare? quaſi difficile ſit,
Utinam tam aliquid invenire facile poſſis Phaedria
line 5 Quàm hoc peribit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l:
Ego quo
que unà pereo, quod mihi eſt charius.
Ne iſtoc tam iniquo patiare animo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Minimé▪
Sed nunquid aliud vis? quin effectum dabo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Munus noſtrum ornato verbis quoad poteris, & iſtum 〈◊〉
Quoad poteris ab eâ pellito.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Memini, tametſi
line 10 Nullus moneas.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ego rus ibo, atque ibi manebo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Cenſeo. Sed heus tu.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid vis?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Cenſen' poſſe 〈◊〉
Obfirmare & perpeti, ne redeam interea?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Téne? non hercle
Arbitror; nam aut jam revertê •… , aut mox noctu te
Adigent horſum inſomnia.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Opus faciam, ut defatiger uſe▪
line 15 Ingratiis ut dormiam.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Vigilabis laſſus, hoc plùs
Facies.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ah, nihil dicis, Parmeno, ejiciunda hercle
Haec eſt mollities animi: Nimis me indulgeo.
Tandem ego non illâ caream, ſi ſit opus, vel totum▪ triduum?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hui univerſum triduum? vide quid agis.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Stat ſe •…

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 20 Dii boni, quid hoc morbi eſt? adeon' ho •… immu • arier
Ex amore, ut non cognoſcas eundem eſſe? hoc nemo fuit.
Minùs ineptus, magis ſeverus quiſquam, nec magis continens.
Sed quis hic eſt, qui huc pergit? Atat, hic quidem paraſitus Gnatho
Militis, ducit ſecum unà virginem dono huic. Pape!
line 25 Facie honeſtâ. Mirum ni ego me turpiter hodie hic dabo,
Cum meo decrepito hoc Eunucho: haec ſuperat ipſam Thaidem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O Wonderful! how much is one man more excellent to an another?
What oddes there is
Betwixt a wiſe man and a fool? This came into my mind thus upon th •… occaſ •• n;
As I was coming hither to day, I met with one of my own rank
And condition, a man that was no niggard, who had conſumed as 〈…〉 had done
line 5 The goods which his father had left him: I ſee him all naſty, ſlovenly,
Sickly, full of tatters and years: What apparel is this? quoth I,
Becauſe▪ I poor man, have idlely ſpent what I had; Alas, to what eſtate
Am I brought? All my acquaintance and friends forſake me.
Hereupon I ſcorned him in compariſon of my ſelf. what you, Idle fellow, quoth I,
line 10 Have you ſo behaved your ſelf, as that you have no hope left in you?
Have you loſt your wit with your eſtate? Do you not ſee me
Come from the ſame eſtate, what my colour, neatneſs, cloathing, and plight of body is?
I have all things, and yet have nothing: and though I have nothing, yet
I want nothing. But I poor man, can neither endure to be made a fool on,
line 15 Nor can I away with blows. What, do you think it is done by theſe things?
You are far deceived. This ſort of men made again of it in times paſt,

l.hi: In the dayes of old: This is a new kind of bird-catching.
Beſides, I firſt was he that invented this way: There is a ſort of men
That would have themſelves reputed the braveſt in the world. I follow theſe.

l.label: line 20
l.hi: I do not apply my ſelf to theſe, that they may laugh at me, but I laugh at them for the nonc • :
And withal, I wonder at their wits: what ſoever they ſay, I commend it; and again
If they unſay it, I commend that too; if any one deny this or that, I deny it; if he ſay it, I ſay it.
Laſtly, I have ſuch a command over my ſelf, as to flatter them in every thing;
This is the greateſt gain in the world now.
A pretty fellow inindeed!

l.label: line 25
l.hi: He makes theſe men ſtark mad that were but fools before.
Whilſt he and I talkt thus, in the mean time, as we came into the ſhambles,
There came running, and glad to meet me, all the Comfit-makers, Fiſhmongers, Butchers,
Cooks, Pudding-wrights, Fiſher-men, Fowlers, whom I had been beneficial to,
When I had my eſtate, and ſince I loſt it, and yet do many good turns too; they ſalute me, they invite me 〈◊〉 ſupper,

l.label: line 30
l.hi: They bid me welcome. When that poor hunger-ſtarved fellow ſaw me
To be in ſo great repute, and that I got my living ſo eaſily, then
The man began to intreat me, that be might have leave to learn it of me:
I bade him follow me, if be could learn; that as the Sects of Philoſophers
Have their names from them, ſo Paraſites in like manner might be called Gnathonicks.

l.label: line 35
l.hi: Do you not ſee what idleneſs and other mens meat can do?

sp.speaker: G.

l.hi: But I make ſmall baſte

sp.l: To bring this maid to Tha is, and to intreat her to come to ſupper.
But I ſee Parmeno, the rivals ſervant, ſad before Thais's door:

l.hi: All is well enough yet I forſooth men may ſtand and ſtarve here.
I am reſolved to play upon this knave.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Theſe ſuppoſe Thais is theirs,

l.label: line 40
l.hi: By this preſent.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Gnatho greeteth Parmeno his eſpecial friend With many ſalutations, what are you doing?

l.hi: I am ſtanding.
I ſee that. But do you ſee any thing here which thou wouldeſt not ſee?
I ſee you.
So I think. But ſee you nothing elſe?
Why ſo?
Becauſe
You are ſad.
Never a whit indeed.
Be not ſo. But do you think of

l.label: line 45
l.hi: This ſlave?
She is no ill-favoured one indeed.
I nettle the fellow.
How, you are quite deceived!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: How weldome will this preſent be to Thais

l.hi: Thinkeſt thou?
This is as much as if you ſhould ſay, that we are packt out hence;
But do you hear, There is an alteration of all things.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Parmeno,

l.hi: I will ſet you at eaſe for theſe whole ſix months;

l.label: line 50
l.hi: That you may not run to and fro, nor ſit up till light day:
Do not I make you a happy man?
What me! whoo.
Thus I uſe to pleaſure my friends.
I commend you.
I detain you, perhaps you had gone ſomwhither elſe
If I had not detained you,
No whither.
Then
Afford me a little of your help; cauſe that I may be admitted in to her.

l.label: line 55
l.hi: Well, go on, theſe doors ſtand open for you, becauſe you bring that maid.
Would you have any body called out hither?
Let but theſe two dayes
Be paſſed, and I will be ſure to make you that are happy, to open me the doors now with one little finger,
That you ſhall often kick againſt with your heels to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Do you ſtand here yet, Parmeno? what are you left to be a Watchman,
line 60 Leſt any Meſsenger ſhould hap now to ſtep privily from the Soldier to Thais?

sp.speaker: Par.

l.hi: Wittily ſpoken; Marvellous things they muſt be, that ſhould pleaſe the ſoldier.
But do not I ſee my Maſters younger ſon coming hither?

sp.l: I wonder why he went from Piraeum, for he is now to keep publick watch there.

l.hi: There is ſomething in the matter, and comes haſtily; he looks about him I know not at what.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: D •… immortales, ho • ini homo quid praeſtat? ſtulto intelligens.
Quid intereſt? H • c adeo ex h •… re venit in mentem mihi:
Conveni hod • e adv •… quendom mei loci hinc,
Atque ordinis, hom nem haud impurum, itidem patria
line 5 Qui abligurierat b • na; •… deo ſentum, ſqualidum,
Aegrum, pa •… ann • ſque obſi 〈…〉 Quid iſtuc, inquam,
Ornat • eſt? quoniam miſer, quod hab •• , perd • di. Hem, quò▪
Redactus ſum? omnes not • me a •… deſerunt.
Hic ego illum contempſi prae 〈◊〉 : Quid, homo, inquam, ignaviſſime,
line 10 Itáne parâſtite, ut ſpes nulla reliqua in te •• ciet tibi?
Simul conſilium cum re am •• ſt • ? viden' me • x eodem
Ortum loco, qui color, nitor, veſtis, quae habitudo eſt corporis?
Omnia habeo, neque quidquam habeo▪ nihil cum eſt, nihil
Defi • tamen. At ego infelix, neque ridiculus eſſe,
line 15 Neque plagas pati poſſum. Quid? tu his rebus credis fieri?
Tota erras viâ. Olim iſti fuit generi quondam
Queſtus apud ſeclum prius. Hoc novum eſt aucupium:
Ego adeò hanc primus inveni viam: Eſt gonus hominum
Qui eſſe primos ſe omnium rerum volunt: hos confector;
line 20 Hiſce ego non paro me ut rideant, ſed his ultro arrideo, & corum
Ingenia admiror ſimul: quicquid dicunt, laudo: id rurſum
Si negant, laudo id quoque; negat quis, nego; ait, aio:
Poſtremò imperavi egomet mihi omnia aſſentati.
Is queſtus nunc eſt multò uberrimus.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Scitum hercle
line 25 Hominem: hic homines prorſum è ſtultis inſanos facit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Dum haec loquimur, interea loci ad macellum ubi convenimus▪
Concurrunt laeti mihi obviam, cupedinarii omnes, cetarii, lanii,
Coqui, fartores, piſcatores, aucupes, quibus & re ſalvâ
Et perditâ profueram, & pr •… um ſaepe: ſalutant: ad coenam vocant:
line 30 Adventum gratulantur. Ille ubi miſer famelicus videt
Me eſſe tanto honore, & tam facilè victum quaerere; ibi
Homo cepit me obſecrare, ut ſibi liceret dicere id de me.
Sectari juſſi, ſi potis eſt, tanquam Philoſophorum habent diſciplinae
Ex ipſis vocabula, paraſiti itidem ut Gnathonici vocentur.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 35 Viden' otium, & cibus quid facit alienus?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sed ego ceſſo
Ad Thaidem hanc deducere, & rogare ad coenam ut veniat;
Sed Parmenonem ante oſtium Thaidis triſtem video,
Rivalis ſervum: ſalva res: nimirum hic homines frigent.
Nebulonem hunc certum eſt eludere.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hioe hoc munere
line 40 Arbitrantur ſuam Thaidem eſſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Plurimâ ſalute
P •• menonem ſummum ſuum impertit Gnatho. Quid agitur 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Statur.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Video. Numquidnam hic quod nolis vides?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Te.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Credo. At nunquid aliud?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Qui dum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quia
Triſtis es.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nihil quidem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ne ſis. Sed quid videtur
line 45 Hoc tibi mancipium?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Non malum hercle.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Uro hominem.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ut falſus animo es!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quàm hoc munus gratum Thaidi
Arbirrare eſſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hoc nunc dices, ejectos hinc nos.
Omnium rerum, heus tu, viciſſitudo eſt

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sex ego te
Totos, Parmeno, hos menſes quietum reddam:
line 50 Ne ſurſum deorſum curſites: neve ad lucem uſque vigiles▪
Ecquid bee te?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Mene? pape.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: • Sic ſoleo amicos.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Laudo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Detineo te fortaſſe; tu profectus aliò fueras,
Si te non detinuiſſem.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nuſquam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tun' igitur
Paululum da mihi operae, fac ut admittar ad illam:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 55 Agè modò, nunc tibi patent fores hae, quia iſtam ducis.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Num quem evocari huc vis foras?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sine biduum hoc
Pretereat, qui mihi nunc uno digitulo aperis fores fortunatus,
Ne tu iſtas faxo calcibus ſaepe inſultabis fruſtra.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Etiam nunc hic ſtas, Parmeno? Eho, inumnam relictus cuſtos,
line 60 Ne quis fortè nunc internuncius clàm à milite ad iſtam curſitet?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Facetè dictum. Mira verò militi quae placeant.
Sed videon' herilem filium minorem huc advenire?
Mir •• quid ex Piraeo abierit; nam ibi cuſtos publicè eſt nunc.
Non temerè eſt, & properans venit: neſcio quid circumſpectat.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I Am undone, the maid is nowhere to be found; and I am loſt too, that loſt her
Out of my ſight. Where ſhould I ſeek her? where ſhould I look after her? whom ſhould I ask for her?
What way ſhould I tak? I am uncertain: yet this is my onely hope,
Whereever ſhe is, ſhe cannot be long concealed. O beautifull face! I will
line 5 From henceforward blot out all other women out of my mind; I am weary of
Theſe common ordinary beauties.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But look you where the other brother is,
He talks ſomething of love.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O this unfortunate old man!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This is he indeed,
Who if he begin to love, you will ſay his other brother was but a ſport and a ieſt,
In compariſon of theſe things which his mad fit will afford.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I wiſh
line 10 Some miſchief had befallen thot old man that ſtayed me to day;
And me too, becauſe I ſtood ſtill, and did not ſet him light. But look where Parmeno is, God ſave you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why are you ſo ſad? why are you not merry? whence come you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Truly I do not know either whence I come, nor whither I go, I have ſo utterly
line 15 Forgotten my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: How, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am in love.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Now, Parmeno,
Shew your ſelf what an honeſt man you are; you know you often promiſed me, ſaying, Chaerea,
Do but find out one that you can love, and I will let you know how far
I am able to pleaſure you in that matter; when I give thee all my Fathers proviſion
Into thy cock-loft privately.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Go on, you fool.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Truly this was done:
line 20 See that you perform your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: If ſo be the thing
Be worthy that one ſhould beſtow pains about it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: The maid is not like
Our ordinary Laſſes, whom the mothers ſtrive that they may have their ſhoulders
Down, and have their bodies laced, that they may be ſlender. If ſo be
One be a little groſſer, they ſay ſhe is a Champion, they abridge them of their diet;
line 25 Although their nature be good, yet by their looking to they make them as ſmall as bulruſhes, and therefore they are loved.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What a one was thine?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Such a feature of a face is ſeldome ſeen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Wh • o.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Her
Colour is natural, her bodie is ſound, and full of good blood.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Of what yeers is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sixteen▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: The very prime of her age.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: See thou procure me her, either by force, or by privie ſtealth, or by love for a while.
It makes no matter to me, ſo I may but have her.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What whoſe maid is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 30 Truly, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Whence is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I can tell you juſt as much.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Where dwelleth ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I cannot tell that neither. Where loſt you her?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In the way.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: How
Came you to loſe her?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Truly as I came I was now angry at my ſelf for that,
Neither do I think there is any man to whom all good fortunes.
Fall out more▪ croſs.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What villany is this?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What is done?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 35 Do you ask? Do you not know Archimedes a kinſman of my faand of his age?
Why ſhould I not?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He, as I was following the maid, met me. Truly it was inconveniently.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nay indeed unluckily, for other things may be accounted inconveniences.
I may ſafely ſwear I had not ſeen him at all theſe ſix or ſeven months
Laſt poſt, but juſt now, when I had leaſt mind to ſee him, and when I h •• no need.
line 40 Why, is not this a very ſtrange thing? What ſay you?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He preſently came running to me, a great way off, being crooked,
• rembling, with his lips hanging down, groaning; Ho, h • , I ſpeak to you?
Chaerea, ſaith he, I ſtood ſtill. Wot you what I would have with you? Tell me; To morrow
I muſt have a trial. What then? I would have you be ſure to tell your father, that be may
Remember to be of my counſel betimes in the morning. He was an hour telling this,
line 45 I asked him if he would have any thing elſe? He ſaid, nothing at all, I go my way;
When I looked this way towards the maid, ſhe fairly had turned in the mean while
Into this ſtreet of ours.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: It is a wonder if he do not ſpeak of this maid which
Was given erewhile for a preſent to Thais.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: When I came hither, here was no maid;

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Did any company follow the maid?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yes, a Paraſite
line 50 With a ſervant maid.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: It is even ſhe. Say no more; the matter is now at a point.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You minde other things.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Truly I minde this.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do you know who ſhe is? tell me,
Or have you ſeen her?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I have ſeen her, and know her.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And wot you where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Shee is brought hither to Thais the whore, and is given her for a preſent.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Who
line 55 Is he that is ſuch an able man with ſo great a preſent?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Thraſo the ſouldier,
Phaedria's corrival.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You tell me my brother hath a hard game to play.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Yes,
Indeed if you knew but what a gift he hath provided on the other ſide to match with this,
Then you would ſay ſo the rather.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What I pray you, in good ſooth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: An Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That
Ill-favoured fellow I pray you, whom he bought yeſterday, that old man,
line 60 That is more like a woman then a man?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: That very ſame.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Certainly the man will be
Thruſt out of doors with his gift. But I did not know that that Thais was our neighbour.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: She hath not been long ſo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am undone. That I ſhould never have ſeen her yet.
Come tell me, is ſhe as handſome as ſhe is reported to be?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But
Shee is not to be compared to this of mine.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: That is another matter.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I pray thee in earneſt

line 65
Parmeno, ſee to it, that may obtain her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will do the beſt I can, and will do my endeavour,
I will help you; would you have me do more?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Why do you go home now?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That I may bring theſe ſlaves to Thais, ſo as your brother bade me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O that happy Eunuch, that is to be beſtowed into this houſe!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do you ask? He ſhall alwayet behold his fellowſervant at home
line 70 Of a perfect beauty: he ſhall diſcourſe with her; he ſhall be with her
In one houſe; he ſhall ſometimes take his victuals with her; he ſhall ſometimes
Sleep by her ſide.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What if you your ſelf now ſhould be made the happy man?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: How,
Parmeno? anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You moy take his clothes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: His clothes?
What then muſt I do afterwards?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will bring you in his ſtead.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I hear you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 75 I will ſay that you are he.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You may enjoy thoſe commodities
Which you ſaid erewhile he was like to enjoy. You may diet with her, you may by her touch her,
Dally with her, and ſleep by her ſide: foraſmuch as none of them
Knoweth you, nor can they tell who you are. Beſides your countenance and age is ſuch,
As you may eaſily prove your ſelf to be the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You have ſaid well, I never knew
line 80 Better counſel to be given. Come on, let us go in, dreſs me juſt now, bring me to her
As faſt as you can.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What do you mean? truly I did but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You prate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I am undone: what have I done poor wretch? whether do you thruſt me? you will throw me over by and by.
Truly I read you, tarry.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Let us go.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do you go on.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am reſolved.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Have a care this be not too raſh a reſolution now.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Truly it is not: Let me do it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 85 But the puniſhment will light upon me. Alas! we commit a villanous act.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Is it
A villanous act, i • I be brought into a bawdy-houſe, and now come even with
Thoſe whores, which contemn our young years, and continually torment us every way,
And beguile them ſo as they have beguiled us;
Or rather, is it fit I ſhould put up theſe things? It is but juſt that I ſhould
line 90 Play them a trick; which will they that know it • nd fault withal?
Every body will think it was well done.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What is that; if you be reſolved to do it, do it.
But do not lay the blame on me afterwards.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I will not▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do you bid me do it?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I bid you; noy, I charge and command you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will never reſiſt
Your authority. Follow me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: God ſpeed us well.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: OCcidi. Neque vergo eſt uſquam, neque ego, qui illam è conſpectu
Amiſi meo: ubi quaeram? ubi inveſtigem? quem perconter?
Quam inſiſtam viam? incertus ſum. Una haec ſpes eſt,
Ubi ubi eſt, diu celari non poteſt. O faciem pulchram! dele •
line 5 Omnes dehinc ex animo mulieres. Taedet quotidianarum
Harum formarum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ecce autem alterum, neſcio quid
De amore loquitur.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O infortunatum ſenem!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hic verò eſt,
Qui ſi occeperit amare, ludum jocúmque dices fuiſſe illum
Alterum, praeut hujus rabies quae dabit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ut illum
Méque adeò, qui reſt▪ terim; tum autem qui illum non
Flocci fecerim. Sed eccum Parmenonem, Salve.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid tu es triſtis? quid ve es alacris? unde is?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ego neſcio hercle, neque unde eam, neque quorſum eam, ita prorſus
line 15 Sum oblitus mei.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Qui quaeſo?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Amo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nunc, Parmeno,
Te oſtendes qui vir ſies; ſcis te mihi ſaepe pollicitum eſſe: Chaere • ,
Al • quid inveni modò quod ames; in ea re utilitatem ego faciam
Ut cognoſcas meam; cùm in cellulam ad te patris penum omnem
Congerebam clanculùm.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Agè, inepte:

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hoc hercle
line 20 Factum eſt; faxis ut promiſſa appareant.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Adeò eſt
Digna res ubi nervos intendas tuos.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Haud ſimilis
Virgo eſt virginum noſtrarum; quas matres ſtudent devinctis
Humeris eſſe, vincto corpore, ut graciles ſient. Siquidem
Habitior paulò, pugilem eſſe a • unt, deducunt cibum; tametſi

line 25 Bona eſt natura, reddunt curaturâ junceas. Ita
que ergo amantur.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid tua iſtaec?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nova figura oris.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Pape.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Color.
Verus. Corpus ſolidum, & ſucci plenum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Anni.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sedecim.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Flos
Ipſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hanc tu mihi vel vi, vel clàm, vel precariò fac tradas,
Mihi nihil refert, dum potiar modó.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid, virga cuja eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 30 Neſcio hercle.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Unde eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tantundem.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ubi habitat?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ne id quidem.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ubi amiſiſti?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In viâ.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Qua ratione
Amiſiſti?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l:
Ne
que quenquam hominem eſſe arbitror, cui magis bonae faelicitates
Adverſae ſient.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid hoc eſt ſceleris?

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.l: Perii.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid factum eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l:
line 35 Rogas? patris cognatum, at
que aequalem Archimedem noſtin'?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quidni?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Is dum ſequar, fit mihi obviam▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Incommodè herele.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Immò enimvero infoeliciter. Nam incommoda alia ſunt dicenda
Illum, liquet mihi dejerare, his menſibus ſex vel ſeptem prorſum non

Vidiſſe proximis, niſi nunc, cùm minimè vellem minimé
que opus fuit.
line 40 Eho, Nonne hoc monſtri ſimile eſt? Quid ais.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Maxumé.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Continuò accurrit ad me, quàm longè quidem incurvus,
Tremulus, labi • s demiſſis, gemens; Heus, heus, tibi dico,
Chaerea, inquit; reſtiti: ſcin' quid ego te volebam? Dic cras;
Eſt mihi judicium; quid tum? ut diligenter nuncies patri, advocatus
line 45 Manè mihi eſſe ut meminerit. Dum haec loquitur, abiit hora.
Rogo numquid velit. Rectè, inquit, abeo. Cùm huc reſpicio
Ad virginem, illa ſeſe interea commodùm huc verterat
In hanc noſtram plateam.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Mirum ni hanc dicit, modò huic
Quae data eſt dono.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Huc cum advenio, nulla erat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 50 Comites ſequuti ſunt ſcilicet virginem?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Verum paraſitus
Cum ancillâ.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ipſa eſt. Deſine, jam conclamatum eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Alias
Res agis.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Iſtuc equidem ago.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Noſtin' quae ſit? dic mihi
Aut vidiſt in'?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Vidi, novi.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Et ſcis ubi ſict?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Huc
Deducta eſt ad Thaidem meretricem, ei dono datur.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quis
line 55 Is eſt tam potens cum tanto munere hoc?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Miles Thraſo,
Phaedriae rivalis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Duras partes fratris praedicas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Immò
Enim ſi ſcias quod donum huic dono contra comparet, tum magis
Id dicas.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quidnam, quaeſo, hercle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Eunuchum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Illúmne?
Obſecro inhoneſtum hominem, quem mercatus eſt heri, ſenem,
line 60 Mulierem?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Iſtunc ipſum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Homo quatietur certè
Cum dono foras. Sed iſtam Thaidem non ſcivi nobis vicinam:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Haud diu eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Perii. Nunquámne etiam me illam vidiſſe.
Ehodum dic mihi, eſtné ut fertur, formâ?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Sane.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: At
Nihil ad noſtram hanc.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Alia res eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Obſecro hercle.

line 65
Parmeno, Fac ut potiar.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Faciam ſedulò, ac dabo operam,
Adjuvabo, nunquid me aliud vis?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid nunc is domum?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ut mancipia haec, ita ut juſſit frater, ducam ad Thaidem.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O Fortunatum iſtum Eunuchum, qui quidem in hanc detur
Domum!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid ita?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Rogitas? Summâ formâ ſemper
line 70 Conſervam domi videbit: colloquetur; aderit unâ
In unis aedibus: cibum nonnunquam capiet cum eâ; interdum
Proptèr dormiet.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid ſi nunc tute fortunatus fias?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quâ re
Parmeno? reſponde.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Capias tu veſtem illius.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Veſtem?
Quid tum poſtea?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Pro illo te deducam

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Audio.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Te illum
line 75 Eſſe dicam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Intelligo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tu illis fruare commodis, quibus
Tu illum dicebas modò. Cibum una capias, adſis, tangas, ludas,

Proptèr dormias: quandoquidam ne
que illarum te quiſquam

Novit, ne
que ſcit qui ſies; praeterea forma & aetas ipſa eſt, facilè
Ut pro Eunucho probes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Dixti pulchrè, nunquam vidi melius
line 80 Conſilium dari. Agè, eamus intro, nunc jam orna me, adduc,
Quantum potes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid agis? Jocabar equidem.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Garris.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Perii, quid ego egi miſer? quò trudis? perculeris jam tu me?
Tibi equidem dico, mane.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Eamus.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Pergin'?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Certum eſt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Vide ne nimium callidum hoc ſit modò.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non eſt profectò. Sine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 85 At enim iſtaec in me cudetur faba: •… ium facimus.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: An id
Flagitium eſt, ſi in domum meretriciam deducar, & illis crucibus,
Quae nos noſtrámque adoleſcentiam habent deſpicatam, & quae nos

Semper omnibus cruciant modis, nunc referam gratiam at
que
• tidem fallam,
Ut ab illis fallimur? an potiùs haec pati? aequum eſt fieri ut à me
line 90 Ludantur dolis; quod qui reſciverint, culpent? ill • d meritò
Factum omnes putent.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc? ſi certum eſt facere, facias.
Verùm ne pòſt conferas culpam in me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nonfaciam.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Jubéſne?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Jubeo; immo cogo atque impero.

sp.speaker: Par,
sp.l: Nunquam defugiam
Authoritatem. Sequere.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Dii vortant bene.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: ANd did Thais give me great thanks?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Huge ones.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Say you ſo!
Is ſhe glad?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Not ſo much indeed for the gift it ſelf, as for that you beſtowed it:
Indeed ſhe heartily rejoyceth at that.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I come hither to ſee, that when time ſerveth
I may bring my preſent; But ſee where the Soldier is.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Truly I have that gift,
line 5 That every thing which I do, is well taken from me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Indeed I have obſerved ſo much.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Even the King gave me alwayes great thanks for what I did; but he did not ſo to others.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He often times by words trasfers the great honour upon himſelf, which was got
By other mens pains; who hath the wit that you have?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: You have it right.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Therefore the King had you in repute.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Yes indeed.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: To delight himſelf with you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Yes;

line 10
And to commit all his armie and his counſels to me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: This is a wonder.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: And beſides,
If at any time he grew weary of mens company, or was tired with buſineſs,
When he would take his eaſe, as though: do you not know my meaning?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I know it.
As though when he would eaſe his mind of that trouble.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: You hit it.
Then had he to be his gueſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: • hoo, you tell me of a fine king indeed.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 15 Yea, he is ſuch a man as there are but few men like him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nay,
I think there are none like him, if he keep you company.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: They all envied me,
And ſpake ill of me behind my back: I cared not a button; they ſpited me pittifully;
But one of them very greatly, whom he had made maſter of his Indian Elephants,
When he began to be more trouble ſome then others; I pray you, you Yeoman of the ſtirrup, (quoth I) are you ſo • ickiſh,
line 20 Becauſe you have the charge over the beaſts?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Truly, it was well and wiſely
Spoken: Whoo! You ſtifled the fellow. What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: He was preſently
Mute.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What ſhould he but be ſo?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: O ſtrange▪ That vile raſcall,
And wretch, and that errand thief.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: What Gnatho, did I never tell you that,
How I handled the yong man of Rhodes at a feaſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Never. But
line 25 I pray you tell it me. I have heard it a thouſand times already.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: This ſame
Yong man of Rhodes, which I ſpeak of, was with me at a feaſt: By chan •… ,
I had a whore, he began to jeer at that, and to ſcoff me. What ſay you,
You ſhameleſs fellow ſaid I? You are a Hare your ſelf, and look for a dain • y bit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Wittily, dai • tily, finely ſaid, nothing ſurpaſseth it.
line 30 Was this a ſaying of your own forſooth? I thought it had been an old one.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Had you heard it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Many times; and it is reported for a choyce one.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: It is mine own.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I am ſorry that it was
Spoken to an undiſcreet young man, and one that is a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But a miſchief light on thee.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What ſaid he, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: He was quaſht: All that were by, were ready to die with laughing. To be ſhort, they were all afraid of me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Not without cauſe.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: But do you hear, had I not beſt clear my ſelf to Thais concerning the maid,
line 35 Becauſe ſhe ſuſpected that I love her?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: By no means: Nay rather
Increaſe her ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Do you ask? Do you not know, if ſhe at any time
Make mention of Phaedria, or if ſhe commend him, that ſhe may nettle you ſoundly?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: To prevent that, there is no remedy but this; when ſhe
Shall name Phaedria, do you preſently name Pamphilus: If ſhe ſhall at any time
line 40 Say, let 〈◊〉 admit Phaedria to feaſt it with us; do you ſay, let us encourage
Pamphila to ſing; if ſhe ſhall commend his beauty,
Do you on the contrary commend hers. To be ſhort, give her quid for quo,
Which may vex her at the heart.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: If ſhe loved me, Gnatho, then that might do ſome good.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Foraſmuch as ſhe deſireth and loveth what you give, ſhe ere this
line 45 Loveth you; now any thing may be eaſily done to vex her; ſhe will alwayes fear,
Leſt you in your angry fit ſhould beſtow elſewhere the commodity which ſhe
Now getteth by you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: You ſay well; but that never entered into my thoughts.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It is fondly done; for you did not conſider of it: But, Thraſo, how much better
Might you have found out this ſame thing your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: MAgnas verò agere gratias Thais mihi?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ingentes.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Ain' tu?
Laetatur?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non tam ipſo quidem dono, quàm abs te datum eſſe:
Id verò ſeriò triumphat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Huc proviſo, ut ibi tempus ſiet,
Deducam; ſed eccum •• l • tem.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Eſt iſtuc datum profectò,
line 5 Ut grata mihi ſint q • ae fac • o omnia.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Advorti hercle animum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Vel rex ſemper maxumas mihi agebat, quicquid feceram, aliis non item.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Labore alieno magnam partam gloriam verbis ſaepe in ſe
Tranſmovet, qui habet ſalem qui in te eſt.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Habes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Rex te ergo inoculis.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Scilicet.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Geſtire.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Verùm

line 10
Credere omnem exercitum ſuum & conſilia.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Mirum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Tum
Sicubi eum ſatietas hominum, aut negotii fiquando odium
Ceperat, requieſcere ubi volebat, quaſi: noſtin'?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Scio.
Quaſi ubi illam expueret miſeriam ex animo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Tenes.
Tum me convivam adducebat ſibi.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hui, regem elegantem.
line 15 Narras.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Imò. ſic homo eſt perpaucorum hominum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Imò,
Nullorum arbitror, ſi tecum vivit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Invidêre omnes mihi,
Mordere clanculum: ego flocci pendere: illi invid êre miſerè.
Verùm unus tamen impensè, elephantis quem Indicis praefecerat,
Is ubi moleſtus magis eſt; quaeſo, ▪inquam, Strato, cóne es ferox,
line 20 Quia habes imperium in belluas?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Pulchiè mehercule dictum,
Et ſapienter. Pape, jugulâras hominem. Quid ille?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Mutus
Illico.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid ni eſſet?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Dii voſtram fidem! Hominem perditum,
Miſerum & illum ſacrilegum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid illud, Gnatho, quo pacto
Rhodium tetigerim in convivio, nunquam dixi tibi?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nunquam. Sed
line 25 Narra obſecro. Plus millies jam audivi.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Unà in
Convivio erat hic, quem dico, Rhodius adoleſcentulus. Fortè
Habui ſcortum, cepit ad id ludere, & me irridere. Quid ais,
Homo, inquam impudens? Lepus tute es, & pulpamentum quaeris.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Facetè, lautè, lepidè, nihil ſupra.
line 30 Tuúmne hercle hoc dictum erat? Vetus credidi.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Audieras?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Saepe & fertur in primis.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Meum eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Doler dictum imprudenti
Adoleſcenti & libero.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: At te dii perdant.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid ille quaeſo?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Perditus. Riſu omnes, qui aderant, emori. Denique, omnes metuebant.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non injuriâ.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sed heus tu, pergon' ego me de iſtac Thaidi,
line 35 Quòd eam me amare ſuſpicata eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nihil minùs. Imò, auge
Magis ſuſpicionem.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Cur?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Rogas? ſin'? ſiquando illa
Mentionem Phaedriae facit, aut ſi laudat, te ut malè urat.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sentio.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Id ne fiat, haec res ſola eſt remedio, ubi
Nominabit Phaedriam, tu Pamphilam continuó. Siquando
line 40 Illa dicet, Phaedriam intromittamus commeſſatum: tu, Pamlam
Cantatum provocemus. Si laudabit haec illius formam,
Tu hujus contrá. Denique par pro pari referto, quod eam
Mordeat.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Siquidem me amaret, tum iſtuc prodeſſet Gnatho.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quando illud, quod tu das, expectat atque amat, jamdudum
line 45 Te amat; jamdudum illi facile fit quod doleat; metuet ſemper,
Quem ipſa nunc capit fructum, ne quando iratus tu alio
Conferas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Bene dixiſti: at mihi iſtuc non in mentem venerat.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ridiculum! non enim cogitaras▪ caeterùm idem tute meliùs
Q • antò inveniſſes, Thraſo!

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: ME thought, I heard the Soldiers voyce
Even now: and look where he is! God ſave you, my Thraſo.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O my Thais,
Mine own ſweet-heart, how is it with you? Do you love me ere a whit
For that ſinging wench?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: How handſomly doth he complement! what a beginning hath he made at his coming!

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 5 Very much according to your demerits.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Let us go then to ſupper, Why ſtay you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Behold the other! he would ſay he was ſpit out of that mans mouth.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: When you will;
I will make no ſtay.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will go to them, and make as though I came but now forth.
Thais, Are you going any whither?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: O Parmeno, It is well done
Truly of you: I am going to day.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: What? Do you not ſee this man?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 10 I ſee him, and it irk's me ſo to do. When you pleaſe, the Preſents are ready for you from Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why ſtand we ſtill? Why go we not hence?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I pray you forſooth, that we may
By your good leave, give this Gentlewoman what we deſire; and that we may
Have liberty to come and ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I think, they are very goodly gifts, not like mine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The deed will make mention. Do you hear; bid thoſe come forth adores quickly, whom I commanded to be brought out.
line 15 Come you hither: This wench came as far as from Aethiopia.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Here are three pounds.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Scarce.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Where are you Dorus? come hither: Look you where an Eunuch is,
Of what a lovely countenance, of what a perfect age!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I ſwear
He is a comely perſon.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What ſay you, Gnatho? Do you find any thing, that you can diſlike in him?
And what ſay you Thraſo? they hold their tongues: they commend him ſufficiently. Make trial of him
line 20 At his book, make trial of him in wraſtling, or in muſick, I will uphold him
To be skilfull in thoſe things, which it is fitting for a young Gentleman to know. And he that ſent theſe things, doth not deſire you
To live with him alone, and that others ſhon •… ſhut out for his ſake; nor doth he tell of
His fights, nor brag of his marks of honour: nor doth he hinder you, which
Some body doth; but he thinks it ſufficient, if he be then entertained,
line 25 When it will be no trouble to you, when you pleaſe, and when time ſhall ſerve.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: It ſeems
This fellow is a ſervant to ſome poor and beggerly Maſter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: For indeed I am ſure,
No body could abide to have this fellow, that hath wherewithal to get another.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hold you your tongue,
Whom I think to be the baſeſt raſcal in the world: for thou that canſt find in thy heart
To flatter this fellow, wilt not ſtick, I ſuppoſe, to do any thing
line 30 For a morſel of bread.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Shall we now go?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I will firſt bring theſe in,
And withal give order what things I would have done; afterwards I will come forth preſently.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I will be gone hence. Do you tarry for her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It is not fit for a Commander
To go with his ſweet-heart along the way.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What ſhould I uſe many words to thee?
You are like your Maſter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: That which you ſaid
line 35 Even now, and that ſaying concerning the Rhodian comes into my mind. But Thais comes forth.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Go thy way, ſtep before, that things may be got ready at home.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Pythias, ſee you look diligently to it; that if Chremes chance to come hither,
You intreat him firſt to tarry; if that cannot conveniently be done, to come again;
If he cannot do that, bring him to me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I will do ſo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 40 What? what elſe would I ſay? hoe, look well to that maid;
See that you keep home.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Let us go.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Do you come after me (maids.)

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: AUdire vocem modò militis
Viſa ſum: atque eccum. Salve mi Thraſo.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O Thais mea,
Meum ſuavium, quid agitur? Ecquid nos amas de fidicinâ
Iſtâc?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quàm venuſtè! quod dedit principium adveniens!

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 5 plurimùm merito tuo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Eamus ergo ad caenam. Quid ſtas?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hem alterum: ex homine hunc natum dicas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Ubi vis,
Non moror.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l:
Adibo at
que adſimulabo, quaſi nunc exeam.
Ituran' Thais quopiam es?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Hem Parmeno, Bene pol
Feciſti: hodie itura.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quò?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid? hunc non vides?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 10 Video & me taedet. Ubi vis, dona adſunt tibi à Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid ſtamus? Cur non imus hinc?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quaeſo hercle ut liceat,
Pace quod fiat tuâ, dare huic quae volumus: Convenire
Et colloqui.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Perpulcra credo dona, haud noſtris ſimilia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Res indicabit. Heus, jubete iſto, foras quos juſſi ocyus.
line 15 Procede tu huc. Ex Aethiopiâ eſt uſque haec.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Hîc ſunc tres
Minae.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Vix.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ubi tu es, Dore: accede huc. Hem Eunuchum,
Quàm liberali facie, quàm aetate integrâ!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ita me dii ament,
Honeſtus.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid tu ais, Gnatho? nunquid habes quod contemnas?
Quid tu autem Thraſo? Tacent: Satis laudabant: fac periculum
line 20 In literis, fac in palaeſtrâ, in muſicis; quae liberum ſcire
Aequum eſt adoleſcentem, ſolertem dabo. Atque haec qui miſit non ſibi ſoli poſtulat

Te vivere, & ſuâ cauſâ excludi caeteros, ne
que pugnas

Narrat, neque cicatrices ſuas oſtentat: ne
que tibi obſtat, quod
Quidam facit: verùm ubi moleſtum non erit, ubi tu voles, ubi
line 25 Tempus erit, ſat habet, ſi tum recipitur.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Apparet ſervum hunc
Eſſe domini pauperis, miſerique.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non hercle nemo poſſet, ſat
Scio, qui habet, quî pararet alium, hunc perpeti.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tace tu
Quem ego eſſe infra infimos omnes puto homines; nam qui
Huic animum aſſentari duxeris, è flammâ te cibum
line 30 Petere poſſe arbitror.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Jámne imus?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Hos prius introducam,
Et quae volo ſimul imperabo: poſtea, continuò exeo.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ego hinc abeo. Tu iſtam opperire.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Non convenit unà ire
Cum amica imperatorem in viâ.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid tibi egò dicam multa?
Domini ſimilis es.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid rides?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Iſtuc quod dixti
line 35 Modò, & illud de Rhodio dictum, in mentem venit. Sed Tha is exit.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Abi, praecurre, ut ſint domi parata.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Fiet.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Diligenter,
Pythias, fac ut cures, ſi Chremes huc fortè advenerit,
Ut ores, primùm ut maneat: ſi id non commodum eſt, ut redeat:
Si id non poterit, ad me adducito.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ita faciam.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 40 Quid? quid aliud volui dicere? Hem, curate iſtam diligenter
Virginem; domi adſitis, facite.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Eamus.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Vos me ſequemini.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: TRuly the more and more I conſider it, without doubt this Thais will do me
Some great miſchief, I ſee I am ſo cunningly deſtroyed by her.
Even then when ſhe firſt bade I ſhould be ſent for to her houſe, (one may ask,
What had you to do with her? Truly I do not know) when I came, ſhe found
line 5 An occaſion to make me tarry there. Shee ſaid ſhe had offered a ſacrifice, and would ſpeak
With me about ſome ſerious buſineſs. I had then a ſuſpition that all theſe things
Were done in knavery: Shee ſate down by me, ſhee offered her ſelf to to me;
Shee ſought occaſion of diſcourſe: When ſhee had little to ſay, ſhe came to this, as to enquire of me how long ago
It was ſince my father and mother died; I told her it was a long while agoe.
line 10 Shee asked me whether I had any land at Sunium, and how far it lay from the ſea? I think,
This likes her well; ſhe hopes ſhe can get it from me. Laſtly, ſhe asked me, whether I had
Ever a little ſiſter loſt from thence? whether any body was loſt with her? and what ſhe had
When ſhe was loſt? and whether any body could know her? why ſhould ſhe ask theſe things,
Unleſs perhaps ſhe feigneth that ſhe is that little ſiſter of mine which was loſt long ago?
line 15 Such is her boldneſs: But ſhe, if ſhe be living, is ſixteen year old,
Beſides ſhe ſent to intreat me, that I would come to her. Let her tell me in good earneſt
What ſhe would with me, or let her not trouble me. I will not come the third time, Ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Its I Chremes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: O moſt pretty,
line 20 Dear heart!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I ſay, I am like to be trepand.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Thais
Did moſt earneſtly intreat you, that you would come again to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am going into the countrey.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I beſeech you do it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I ſay, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But do you tarry then
Here at our houſe, till ſhe come again.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why, my Chremes?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Get thee hence with a miſchief.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: If you be ſo
line 25 Reſolved upon it, I pray you ſtep over thither where ſhe is,

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I go then.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Go your way Dorias, bring this man quickly to the ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l:
PRofectò quanto magis, magiſ
que cogito, nimirum dabit Thais
Mihi magnum malum: Ita me ab eâ aſtutè video labefactarier.
Jam tum cùm primù n juſſit me ad ſeſe accerſier domum: (roget
Quis, Quid tibi cum eâ? ne nôram quidem) ubiveni, cauſam,
line 5 Ut ibi manerem, repperit; Ait, rem divinam feciſſe ſe, & rem ſeriam,
Velle agere mecum. Jam tum erat ſuſpicio dolo malo haec
Fieri omnia. Ipſa accumbere mecum, mihi ſeſe dare,
Sermonem quaerere. Ubi friget, huc evaſit; Quàm pridem
Pater mihi & mater mortui eſſent: dico, jam diu. Rus Sunii
line 10 Ecquod habeam, & quam longè à mari? Credo ei placere
Hoc: ſperat ſe à me avellere. Poſt • emò, ecqua inde parva
Periſſet ſoror? ecquis cum eâ unâ; & quid habuiſſet,
Cù n periit? ecquis eam poſſet noſcere? haec cur quaereret
Niſi ſi illa fortè, quae olim periit parvula ſoror, hanc ſe
line 15 Intendit eſſe? ut eſt audacia. Verùm ea ſi vivit, annos
Nata eſt ſedecim, non major. Thais, ego quam ſum, majuſcula eſt.
Miſit porrò orare, ut venirem. Seriò aut dicat quid vult,
Aut moleſta ne ſiet. Non hercle veniam tert ó. Heus, heus,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ecquis hîc eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ego ſum Chremes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: O capitulum
line 20 Lepidiſſi num.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Dico ego mihi inſidias fieri.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Thais
Maxumo te orabat operc, ut cras redires.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Rus eo.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Fac amabó.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non poſſum inquam.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: At tu apud
Nos hîc mane, dum redeat ipſa.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nihil minus.
