sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Cur mi Chremes?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Malam rem! hinc abi.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Si iſtuc
line 25 Ita certum eſt tibi, amabò ut illuc tranſeas ubi illa eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Eo.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Abi, ô Dorias, citò hunc deduc ad militem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I Swear, as far forth as I ſee by the ſouldier, I poor woman
Do ſomewhat fear, leſt that mad fellow ſhould make any buſtle to day,
Or offer violence to Thais. For after Chremes the yong man
The maids brother came, ſhe intreated the ſouldier to give order
line 5 That he might be let in; he was preſently angry, and yet durſt not ſay nay:
Moreover Thais was urgent upon him to invite the man; that ſhe did
To ſtay Chremes there, becauſe ſhe had had no time for that matter
Which ſhe deſired to tell him concerning his ſiſter. He inviteth him with a heavie heart,
He tarried there, ſhe begins to talk with him. Now the Souldier thought
line 10 That a copeſmate was brought him before his eyes; and therefore
He endeavoured to do what he could to croſs her. Ho boy, ſaith he, call me Pamphila,
That ſhe may make us m • rry here. Shee cryeth out, By no means
Admit her to the banquet: The ſouldier fell from that to chiding.
In the mean time the woman ſtrips her ſelf of her gold, and gives it me to carry away.
line 15 This is a ſign, I know, ſhe will get her ſelf away thense, as ſoon as ſhe can.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: ITa me Dii bene ament, quantum ego illum vidi, non
Nihil timeo miſera, ne quam ille hcdie inſanus turbam
Faciat aut vim Thaidi. Nam poſtquam advenit Chremes
Adoleſcens frater virginis, militem rogat ut eum admitti

line 5 Jubeat; ille continuò iraſci, ne
que audere negare.
Thais porrò inſtare ut hominem invitet; id faciebat
Retinendi illius causâ, quia, illa quae cupiebat de ſorore
Ejus indicare, ad eam rem tempus non erat. Invitat triſtis;
Manſit ibi; illa cum illo ſermonem incipit; miles verò ſibi
line 10 Putare adductum ante eculos aemulum; voluit facere
Huic contrà aegrè! Heus, inquit, puer, Pamphilam accerſe,
Ut delectet hîc nos: illa exclamnt; minimè gentium
In convivium illam: miles tendere inde ad jurgium;
Interea au • um ſibi clàm mul • er demit; dat mihi ut auferam:
line 15 Hoc eſt ſignum, ubi primùm poterit, ſubducet ſe illirc, ſcio.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: AS I was going into the country, I began (as it falls out when
Any trouble is in ones minde) to conſider one thing after another,
And to conſtrue them all to the worſt ſenſe: What needs many words?
Whilſt I muſed upon theſe things, I went unawares beyond my houſe. I was gone
line 5 Already a good way from it. As ſoon as I perceived it, I came back again, being indeed not very well.
When I came to the turn, I ſtood ſtill, and began to think with my ſelf;
What now, muſt I tarry here alone two days without her?
What then will be next? It is nothing. What? nothing? If I may not have leave
To touch her, why, ſhall I not have leave ſo much as to ſee her? If I may not do that,
line 10 I may do this at leaſt. Surely it is ſomething to enjoy the ſight of ones ſweet-heart,
I willingly paſs by my country-houſe. But what is the matter,
That Pythias goeth out of doors ſo fearful on a ſudden?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: DUm rus eo, coepi egomet mecum inter vias, (ita ut fit ubi
Quid in animo eſt moleſtiae) aliam rem ex aliâ cogitare,
Et ea omnia in pejorem partem. Quid opus eſt verbis?
Dum haec reputo, praeterii imprudens villam. Longè jam
line 5 Abieram. Cùm ſenſi, redeo rurſum, malè verò me habens.
Ubi ad ipſum veni d • verticulum, conſtiti; occepi mecum
Cogitare, hem, biduum hic manendum eſt ſoli ſine illâ?
Quid tum poſtea? nihil eſt; quid? nihil? ſi non tangendi
Copia eſt, eho, ne videndi quidem erit? ſi illud non licet,
line 10 Saltem hoc licebit. Certè extremâ linea amare, haud
Nihil eſt. Villam praetereo ſciens. Sed quid hoc eſt,
Quòd timida ſubitò egreditur Pythias?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: WHere ſhall I poor woman finde that wicked and ungracious fellow?
Or where ſhall I ſeek for him? That he ſhould dare to commit
This ſo bold a prank!

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I am afraid what this ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Moreover
And beſides the rogue, after he had befooled the maid, he pittifully tare
line 5 All her clothes.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Who if he were but now offered
Me, how willingly could I claw out the eyes of that wizard!

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I know not indeed what a ſtir hath been made at home, whilſt I was away, I will go to her.
What is the matter? why do you make ſuch haſte, or whom do you look for, Pythias?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ah Phaedria! whom do I look for? get you hence whither you deſerve to go with

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Such unpleaſant gifts of yours.
What is the matter?
Do you ask
Me? what a ſtir that Eunuch which you gave us hath made? He hath defloured
The maid which the Souldier gave my Miſtreſs for a preſen • .
What ſay you?
I am undone.
You are drunk.
I wiſh they were ſo, that
Wiſh me ill.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Alas! I pray you, my Pythias, What ſtrange thing

l.label: line 15
l.hi: Was that?
You are mad, how could an Eunuch do that?
I know him not, who he was, but the thing it ſelf evidenceth
This that he hath done: The maid her ſelf weepeth, neither dare ſhe
Tell you, when you ask her, what the matter is: and that honeſt man is not to be ſeen.
Beſides, I poor woman ſuſpect this, that he ſtole away ſomething out of the houſe

l.label: line 20
l.hi: When he went away.
I cannot ſufficiently marvail, whether that idle fellow
Could go far off, unleſs perhaps he be gone home again to • ur houſe.
I pray you, go ſee, whether he be, or not.
I will let you know preſently.
I am undone!
I pray you, my dear-heart, I never ſo much as heard of ſuch an a • ominable trick.
But indeed I had heard that they are the greateſt lovers of women in the world,

l.label: line 25
l.hi: But that they can do nothing: but it never came into my mind, poor woman:
For I ſhould have ſhut him up ſomewhere, and not have committed the maid to him.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l:
UBi ego illum ſceleroſum miſera at
que impium inveniam?
Aut ubi quaeram? Hoccine tam audax facinus facere
Eſſe auſum?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hoc quid ſit, vereor.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quin
Etiam inſuper ſcelus, poſt quam ludificatus eſt virginem, veſtem
line 5 Omnem miſerè conſcidit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hem?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Qui ſi nunc ſi detur
Mihi, ut ego unguibus facilè illi in oculos involem venefico!

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Neſcio quid profectò abſente nobis turbatum eſt domi: adibo
Quid iſtuc? quid feſtinas? aut quem quaeris, Pythias?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hem Phaedria, egon' quem quaeram, abi hinc quò dignus cum
line 10 Donis tuis tam inlepidis.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc eſt rei?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Rogas
Me? Eunuchum quem dediſti nobis, quas turbas dedit? Virginem
Quam herae dono dederat miles, vitiavit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Perii.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Temulenta es.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Utinam ſic ſient, qui mihi
Malè volunt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Au, obſecro mea Pythias, quid iſtucnam
line 15 Monſtri fuit?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Inſanis, qui i • tuc facere Eunuchus
Potuit?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ego illum neſcio qui fuerit; hoc quod fecit

Res ipſa indicat. Virgo ipſa lachrumat, ne
que cùm rogites,
Quid ſit, audet dicere. Illa autem bonus vir nuſquam apparet.
Etiam hoc miſera ſuſpicor, aliquid domo abeuntem
line 20 Abſtuliſſe.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nequeo mi • ari ſatis, quò ille abire
Ignavus poſſet long ùs: niſi domum fortè ad nos rediit.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Viſe, amabò, num ſit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Jam faxo ſcies.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Perii,
Obſecro, tam infandum facinus, mea tu, ne audivi quidem.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: At pol ego amatores audieram mulierum eſſe eas maxumos,
line 25 Sed nihil poteſſe. Verùm miſerae non in mentem venerat:

Nam illum aliquò concluſiſſem, ne
que illi commiſiſſem virginem.

l.hi: COme out of doors, you rogue; but do you ſneak back indeed? you runnagate-rogue, come out.
Yau that are ill bought.
I beſeech you.
Oh, ſee what a wry mouth
The hang-man makes! Why came you back hither again?
Why are your clothes changed? what ſay you? If I had ta • ried never ſo litle • onger,

l.label: line 5
l.hi: I ſhould not have found him at home, he had made himſelf ſo ready to run away.
Have you the ſellow, I pray you?
What elſe ſhould I but have him?
O well done!
This is very well done indeed.
Where is he?
Do you ask? do you not ſee him?
Whom I pray you, ſhould I ſee?
This fellow
Forſooth.
What fellow is this?
He that was brought

l.label: line 10
l.hi: To you to day.

sp.speaker: Py.

l.hi: None of us ever ſaw this fellow

sp.l: With our eyes, Phaedria.

l.hi: Did none of you ſee him?
I pray, did you believe
That this was the fellow that was brought to us?
For whom elſe ſhould I believe
To be he? I had no body elſe.
Fi • , this fellow is not ta be compared
To him; he had an handſome face, and well-favoured.

l.label: line 15
l.hi: So he ſeemed to you er • -while, becauſe he was • lad in a changeable ſuit;
Now you think him to be ugly, becauſe he hath not that on.

sp.speaker: Py.

l.hi: I pray you hold your peace; as if indeed there was but a very little difference betwixt them.

sp.l: There was brought to our houſe to day a young youth, whom you, Phaedria,

l.hi: Would indeed be glad to ſee: but this is a wizz • nd, old, d • ouſie, aged fellow,

l.label: line 20
l.hi: As tawnie as a wee ſil.
How now, what a tale is this? you bring me to this print,
That I know not what I have done. Ho you ſirrah, did not I buy you?
You bought me.
Bid him anſwer me again.
Ask him.

sp.speaker: Py.

l.hi: Did you come to our houſe to day? be ſaith no: But that other came

sp.l: Being about ſixteen years old, whom Parmeno brought with him.

l.hi: Come on,

l.label: line 25
l.hi: Now tell me this firſt, whence had you that ſull which you have?
You ugly fellow, will you tell me, or no?

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: Chaerea came.

l.hi: My brother?
Yes.
When?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To day.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: How long ago?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Juſt now.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: With Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Did you know him before?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No.
line 30 Neither did I ever hear any man ſay who he was.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: How then?
Did you know that he was my brother?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Parmeno ſaid
That it was he, he gave me this ſuit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: He put on mine himſelf, afterwards they went both together out of doors.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Do you now ſufficiently beleeve that I am not drunk, and that I have told no lie?
line 35 Now it is ſure enough that the maid is defloured.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go to now
You great beaſt, do you beleeve this fellow what he ſaith?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: What ſhould I beleeve him for?
The deed heareth mention.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go aſide thither a little.
Do you hear? ay but a very little, that is enough: Tell me now this again:
Did Chaerea pull off thy cloaths from thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He did ſo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 And did he put them on?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He did ſo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And was he brought hither in ſtead of you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O wonderful! O the roguiſh and audacious fellow!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Wo is me! what do you not yet beleeve that we have been mocked moſt baſely?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Its a marvel but you beleeve what this fellow ſaith. I know not what to do.
Do you hear, ſirrah? Deny it again, can I not get the truth out of you to day?
line 45 Did you ſee my brother Chaerea?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I ſee, he cannot confeſs
Without he be puniſhed. Follow me this way. One while he ſaith it, another while he denieth it. Intreat me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I beſeech you Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go in a doors.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ah welladay!

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I know not,
How by any other means I can come honeſtly off hence; there is no help, if theſe things be true;
Shall you, you knave, make a laughing ſtock on me here?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I am as ſure
line 50 That this is a trick of Parmeno's, as that I live.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So it is.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I will finde
How I may be even with him to day. But now Dorias, what do you perſwade
To be done?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you ask concerning that maid?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes,
Whether ſhould I hold my tongue, or tell it abroad?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you, truly if you be wiſe, not know what you do know;
Neither concerning the Eunuch, nor the deflouring of the maid. By this means you ſhall both
line 55 Winde your ſelf out of all trouble, and do him a pleaſure. Only ſay, that Dorus is gone.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: So I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But do not I ſee Chremes? Thais will be here by and by.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Becauſe when I came away thence, juſt then began a buſtle
Betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Do you have away the gold: I will know of him what the matter is.

div.head: Actus IV. Scen. 4.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: EXiforàs, ſceleſte: at etiam reſtitas? fugitive, prodi:
Malè conciliate.

sp.speaker: Doïus.
sp.l: Obſecro.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Oh, illud vide os
Ut ſibi diſtorſit carnifex. Quid huc reditio eſt?
Quid veſt is mutatio? quid narras? paululum ſi ceſſâſſem,
line 5 Domi non offendifſem; ita jam ornabat fugam,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Habéſne hominem amabó?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid ni habeam?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: O factum benè 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Iſtuc pol verò bene.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ubi eſt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Rogitas? non vides?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Videam, obſecro, quem?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hunc
Scilicet.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quis homo hic eſt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Qui ad vos
line 10 Deductus hodie eſt.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hunc oculis ſuis noſtrarum nunquam
Quiſquam vidit, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Non vidit?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: An tu hunc
Credidiſti eſſe, obſecro, ad nos deductum?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nam quem
Alium? habui neminem.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Au, ne comparandus hic
Quidem eſt ad illum. Ille erat honeſtâ facie & liberali.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nunc • ò tibi videtur faedus, quia illam n • n habet.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Tace obſecro; quaſi verò paululum inter • iet. Ad nos
Deductus hodie eſt adoleſcentulus, quem tu videre ve • ò
Velles, Phaedria: Hic eſt vietus, vetus, veternoſus, fenex, colore
line 20 Muſtelino.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hem, quae eſt fabula? cò redigis me,
Ut quid egerim ego neſciam. E • o ru, emin' ego te?

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: E • iſti.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Jube mihi denuo reſpondeat.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Roga.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Veniſtin' hodie ad nos? nega • . At ille alter venit natus
Annos ſedecim, quem ſecum adduxit Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Agedum,
line 25 Hoc nunc mihi expedi primùm; iſt • m quam habes, unde habes
Veſtem? monſtrum hominis, num dicturuses?

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: Venit Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Frat •• ne?

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quando?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hodie.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quàm dudum?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Modó.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quîcum?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Cum Parmenone.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Narráſne eum priús?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Non
line 30 Nec quis eſſet unquam audi • ram dicier.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Unde igitur
Fratrem meum eſſe ſciebas?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Parmeno dicebat
Eum eſſe: is dedit mihi hanc veſtem.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Occidi.

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: Meam ipſe induit, pòſt ambo unà abierunt forás.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Jam ſatis credis ſobriam eſſe me, & nihil mentitam?
line 35 Jam ſatis certum eſt virginem vitiatam eſſe?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Age nunc
Bellua, credis huic quod dicat?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quid iſti credam?
Res ipſa indicat.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Concede iſtue paululum.
Audin etiam nunc paululúm; ſat eſt; dic dum hoc rurſum,
Chaerea tuam veſtem detraxit tibi?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Factum eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 Et eam eſt indutus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Factum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Et pro te huc deductus eſt?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l:
Jupiter magne! O ſceleſtum at
que audacem hominem!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Vae mihi; etiam nunc non credis indignis nos eſſe irriſas modis?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Mirum, ni tu credas, quid iſte dicat; quid agam, neſcio. Heus tu,
Negato rurſum. Poſſúmne ego hodie ex te exculpere verum?
line 45 Vidiſtin fratrem Chaeream?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Video, non poteſt fateri
Sinc malo. Sequere hâc; modò ait, modò negat. Ora me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Obſecro te verò Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I intró.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hei, hoi.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Al • o
Pacto honeſtè quomodo hinc abeam, neſcio. Actum eſt, ſiquidem; tu me
Hîc etiam nebulò ludificabere?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Parmenonis tam ſcio
line 50 Eſſe hanc technam, quàm me vivere.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sic eſt.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Inveniam
Pol hodie parem ubi referam gratiam. Sed nunc quid faciundum
Suades, Dorias?

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: De iſtâc virgine rogas?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ita.
Utrum taceam, an praedicem?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Tu pol ſi ſapis, quod ſ • ias, neſcis,

Ne
que de Eunucho, ne
que de vitio virginis. Hac re & te omni

div.l: line 55 Turbâ evolves, & illi gratum feceris. Id modò dic, abiiſſe Dorum.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ita faciam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sed videon' Chremem? Thais jam aderit.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quid ita?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Quia tùm inde abeo, jam tum inceperat turba
Inter eos.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Tu aufer aurum: ſcibo ex hoc quid ſiet.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: ALas, in good truth, I am beguiled. The wine that I have drunk hath over-maſtered me.
And while I ſate at the table, how fine and ſober I did think my ſelf to be?
Since I have riſen, neither my feet, nor my wit, do as they ſhould do.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Chremes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Oh, Pythias. O how much fairer now
line 5 Do you ſeem to me to be, then you did er • while?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Truly, you are far more cheerful.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Certoinly this is a true ſaying, Without meat and drink luſt groweth cold. But Thais came long before.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Is ſhe Gone from the ſouldiers already?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Long ago, an age ſince, there was
A great contention betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Did ſhe ſay nothing then that you ſhould follow her?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 10 Nothing, but as ſhe went away ſhe beckned to me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why, was not that enough?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But I did not know that ſhe meant that, but the ſouldier righted me, which
I did not well underſtand, for he thruſt me out of doors;
But 〈◊〉 I ſee her: I wonder where I got before her.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: AT at, data hercle verba mihi ſunt. Vicit me vinum quod bibi;
Ac dum accubabam, quam videbar mihi eſſe pulchrè ſobrius?

Poſtquam ſurrexi, ne
que pes ne
que mens ſatis ſuum officium facit.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Chreme.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ehem Pythia, vah quanto nunc formoſior
line 5 Videre mihi, quam dudum?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Certè quidem tu pol multò alacrior.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Verbum hercle hoc verum eſt, Sine Cerere
Et Libero friget Venus. Sed Thais multò antè venit.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Anne
Abiit jam a milite?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Jamdudum, aetatem. Lites factae ſunt
Inter eos maxumae.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nihil dixit tum ut ſequerêre ſeſe?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 10 Nihil niſi abiens mihi innuit.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Eho, nonne id ſat erat?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: At neſciebam id dicere illam, niſi quia correxit miles; quod
Intellexi minus: nam me extruſit forás.
Sed eccam ipſam video: miror ubi ego huic antevorterim.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I Believe indeed he will be here by and by, that he may take her

l.hi: From me; Let him come. But if he touch her with one
Finger, I will preſently ſcratch out his eyes; I can ſo long abide
His fooleries, and his big words, whilſt they are but words; but

l.label: line 5
l.hi: If they be turned to deeds, he ſhall he beaten.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thais, I have been

l.hi: Here a good while.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: O my Crhemes! I look for you. Do you know that this buſtle

l.hi: Was made becauſe of you, and that ſo all the matter concerneth you?
Me, how? as though I made it.
Becauſe whiſt I laboured
To give and reſtore you your ſiſter again, I have endured theſe and many the like things.

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Where is ſhe?
At home at my houſe.
Ha.
What is the matter?
She hath been brought up ſo as it befitteth you and her.
What ſay you?
As
The matter is, I beſtow her on you, and do not demand any thing of you for her.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thais, I both thank you, and will alſo ſtudy to requite you, ſo as you have deſerved.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: But take heed Chremes, that you do not loſe her, before you receive her of me;
line 15 For this is ſhe, whom the ſouldier cometh to take from me by force. Pythias, go you

l.hi: And fetch the little cabinet out of the houſe with the tokens.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thais, Do you not ſee him?

l.hi: Where is it laid?
In the trunk, thru ſpitefull queane, doeſt thou make no baſte?
Do you not ſee the ſouldier, and what forces he bringeth with him? Alas, alas.
What man, I pray you, are you faint-hearted? Away, away.
Am I faint-hearted?

l.label: line 20
l.hi: There is no man living leſs fearfull.
And ſo you have need.
Alas,
I fear what kind of man you think me to be.
Nay conſider this,
• im whom you have to do; he is a ſtranger, leſs powerfull
Then you, not ſo well acquainted, having fewer friends here.
I know that;
But it is a folly to ſuffer that to be done, which you may avoid. I had rather

l.label: line 25
l.hi: We ſhould provide before-hand, then be revenged on him after a wrong is received:
Go you and lock the door on the in-ſide, whilſt I make a ſtep hence to the market;
I deſire we may have ſome Mediators here in this combuſtion.
Tarry, tarry.
It is better.
Tarry.
Let me go,
I will be here again by and by.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Chremes, we have no need of them. Do but ſay this,

l.label: line 30
l.hi: That ſhe is your ſiſter, and that you loſt her when ſhe was a little girle,
That you have now come to the knowledg of her. Let him ſee the tokens.
They are here.
Lay hold of him: If he ſhall offer any violence, bring an action againſt him. Do you underſtand me?
Very well.
See you ſpeak this with a good courage.
I will.
Take up you cloak about you. Alas, he himſelf hath need of a Counſellor,

l.label: line 35
l.hi: Whom I have got to defend me.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: CRedo equidem illum jam jam adfuturum eſſe, ut illam à me
Eripiat. Sine veniat. Atqui ſi illam digito attigerit
Uno, oculi illico effodientur. Uſque adeò ego illius ferre poſſum
Ineptias & magnifica verba, verba dum ſint; verùm enim
line 5 Si ad rem conferentur, vapulabit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thais, ego jamdudum
Hic adſum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: O mi Chremes, teipſum expecto. Scin' tu turbam
Hanc propter te eſſe factam, & adeo ad te attinere hanc omnem rem?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ad me, qui? quaſi iſtuc.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quia dum tibi ſororem ſtudeo
Reddere ac reſtituere, haec atque hujuſmodi ſum multa paſſa.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 10 Ubi ea eſt?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Domi apud me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid eſt?
Educta eſt ita ut téque illáque dignum eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quod

Res eſt. Hanc tibi dono do, ne
que repeto pro illâ quicquam abs te pretii.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Et habetur & referetur, Thaeis, à me ita uti merita es, gratia.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: At enim cave, ne priuſquàm hanc à me accipias, amittas, Chreme,
line 15 Nam haec ea eſt quam miles à me nunc ereptum venit. Abi tu; ciſtellam,
Pythias, domo effer cum monumentis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Viden' tu illum, Thais?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ubi ſita eſt.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: In riſco; odioſa ceſſas?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Militem fecum
Atque quantas copias adducere? At, at.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Num formidoloſus
Obſecro es, mi homo? apageſis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Egon' formidoloſus?
line 20 Nemo eſt hominum, qui vivat, minus.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l:
A
que ita opus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Au,
Metuo qualem tu me hominem eſſe exiſtumes.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Immo hoc
Cogitato, quicum res tibi eſt, peregrinus eſt, minùs potens
Quàm tu minùs notus, minùs amicorum hîc habens.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scio
Iſthuc, ſed tu quod cavere poſſis ſtultum eſt admittere. Malo ego
line 25 Nos proſpicere, quàm hunc ulciſci acceptâ injuriâ; abi tu,
Atque obſera oſtium intus, dum ego hinc tranſcurro ad forum.
Volo hîc ego addeſſe advocatos nobis in turbâ hâc.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Mane, mane.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Melius eſt.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Mane.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Omitte,
Jam adero.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Nihil opus eſt iſtis, Chreme. Hoc modò die
line 30 Sororem eſſe illam tuam, & te parvam virginem amiſiſſe,
Nunc cognôſſe; ſigna oſtende.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Adſunt.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Cape,
Si vim faciet, in jus ducito hominem. Intellextin'?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Probè.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Fac animo haec praeſenti dicas.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Faciam.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Attolle pallium. Phy, huic ipſi opus patrono eſt, quem
line 35 Defenſorem paro.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: GNatho, Is it fit that, I ſhould put up this ſo notable abuſe offered me?
It is better for me to die. Simalio, Dorax, Syriſcus,

l.hi: M • rch after me. Firſt of all I will pull down the houſe.
Very well.
I will take the maid away by force.
Exceeding well.
I will puniſh her ſharply.

l.label: line 5
l.hi: Bravely ſpoken!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dorax, come hither, into the middle of the army with the door-bar.
Do you Simalio, march into the left wing; and you, Syriſcus, into the right. Give me the reſt.
Where is Captain Sanga, and his company of ſlaves?

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: Look at him,

sp.l: Here he is.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l:
What, you coward, do you think to fight with a di ••
clout,
That you bring it hither?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: What I? I know the vatour of my General,
line 10 And the manlineſs of his ſouldiers, that this could not be ended
Without blood ſhed, and therefore I brought to wipe their wounds.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Where are the others?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: What others with a miſchief? None but Sannio
Keepeth the houſe.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Do, ſet theſe in array here. And I being behinde
The Vaunt-guard will thence give the Word to all.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: That is a wiſe part:
line 15 After he had ſet theſe in array, he provided for himſelf in a ſure place.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: This ſame thing.
Now Pyrrhus was wont to do.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do you not ſee Thais,
What thing he doth? Certainly that was very good counſel which I gave you
About ſhutting up the door.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: That which ſeemeth to you now a a gallant fellow,
Is but this great boobie? do not fear him.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What do you think?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: line 20 I could now heartily wiſh you had a ſling given, that you might hit them aloof hence
Out of this cloſe place; they would run away.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: But look where I ſee
Thais her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: How quickly do we fall in upon them?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Tarry: It becometh
A wiſe man to try all things by words rather then arms. How know you, whether
She will do what I command her without compulſion or not?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: O ſtrange!
line 25 What a great matter it is to be wiſe? I never come to you, but I learn ſomething of you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Firſt and foremoſt, anſwer me this, when I gave you that maid,
Did not you ſay, you would keep me onely company theſe days?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: And what then?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Do you ask? who have brought me your lover here preſent before your eyes.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: What can you do to him?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: And conveyed your ſelf-with him privily from me.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 30 It was my minde to do ſo.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Therefore give me Pamphila again hither.
Except you had rather her taken from you by force.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Should ſhe give her you, or ought you to meddle with her you errant raſcal?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Ah, what do you do? hold your tongue. What mean you?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ought not I meddle
With my own?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What yours you rogue!

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Have a care, you know not
What a man you now give ill words to.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do you get you gone hence? Do you know
line 35 How the matter goeth with you? If you make any ſtir here to day,
I will make you alway remember this place, and day, and me too.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: I am ſorry for you, that you make ſuch a worthy man as this your enemy.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I will break your pate by and by, unleſs you be gone.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Say you ſo indeed you cur; do you do ſo?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What fellow are you?
line 40 What would you have? what have you to do with her?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You ſhall know.
Firſt I ſay ſhe is a free woman.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: A Citizen of Athens.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Whoo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: My own ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You impudent fellow!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Souldier,
Moreover I charge you, that you offer no violence towards her. I am going
To Sophrona the nurſe, to fetch her, and ſhew her theſe tokens.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: line 45 Can you hinder me from touching my own?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I forbid you,
I ſay.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Do you hear? This man accuſeth himſelf of felony,
Is not this ſufficient for you?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Do you ſay ſo too, Thais?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Go look ſome body
That may anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What do we now?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Marry let us go back again,
She will come to you by and by, beſeeching you on her own accord.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Think you ſo?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Yes,
line 58 Aſſuredly, I know the nature of women: They will not, when you will; when you will not,
They fain will with all their heart.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You think rightly.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: I will now disband the armie.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: When you will.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Sanga, as becometh valiant ſouldiers, ſee
You remember to do at home, and by the fire-ſide.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: My minde is in the pottage pot
Long ago.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: You are an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: March after me this way.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: HAnccine ego ut contumeliam tam inſignem in me accipiam,
Gnatho? Mori me ſatius eſt. Simalio, Dorax, Syriſce,
Sequimini. Primùm aedes expugnabo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Rectè.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Virginem eripiam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Probè.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Malè mulctabo ipſam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 5 Pulchrè!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: In medium huc agmen cum vecti Dorax;
Tu, Simalio, in ſiniſtrum cornu; tu, Syriſce, in dexterum. Cedo alios.
Ubi centurio eſt Sanga, & manipulus furum?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Eccum
Adeſt.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid, ignave, peniculon' pugnare, qui
Iſtum huc portas, cogitas?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: Egóne? imperatoris
line 10 Virtutem noveram, & vim militum, fine ſanguine
Hoc non poſſe fieri, qui abſtergerem vulnera.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ubi alii?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: Qui malum alii? ſolus Sanniò ſervat
Domum.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Tu hoſce inſtrue hîc. Ego verò poſt
Principia, inde omnibus ſignum dabo.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Illuc eſt ſapere:
line 15 Ut hoſce inſtruxit, ipſi ſibi cavit loco.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Idem hoc
Jam Pyrrhus factitavit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Viden' tu, Thais,
Quam hic remagit? nimirum concilium illud rectum eſt
De occludendis aedibus.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sanè, quod tibi nunc vir videatur
Eſſe, hic nebulo magnus eſt, ne metuas.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid videtur?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: line 20 Fundam tibi nunc nimis vellem dari, ut tu illos procul hinc
Ex occulto caederes; facerent fugam.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sed eccam Thaidem
Ipſam video.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Quàm mox irruimus?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Mane. Omnia
Prius experi • i verbis quàm armis ſapientem decet. Quî ſcis, an
Quae jubeam ſine vi faciat?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Dii veſtram fidem! quanti eſt
line 25 Sapere! nunquam accedo, quin abs te fiam doctior.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Thais, primùm hoc mihi reſponde, cùm tibi do iſtam virginem,
Dixtin', hos dies mihi ſoli dare te?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid tum poſtea?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Rogitas? quae mihi ante oculos tuos coràm amatorem adduxiſti tuum?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid cum illo agas?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Et cum eo clà n te ſubduxiſti mihi.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 30 Libuit.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Pamphilam ergo huc redde, niſi vi mavis
Eripi.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tibi illam reddat, aut tu eam tangas, omnium?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Ah, quid agis? tace. Quid tu tibi vis?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ego non tangam
Meam?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tuam autem, furcifer?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Cave ſis, Neſcis cui
Maledicas nunc viro.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Num tu hinc abis? Scin' tu ut
line 35 Tibi res ſe habeat? Si quicquam hodie hîc turbae feceris,

Faciam ut hujus loci, dieique, mei
que ſemper memineris.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Miſeret tui me, qui hunc tantum hominem facias inimicum
Tibi.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Diminuam ego caput tuum hodie, niſi abis.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Ain' vero canis? ſiccine agis?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quis tu homo es?
line 40 Quid tibi vis? quid cum illâ rei tibi eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scibis.
Principiò, eam eſſe dico liberam.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Hem!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Civem Atticam.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Hui!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Meam ſororem.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Os durum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Miles,
Nunc adeò edico tibi, ne vim facias ullam in illam. Ego co
Ad Sophronam nutricem, ut eam adducam, & ſigna oſtendam
line 45 Haec.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Tun' me prohibeas meam ne tangam?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Prohibe • ,
Inquam.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Audin' tu? hic furti ſe alligat,
Satin' hoc tibi eſt?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Idem tu hoc ais, Thais?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quaere,
Qui reſpondeat.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid nunc agimus?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Quin redeamus? jam haec
Tibi aderit ſupplcans ultro.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Credin'?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Immo
line 50 Certè, novi ingenium mulierum. Nolunt ubi velis; ubi nolis,
Cupiunt ultro.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Bene putas.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Jam dimitto exercitum.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ubi vis.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l:
Sanga, ut fortes decet milites, domi foci
que
Fac viciſſim ut memineris.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: Jamdudum animus eſt
In patinis,

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Frugi es.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: Vos me hac ſequimini.

l.hi: DO you go on to talk doubtfully, you errant quean?
I know, I know not: I heard it: I was not there.
Will not you tell it me plainly, whatſoever it is?
The maid with her clothes rent, is weeping, and ſaith not a word.

l.label: line 5
l.hi: The Eunuch is gone: why ſo? what is done, doeſt thou not ſpeak?
What ſhould I poor woman ſay to you? they ſay it was not An Eunuch.
Who was it then?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That ſame Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: What, Chaerea?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That young ſtripling Phaedria's brother.

l.hi: What ſay you, you witch!
But I have found it to be true.

l.label: line 10
l.hi: How, I pray you, came he to our houſe, or wherefore was he brought?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I know not, but I that think he loved Pamphila.

l.hi: Alas, I am undone, poor woman!
I am unfortunate, if thoſe things be true which you ſay.
Why doth the maid weep?
For that I ſuppoſe.
What ſay you,
You wicked quean? Did not I give you charge about that, when I went away hence?
What ſhould I do? ſhe was committed to him alone, as you gave order.
You quean, you committed a ſheep to a wolf; I am aſhamed
That I ſhould be thus deceived: What fellow is it?
Miſtreſs, hold your tongue, I pray you, we are well enough.
We have the man himſelf.
Where is he?
Look you, on your left-hand.

l.label: line 20
l.hi: Do you not ſee him?
I do ſee him.
Cauſe him to be laid hold on, as ſoon as you can.
You fool, what ſhall we do to him?
What ſhould I do, do you ask?
See, I pray you, if when you look on him, he ſeem not to be a ſhameleſs perſon,
He is not; beſides, how very confident is he?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: PErgin' ſceleſta mecum perplexè loqui?
Scio, neſcio: abiit: audivi: ego non aſſui.
Non tu iſtuc mihi dictura a perrè es, quicquid eſt?
Virgo, conſciſſâ veſte, lachrymans obticet.
line 5 Eunuchus abiit? quamobrem? quid eſt factum? taces?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quid tibi ego dicam miſera? illum Eunuchum negant Fuiſſe.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quis fuit igitur?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Iſte Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Qui Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Iſte ephebus frater Phaedriae.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid ais, venefica?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Atqui certè-repperi.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 10 Quid is obſecro ad nos, aut quamobrem adductus eſt

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Neſcio; niſi amâſſe credo Pamphilam.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Hem, miſera, occidi.
Infoelix, ſiquidem tu iſtaec vera praedicas.
Quid lacrymat virgo?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Id opinor.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid ais,
Sacrilega? Iſtuccine interminat •• ſum hinc abiens tibi?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: line 15 Quid facerem? ita ut juſiſti, ſoli credita eſt.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sceleſta, ovem lupo commiſiſti; diſpudet,
Sic mihi data eſſe verba; quid illic hominis eſt?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hera mea, tace obſecro, ſalvae ſumus.
Habemus hominem ipſum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Ubi is eſt?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He •… , ad fini •… .
line 20 Viden'?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Video.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Comprehendi jube, quantum potes.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid illi faciemus, stulta?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quid faciam, rogas?
Vide amabò, ſi non, cùm aſpicias, os impudens
Videtur.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Non eſt, tum quae ejus confidentia eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: AT Antipho's houſe, both his mother and father

l.hi: Were at home, as if it had been for the nonce, ſo as I could
By no means go in, but they muſt ſee me. In the mean time
Whilſt I was ſtanding at the door, an acquaintance of mine

l.label: line 5
l.hi: Came and met me; when he ſaw me, I betook me to my heels as faſt as I could,
Into a back corner where no body dwelt, and from that
Into another, and thence into another; ſo I became moſt wretched
In running away, for fear any body ſhould know me.

sp.l: But is this Thais, which I ſee? it is ſhe. I am at a ſtand.

l.label: line 10
l.hi: What ſhall I do? what is it to me? what will ſhe do to me?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Let us go to him. Good man Dorus, God ſave you: tell me, did you run away?

l.hi: Miſtreſs, I did ſo.
Do you like that very well?
No.
Did you think you ſhould go ſcot-free?
Forgive me this one fault,
And if ever I do any more, I will give you leave to kill me.

l.label: line 15
l.hi: Was you afraid of my cruelty?
No.
What then?
I was afraid of this woman, leſt ſhe ſhould accuſe me unto you.
What had you done?
A very ſmall matter.
Ah you ſhameleſs fellow, a ſmall matter? Do you think it
A ſmall matter to defile a maid that is a Citizen?

l.label: line 20
l.hi: I took her to be my fellow-ſervant.
Your fellow-ſervant? I can ſcarce refrain my ſelf
But I muſt flie about his ears; the ugly knave beſides
Cometh voluntarily to mock us.
Can you be gone you mad girle?
Why forſooth
Should I go hence? ſhould I believe that rogue in any thing? eſpecially
When he confeſseth himſelf to be your ſervant?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 25 Let us ſee theſe things paſs: Chaerea, you have not done

l.hi: As it became you; For though I very well deſerve to have
This abuſe, yet you was an unmeet perſon to do it.
Neither indeed do I know what courſe to take
About this maid; you have put me to ſuch a non-plus,

l.label: line 30
l.hi: That I cannot reſtore her to her friends,
So as it was fitting; and as I endeavoured,

sp.l: That I might gain my ſelf thanks for a compleat benefit, Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Ch.

l.hi: But I hope there will be henceforward a continual amity

sp.l: Betwixt us, Thais; for oft times from ſome ſuch thing as this is,

l.label: line 35
l.hi: And from a bad beginning, great acquaintance
Hath grown. What if ſome God would have it thus?
Truly I conſtrue it in that ſenſe, and wiſh it may be ſo.
Nay, I pray you, underſtand this one thing, that I did not do it
To abuſe you, but out of love.

sp.speaker: Th.

l.hi: I know it.

l.label: line 40
l.hi: And therefore indeed I the rather pardon you.

sp.l: I am not of ſo unkind a nature, Chaerea,

l.hi: Nor ſo unexperienced, that I ſhould not be able to know, what love can do.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thais, I ſwear, I love you too.

l.hi: Then, Miſtreſs, I perceive you had need to take heed of this fellow.

l.label: line 45
l.hi: I dare not be ſo bold.
I do not truſt you any whit at all.
Give over.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thais, I commit and commend my ſelf to your fidelity.

l.hi: Now I beſeech you be my helper in this matter.
I deſire you to be my patroneſs, and I beſeech you:
I wiſh I were dead, if I do not marry her hereafter.

l.label: line 50
l.hi: Yet if you father.
What! I am ſure be will be willing,
If ſo be ſhe be but a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Th.

l.hi: Tarry here a little
If you will; the maids brother will be here by and by:
He went to fetch the nurſe, which nurſed her when ſhe was a little one.

sp.l: Chaerea, you your ſelf ſhall be by at the owning of her.

l.label: line 55
l.hi: I will indeed tarry.
Will you, in the mean time whilſt he come,
That we tarry at home rather, than here before the door?
Yes, I am heartily willing to it.
I pray you, what are you going to do?
For why?
Do you ask? Do you think to entertain this fellow Into the houſe hereafter?
Why not?
Take this on my word, 60. He will make ſome buſtle again.
Tuſh, I pray thee, hold thy tongue.
You ſeem not to have obſerved his boldneſs.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Pythias, I will no do ſo.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Truly, Chaetea, I do not truſt you; Ʋnleſs it be in a thing not committed to you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But, Pythias,

l.hi: Do you look to me.
Truly I dare neither commit any thing to you

l.label: line 65
l.hi: To keep, nor take charge of you. Away with you.
Her brother is here in good time.

sp.speaker: Ch.

l.hi: Truly I am undone, I pray you

sp.l: Let us go hence in adoors, Thais. I am loth he ſhould ſee mee

l.hi: In the ſtreet with theſe clothes.
Why ſo, for ſooth; is it becauſe you are aſhamed?
That is the matter.
That is the matter? a maid I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Th.

l.hi: Go before, I will come after:

sp.l: line 70 Pythias, do you ſtay there, that you may bring in Chremes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l:
APud Antiphonem uter
que mater & pater,
Quaſi deditâ operâ domi erant, ut nullo modo
Introne poſſem, quin viderent me. Interim
Dum ante oſtium ſto, notus mihi quidam obviam
line 5 Venit: ubi videt, egomet in pedes quantum queo,
In angiportum quoddam deſertum, inde item
In aliud, inde in aliud, ita miſerrimus
Fui fugitando, ne quis me cognoſceret.
Sed eſtne Thais, quam video? ipſa eſt. Haereo,
line 10 Quid faciam? Quid meâ autem? quid faciet mihi?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Adeamus. Bone vir, Dore, ſalve. dic mihi, aufugiſtin'?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hera, factum.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Satin' id tibi placet?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Credin' te impunè abiturum?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Unam hanc noxam
Amitte, ſi aliam admiſero unquam, eccidito.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 15 Num meam ſaevitiam veritus es?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid igitur?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hanc metui, ne me criminaretur tibi.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quid fecera • ?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Paululum quiddam.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Eho impudens, paululum? An paululum eſſe
Hoc tibi videtur, virginem vitiare civem?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 20 Conſervam credidi.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Conſervam? vix me contineo,
Quùm involem in capillum; monſtrum eriam ultro
Deriſum advenit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Abin' hinc inſana?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quid ita verò
Abeam? Credon' iſti quicquam furcifero, praeſertim
Cùm ſe ſervum fateatur tuum?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 25 Miſſa iſtaec faciamus. Non te d •… num, Chaerea,
Feciſti. Nam ſi ego digna hâc contumeliâ
Sum maxumè, at tu indignus qui faceres tamen.
Neque aedipol quid nunc consilii capiam, ſcio,
De virgine iſtâc: ita conturba ſtimihi
line 30 Rationes omnes, ut eam non poſſim ſuis

Ita ut aequum fuerat, at
que ut ſtudui tradere,
Ut ſolidum pararem hoc mihi beneficium, Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: At dehinc ſpero aeternam inter nos gratiam
Fore, Thais: ſaepe ex hujuſmodi re quapiam,
line 35 Et ex malo principio magna familiaritas
Conflata eſt. Quid ſi hoc quiſpiam voluit Deus?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l:
Equidem pol in eam partem accipió
que & volo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Immo ita quaeſo, unum hoc ſcito, contumeliae
Non me feciſſe cauſâ, ſed amoris.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Scio,
line 40 Et pol propterea nunc magis ignoſco tibi.
Non adcò inhumano ſum ingenio, Chaerea,

Ne
que imperita, ut quid amor valeat, neſciam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l:
Te quo
que Thais, ita me dii bene ament, amo.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Tum pol tibi ab iſtoc, hera, cavendum intelligo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 45 Non auſim.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nihil tibi quicquam credo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Deſinas.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ego me tuae committo & commendo fidei.
Nunc ego te in hac re mihi oro ut adjutrix ſies.
Te mihi patronam cupio, Thais, te obſecro;
Emoriar, ſi non hanc uxorem duxero.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: line 50 Tamen ſi pater.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid? ah volet, cortò ſcio,
Civis modò haec ſit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Paululum operirier
Si vis. Jam frater ipſe hic aderit, virginis.
Nutricem accerſitum iit, quae illam aluit parvulam.
In cognoſcendo tute ipſe hîc aderis, Chaerea.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 55 Ego vero maneo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Viſne interea dum venit,
Domi oppe • iamur potiùs, quàm hîc ante oſtium.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Imo percupio.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quam tu rem actura, obſecro, es?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Nam quid ita?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Rogitas? Hunc tu in aedes cogitas
Recipere poſthac?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Cur non?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Crede hoc meae fidei,
line 60 Dabit hic aliquam pugnam denuo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Au, tace, obſecro.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Parùm proſpexiſſe ejus videre audaciam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non faciam, Pythias.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Non pol credo, Chaerea,
Niſi ſi commiſſum non erit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quin, Pythias,
Tu me ſervato.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Neque pol ſervandum tibi

line 65 Quicquam dare auſim, ne
que te ſervare. Apage te.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Adeſt optimè ipſe frater.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Perii hercle, obſecro,
Abeamus intrò, Thais: Nolo me in viâ
Cum hac veſte videat.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Quamobrem tandem? an quia pudet?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Id ipſum.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Id ipſum? virgo verò?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I prae, ſequar.
line 70 Tu iſtic mane, ut Chremetem introducas, Pythias.

l.hi: VVHat? what can I now deviſe in my mind?
What? how ſhall I requite that wicked fellow,
That put him upon us?
Stir you ſelf apace,
Nurſe.
I ſtir.
I ſee that, but you make no riddance.

l.label: line 5
l.hi: Have you ſhewed the tokens already to the nurſe?
All.
I pray you, what ſaith ſhe? doth ſhe know them?
Yes, and remembreth them too.

sp.speaker: Py.

l.hi: Truly you tell me good news, for I wiſh the maid well.
Go ye in, my Myſtreſs hath looked for you at home a good while ago.

sp.l: But look, I ſee that honeſt man Parmeno go along.

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Do you ſee how leiſurely he goeth, forſooth.
I hope I have got a trick, how to vex him after my own faſhion.
I will go in, that I may know the certainty about the owning of her:
Afterwards I will come forth, and terrifie this wicked varlet.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: QUid? quid venire in mentem nunc poſſit mihi?
Quidnam? quî referam illi ſacrilego gratiam,
Qui hunc ſuppoſuit nobis?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Move verò ocyus
Te nutrix.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Moveo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Video, ſed nihil promoves.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: line 5 Jámne oſtendiſti ſigna nutrici?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Omnia.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Amabò, quid ait, cognoſcitne?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ac memoriter.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Bene aedipol narras: nam illi faveo virgini.
Ite intrò, jamdudum hera vos expectat domi.
Virum bonum eccum Parmenonem incedere
line 10 Video. Viden', ut otioſus it, ſi diis placet.
Spero me habere quî hunc mco excruciem modo.
Ibo intrò, de cognitione ut certum ſciam:
Poſt exibo, atque hunc perteribo ſacrilegum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I Come again to ſee what Chaerea doth here;

l.hi: For if he have cunningly carried the matter, O ſtrange!

sp.l: What and how real commendations ſhall Parmeno get?

l.hi: For to let that paſs, that I have gotten him his love, which was very hard, and

l.label: line 5
l.hi:
Dear to purchaſe of a covetous whore, that maid which he loved,
Without any trouble, without any charge, without any loſs: That other thing;
That indeed is it which I think I deſerve the garland for,
That I have found, how a young man may know
The diſpoſitions and behaviour of whores;

l.label: line 10
l.hi: That when one knoweth them betimes, he may hate them for ever;
Who whilſt they are ahroad, nothing in the world is more cleanly,
Nor any thing more demure, nor more neat;
Who when they ſup with their lover, feed nicely; but
How naſty they are at home, by themſelves, and greedy of neat;

l.label: line 15
l.hi: After what faſhion they ſoſſe brown-bread out of cock-crown pottage:
To know all theſe things is a making to young-men.
You rogue, I will indeed be revenged on you for thoſe your ſayings,
And doings; that you may not play upon us ſcot-free.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: REviſo, quidnam Chaerea hîc rerum gerat,
Quòd ſi aſtu rem tractavit, Dii voſtram fidem!
Quantam & quàm veram laudem capiet Parmeno?
Nam ut mittam, quòd & amorem difficillimum, &
line 5 Ca •… ſimum ab meretrice avarâ, virginem
Quam amabat, cam confeci ſine moleſtiâ,
Sine ſumptu, ſine diſpendio: Tum hoc alterum,
Id verò eſt quod ego mihi puto palmarium,
Me reperiſſe, quomodo adoleſcentulus
Meretricum ingenia & mores poſſet noſcere:
line 10 Matur • ut cùm cognôris, perpetuò oderis?
Quae dum for is ſunt, nihil videtur mundius,
Nee magis compoſitum quidquam, nec magis elegans:
Quae cum amatore cùm coenant, liguriunt:
Harum videre ingluviem, ſordes, inopiam,

Quàm inhoneſtae ſolae ſint domi, a •
que avidae cibi,
line 15 Quo pacto jure heſterno panem atrum vorent;
Noſſe omnia haec, ſalus eſt adoleſcentulis.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ego pol te pro iſt is dictis & factis, ſcelus,
Ulciſcar, ut ne impunè in nos illuſeris.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: O Wonderful ſtrange, an ugly prank! that unhappy young-man! O roguiſh Parmeno, who brought him hither?

l.hi: What is the matter?
It pitieth me to ſee it, and therefore I poor woman can hither out of doors, that I might not ſee it.
What examples do they think ſhall be made of him, which are not ſor him?

sp.speaker: Par.

l.hi: O Jupiter,

sp.l: line 5 What ado is there? am not I undone? I will go to her: What is the matter, Pythias!

l.hi: What ſay you? on whom ſhall examples be made?
Do you ask, you bold fellow?
You have undone that young-man whom you brought inſtead of the Eunuch,
Whilſt you ſtrive to begule us.
Why ſo, or what is done, tell me?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I will tell you: That maid which was given for a preſent to Tha is to day;

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Do you know that ſhe is a Citizen here hence, and that her brother is a great Gentleman?
I know it not.
But ſhe is found ſo to be, the poor youth hath defloured her,
When her brother being a very paſsionate man knew theſe things.
What did he?
Firſt, he bound him after a pitiful manner.
Bound him, what now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And indeed when Thais intreated him that he would not do it.

l.label: line 15
l.hi: What ſay you?
Now he threatneth moreover that he will do, as is uſed to be done to whoremaſters;
A thing which I never ſaw to be done, nor deſire to ſee.
With what confidence
Dareth he to attempt ſo great a villany?
Why ſo great?
Do not you think it a very great one?
What man ever ſaw one taken for a whoremaſter
In a baudie houſe?
I know not.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But Pythias, that ye may not but know this,

l.label: line 20
l.hi: I tell you, and tell you plainly, that he is our maſters ſon.
Alas,
I pray you is it he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Let not Thais ſuffer any wrong to be done to him,

l.hi: And withal, why do not I my ſelf go in?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Have a care Parmeno,

l.hi: What you do, leſt you do him no good, but undoe your ſelf; for they think this,
What ever it is that is done, to be long of you.
What then ſhall I do poor man,

l.label: line 25
l.hi: Or what ſhall I begin? but lo I ſee the old man coming out of the country again,
Should I tell him, or not? Truly I will tell him though I know ſome great harm
Attendeth me. But it is neceſſary that he ſhould help him.
You are wiſe,
I am going in. Do you tell him all the matter in order: how it was done.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: PRo Deûm fidem, facinus foedumio infoelicem adoleſcentulum! O ſccleſtum Parmenonem, qui iſtum huc adduxit?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l:
Miſcret me: ita
que ut ne viderem, miſera huc effugi foras.
Quae futura exempla dicunt in eum indigna?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O Jupiter,
line 5 Quae illaec turba eſt? numnam ego perii? ad • be. Quid iſtue, Pythias?
Quid ais, in quem exempla ſient?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Rogitas audaciſſime?
Perdidiſti iſtum, quem adduxti pro Eunucho, adoleſcentulum,
Dum ſtudes dare verba nobis.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid ita? aut quid factum eſt, cedô.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Dicam; virginem iſtam, Thaidi hodie quae dono data eſt,
line 10 Scin' cam hinc civem eſſe? & ejus fratrem adprime nobilem?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Neſcio.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Atqui ſic inventa eſt, cam iſte vitiavit miſer,
Ille ubi haec reſcivit frater violentiſſimus.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quidnam fecit?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Pri • ùm cum miſeris modis.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Colligavit? Hem!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l:
At
que equidem orante, ut ne id faceret, Thaide.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 15 Quid ais?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nunc minitatur porrò ſeſe id facturum, quod maechis ſolet,

Quod ego nunquam vidi fieri, ne
que velim.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quâ audaciâ tantum
Facinus audet?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Quid ita tantum?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Annon tibi hoc maxumum?
Quis homo pro maecho unquam vidit in domo meretriciâ
Deprehendi quenquam?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Neſcio.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: At ne hoc neſciatis, Pythias,
line 20 Dico & edico vobis noſtrum eſſe illum herilem filium.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hem!
Obſecro an is eſt?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ne quam in illum Thais vim fieri ſinat.
Atque adeò autem, cur non egomet int • ò eo?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Vide, Parmeno,

Quid agas, ne ne
que illi proſis, & tu pereas; nam hoc putant,
Quicquid factum eſt, à te eſſe ortum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid igitur faciam miſer?
line 25 Quidve incipiam? ecce autem de rure video redeuntem ſenem,
Dicam huic, an non? Dicam hercle, etſi mihi magnum malum
Scio paratum. S • d neceſſe eſt ut huic ſubveniat.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Sapis,
Ego abeo intrò. Tu iſti narrato omnem rem ordine, ut factum eſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I Get this benefit by my conntrey farm which lieth neer the city, I never • feel • any weariſomneſs either of the • country or
When I begin to be weary, I change my place.
But is not this Parmeno? Certainly, it is even be:
line 5 Whom do you tarry for Parmeno, here before the door?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What man is that? Ho maſter, you are welcome hither.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Whom do you tarry for Parmeno? I am undone. I am not able
To ſpeak for fear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha, what is the matter, why do you tremble?
Are they all well? tell me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Maſter, I would firſt have you to think
line 10 The ſame as the matter is; whatſoever is done in this kinde,
Is not done through my fault.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You have done well to ask.
I ſhould have told you the matter before hand. Phaedria bought an Eunuch,
Which he beſtowed on this woman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: On whom?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: On Thais.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hath he bought one?
Without doubt I am undone; for how much?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: For twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There is no remedie.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: line 15 Beſides Chaerea is in love here with a minſtrelleſs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How now, what?
Is he in love, doth he know already what a whore meaneth? is he come to the town?
One miſchief cometh on the neck of another.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Maſter, do not look on me,
He doth not theſe things at my ſetting on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Speak no more of your ſelf, you rogue,
If I live, I will; but firſt tell me this whatſoever it is.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: He was brought
line 20 To this Thais inſtead of that Eunuch.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Inſtead of the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes, Afterwards they apprehended him within, in ſtead of the Eunuch, and bound him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: See the boldneſs of theſe whores.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is there any more
Miſchief or harm beſides, which you have not told me?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This is all.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do I forbear to break in hither within upon them?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: There is no doubt, but ſome
line 25 Great miſchief will redound to me from this matter, but it was neceſſary to do it.
I am glad that any miſchief is like to befall theſe by my means.
For the old man now a long time hath fought ſome occaſion,
How he might play them ſome not able trick: and now he hath found one.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: EX meo propinquo rure, hoc capio commodi, Neque agri n • que urbis odium me unquam percipit.
Ubi ſatias coepit fieri, commuto locum.
Sed eſtné ille Parmeno? & certè ipſus eſt.
line 5 Quem praeſtolare, Parmeno, hîc ante oſtium?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quis homo eſt? Ehem, ſalvum te adveniſſe, here, gaudeo.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Quem praeſtolare, Parmeno?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Perii. Metu
Lingua haeret.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ehem, quid eſt? quid tu trepidas?
Satin' ſalvae? dic mihi.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here, primùm te arbitrari
line 10 Id quod resleſt, velim. Quicquid hujus factum eſt,
Culpâ non factum eſt meâ.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Rectè ſanè interrogâſti.
Oportuit rem praenarrâſſe me. Emit quendam Phaedria Eunuchum,
Quem dono huic daret.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Cui?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thaidi.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Emit? Perii
Hercle; quanti▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Viginti minis.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Actum eſt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tum
line 15 Quandam fidicinam amat hic Chaerea.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ehem, quid?
Amat? an ſcit jam ille quod meretrix ſiet; an in aſtu venit?
Aliud ex alio malum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here, ne me ſpectes, me impulſore
Haec non facit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Omitte de te dicere; ego te, furcifer,
Si vivo; ſed iſtud quicquid eſt primùm expedi.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is pro illo
line 20 Eunucho ad Thaidem hanc deductus eſt.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Pro Eunuchon'?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sic eſt. Hunc pro Eunucho poſtea comprehendêre intus & conſtrinxêre.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Occidi.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Audaciam meretricum ſpecta.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Numquid eſt
Aliud mali damnive, quod non dixeris, reliquum?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tantum eſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ceſſo huc intrò irrumpere?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Non dubium eſt quin mihi magnum
line 25 Ex hac re ſit malum, niſi quia neceſſe ſuit hoc facere.
Id gaudeo propter me hiſce aliquid eſſe eventurum mali:
Nam jam diu aliquam cauſam quaerebat ſenex,
Quamobrem inſigne aliquid faceret iis: nunc repperit.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: TRuly never any thing happened to me this many a day,
Which I more deſired might happen, then that the old man came juſt now in into our houſe being miſtaken.
He was a laughing-ſtock to me onely, who knew what he feared.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now I come forth, that I may ſpeak with Parmeno.
line 5 But I pray you, where is he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Doth ſhe ſeek for me?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And lo I ſee him.
I will go to him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What is the matter you fooliſh girl? what would you have? what do you laugh at? Do you go on?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I am undone,
I am weary already poor woman with laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Do you ask?
I never ſaw, nor never ſhall ſee a fooliſher fellow then you are; ah
It cannot be ſufficiently told what ſport you have made within:
line 10 But at firſt I took you to be a diſcreet and wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Muſt you needs preſently beleeve thoſe things which I told you?
Did it not repent you of the wicked act, which the yong man had done,
By your advice, unleſſe you muſt further bewray the poor man to his father?
For what heart do you think he had then, when his father ſaw him
line 15 To have thoſe clothes on? what? do you now know, that you are in a poor caſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ha, what ſay you, you errant quean? did you tell me a lye? what do you laugh?
Do you think it ſuch a fine trick to mock us, you drab!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: A very fine one.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: If you can eſcape ſcot-free with that.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But what can you do?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will requite you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I think ſo. But Parmeno, that which you threaten me perhaps is for a long time to come;
line 20 You ſhall be now puniſhed, who doeſt ennoble a fooliſh yong man
By ſuch villanous deeds, and bewray him too: They will both of them make you an example.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I am quite undone.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is the honour you are like to have for that ſervice. I am gone.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I poor man am undone to day, like a rat, by my own ſqueaking.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: NUnquā aedipol quidquam jam diu, quod magis vellem evenire,
Mihi evenit, quàm quod modò ſenex intrò ad nos venit errans.
Mihi ſoli ridiculo fuit, quae quid timeret ſciebam.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid hoc autem eſt?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nunc id prodeo, ut conveniam Parmenonem.
line 5 Sed ubi obſecro eſt?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Me quaerit haec?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l:
At
que eccum video.
Adibo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid eſt, inepta? quid tibi vis? quid rides? Pergin'?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Perii,
Defeſſa jam ſum miſera te ridendo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid ita?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Rogitas?
Nunquam pol hominem ſtultiorem vidi, nec videbo; ah,
Non ſatis poteſt narrari quos ludos praebueris intus:
line 10 At etiam primò callidum ac diſertum credidi hominem.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Illi • óne credere ea, quae dixi, oportuit te?
An poenitebat flagitii, te authore, quod feciſſet
Adoleſcens, ni miſerum inſuper etiam patri indicares?
Nam quid illi credis animi tum fuiſſe, ubi veſtem vidit
line 15 Illam eſſe eum indutum pater? quid? jam ſcis te periiſſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ehem, quid dixti, peſſuma? an mentita es? etiam rides?
Itán' lepidum tibi viſum eſt ſcelus, nos irridere?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nimium.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Siquidem iſtuc impunè habueris.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Verúm.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Reddam hercle.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Credo, ſed in diem iſtuc Parmeno eſt fortaſſe, quod minitare:
line 20 Tu jam pendebis qui ſtultum adoleſcentem

Nobilitas flagiriis, & cundem indicas: uter
que exempla in te edent.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nullus ſum.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hic pro illo tibi munere honos eſt habitus. Abco.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Egomet meo indicio miſer, quaſi forex, hodie perii.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: WHat now, with what hope, or to what intent go we hither? what do you attempt Thraſo?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What I? that I may yeeld my ſelf to Thais, and do as ſhe biddeth me.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: May I not as well ſerve her, as Hercules ſerved Omphale:

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: I like the example: I wiſh I may ſee your head broken with her ſlipper.
line 5 But her doors creak.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: But what miſchief is this?
I never ſaw this fellow yet; why doth he skip forth ſo haſtily?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: QUid nunc! quâ ſpe, aut quo conſilio huc îmus? quid incoeptas Thraſo?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Egóne? ut Thaidi me dedam, & faciam quod jubeat.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quî minus huic, quàm Hercules ſervivit Omphalae?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Exemplum placet. Utinam tibi commitigari videam ſandalio caput.
line 5 Sed fores crepuêre ab eâ.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Quid autem hoc eſt mali?
Hunc ego nunquā videram etiam; quidnam hic properans proſilit?

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.l: O Country men, is any man living more happy then I?
Truly no man at all, for the gods have plainly ſhewed all their power
On me, to whom ſo many good things have come together on ſuch a ſuddain.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why is he ſo merry?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O my Parmeno, O thou that art the inventer,
line 5 And the beginner, and perfecter of all my pleaſures; do you know in what joyes I am?
Do you know that my Pamphila is found to be a citizen?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I have heard ſo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And
Do you know that ſhe is my bride?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It is well done, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Do you not hear what he ſaith?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Beſides I am glad for my brother Phaedria,
That all his love is ſecure: there is but one houſe;
line 10 Thais commended her ſelf into my fathers protection and fidelity.
She hath yeelded her ſelf to us.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then Thais is wholly your brothers.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yes.
Now this is another thing whereof we may be glad; the Soldier is driven out of doors:
Then do you ſee, that my brother whereever he is, may hear of theſe things as ſoon as may be.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will go ſee for him at home.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Do you make any doubt now Gnatho, but that I am undone for ever?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: line 15 Without doubt, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What, ſhall I mention the firſt, or whom ſhould I moſt
Commend? Him that gave me advice to do it, or my ſelf that durſt adventure
To begin? or ſhould I extol fortune, which was my conductreſs?
Which hath brought to paſs ſo many things, ſo great, ſo fitly, all in one day?
Or ſhall I commend my fathers pleaſantneſs, and courteous behaviour?
line 20 O Jupiter, I beſeech thee, continue this proſperity to us.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O ſtrange! what incredible things did Parmeno tell me even now?
But where is my brother?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He is at hand.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I verily believe ſo.
Brother, there is nothing in the world deſerves more to be loved, than this your Thais,
She is ſuch a fautrix to all our family.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Whoo, do you commend her to me?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am undone.
line 25 The leſs hope there is, the more I am in love. I pray you, Gnatho help me,
My hope hangeth on thee.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Bring this to paſs
By intreaty or for money, that I may have ſome ſhare in Thais's favour now at laſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It is a hard matter?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: If you have any liſt, I knew you what you can do:
If you will but do it, ask what gift or reward you will, and you ſhall have it at a wiſh.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 30 What ſo?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: If I bring it to paſs, I deſire this, that your houſe
May be open to me, whether you be preſent, or abſent, that I may alwayes have a place, though I be uninvited.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I give you my word it ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will go about it.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Whom do I hear here?
O Thraſo!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: God ſave you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Perhaps you do not know what things are done here.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I do know.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Why then do I ſee you in theſe quarters?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: line 35 I rely upon you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do you know how you rely? Souldier, I tell you plainly,
If I find you in this ſtreet ever hereafter, it ſhall not avail you to ſay to me I was ſeeking another man,
I was paſſing this way; you are but a dead man.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Soft, it doth not become you to do ſo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I have ſaid it.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: I am not acquainted with your proud behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Firſt, hear me a few words, which when I ſhall have ſaid, do as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 Let us hear you.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Do you Thraſo, go aſide thither a little. Firſt, I would fain have you
Both beleeve me this, that whatſoever I do in this matter,
I do it chiefly for my own ſake; but if it be alſo beneficial to you, it is a folly
For you not to do it.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: I think the royal ſouldier ought to be entertained.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What, to be entertained?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Do but conſider of it; Phaedria, you indeed
line 45 Live merrily with her, for you love well to fare daintily:
You have but little to give, and Thais muſt of neceſſity receive much,
That ſhe may be able to maintain your love without your coſt.
For all theſe purpoſes, there is no man more fit, or more for your uſe.
Firſt, he both hath what to give, and no body giveth more freely then he.
line 50 He is a fool, a dunce, a dull fellow, he ſnorteth whole nights and dayes.
And you need not fear leſt the woman ſhould love him, you may eaſily drive him away, when you will.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What do we do?

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Beſides, this alſo which I think to be a very main matter,
There is no body entertaineth a man better, nor more laviſhly at all.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: It is a wonder if we ſhall not have need of that man one way or other.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I think ſo to.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: line 55 Ye do well; this one thing alſo I intreat you, that you would entertain me
Into your company; I have laboured about this long enough.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: We entertain you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: But I Phaedria, you Chaerea for this favour

l.hi: Will deliver him up to you to be devoured, and made a fool on.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He deſerveth it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thraſo, come hither when you will.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I pray you what do we?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 60 What? they did not know you, till I told them your behaviour,
And commended you according to your deeds, and vertuous qualities:
I have obtained my requeſt.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: It is well done of you, I thank you heartily:
I was never yet in any place, but every body loved me very well.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Did not I tell you, that this man did roll in Rherorick?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 65 There is nothing praetermitted: Go this way. Fare ye well, and clap your hands.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O Populares, ecquis me hodie vivit fortunatior?
Nemo hercle quiſquam. Nam in me planè dii poteſtatem ſuam
Omnem oſtendêre, cui tam ſubitò tot congruerint commoda.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Quid hic laetus eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O Parmeno mi, O mearum voluptatum omnium
line 5 Inventor, incoeptor, perfector, ſcin' me in quibus ſim gaudiis
Scis Pamphilam meam inventam civem?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Audivi.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Seis
Sponſam mihi?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Bene, ita me Dii bene ament, factum.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Audin' tu, hic quid ait?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tum autem Phaedriae
Meo fratri gaudeo, eſſe amorem omnem in tranquillo: una eſt domus:
line 10 Thais ſe patri commendavit in clientelam & fidem:
Nobis dedit 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Fratris igitur Thais tota eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scilicet.
Jam hoc aliud eſt quod gaud • amus, miles pellitur forás.
Tum tu, frater ub • ubi eſt, fac quam primùm haec audiat.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Viſam domi.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l:
Nunquid, Gnatho▪
•… c dubitas, quin ego nunc perpetuò perierim?
line 15 Sine dubio, opinor.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid commemorem primùm, aut quem laudem
Maxumè? Illúmne qui mihi dedit conſilium ut facerem, an me qui auſus 〈◊〉
Incipere? an fortunam collaudem quae gubernatris fuit?
Quae tot res tantas, tam opportunè in unum concluſit diem?
An mei patris feſtivit •… & fac •… em?
line 20 O Jupiter, ſe 〈◊〉 , 〈◊〉 , •… c bona nobis.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: D •… voſtram fi •… meno modò quae narravit?
Sed ubi eſt frater?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: •… ò eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Gaudeo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Satis credo.
Nihil eſt Thaide •… â dignius quod ametui; ita neſtrae omni eſt
Fautrix familiae.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: H • i, •… h • illam laudas?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Perii.
line 25 Quanto minus ſpei mihi eſt, tanto magis amo. Obſecro, Gnatho,
In te ſpes eſt.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Quid vis. faciam?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Perfice hoc precibus,
Pretio, ut haeream in parte aliquâ tandem apud Thaidem.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Difficile eſt.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Si quid collibuit, novi te. Si effeceris,
Quidvis donum & praemium à me optato, id optatum feres.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: line 30 Itáne?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sic erit.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Si effecero, hoc poſtulo, ut tua mihi domus,
Te praeſente, abſente, pateat: invocato ut ſit locus ſemper.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Do fidem, futurum.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Acc • ngar.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quem ego hîc audio?
O Th •… ſo!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Salvete.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Tu fortaſſe quae facta hîc ſcient, neſcis.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Cur te ergo in his ego conſpicio regionibus?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: line 35 Vobis fretus.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Scin' quàm fretus? miles, edico tibi, ſi te in plate 〈◊〉
Offendero hâc pòſt unquàm, nihil eſt quod dicas mihi, Alium quaerebam,
Iter hâc habui: periiſti.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Eja, haud ſic decet.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Dictum eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non cognoſco veſtrum tam ſuperbum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Sic erit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Prius audite paucis, quod cùm dixero, facitote.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 Audiamus.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tu concede paululum iſtuc, Th • aſo. Principiò ego vos.
Ambos credere hoc mihi vehementer volo, me hujus quicquid faciam,
Id facere maxumè cauſâ meâ: verùm ſi idem vobis prodeſt, vos non
Facere inſcitia eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Militem ego rivalem recipiendum
Cenſeo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hem, recipiendum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Cogita modò; tu hercle cum illâ
line 45 Phaedria, & libenter vivis, etenim bene libenter victitas.
Quod des paulum eſt, & neceſſe eſt multum accipere Thaidem,
Ut tuo amori ſuppeditare poſſit ſine ſumptu tuo.
Ad omnia haec, magis opportunus, nec magis ex uſu tuo
Nemo eſt; principiò & habet quod det, & dat nemo largius.
line 50 Fatuus eſt, inſulſus, tardus, ſtertit noctes & dies,
Neque iſtum metuas, ne amet mulier: facilè pellas ubi velis.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid agimus?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: praeterea, hoc etiam quod ego vel plurimum puto,

Accipit hominem nemo melius prorſum, ne
que prolixiús.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Mirum ni illoc homine quoquo pacto opus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Idem ego arbitror.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 55 Rectè facitis; unum etiam vos • ro, ut me in veſtrum gregem
Recipiatis, ſatis diu jam hoc ſaxum volvo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Recipimus.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ac lubenter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: At ego pro iſtoc ô Phaedria, & tu Chaerea,
Hunc comedendum & deridendum vobis praebebo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Placet.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Dignus eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thraſo, ubi vis, accede.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Obeſecro te, quid agimus?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 60 Quid? iſti te ignorabant, priùs quàm eis mores oſtendi tuos,
Et collaudavi ſecundum facta & virtutes tuas:
Impetravi.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Bene feciſti, gratiam habeo maxumam,
Nunquam etiam fui uſquam, quin me omnes amârint plurimum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Dixtin' ego vobis in hoc eſſe Atticam eloquentiam?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 65 Nihil praetermiſſum eſt. Ite hâc. Vos valete, & plaudite.

div.p: TERENCE'S HEAUTONTIMORUMENOS ENGLISH AND LATINE.

div.head: HEAUTONTIMORUMENOS A COMEDIE, Of Publius Terentius, An African of Carthage:
div.p: Acted At the Megaleſian Games when Lucius Cornelius Lentulus And Lucius Valerius Flaccus were Aediles Curules.
Lucius Ambivius Turpio and Lucius Attilius Praeneſtinus acted it.
Flaccus the Son of Claudius ſet the Tune.
It is a Greek Comedie of Menanders; It was acted firſt with Pipes that had an odd number of holes, and afterwards with two that were held on the right ſide of the mouth.
Publiſhed when Marcus Juventius and Marcus Sempronius were Conſuls.
In the Year, Since the City Rome was built, 591. Before the birth of Chriſt, 161.

div.head: HEAUTONTIMORUMENOS PUBLII TERENTII Carthaginenſis Afri.
div.p: Acta Ludis Megalenſibus, L. Cornelio Lentulo & L. Valerio Flacco Aedilibus Curulibus.
Egerunt L. Ambivius Turpio & L. Attilius Praeneſtinus.
Modos fecit Flaccus Claudii.
Graeca eſt Menandri.
Acta primùm tibiis imparibus, deinde duabus dextris.
Acta III. Edita M. Juventio & M. Sempronio conſulibus.
Anno Ab urbe condita, DXCI. Ante Chriſtum natum, CLXI.

div.head: The Speakers, or Actors in this Comedy.
The Argument or Plot of Heautontimorumenos, By Cajus Sulpitius Apollinaris.
div.l: A Harſh Father enforced his Son Clinia, that was in love
With Antiphila, to go to be a Soldier;
And being ſorry for what he had done, he vexed himſelf.
After he returned, within a while, he went to lodg with Clitipho,
Ʋnwitting to his Father: this Clitipho loved the whore Bacchis.
When Clinia ſent for his deſired Antiphila,
Bacchis came as his ſweat-heart, and Antiphila apparelled
Like a waiting-maid. This was done that Clitipho
Might conceal the matter from his Father. He by Syrus's ſubtle tricks,
Gets ten Pounds from the old-man, to beſtow on the Whore.
Antiphila is found to be Clitipho's ſiſter,
Clinia takes her to wiſe, and Clitipho another woman.

div.head: Heautontimorumeni Argumentum, C. Sulpitio Apollinari Authore.
div.l: IN militiam proficiſci gnatum Cliniam,
Amantem Antiphilam, compulit durus pater:
Animique ſeſe angebat, facti poenitens.
Mox ut reverſus eſt, clam patrem divertitur
Ad Clitiphonem: is amabat ſcortum Bacchidem.
Cùm accerſeret cupitam Antiphilam Clinia,
Ut ejus Bacchis venit amica, ac ſervolae
Habitum gerens Antiphila. Factum id, quò patren
