sp.speaker: S
sp.l: Fie, as if you wanted a place.
Go forſooth this way, or that way, whither you will.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He ſaith well
I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Syrus, an ill end come to thee
That thruſteſt me thence.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But do you hold thoſe hands hereafter.
line 35 Suppoſe you ſo indeed? what do you think Chremes, he will do further,
Unleſs you obſerve, chaſtiſe, and admoniſh him, as far as God will enable you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I will look to that.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But maſter, you muſt now look to him.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: If you be wiſe, for he regards me leſs and leſs.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Syrus, What ſay you? Have you done any thing about that matter, of which I ſpake to you a while ago?

line 40
Or have you found any thing that liketh you, or not yet at all?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 you ſpeak
About the trick? whilſt I have found one lately.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You are an honeſt fellow, tell me what it is.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I will tell you, but as one thing fell out after another.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What is it Syrus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: This is a very naughtie whore.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: So ſhe ſeems.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nay, if you knew all.
See this prank which ſhe begins to play. There was an old woman of Corinth here.
line 45 This woman had lent her ſixteen pounds and a mark.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What then? She died and left behinde her a yong daughter,
She was left as a pawn to this whore for that money.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I underderſtand you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: She hath brought her with her, and ſhe is now with your wife.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Clinia intreateth her to beſtow her on him, and yet deſireth to give her
line 50 Afterwards the ſixteen pounds and a mark.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And will be indeed deſire it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Whoo, is that any queſtion?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I thought ſo; what do you now think to do?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What I? I will go to Menedemus, and tell him ſhe was bought from Caria,
Being rich, and a gentlewoman; if he will buy her again, much gain is to be got by her.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I will now anſwer you for Menedemus.
line 55 I will not buy her; What will you do?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Speak as one would have you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But there is no need.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Is there no need?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No indeed.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Why ſay you ſo? I wonder.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You ſhall know by and by▪ Tarry, tarry; what is the matter,
That our door creaks ſo much?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: QUid iſtuc, quaeſo? qui iſtic mos eſt Clitipho?
Itáne fieri oportet?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Quid ego feci?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Vid • n' ego te mod •
Manum in ſinum huic meretrici inſ • rere?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Acta haec res eſt, perii.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Méne?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hiſce oculis:
line 5 Ne nega. Facis adeò indignè injuriam
Illi, qui non abſtaneas manum? nam iſtaec quidem
Contumelia eſt, hominem amicum recipere

Ad te, at
que ejus amicam ſubagitare; Vel heri in vino
Quàm immodeſtus fuiſti?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Factum eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quàm moleſtus?
line 10 Ut equidem (ita me dii ament) metui quid futurum denique
Eſſet. Novi ego amantium animum, advortunt graviter,
Quae non cenſeas.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: At mihi fides apud hunc eſt,
Nihil me iſtius facturum, pater.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Eſto; at oertè
Coneedas aliquo ab ore • orum aliquantiſper. Multa fert
line 15 Libido; ea prohibet facere tua praeſentia. Ego de me facio Conjecturam. Nemo eſt meorum am • corum hodie, apud quem Expromere omnia mea occulta, Clitipho, audeam.
Apud alium prohibet dignitas, apud alium ipſius facti Piget, ne ineptus, ne protervus videar: quod illum facere credito.

line 20 Sed noſtrum eſt intelligere utcun
que atque ubicun
que opus opus obſequi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid iſtic narrat?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Perii.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Clitipho, haec ego
Praecipio tibi, hominis frugi & temperantis functus officio.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Tace, ſodes.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Rectè ſane.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Syre, pudet me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Credo, neque id injuriâ; quin mihi moleſtum eſt.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Pergin'
line 25 Hercle!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Verum dico, quod videtur.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Nonne accedam
Ad illos?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Eho, quaeſo, una accedendi via eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Atenim hic priùs ſe indicaverit, quàm ego argentum effero.
Chreme, vin'tu homini ſtulto mihi auſcultare?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid Faciam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: J • be hunc abire hinc aliquó.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Quò ego hinc
line 30 Abeam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quò lubet. Da illis locum. Abi deambulatum.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Deambulatum? quò?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Vah, quaſi deſit locus.
Abi, ſanè, iſtâc, iſtorſum, quò vis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Rectè dicit,
Cenſeo.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Dii te eradicent, Syre, qui me iſtinc
Extrudis.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: At tu tibi iſtas poſthac comprimito manus.
line 35 Cenſen' verò, quid illum por • ò credis facturum, Chreme,
Niſi eum, quantum tibi op • s Dii dant, ſervas, caſtigas, mones?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ego iſtuc curabo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Atqui nunc, here, tibi adſervandus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Fiet.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Si ſapias; nam mihi jam minus minúſ
que obtemperat.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid tu? ecquid de illo, quod dudum tecum egi, egiſtin', Syre?

line 40
Aut reperiſti tibi quod placeat, an nondum etiam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: De fallaciâ
Dicis? eſt, inveni quandam nuper.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Frugies; cedò quid id eſt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Dicam, verùm ut aliud ex alio incidit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quidnam, Syre?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Peſſima haec eſt meretrix.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ita videtur.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Immo, ſi ſcias.
Hoc vide quod inceptat facinus. Fuit quaedam anus Corinthia hîc;
line 45 Huic drachmarum argenti haec mille dederat mutuum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid tum?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ea mortua eſt: reliquit filiam adoleſcentulam,
Ea relicta huic arraboni eſt pro illo argento.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Intelligo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Hanc ſecum huc adduxit, ea
que eſt nunc ad uxorem tuam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid tum?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Clinia orat ſibi uti nunc det illam; illi tamen pòſt daturum mille
〈◊〉 . Nummum poſcit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Et poſ • it quidem?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hui, dubiúmne
Id eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ego ſic putavi. Quid nunc facere cogitas?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Egóne? ad Menedemum ibo: dicam hanc eſſe captam ex Caria,
Ditem & nobilem; fi redimat, magnum in eâ eſſe lucrum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Erras.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid ita?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Pro Menedemo ego nunc tibi
line 55 Reſpondeo, Non emo: quid agis?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Op • ata loquere.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Atqui non eſt opus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non opus eſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non hercle veró.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quî iſtuc? miror.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Jam ſcies. Mane, mane; quid eſt, quòd tam.
A nobis graviter crepuére fores?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: UNleſs I be deceived, ſurely this is the ring, which I ſuppoſe it to be. That with which my daughter was expoſed with.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Syrus, what meaneth this talk?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What is it? Do not you think it
To be it?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Truly I told you preſently, as ſoon as you ſhewed it me,
line 5 That it was it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: But be ſure that you now look well upon it,
My nurſe.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I have viewed it ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Now go your way in, and if ſhe
Have already waſhed, bring me word. In the mean time I will tarry for my husband here.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: She would ſpeak with you, you may ſee what ſhe would have: I know not why ſhe is ſad,
There's ſome occaſion: I fear what the matter ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What ſhould it be? truly ſhe
line 10 Will tell us great trifling tales now with much ado.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: O ho, my husband.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O ho, my wife.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I am looking for you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Speak, what
You would have.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Firſt, I intreat you that you would not think
That I durſt do any thing contrary to your command.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Would you have me
Beleeve you this, though it be a thing not to be beleeved? I beleeve you.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I know not
line 15 What fault this excuſe importeth.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Do you not remember that I was with childe,
And that you gave me very ſtrict charge, that if I had a girl I ſhould not
Bring it up?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I know what you have done, you have brought it up.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Have you done ſo?
Then, miſtreſs, my maſter hath received damage.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Not ſo,
But there was here an old woman of Corinth, an honeſt woman, I gave her to be caſt forth.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 20 O Jupiter, that you ſhould be ſo void of wit!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I am undone.
What have I done?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But do you ask?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I have done amiſs, my Chremes,
I have done it unwittingly.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I know that for certain, though you ſhould ſay ſay to it,
That you both ſay and doe all things unwittingly and unadviſedly;
You diſcover ſo many faults in this matter. For firſt now▪ if you would have done
line 25 As I commanded you, ſhe ſhould have been killed, you ſhould not have diſſembled her death
In words, and given her hope of life in very deed. But I paſs by that; that was but pity,
And a motherly minde, I bear with it. But how well have you looke to it? what did you intend?
Conſider with your ſelf, your daughter forſooth is moſt manifeſtly betrayed to that old woman
By you, either to turn whore, or to be ſold publikely. I think this was
line 30 Your thought; any thing is well enough, ſo ſhe may but live. What ſhould one do with thoſe
That know neither right nor reaſon, what is fitting? be a thing better or worſe,
Be it for them, or againſt them, they regard nothing but what they liſt.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: My Chremes,
I confeſs, I have offended, I am confuted; now I intreat you this, by how much more
Experienced your minde is, and more inclinable to pardon, that your equity
line 35 May be ſome protection to my folly.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yes indeed
I will pardon that fault. But Soſtrata, my gentleneſs doth badly teach you
Many things. But what ever it be, ſpeak, wherefore it was begun.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: As we fooliſh and ſorry women are all ſuperſtitious; when I gave her to her to be expoſed,
I pluckt the ring from off my finger, and bade her expoſe it with the girl;
line 40 That if ſhe died ſhe might not be quite without ſome of óur goods.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That is very well, you both ſaved your ſelf and her.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: This is that ring:

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Whence had you it?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Of the yong woman which Bacchis brought with her.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What doth ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: She whilſt ſhe went to waſh her,
Gave me the ring to keep. I did not minde it at firſt, but after I lookt upon it, I knew it preſently.
line 45 I came in haſte to you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What now do you conjecture or finde concerning her?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I know not, but you may ask of her, whence ſhe had it, if ſhe may
Be found.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I am undone, I ſee more hope then I would; ſhe is ours, if it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Is ſhe alive to whom you gave her?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What did ſhe ſay
Shee did heretofore?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: That which I bade her.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tell me what was the name
line 50 Of the woman, that ſhe may be enquired after.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Philtere.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: That is ſhe, it is a wonder
If ſhe be not ſafe, and I undone.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Soſtrata, follow me in this way.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: How is it fallen out beyond my expectation! how greatly feared I, leſt you ſhould be
As hard-hearted now, as you was heretofore, Chremes, about bringing her up!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: A man may not be
Oftentimes as he would, if the matter do not permit. Now ſo is the time with me that I deſire
line 55 A daughter, whereas once I coveted nothing leſſe.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ʋnleſs I be deceived, an ill turn is not far off me,
My forces are now quite driven into ſuch a narrow ſtrait,
Except I finde out ſome trick, that the old may not know this is his ſons ſweet-heart.
For there is nothing for me to hope on about getting the money, or that I ſhould deſire
To deceive the old man; I ſhall be glad if I may get away with a whole skin.
line 60 I am vext that ſuch a good morſel is ſuddenly taken out of my chaps;
What ſhould I do? or what ſhall I deviſe? I muſt begin to reckon anew;
There is nothing ſo hard, but by ſearching it may be found out.
What if I ſhould begin this thus? it is to no purpoſe. What if thus? I ſhall do all one.
But I think it may be thus: it cannot be; Yes, very well; O brave! I have a very fine way.

l.label: line 65
l.hi: Truly I ſuppoſe I ſhall for all this draw into my fingers that ſame monie which is apt to be gone.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: NIſi me animus fall it, hic profectò eſt annulus, quem Ego ſuſpicor. Is quîcum expoſita eſt gnata.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid vult ſibi, Syre, haec oratio?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Quid eſt? iſne tibi
Videtur?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Dixi equidem, ubi mihi oſtendiſti,
line 5 Illicò cum eſſe.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: At ut ſatis modò contemplata ſis, mea Nutrix.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Satis.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l:
Abi nunc jam intró, at
que illa
Si jam laverit, mihi nuntia. Hîc ego virum interea operibor.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Te vult: ut videas quid velit; neſcio quid triſtis eſt,
Non temerè eſt: metuo quid ſit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid ſiet? nae iſta hercle
line 10 Magno jam conatu magnas nugas dixerit.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Ehem, mi vir.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ehem, mea uxor.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Teipſum quaero.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Loquere, quid Velis.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Primùm hoc te oro, ne quid credas me adverſ • m Edictum tuum facere eſſe auſam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Vis me iſtuc tibi, etſi
Incredibile eſt, credere? credo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Neſcio quid peccati
line 15 Portat haec purgatio.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Meminiſtin' me eſſe gravidam,
Et mihi te maximo opere interminatum, ſi puellam parerem, nollc
Tolli?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scio quid feceris, ſuſtuliſti.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Sic eſt factum?
Domina, Ergo herus damno auctus eſt.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Minimè. Sed erat hîc anus Corinthia haud impura, ei dedi exponendam.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 20 O Jupiter, tantámne eſſe in animo inſcitiam!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Perii.
Quid ego feci?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Atrogitas?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Si peccavi, mi Chremes,
Inſciens feci.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Id quidem ego, etſi tu neges, certe ſcio,

Te inſcientem at
que imprudentem dicere ac facere omnia.
Tot peccata in hac re oſtendis. Nam jam primùm ſi meum imperium
line 25 Exequi voluiſſes, interemptam oportuit, non ſimulare mortem
Verbis, re ipsâ ſpem vitae dare; at id omitto; miſcricord • a,
Animus maternus, ſino; quàm bene verò abs te proſpectum eſt▪ quid voluiſti?
Cogita: nempe anui illi prodita abs te filia eſt planiſſimé,
Per te; vel uti quaeſtum faceret, vel uti veniret palàm. Credo id
line 30 Cogitâſti, quidvis ſatis eſt dum vivat modó. Quid cum illis agas,
Proſit, obſit; nihil vident, niſi quod lubet.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Mi Chreme,
Peccavi, fateor, vincor; nunc hoc te obſecro, quanto tuus eſt
Animus natu gravior, ignoſcentior, ut meae ſtultitiae
line 35 Juſtitia tua ſit aliquid praeſidii.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Scilicet equidem
Iſtuc factum ignoſcam. Verùm, Soſtrata, malè docet te mea facilitas
Multa. Sed iſtud quicquid eſt, quâ hoc occeptum cauſâ eſt, loquere.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Ut ſtultae & miſerae omnes ſumus religioſae; cùm exponendam do
Illi, de digito annulum detraho, & cum dico ut unà cum puellâ
line 40 Exponeret. Si moreretur, ne expers partis eſſet de noſtris bonis.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l:
Iſtuc rectè, conſervâſti te at
que illam.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Hic is eſt annulu • .

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Unde habes?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Quam Bacchis ſecum adduxit adoleſcentulam.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Hem!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid ea narrat?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Ea lavatum dum it, ſervandum mihi
Dedit annulum. Non advorti primò; ſed poſtquam aſpexi, illico cognovi.
line 45 Ad te exilii.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid nunc ſuſpicare, aut invenis de illâ?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Neſcio, niſi ut ex ipsâ quaeras, unde hunc habuerit, ſi potis eſt
Reperiri.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Interii, plus ſpei video quàm volo; noſtra eſt, ſi ita eſt;

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Vivitne illa, cui tu dederas?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Neſcio.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quid renunciavit
Olim feciſſe?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Id quod juſſeram.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nomen mulieris cedò
line 50 Quid ſit, ut quaeratur.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Philtere.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ipſa eſt; mirum, ni
Illa ſalva eſt, & ego perii.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Soſtrata, ſequere intrò hâc.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Ut praeter ſpem evenit! quam timui malè, ne nunc animo ita eſſes duro,
Ut olim in tollendâ, Chreme!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non licet hominem eſſe ſaepe
Ita ut vult, ſi res non ſinit. Nunc ita tempus eſt mihi ut cupiam filiam, olim
line 55 Nihil minús.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Niſi me animus fall • t, haud multum a me aberit infortunium,
Ita hercle in anguſtum oppidò nunc meae coguntur copiae:
Niſi aliquid video, ne eſſe amicam hanc gnati reſciſcat ſenex.
Nam quod de argento ſperem, aut poſſe poſtulem, me fallere,
Nihil eſt; triumpho, ſi licet me latere tecto abſcedere
line 60 Crucior bolum tantum mihi eſſe ereptum tam ſubitò è faucibus.
Quid agam? aut quid comminiſcar? ratio de integro ineunda eſt mihi.
Nihil tam difficile eſt, quin quaerendo inveſtigari poſſiet.
Quid ſi hoc ſic incipi • m? nihil eſt; fi ſic? tantundem egero.
At ſic opinor: non poteſt; immò, optumè; euge, optumam habeo.

l.label: line 65
l.hi: Retraham hercle opinor ad me idem illud fu gitivum argentum tamen.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: NOthing hereafter can happen to me ſo weightie, which May cauſe me any grief; this ſo great joy hath befallen me.
I now yeild my ſelf to my father, to become more thrifty then he would have me.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: The matter hath not deceived me, as far as I hear by his words.
line 5 I am glad that this is fallen out to you according to your deſire.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: O my Syrus, have you heard I pray you?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What elſe, who was continually with them?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: To whom did you ever hear any thing happen ſo well?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: To •• man.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: And I ſwear, I am not ſo much glad for my own ſake,
As for hers, whom I know to deſerve all the reſpect that may be.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 10 So I think; but now, Clinia, go to, let me have your help again.
For your friends buſineſs muſt alſo be looked to, that it may be made ſafe:
Leſt the old man ſhould now perceive any thing about the love.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Be quiet.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: My Antiphila ſhall be married to me.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Do you ſo interrupt me in my ſpeech!

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: What ſhall I do, my Syrus? I am glad: bear with me.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I do bear with you, but indeed.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: line 15 We are very happy.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I ſuppoſe, I beſtow my labour in vain.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Speak; I hear you.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But you will not now hear me this.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I will do it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I ſay, Clinia, you muſt have a care of your friends buſineſs that it be made ſafe:
For if you now go away from our houſe, and leave Bacchis here, the old man will know
Preſently that ſhe is Clitipho's ſweet-heart; but if you have her away, it will be concealed

line 20
So as it hath been hitherto.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: But Syrus, there is nothing more
Againſt my marriage; for with what face ſhall I ſpeak to my father?
Do you underſtand what I ſhould ſay?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What elſe?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: What ſhould I ſay? what excuſe
Shall I make?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What? I would not have you lie; tell him plainly
How the matter is.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I charge you, tell him that you
line 25 Love her, and deſire to marry her, and that this is Clilipho's ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: You command me
A very honeſt and juſt thing, and eaſie to be done; and forſooth
You would now have me intreat my father this, that he would conceal it from your old man.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Nay, I would have him tell all the matter down-right in order.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Ha,
Are you well in your wits, and not drunk? Truly you go the way to undo him quite; for how
line 30 For how can he be in ſafety? tell me.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Indeed I think this courſe
The beſt; herein I gallantly vaunt my ſelf, that have ſo great power
In me, and ability of ſuch craft, as that by telling the truth
I can deceive them both; that when our old man telleth yours that ſhe is
His ſons ſweet-heart, he may not beleeve it for all that.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: But by this means
line 35 You take from me again all hope of marriage: for as long as he ſhall think
That ſhe is my ſweet-heart, he will not adventure his daughter. You perhaps,
Make ſmal reckoning what ſhall become of me, ſo you may ſhift for him.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What
With a miſchief, do you think I deſire it to be diſsembled long? its but for one day,
Till I get the money, and no more.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Do you account ſo much enough?
line 40 What then I pray you, if my father know it? what if I tell you
As they that ſay, What if the skie ſhould fall now?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I am afraid
What to do.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Are you afraid? as if it were not in your own power
To acquit your ſelf what time you liſt, and make the matter manifeſt.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l:
〈◊〉 , 〈◊〉
•• c • his • e brought.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.l: In very good ti •• , ſhe her ſelf cometh forth.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: NUlla mihi res poſthac poteſt jam intervenire tanta, quae mihi Aegritudinem afferat: tanta haec laetitia aborta eſt,
Dedo patri me nunc jam, ut frugalior ſim quàm vult.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Nihil me fefellit, quantum audio hujus verba.
line 5 Iſtuc tibi ex ſententiâ tuâ obtigiſſe laetor.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: O mi Syre, audiſtin' obſecro?

sp.speaker: Sy.
Cl.
sp.l: Cui aequè audiſti commodè quicquam eveniſſe?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Nulli.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l:
At
que ita me Dii ament, ut ego nunc non tam meâpte cauſâ
Laetor, quam illius, quam ego ſcio eſſe honore quovis dignam.
line 10 Ira credo; ſed nunc Clinia, age, da te mihi viciſſim,
Ne quid de amore nunc ſenex.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: O Jupiter

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quieſce.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Antiphila mea nubet mihi.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Siccine me interloquere?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Quid faciam, mi Syre? gaudeo; fer me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Fero, hercle vero

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: line 15 Deorum vitam adeptti ſumus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Fruſtra operam, opinor ſumo.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Loquere, audio.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: At jam hoc non audies.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Agam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l:
Vid • ndum, inquam, amici quo
que res, Clinia, tui in tuto ut collocetur:
Nam ſi nunc à nobis abis, & Bacchidem hic relinquis, ſenex reſciſſcet
Illico eſſe amicam hanc Clitiphonis: ſi adduxeris, celabitur

line 20
Itidem, ut celata eſt adhuc.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Atenim iſtoc nihil eſt magis
Syre, meis nuptiis adverſum: nam quo ore appellabo patrem?
Tenes, quid dicam?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quidni?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Quid dicam? quam cauſam
Afferam?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid? nolo mentiare, apertè ita ut res ſoſe
Habet, narrato.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Jubeo illam te
line 25 Amare & velle uxorem: hanc eſſe Clitiphonis.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Bonam
Atq: juſtam rem oppidò imperas, & factu facilem; & ſcilicet
Jam me hoc voles patrem exorare, ut celet ſenem veſtrum.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Imò, ut rectâ viâ rem narret ordine omnem.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Hem,
Satin' ſanus es & ſobrius? Tu quidem illum planè perd • s; nam quî
line 30 Ille poterit eſſe in tuto? dic mihi.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Huic equidem conſilio
Palmam do, hic me magnificè effero, qui vim tantam
In me & poteſtatem habeam tantae aſtutiae, vera dicendo
Ut eos ambos fallam; ut cùm narret ſenex noſter veſtro iſtam eſſe
Amicam gnati, non credat tamen.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: At enim ſpem iſtoc
line 35 Pacto rurſus nuptiarum omnem mihi eripis; nam dum amica •
Hanc meam eſſe credet, non committet filiam. Tu fortaſſe
Quid me fiet, parvi pendis, dum illi conſulas.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid,
Malùm me aetatem cenſes velle id aſſimularier? Unus eſt dies,
Dum argentum eripio • nihil amplius.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Tantum ſat habes?
line 40 Quid tum quaeſo, ſi pater hoc reſciverit?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid ſi redeo
Ad illos, qui aiunt, Quid ſi nunc coelum ruat?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Metuo
Quid agam.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Metuis? quaſi non ea poteſtas ſit tua,
Quo velis in tempore ut te exſolvas, rem facias palam.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Age, age, traducatur Bacchis.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Optum • , ipſa exit fo • as.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: TRuly, Syrus's his promiſes have ſaucily enough brought me hither
For the ten pounds which be promiſed me. But if he ſhall now
D • ceive me, he ſhall come in vain, often intreating me to come.
Or when I ſhall have told him, and appointed that I will come, when he
line 5 Hath carried certain word, Clitipho ſhall then hang in hope,
I will deceive him and not come; I ſhall make Syrus's back to ſmart for it.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Shee promiſeth you pretty well. But do you think ſhe jeſteth?
Shee will do it, except I take heed.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: They are aſleep, but indeed
I will rouſe them. My Phrygia, did you not hear even now, what country houſe
line 10 Of Charinus's that fellow ſhewed us?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I heard him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: He ſaid it was next
To this ground on the right hand.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I remember it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Run
Apact; the ſouldier keeps with him a feaſt to Bacchus.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Why doth ſhe begin theſe things?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Tell him, that I am here ſore againſt my will, and that I am kept perforce,
But that I will deceive them one way or other, and will come.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 15 I am undone indeed. Bacchis, tarry, tarry; whither do you ſend that maid, I pray you?
Bid her tarry.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Go your way.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But the money is ready.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: But I tarry here.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But it ſhall be given you by and by.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: As you pleaſe; do I urge you?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But I pray you, know you not what you are to doe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You muſt now ſtep, over to Menedemus houſe, and all your train,
Muſt be brought over thither.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: What do you do, you rogue?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What I? I am coyning the money.
Which I muſt give you.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Do you think me fit to make a fool on?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: It is not for nothing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: What have you any thing to do with me here?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: No, I will but give you your own.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Let us go.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Follow me this way. Ho Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Who would have any thing with me?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Syrus.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: What is the matter? Bring over all Bacchis maids hither to your houſe quickly.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Do not ſtand to ask.
And let them bring what things they brought with them hither. The old man will hope
line 25 That his charge is leſſened by their going hence. Truly, he little knoweth what great loſſe
This little gain may bring him. You know not what you do know,
D • omo, if you be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: You ſhall tell them, I will be as mute as a Fiſh.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: SAtis pol protervè me Syri promiſſa huc adduxerunt,
Decem minas quas mihi pollicitus eſt. Quod ſi nunc me
Deceperit, • aepe obſecrans me ut ut veniam, fruſtra veniet:
Aut cùm venturam dixero & conſtituero, cùm is certe
line 5 Renunciaverit, Clitipho tum ſpe pendebit animi,
Decipiam ac non veniam; Syrus mihi tergo paenas pendet.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Satis ſcitè promittit tibi.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Atqui tu hanc jocari credis?
Faciet, niſi caveo.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Dormiunt; ego pol iſtos
Commovebo. Mea Phrygia, and iſtin modò iſte homo quam villam
line 10 Demonſtravit Charini?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Audivi.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Proxumam eſſe
Huic fundo ad dextram?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Memini.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Curriculo
Percurre: apud eum miles Dionyſia agitat.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid haec inceptat?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Dic me hîc oppidò eſſe invitam, atque aſſervari:

line 15 Verùm aliquo pacto verba me his daturam eſſe, at
que venturam.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Perii hercle: Bacchis mane, mane; quò mittis iſtam nunc quaeſo?
Jube, maneat.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Abi.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quin eſt paratum argentum.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Quin ego hîc maneo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Atqui jam dabitur.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Ut lubet, num ego inſto?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: At ſcin, quid ſodes facias?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Tranſeundum nunc tibi ad Menedemum eſt, & tua pompa
Eò traducenda eſt.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Quam rem agis, ſcelus?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Egon'? argentum cudo,

line 20
Quod tibi dem.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Dignam me putas, quam illudas?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 eſt temeré.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Etiámne tecum hîc res mihi eſt?

sp.speaker: S •…
sp.l: •… inimè, tuum tibi reddo.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Eatur.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Sequere me hâc. Heus Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quis me vult?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Syrus.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quid eſt rei?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ancillas omnes Bacchidis
Traduce huc ad vos properé.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Quam ob rem?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ne quaeras.
line 25 Et ferant, quae ſecum huc attulerunt. Sperabit ſumptum ſibi ſenex
Levatum eſſe harum abitu. Nae, ille haud ſcit hoc paululum lucri,
Quantum ei damni apportet. Tu neſcis id quod ſcis,
Dromo, ſi ſapies.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: Mutum dices.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I Swear, I pity Menedemus's hap,
That ſo much miſchief hath befallen him,
As to maintain that woman with all her family,
Though I know he will not be ſenſible of it theſe two or three dayes,
line 5 He hath had ſuch a great deſire after his ſon.
But when he ſhall ſee that he ſhall be daily at ſuch charges
In houſe-keeping, and that there will be no mean,
He will wiſh again that his ſon were gone from him.
I ſee Syrus in good time, Lo where he is.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Do I make no haſte to ſet on him?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Syrus.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 10 What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I wiſhed long ago to have met with you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Me thinks you have been doing ſomething now with the old man,
I know not what.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Do you mean about that which you ſpake of ere-while? I fully diſta • ched it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What in good earneſt?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: In good earneſt truly.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I cannot forbear,
But I muſt ſtroke thy bead. Come hither to me, Syrus,
line 15 I will do you ſome good turn for that matter, and with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But if you knew how prettily it came into my minde.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Fie do you brag, that it fell out according to your minde?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: No, indeed, I tell you the truth.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tell me what it is.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l:
Cli • i •
told Menedemus that this Bacchis
line 20 Is your ſon Clitipho's ſweet-heart, and that he brought her with him
For that reaſon, for fear you ſhould fully perceive it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Speak in good ſooth.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I ſay it is too too well.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Yes, ſo far well enough.
But bear further, what bravery remaineth;
He will tell you that himſelf ſaw your daughter,
line 25 And that her beauty liked him well, after he ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Her,
And that he would fain have her to wife.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Doth he mean her which was found erewhile?
And he will bid that ſhe be required.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Why ſay you that Syrus?
For I underſtand nothing at all.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Tuſh, you are a dullard.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Perhaps ſo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He ſhall have money given him for the marriage,
line 30 Wherewith he may get gold and cloathes; do you apprehend me?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Let him get it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: That ſame is it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But I will neither give nor promiſe her to him.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: No? why?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do you ask me why? to a fellow?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Do as you liſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: ITa me Dii amabunt, ut nunc Menedemi vicem
Miſeret me, tantum deveniſſe ad cum mali,
Illancine mulierem alere cum illâ familiâ,
Etſi ſcio hoſce aliquot dies non ſentiet,
line 5 Ita magno deſiderio fuit ei filius.
Verùm ubi videbit tantos ſibi ſumptus domi
Quotidianos fieri, nec fieri modum,
Optabit rurſum ut abeat ab ſe filius.
Syrum optumè, eccum.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ceſſo hunc adoriri?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Syre.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Hem,

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 10 Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Te mihi ipſum jamdudum exoptabam dari.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Videre egiſſe jam neſcio quid cum ſene.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: De illo quod dudum? dictum ac factum reddidi.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Bonáne fide?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Bonâ hercle.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Non poſſum pati
Quin tibi caput demmulceam. Accede huc, Syre,
line 15 Faciam tibi boni aliquid pro iſtâ re ac lubens.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: At ſi ſcias, quàm ſcitè in mentem venerit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Vah, gloriare eveniſſe ex ſententiâ?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Non hercle verò, verum dico.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Dic quid eſt.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Tui Clitiphonis eſſe amicam hanc Bacchidem
line 20 Menedemo dixit Clinia, & ei gratiâ
Secum adduxiſſe, ne tu id perſentiſceres.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Probè.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Dic ſodes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nimiùm inquam.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Imò ſic ſatis.
Sed porrò auſculta quod ſupereſt fallaciae,
Seſe ipſe dicet tuam vidiſſe filiam,
line 25 Ejus ſibi complacitam formam, poſtquam aſpexerit,
Hanc ſe cupere uxorem.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Modóne quae inventa eſt?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Eam.
Et quidem jubebit poſci.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quamobrem iſtuc, Syre?
Nam prorſus nihil intelligo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Hui, tardus es.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Fortaſſe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Argentum dabitur ei ad nuptias;

line 30 Aurum at
que veſtem, quî; tenéſne?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Comparet.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Id ipſum.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: At ego illi nec do nec deſpondeo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Non, quamobrem?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Quamobrem me rogas? homini?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ut lubet.

div.p: ADELPHI TERENTII Anglo-Latina.
TERENCES ADELPHI Engliſh and Latine.

div.head: ADELPHI
div.p: Publii Terentii Carthagenienſis Afri
Acta Ludis Funebribus Lucii Aemilii Pauli;
Q. Fabio Maximo, & P. Cornelio Africano Aedilibus Curulibus.
Quos fecere L. Attilius Praeneſtinus & Minutius Prothimus.
Modos fecit Flaccus Claudii Tibiis Sarranis.
Graeca eſt Menandri; Edita L. Anicio (Gallo) Marco Cornelio (Cethego) Conſulibus.
Anno Ab Urbe condita D XC V. Ante Chriſtum na • um C LX VIII.

div.head: ADELPHI
div.p: A Comedy of Publius Terentius an African of Carthage.
Acted At the Funeral ſolemnities of Lucius Aemilius Paulus;
Q. Fabius Maximus and Publius Cornelius Africanus Being Aediles Curules.
Which Lucius Praeneſtinus and Minutius Prothimus ſet out.
Flaceus the Son of Claudius tuned it On Pipes that had even holes, ſuch as the Sarrans or Tyrians uſed.
It is a Greek Comedie of Menanders, publiſhed When Lucius Anicius (Gallus) and Marcus Cornelius ( • ethegus) were Conſuls.
In the Year Since the citie Rome was built DXCV. Before Chriſt was born C LX VIII.

div.head: The Argument or Plot of Adelphi, by Caeius Sulpicius Apollinaris.
div.l: WHere as Demea had two young men to his ſonnes,
He giveth Aeſchines to his brother Mitio to be adopted,
But keeps Cteſipho with himſelf. This Cteſipho
Being caught with the pleaſant deportment of a minſtrelleſs,
line 5 And living under a harſh and ſevere father,
His brother Ae • chinus concealed, and took upon him too
The report of his love, and at laſt
He took the m • nſtre leſs from the bawd by force. This ſame Aeſchinus
Had defloured a poor girl a citizen of Athens;
line 10 And had plight her his tr • th, that ſhe ſhould be his wife.
After the truth was diſcovered, Aeſchinus married
The maid the citizen of Athens, that he had defloured;
Cteſipho enjoyeth the minſtrelleſs as his wife,
His harſh father D • mea being over-intreated with much adoe.

div.head: Adelphorum argumentum; C. Sulpicio Apollinari authore.
div.l: DUos cum haberet Demea adoleſcentulos,
Dat Mitioni fratri adoptandum Aeſchinum,
Sed Cteſiphonem retinet. H •… hariſtriae
Lepore captum, ſub doro ac t • i • ti patre,
line 5 Frater celabat Aeſchinus, faman, quoque
Amoris in ſe transferebat, benique
Fidicinam lenoni eripuit. Vitiaverat
Fidénque dederat, hanc ſibi uxo • em fore.
line 10 Demea jurgate, & graviter f • rre; mox tamen,
Ut veritas patefacta eſt, ducit Aeſ • hinus
A ſe vitiatam civem Atticam virginem;
Uxore potitur Cteſipho cithariſtriâ,
Exo ato ſuo patre duro Demeâ.

div.head: The Actors or Speakers in this Comedie.
The Prologue.
div.l: Foraſmuch as the Poet perceived his Comedie, which we are to act,
To be pryed into by carping men, and that his adverſaries
Wreſt all to the worſe ſenſe:
He will lay open himſelf, and you ſhall be the judges,
line 5 Whether the thing done ought be acconnted for his commendation, or diſpraiſe.
Synapothneſcontes is a Comedie of Diphilus's,
Plautus made it a Comedie called Commorientes;
In the Greek Comedie there is a young-man that took forsibly
A whore from a bawd; in the firſt part of the Comedie, Plautus
line 10 Left that place unmedled with; Terence hath taken it to himſelf
Into his Adelphi, and hath tranſlated it word by word.
We are to act it as a new one. Conſider well,
Whether you think there is a theft committed, or a place
Taken in, which was omitted by Plautus's negligence;
line 15 For as for that which theſe ill-willed perſous ſay, that noble perſonages
Doe help him, and write together with him day by day;
What they think to be a mighty diſgrace,
He takes it to be a very great commendation, foraſmuch as he liketh them
Who give content to you all in general, and the people alſo,
line 20 Whoſe aid in war, in peace, in private affairs,
Every one uſed, as his occaſions were, without diſdain.
Furthermore, do not expect (I ſhould tell you) the plot of the Comedie.
The two old men that will come firſt, will diſcover part,
Others will ſhew apart in the acting. See, that your indifferency
May adde to the Poet's induſtry for writing.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: POſtquam Poeta ſenſit ſcripturam ſuam
Ab iniquis obſervari, & adverſarios
Rapere in pejorem partem, quam acturi ſumus:
Indicio de ſe ipſe erit, vos eritis judices,
line 5 Laudin' an vitio duci factum oporteat.
Synapothneſeontes Diphili comoedia eſt,
Eam Commorientes Plautus fecit fabulam:
In Graeca adoleſcens eſt, qui lenoni eripuit
Mere • icem; in primâ fabulâ, eum Plautus locum
line 10 Reliquit integrum; eum hic locum ſumpſit ſibi
In Adelphos, verbum de verbo expreſſum extulit.
Eam nos acturi ſumus novam; Pernoſcite,
Furtú • ne factum exiſtumetis, an locum
Reprehenſum, qui praeteritus negligentiâ eſt.
line 15 Nam quod illi dicunt malevoli, homines nobiles
Eum adjutare, aſſiduéque unà ſcribere:
Quod illi maledictum vehemens eſſe exiſtimant,
Eam laudem hic ducit maxumam, cùm illis placet,
Qui vobis univerſis, & populo placent;
line 20 Quorum operâ in bello, in otio, in negotio,
Suo quiſque tempore uſus eſt ſine ſuperbiâ.
Dehinc ne expectetis argumentum fabulae;
Senes qui primi venient duo, partem aperient,
In agendo partem oſtendent. Facite, aequanimitas
line 25 Poetae ad ſcribendum augeat induſtriam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: STorax! Aeſchinus is not come back again this night from ſupper,
Nor any one of my ſervants which went to meet him?
Indeed this is true that folks ſay if one be abſent any where,
Of if one linger anywhere, it were better that thoſe things ſhould fall out,
line 5 Which your wife ſpeaks againſt you, or which ſhe imagineth in her minde
Being angry, then thoſe things which tender parents conceit
If you linger your w • fe thinks either that you love ſome bodie elſe,
Or t •… t y • u are beloved of ſome bodie, or that you are tipling, or taking your pleaſ • re,
And that you alone are in a good condition, when ſhe is in an evil caſe.
line 10 What thoughts do run in my mind, becauſe my ſon is not come •… home?
With what things am I now troubled? fear be ſhould be ſtarved,
Or fallen ſomewhere, or have broken ſome joyns of him.
Ah, that any man ſhould propoſe in his mind, no
Provide what m • y be dearer then he is to himſelf!
line 15 But for all this he is none of my ſon, be is my brother's. He is quite
Of another diſpoſiti • n: now ever ſince I was a youth,
I h • ve followed this quiet citizen's life, and my own eaſe,
And • hat which they account to be a happy thing,
I never had a wife; he is as far on the other ſide, be follows all theſe,
line 20 To ſpend his time in the countrey, to keep himſelf alwayes
Sparinglie and hardlie; he hath married a wife, he hath two ſons
Born him; thereupon I adopted this elder ſon to my ſelf.
I have brought him up of a little one, I have eſteemed, and loved him as my own;
I take pleaſure in him, that thing is my only darling.
line 25 I do my utmoſt, that he alſo on the other ſide may account me as a father.
I give him (what he would have) I leave him to his liberty, I think it not neceſſary
To do all things as I may my ſelf. Laſtly, what others do,
Vnknown to their fathers, which youth prompteth,
I have uſed my ſon, not to conceale them from me.
line 30 For he that ſhall uſe to lye or deceive his father, or
Dare to do it, will ſo much the more dare to do it to others.
I think it better to keep in children
With baſh fulneſs and freedom, then with fear.
In theſe things my brother and I do not agree, nor do they pleaſe him.
line 35 He comes often bawling to me, What do you mean, Mitio?
Why do you ſpoil us the young man? why is he in love?
Why doth he tipple? why do you allow him expences in theſe things?
You let him go too brave; you are too fond and fooliſh.
He himſelf is too rigorous beyond all right and reaſon:
line 40 And he is far miſtaken in my judgement truly,
Who thinketh a government to be more ſetled and firm
Which is maintained by force, then that which is gotten by good will.
This is my opinion, and thus I am perſwaded in my minde;
He that doth his duty being conſtrained through ſmart,
line 45 Will ſo long take heed, as he thinks it will come to be known;
If he hope it may be carried cloſely he returns to his old byaſs again.
He whom you gain by a courteſie, doth what he doth heartily,
He ſtudieth to requite you; he will be all one, be he preſent or abſent.
This is a fatherly part, rather to accuſtom a ſon
line 50 To do well of his own accord, then for fear of another.
Herein doth a father and a maſter differ. He that cannot do this,
Let him confeſs he knoweth not how to command children.
But is not this be himſelf of whom I was ſpeaking? yea verily it is he.
I know not why I ſee him ſo ſad; I believe he will chide even now,
line 55 As he uſeth to do. O Demea, I am glad you are come in ſafety hither.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: STorax! non rediit haec nocte à caenâ Ae • chinus,
Neque ſervulorum quiſquam qui adverſum ierant?
Profectò hoc verè di • unt: ſi abſis uſpiam,
Aut ubi ſi ceſſes, evenire ea ſatius eſt,
line 5 Quae in te uxot dicit, & quae in animo cogitat
Irata, quàm illa quae parentes propitii.
Uxor, ſi ceſſes, aut te amare cogitat,
Aut tete amari, aut potare, aut animo obſequi,
Et tibi bene eſſe ſoli, cùm ſibi ſit malé.
line 10 Ego, quia non rediit filius, quae cogito?
Quibus nunc ſollicitor rebus? ne aut ille alſerit,
Aut uſpiam céciderit, aut perfregerit aliquid.
Vah, quemquá • ne hominum in animum inſtituere, aut
Parare, quod ſit carius quàm ipſe eſt ſibi!
line 15 Atqui ex me hic natus non eſt, ſed ex fratre. Is adeò
Diſſimili ſtudio eſt; jam inde ab adoleſcentia,
Ego hanc clementem vitam urbanam, atque otium
Secutus ſum, &, quod fortunatum iſti putant,
Uxorem nunquam habui: ille contrá, haec omnia,
line 20 Ruri agere vitam, ſemper parcè ac dutiter
Se habere; uxorem duxit, nati filii
Duo: inde ego hunc majorem adoptavi mihi:
Eduxi à parvulo, habui, amavi pro meo;
In eome oblecto: ſolum id eſt carum mihi.
line 25 Ille ut item contrà me habeat, facio ſeduló.
Do, permitto; non neceſſe habeo omnia
Pro meo jure agere: poſtremò, alii clanculum
Patres quae faciunt, quae fert adoleſcentia,
Ea ne me celet, aſſuefeci filium.
line 30 Nam qui mentiri, aut ſallere inſuêrit patrem, aut
Audebit, tantò magis audebit caeteros.
Pudore, & liberalitate liberos
Retinere ſatius eſſe credo, quàm metu.
Haec fratri mecum non conveniunt, neque placent.
line 35 Venit ad me ſaepe clamitans Quid agis, Mitio?
Cur perdis adoleſcentem nobis? cur amat?
Cur potat? cur tu his rebus ſumptum ſuggeris?
Veſtitu nimio indulges; nimium ineptus es.
Nimium ipſe eſt durus, praeter aequui & bonum:
line 40 Et errat longè meâ quidem ſententiâ,
Qui imperium credat gravius eſſe aut ſtabilius,
Vi quod fit, quàm illud quod amici • iâ adjungitur.
Mea ſic eſt ratio, & ſic animum induco meum,
Malo coactus qui ſuum officium facit,
line 45 Dum id reſcitum iri credit, tantiſper cavet:
Si ſperat fore clam, rurſum ad ingenium redit.
Ille quem beneficio adjungas, ex animo facit;
Studet par referre, praeſens abſenſque idem erit.
Hoc patrium eſt, potiùs conſuefacere filium,
line 55 Suâ ſponte recte facere, quàm alieno metu.
Hoc pater ac dominus intereſt. Hoc qui nequit,
Fateatur neſcire imperare liberis.
Sed eſtne hic ipſus de quo agebam? & certè is eſt.
Neſcio quid triſtem video; credo jam, ut ſolet,
line 55 Jurgabit. Sal • um te advenire, Demea, gaudemus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: OH • in very good time: it is even you that I looked for.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why are you ſo ſad?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you ask me, and know where Aeſchinus is, why I am ſo ſad?
Did not I tell you this would come to paſs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What hath he done?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What hath he done?
Who is not aſhamed of any thing, nor feareth any man; nor thinks he himſelf
line 5 Bound by any law. For I let paſs thoſe things that were done
Heretofore; what aetrick hath he played but lately?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: He hath broken open the doors, and hath ruſht violently in
Into anothers mans houſe: he hath beaten the good man himſelf
And all his family, and almoſt killed them; he hath forcibly taken away
line 10 The woman which he loved: every body cries out, that it is moſt unworthilie
Done: how many folks, Mitio, have told me this as I was coming to you!
It is in all peoples mouths; and to be ſhort,
If an example be to be compared with him, he doth not ſee his brother
To be buſied about husbandry, to be thriftie & tēperate in the countrey;
line 15 He ſeeth no ſuch thing as this done. When I tell him of theſe things; Mitio,
I tell you, you ſuffer him to be ſpoiled.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Never was there any thing more unreaſonable then an ignorant fellow,
Who thinketh nothing to be right, but what he doth himſelf.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: To what purpoſe is this?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Becauſe you, Demea, judge amiſſe of this matter:
line 20 It is no heinous offence (believe me) for a young man
To haunt whores, nor to fuddle, it is no fault, nor to break open
Doors: if neither I nor you did theſe things,
Want of means did not ſuffer us to do them. Now you account that
For your commendation, which you did then through want.
line 25 There is no equity in this; for if we had had wherewithal it might have been done,
We ſhould have done it: and if you were a wiſe man, you would ſuffer
That ſon of yours to do it now, whileſt age will give him leave,
Rather then, whē he hath buried you, whoſe death he hath long expected,
To do theſe things afterwards for all that in a more unfitting age.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 O Iupiter! you make me mad, man.
Is it not a heinous matter for a yong man to do theſe things?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Piſh,
Hear me. Do not trouble my head about this thing too often.
You gave me your Son to be adopted;
He is now become mine: if he do amiſs, Demea, in any thing,
line 35 He doth it amiſs to me; I ſhall bear the greateſt ſhare (of blame) there.
He feaſteth, he fudleth, he ſmelleth of perfumes at my charges.
Doth he love? I will allow him money, when I think it ſitting;
When I think it not fitting, perhaps he ſhall be pack't out of doors.
Hath he broken any doors? they ſhall be repaired, hath he rent any cloathes? they ſhall be mended.
line 40 I have, I thank God, wherewith alſo to do theſe things, and they do not yet trouble me.
Laſtly, either give over, or appoint whom you will to be judge betwixt us.
I will make it appear that you offend more in this matter then I.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: W • is me.
Learn to be a father of them, who know indeed, what it is to be one.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You are his father by nature, and I by my adviſing him.

sp.speaker: D
sp.l: line 45 Do you adviſe him any thing?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Piſh, if you hold on, I will • be gone.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you ſerve me ſo?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Should I hear you ſo often about the ſame matter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I have a care over him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: And I have a care over him. But, Demea,
Let us both care an equal ſhare. Do you care for the one,
And I alſo for the other. For for you to take care of both, is in a manner
line 50 To demand him again, whom you have given me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ah. Mitio.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why am I againſt it? If that content you,
Let him laviſh it, let him waſte it, let him come to naught. It is nothing at all to me.
Now if I ſpeak any one word hereafter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Are you angry again,

l.hi: Demea?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do not you believe it? Do I demand again whom I have given?
line 55 It is a hard caſe; I am no ſtranger to him, if I withſtand his behaviour. I give over.
You would have me look to one; I do look to him, and I thank God.
Foraſmuch as he is ſo, as I would have him to be, & that your ſon ſhall feel
Hereafter himſelf. I will ſay no worſe againſt him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Something, but not-all is true that he ſaith; nevertheleſſe
line 60 Theſe things are ſome trouble to me, but I would not let him ſee
That I am grieved at it; for he is ſuch a man,
When I pacifie him, I am all I can againſt him, and terrifie him from his purpoſe:
Yet he ſcarcely takes it as a man ought to do; but if I ſhould increaſe
Or elſe help forward his angry fit,
line 65 Truly I ſhould be as mad as he: although Aeſchinus
Doth us ſome wrong in this buſineſs.
What whore is there that he hath not been in love with, or on whom hath he not beſtowed
Something or other? At the laſt now of late (I think he was now grown weary
Of them all) he ſaith he hath a minde to marry a wife.
line 70 I hoped now his youthful courage was abated.
I was glad of it. And l • e his reſolution of a freſh; but what ever it is,
I will know, and meet with the fellow, if he be in the market.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: EHem, oppor uné: teipſum quaerito.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Q • id triſtis es?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Rogit •… me, ubi no • is Aeſchinus ſiet, quid triſtis go •… m?
Dixin' hoc ſore?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid fecit?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ille ſecerit?
Quem neque pudet quiequam, nec metuit quemquam, neque legem putat
line 5 Tenere ſe ullam. Nam illa quae antehac f • cta ſunt
O • i •… o; modò quid diſtignavit?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quidnam id eſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fores effregit, atque in aedes irruit
Alienas; ipſum dominum atque omnem familiam
Multavit uſque ad mortem: cripuit mulierem,
line 10 Quam amabat; clamant omnes indigniſſimè
Factum eſſe: hoc advenienti quot mihi, Mitie,
Dirêre; in ore eſt omni populo; denique,
Si conferendum exemplum eſt, non fratrem videt
Rei dare operam, ruri eſſe parcum ac ſobrium?
line 15 Nullum hujus factum ſimile: Haec cum ill, Mitio,
Dico, tibi dico, tu illum corrumpi ſinis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Qui, niſi quod ipſe facit, nihil rectum putat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quorſum iſtuc?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quia tu, Demea, hoc malè judicas;
line 20 Non eſt flagitium, mihi crede, adoleſcentulum
Scortari, neque potare, non eſt, neque fores
Effringere: haec ſi neque ego, neque tu fe • imus,
Non ſivit egeſtas facere nos. Tu nunc tibi
Id laudi ducis, quod tunc ſeciſti inopiâ.
line 25 Injurium eſt; nam ſi eſſet unde id fieret,
Faceremus: & tu illum tuum, ſi eſſes homo,
Sineres nunc facere, dum per aetatem licet,
Potiùs quàm ubi te expectatum ejeciſſet f • r • s,
Alienore aetate pòſt facere tamen.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Pro Jupiter! tu, homo, redigis me ad inſaniam.
Non eſt flagitium facere haec adoleſcentulum?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ah,
Auſculta. Ne me obtundas de hac re ſaepius.
Is meus eſt factus; ſi quid peccat, Demea,
line 35 Mihi peccat: ego illi maxumam partem feram;
Obſonat, potat, olet unguenta de meo.
Ubi non erit, fortaſſe excludetur forás.
Fores eff •• g •… ? reſtituentur. diſcidit veſtem? reſarcictur.
line 40 Eſt, D •… gr • tia, & unde haec fiant, & adhuc non moleſta ſunt.
Poſte •… ò, aut deſine, aut cedò quemvis arbit • um:
Te plura in hac re peceare oſtendam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hei mihi!
Pater eſſe diſce ab illis, qui verè ſ • iunt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Naturâ to illi pater es, conſiliis ego.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 45 Túne conſulis quicquam?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ah, ſi pergis, abiero.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Siccine agis?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: An ego te toties de eâdem re audiam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Curae eſt mihi.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Et mihi curae eſt; verùm, Demea,
Curemus aequam uterque partem: tn alterum,
Ego item alterum: nam ambos curare, propemodum
line 50 Repoſcere eſt illum quem dediſti.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ah. Mitio.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Mihi ſic videtur.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc▪ Si tibi iſtuc places,
Perſundat, perdat, pereat, nihil ad me attinet.
Iam ſi verbum ullum poſthac.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Rurſum, Demea,
Iraſcere?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: An non credis? repeton' quem dedi?
line 55 Aegrè eſt, alienus non ſum, ſi obſto: hem, deſino.
Unum vis curem; curo; & eſt Diis gratia,
Cùm ita ut volo, eſt, iſte tuus ipſe ſentiet

l.hi: Poſteriús: molo in illum 〈◊〉 viùs dicere.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nec nihil, neque omnia haec ſunt, quae dicit, tamen
line 60 Nonnihil moleſta haec ſunt mihi, ſed oſtendore▪
Me aegrè pati illi nolui; nam ita eſt homo;
Cùm placo, adverſor ſedulò & deterreo,
Tamen vix humanè patitur: verùm ſi augeam,
Aut etiam adjutor ſim ejus iracundiae,
line 65 Inſaniam profectò cum illo. Etſi Aeſchinus
Nonnullam in hac • re nobis facit injuriam.
Quam hic non amavit meretriem, aut cui non dedit
Aliquid? Poſtremò nuper (credo jam omnium
Taedebat) dicit velle uxorem ducere.
line 70 Sperabam jam deferbuiſſe adoleſcentiam,
Gaudebam. Ecce autem de integro; niſi quidquid eſt,

Volo ſcire, at
que hôminem convenire, ſi apud forum eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I Beſeech you, neighbours, help a poor innocent man, Succour one that needeth help.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Leaſurely, ſtand now here without any more adoe.
Why do you look back? There is no danger. This fellow ſhall never meddle with you,
Whileſt I am here.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I will keep her in deſpite of all your teeths.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: line 5 Though he be a miſchievous fellow, yet will be not give occaſion to day to be beaten again.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Aeſchinus hear me, that you may not ſay you was ignorant of my condition of life.
I am a bawd.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But ſuch a one, as any one of the beſt credit hath been in any place.
That you ſhould excuſe your ſelf hereafter, that you were loth this wrong ſhould have been done
To me, I will not value it thus much. Believe me this, I will defend my own right;
line 10 Nor ſhall you ever undoe by words, what you have wronged me in by deeds.
I know theſe words of yours, you were loth it ſhould have been done. Oath will be given, that you do not deſerve
To have this wrong offered you, where as I my ſelf am unworthily dealt withall.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Goe valerouſly on, and open the door.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But, you had as good do nothing herein.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Goe you your wayes in even now.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But I will not ſuffer him.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Come hither, Parmeno;
line 15 You are gone too far that way: ſtand here by this fellow; So, I would have it thus.
Have a care, you do not turn your eyes any whither from mine, that there be no ſtay, if
I wink to you, but your fiſt may be preſently about his eares.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I would have him
To try that.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Oh, ſave her. Let the woman goe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: O wretched
Act!

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: He ſhall give you as much more, unleſſe you take heed.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Oh the wretchedneſſe!

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I had not winked to you
line 20 Yet rather treſpaſs on that ſide. Go your ways now.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What a thing is this?
Aeſchinus, have you the Kingly command here?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: If I had, you ſhould be rewarded
According to your deſerts.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What have you to do with me?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What?
Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I do not deſire.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Have I medled with any thing of yours?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: If you had medled with any thing,
You ſhould have ſmarted for it.

sp.speaker: S
sp.l: How cometh it to be more lawfull for you to have mine, for whom▪
line 25 I have paid my money? anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: It would have been better for you not to have railed
On me before the door. For if you go on to trouble me, you ſhall preſently be haled in,
And be there ſcourged with whip-thongs to death.

sp.speaker: S
sp.l: A free-man with whip-thongs?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O wicked fellow! Do men ſay that here is like freedom to all men?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: If you have brawled enough, bawd, hear me now if you be diſpoſed.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: And I, have I brawled?
line 30 Or you againſt me?

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Let thoſe things paſs, & return to the point▪

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What thing?
Whither ſhould I return?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Would you have me now tell you what may concern you?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I deſire it, ſo it be any thing honeſt.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Whoo, the bawd woud not have me ſpeak diſhoneſt things.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I am a bawd, I confeſs, a common deſtruction of young-men, a perfidious fellow, a plague;
Yet I have done you no wrong.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: For that truly remaineth yet to be done.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: line 35 I pray you Aeſchinus, go back thither, where you begun.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: You bought her,
For twenty pounds, (which thing may it never thrive with thee) ſo much money ſhall be paid you.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What if I will not ſell her? will you force me?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: For I was afraid of that.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: For I think ſhe ſhould not be offered to be ſold who is a free-woman;
For I by laying on my hand reſtore her to her libertie up • n an action of freedome. Now chuſe you,
line 40 Whether you will take you your money, or try your iction. Conſiſider of this, bawd,
Till I return again.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O mighty Iupiter! I do not wonder at them that begin.
To run mad after they have done wrong. He hath pull'd me out of my houſe, he hath beaten me,
He hath taken away my woman, whether I will or no; for theſe ill turnes he requires
I ſhould deliver her for ſo much as I bought her. Oh, he hath given me poor man above 500
line 45 Boxes on the ear. And indeed, ſeeing he hath ſo well deſerved, let it be ſo: he deſireth but
What is his own by right. Well, now I deſire it were done, if ſo be he would but pay my money.
But I gueſs this, when I ſhall ſay I will give him her for ſo much, he will preſently take witneſs,
That I have ſold her; I do but dream of my money, by and by, come again tomorrow. I can
Endure that, if he will but pay it: though it be a wrongfull buſineſs; but I conſider,
line 50 As the matter is; when you begin that trade, you muſt take, and ſay nothing of the injurie
Of young men. But no body will give it me; in vain
Do I caſt up theſe accounts with my ſelf.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: OBſecro, populares, ferte miſero atque innocenti auxilium, Subvenite inopi.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Otioſè, illico jam nunc hic conſiſte.
Quid reſpectas? nihil perîcli eſt. Nunquam, dum ego
Adero, hic te tanget.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ego iſtam invitis omnibus.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: line 5 Quanquam eſt ſceleſtus, committet hodie nunquam ut iterum vap • let.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Aeſchine aud • , ne te ignarum fuiſſe dicas meorum morum,
Leno ego ſum.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: At ita, ut uſquam fuit fide quiſquam optuma.
Tu quod te poſterius purges, hanc injuriam mihi nolle

sp.l: line 10 Neque tu verbis ſolves unquam, quod mihi re malefeceris.
Novi ego veſtra haec, nolle factum; jusjurandum dabitur, te eſſe
Indignum injuria hac: indignis cùm ego met ſim acceptus modis.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Abi praeſtrenuè, ac ſores aperi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Caeterùm, hoc nihil facis.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I intrò jam nunc tu.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: At enim, non ſinam,

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Accede huc, Parmeno;
line 15 Nimium iſthuc abiiſti: hic propter hunc aſſiſte; hem, ſic volo.
Cave nunc jam oculos à meis quoquam dimoveas tuos, ne mora ſit, ſi
Innuero, quin pugnus continuò in malâ haereat.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Iſtuc volo
Ego ipſum experiri.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Hem ſerva, omitte mulierem.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O miſerum
Facinus!

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Geminabit, niſi caves.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hei miſeriam!

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Non innueram,
line 20 Verùm in iſtam partem potiùs peccato tamen: I nunc jam▪

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid hoc rei eſt?
Regnumne Aeſchine, hîc tu poſſides?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Si poſſiderem, ornatus eſſes
Ex tuis virtutibus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid tibi rei mecum eſt?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Nihil.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid?
Noſtin' quis ſim?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Non deſidero.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Tetigin' tui quicquam?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Si attigiſſes,
Ferres infortunium.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quî tibi magis licet meam habere, pro quâ ego
line 25 Argentum dedi? reſponde.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ante aedes non feciſſe erit
Melius hoc convitium. Nam ſi moleſtus perges eſſe, jam intrô abripiêre;

Atque ibi uſ
que ad necem operiêre loris.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Loris liber!

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Sic erit.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O hominem impurum! hiccine libertatem aiunt eſſe aequam omnibus?

sp.speaker: Aeſch
sp.l: Si ſatis debacchatus es, leno, audi, ſi vis, nunc jam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Egóne debacchatus
line 30 Sum autem? an tu in me?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l:
Mitte iſta, at
que ad rem redi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quam rem?
Quo redeam?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Jámne me vis dicere quod ad te attinet?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Cupio, modo aequi aliquid.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Vah, leno iniqua me non vult loqui.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Leno ſum, fateor, pernicies communis adoleſcentium, perjurus, peſtis:
Tamen tibi à me nulla eſt orta injuria.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Nam herele etiam id reſtat.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: line 35 Illuc, quaeſo, redi, quo cepiſti, Aeſchine.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Minis viginti tu illam
Emiſti (quae res tibi malè vertat) argenti, tantum dabitur.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid ſi ego tibi illam nolo vendere? cogéſne?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Mi • imé.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Namque id •• tui.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Neque venundandam ceuſeo, quae libera eſt:
Nam ego liberali illam aſſero cauſâ manu. Nunc vide utrum vis
Argentum accipere, an cauſam meditari tuam, Delibera hoc, dum ego
Redeo, leno.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Proh ſumme Jupiter! minime mirer, qui infanite
Oc • ipiunt ex injuriâ. Domo me eripuit, verberavit; me invito
Abduxit meam. Ob malefacta haec tantidem emptam poſtulat ſibi
Tradier. O, homini miſero plus quingentos colaphos
line 45 Infregit mihi: verùm enim, quando bene promeruit, fiat: ſuum
Jas poſtulat. Age, jam cupio, ſi modo argentum reddat. Sed ego
Hoc atiolor, ubi me dixero dare tanti, teſtes faciat illico
Vendidiſſe me. De argento ſomnium, mox, cras redi. Id quoque
Poſſum ferre, ſi modò reddat: quanquam injurium eſt; verùm cogito
Id quod res eſt, quando eum quaeſtum incepetis, accipienda &
Muſſitanda injuria adoleſcentium eſt. Sed nemo dabit; fruſtra
Ego mecum has rationes deputo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: HOld your peace, I my ſelf will go meet with him, I will make him new glad to take it.
And that he ſaid he is well dealt withall. What is that Sannio, that I hear you
Quarrelled with my maſter, I know not what about?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I never ſaw a quarrell
More unjuſtly carried, then this which was to day betwixt us. I with bearing blowes,
line 5 And he with laying on blowes, we are both quite wearie.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Through your own fault.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: What
Should I doe?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You ſhould have humoured the young-man.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: How could I do it
Better, who have continually ſuffered him to beat me?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Come on, do you know what I would ſay?
To ſet light by monie when occaſion ſerveth is ſometimes the greateſt gain. Whoo, you were afraid,
If you had now yielded from your right a little, and had conformed yo • r ſelf to the young-man,
line 10 You errant fool of all fools, that monie would not come in with uſe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I do not buy hope with readie monie.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You will never grow rich.
Go your way, you know not how to bring men to your lure, Syrus.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I believe that were
Better; but I was never ſo craftie; but rather whatever I could,
I had rather take it for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Go too, I know your minde,
line 15 As if you can have twentie pounds at any time, ſo you fulfill this man's humour.
And beſides they ſay that you are going to Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Tuſh.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And you have bought
Many things, which you are to carrie hence thither, and that a ſhip is hired: I know this,
You are in a doubt what to doe; I hope when you return thence, for all this you will minde this buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I will not ſt • r a foot any whither: I am undone; he hath begu • this upon this hope.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He is afraid

line 20
I have made the fellow he cannot tell what to doe. O roguery! mark this.
He hath come upon me in the very inſtant. I have bought many women, and other things
Which I am to tranſport hence into Cyprus: except I come thither to the mart, I ſhall loſe very much.
If I omit this now, I ſhall do up good in my ſuit, when I return thence, there is nothing to be had.
The ſuit is grown cold, now you come at laſt; why did you ſuffer it? where was you?
line 25 That it were better to loſe my money, then to tarrie here ſo long, or to proſecute
Then.

sp.speaker: Sy
sp.l: Have you now caſt up what you think will be coming to you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Is this a thing fitting for him to doe? that Aeſchinus ſhould offer to do this, to deſire
By force to take her from me?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He begins to quail. I have but this one thing to ſay.
Conſider it, if you like well; divide the whole, rather then come into danger,
line 30 Sannio whether you ſhall ſave or loſe all, He will make hard ſhift to get ten pounds
Somewhere or other.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Woe is me, now I poor man come to doubt of the principal.
He is aſhamed of nothing, he hath made all my teeth looſe, beſides all my head is ſoft
As a fuz-ball with his boxes, and would he defraud me too? I am going no whither hence.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Doe as you pleaſe; will you have any thing elſe? for I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Yes indeed; this
line 35 I pray you, Syrus, however theſe things have been done, yet rather then I will follow ſuites,
Let me have my own paid me, or at leaſt as much as ſhe coſt me. Syrus, I know you never
Made uſe of my friendſhip heretofore; you ſhall ſay I am both mindefull and thankfull.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I will do the beſt I can: but I ſee Cteſipho, he is glad for his ſweet-heart

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: What is it that I intreat you to do?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Stay a little while.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: TAce, egomet conveniam ipſum, ut cupidè accipiat jam f • xo.
Bene dicat ſecum actum. Quid iſtuc, Sannio, quod te audio
Neſcio quid concertâſſe cum hero?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nunquam vidi iniqu • ús
Certationem comparatam, quàm haec quae hodie inter nos fuit. Ego vapulando,
line 5 Ille verberando, uſque ambo defeſſi ſumus.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Tuâ culpâ.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Quid
Agerem?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Adoleſcenti morem geſtum oportuit.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Quî potui
Melius, qui hodie uſque os praebui?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Age, ſcis quid loquar?
Pecuniam in loco negligere, maximum interdum eſt lucrum. Hui, metuiſti,
Si nunc de tuo jure contuliſſes paululùm, atque adoleſcenti
line 10 Eſſes morigeratus, homo hominum ſtultiſſime, ne non tibi
Iſtuc foeneraret.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Ego ſpē pretio non emo.

sp.speaker: Sy
sp.l: Nunquā rē facies,
Abi, neſcis ineſcare homines, Sannio.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Credo iſtuc melius
Eſſe; verùm ego nunquā adeò aſtutus fui; quin quicquid poſſem,
Mallem auſerrem potiùs in praeſentia.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Age, novi tuum
line 15 Animum, quaſi tam uſque tibi ſint viginti minae, dum huic obſequare.
Praeterea autem te aiunt proficiſci Cyprum.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Coemiſſe
Hinc quae illuc veheres multa, navem conductam; hoc ſcio,
Animus tibi pendet; ubi illinc, ſpero, redieris, tamen hoc ages.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Nuſquam pedem; perii hercle, hac ille ſpe hoc incepit.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Timet.

line 20
Injeci ſcrupulum homini.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: O ſcelera! illuc vide in ipſo
Articulo oppreſſit, emptae mulieres complures, & item hinc alia,
Quae porto Cyprum; niſi eò ad mércatum venio, damnum maximum eſt.
Nunc ſi hoc omittam, actum agam ubi illine rediero; nihil eſt,
Refrixerit res, nunc demum venis: cur paſſus? ubi eras?
line 25 Ut ſit ſatius perdere, quàm aut hinc nunc manere tam diu, aut tum
Perſequi.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Jámne enumeraſti id quod ad te rediturum putas?

sp.speaker: Sa
sp.l: Hoccine illo dignum eſt? hoccine incipere Aeſchinnm, per oppreſſionem
Ut hanc mihi eripere poſtulet?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Labaſcit. Unum hoc habeo,
Vide ſi ſatis placet; dividuum face, potiùs quàm venias in periculum,
line 30 Sannio, ſervéſne an perdas • otum. Minus decem conradet
Alicunde.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Hei mihi, etiam de forte nunc verio in dubium miſer.
Pudet nihil, omnes dentes labefecit mihi: praeterea colaphis
Tuber eſt totum caput; etiam inſuper defraudet? nuſquam abeo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ut lubet; nunquid vis, quin abeam?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Imò hercle hoc
line 35 Quae o, Syre, ut ut haec ſunt facta, potiùs quàm lites ſequar,
Meum reddatur, ſaltem quanti empta eſt, Syre. Scio te non eſſe uſum
Antehac amicitiâ meâ; memorem me dices eſſe, & g • at ••• .

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Sedulò faciam: ſed Cteſiphonem video, laetus eſt de amicâ.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Quid, quod te oro?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Pauliſper mane.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: ONe would be glad to receive a courteſie from any man, when need is,
But indeed that courteſie onely brings delight, if he do it, to whom it belongs of right to do it.
O brother, brother, how ſhould I now commend you? I know very will I can never ſpeak
Any thing ſo high, but your deſert goeth beyond it: and therefore I think, I have this one
line 5 Eſpecial thing beyond all other men, that no man in the world hath a brother
That is more excellent in the chiefeſt feats.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: O Cteſipho.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: O Syrus, where is Aeſchinus?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Lo where he is there, he tarrieth for you
At home.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: What it ſhould be? By his means, Syrus,
I am now alive.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: O merry man!

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Who thought all his own concernments
line 10 Were to be neglected by him in regard of my good. The railing terms, the ſlander,
The being in Love, and the offence hath he taken upon himſelf.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He can do no more.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: But who is that? the door creeks.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Tarry, tarry, he himſelf cometh forth.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: ABs quivis homine, cùm eſt opus, beneficium accipere gaudeas.
Verùm enimverò id demum juvat, ſi quem aequum eſt facere, is bene facit.
O frater, frater, quid ego nunc te laudem? ſatis certè ſcio, nunquam ita magnificè
Quicquam dicam, id virtus quin ſuperet tua; itaque unam hanc rem
line 5 Me habere praeter alios praecipuam arbitror, fratrem hominum
Nemini eſſe primarum artium magis principem.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O Cteſipho. O Syre, Aeſchinus ubi eſt?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ellum, te expectat
Domi.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Quid ſit? illius operâ, Syre,
Nunc vivo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Feſtivum caput!

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Qui omnia ſibi pòſt putarit eſſe prae meo
line 10 Commodo. Maledicta, famam, meum amorem, & peccatum in ſe tranſtulit.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nihil ſuprà poteſt.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Sed quiſnam! fores crepuit.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Mane, Mane,
Ipſe exit foras.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: WHere is that rogue?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Doth he ſeek for me? Doth he bring out any thing! I am undone,
I ſee nothing.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: O he very well: I am ſeeking for you; what is done, Cteſipho?
All is cock-ſure, and therefore leave your ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: I indeed do eaſilie
Let it paſse, who have you to be my brother, Aeſchinus, O mine own brother!
line 5 Alas I am afraid to commend you any more to your face, leſt you ſhould think I do it
Rather to flatter you, then that I account it a kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Go to you fool,
As though we were not acquainted betwixt our ſelves, O Cteſipho; but this grieves me,
That we had known it almoſt too late, and that it was come to that paſſe, that if all men ſhould deſire,
They could not help you.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I was aſhamed

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Alas, that is folly,
line 10 Not baſefulneſs, for ſuch a little ſmall to be ready to out-run the country. It is unfit to be ſpoken.
I pray God forbid theſe things.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I have done amiſs.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: What ſaith Sannio to us
Now at laſt?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He is now tame.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I will go to the market, that I way
Diſpatch this fellow; do you go in to her, C •… pho.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Syrus, put him on.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Let us go.
For he is haſting into Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Not ſo faſt indeed: although I tarry alſo
line 15 Idle here.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: It will be paid you, do not fear.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: But ſpeak that he may pay me all.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He will pay you all; do but hold your tongue and follow this way.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I will follow.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Ho,
Ho Syrus.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Anon, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I pray you heartilie diſpatch that very diſhoneſt
Fellow, as ſoon as may be, leſt if he be more provoked,
This may ſome way come to my fathers ear, and then I ſhall be undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 20 This ſhall no be, have a good heart, and do you pleaſe your ſelf with her within,
And command that tables be ſpread for us, and other things be got readie. I will preſentlie,
As ſoon as the buſineſs is done, come home with ſome meat.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Do ſo, I pray thee, and ſeeing
It hath fallen out well, let us have a merry day of this.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: UBi ille ſacrilegus?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Men' quaerit? num quidnam effert! occidi;
Nihil video.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ehem, optumè, teipſum quaerito; quid ſit, Cteſipho?
In tuto eſt omnis res, omitte verò triſtitiam tuam.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Ego illam facilè verè
Omitto, qui quidem re habeam fratrem, Aeſchine, ô mi germane!
line 5 Ah vereor coràm in os te laudare amplius, ne id aſſentandi magis,
Quàm quod habeam gratum facere exiſtumes.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Agc, inepte;
Quaſi non noverimus nos inter nos, O Cteſipho; ſed hoc mihi dolet,
Nos penè ſerò ſciſſe, & in eum locum rediiſſe, ut ſi omnes cuperent tibi,
Nihil poſſent auxiliarier.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Pudebat.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ah, ſtultitia eſt iſtaec,
line 10 Non pudor, tam ob parvulam rem penè ex patriâ; turpe dictu.
Deos quaeſo, ut iſtaec prohibeant.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Peccavi.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Quid ait tandem
Nobis Sannio?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Jam mitis eſt.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ego ibo ad ſorum, ut hunc
Abſolvam; tu intrò ad eam Cteſipho:

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Syre, inſta.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Eamus.
Namque hic properat in Cyprum.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Ne tam quidem: quamvis etiam maneo
line 15 Otioſus hic.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Reddetur, ne time.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Ut & omne reddat.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Omne reddet, tace modò ac ſequere hac.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Sequar.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Heus,
Heus Syre.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Hem, quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Obſecro hercle, hominem iſtum
Impuriſſimum quàm primùm abſolvitote, ne, ſi magis irritatus Siet, aliquâ ad patrem hoc permanet, atque ego tunc perpetuò peririm.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.l: line 20 Non fiet, bono animo eſto; tu cum ill â te intus obiecta interius,

Et lectulos jube ſterni nobis, & parari caetera. Ego jam, tranſactâ r •
▪
Convertam me ad domum cum obſonio.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Ita quaeſo, quando.
Bene ſucceſſit, hilatem hunc ſumamus diem.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I Pray you nurſe, what ſhall be done now?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Do you ask, what ſhall be done?
Well trulie, I hope.

sp.speaker: S.
