sp.l: Now, Nurſe, her pangs begin of her firſt child bearing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Now you fear, as though you were never by at a womans labour, or never bare child your ſelf.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Woe is me poor woman, I have no body, we are all alone, and Geta is not here,
line 5 Nor have I any one to ſend to the Mid-wife, nor that may call Aeſchinus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Trulie he will be here by and by, for he never letteth one day paſs,
But he alwaies cometh.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He is the onelie remedie of my miſeries.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: As the caſe ſtandeth,
It could not be done better, then it is done, miſtris: ſeeing a fault
Is committed, which principallie pertains to him, ſuch a one as he is, of ſuch a ſtock,
line 10 Of ſuch a diſpoſition, born of ſuch a great houſe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It is indeed ſo as you ſay,
I pray God, we may have him ſafe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: OBſecro, mea nutrix, quid nunc fiet?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid fiet, rogas?
R • ctè aedipol, ſpero.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Modò dolores, mea tu, occipiunt primulúm.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Jam nunc times, quaſi nunquam adfueris, nunquam tute pepereris.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Miſeram me, nemin • m habeo, ſolae ſumus, Geta autem hîc non adeſt:
line 5 Nec quem ad obſtetricem mittam, nec qui accerſat Aeſchinum.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Pol is quidē jam hîc aderit; nam nunq • ā unum intermittit diē,
Quin ſemper veniat.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Solus mearum eſt miſeriarum remedium.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: E re natâ,
Meliùs fieri haud potuit, quàm factum eſt, hera; quando vitium
Oblatum eſt, quod ad illum attinet potiſſimum, talem, tali genere,
line 10 Tali animo, natum ex tanta familiâ.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ita pol eſt, ut dicis,
Salvus nobis, Deos quaeſo, ut ſiet.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Now the matter is, that if all men ſhould lay their heads together, and
Seek to remedie this evil, they could not afford any help,
Which evil hath befallen both me, and my miſtris, and my wiſtriſſes daughter. Woe is me, poor wretch, ſo many things on a ſudden
Beſet me round about, from which there is no getting out; violence, povertie,
line 5 Injuſtice, lonelineſs, infamie. Is this the faſhion of the World? O villanies!
O wicked kinde! O ungodlie fellow!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Wo is me poor woman,
What is the matter that I ſee Geta ſo fearful, and making ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Whom neither promiſe,
Ner oath, nor any pitty hath reſtrained, nor pulled back, nor
That her delivery was near, whom poor woman he had baſely defloured by force.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 10 I do not well underſtand what he ſaith.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I pray you, Softrata,
Let us go nearer him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: A wretch that I am, I am ſcarce well in my wits,
I am ſo inflamed with auger. There is nothing that I more deſire, then to meet with
That whole family, that I may utter this anger upon them all, whileſt this grief
Is freſh, I ſhould think I had puniſhed them enough, if I were but revenged of them.
line 15 Firſt I would quite kill that old man, that begat that villany:
And then Syrus the ſetter on; oh, what wayes I would be revenged on him!
I would hoiſe him up on high by the middle, and firſt I would ſet him with his heels upwards,
That he may ſprinkle the way with his brains; I would • ear out the eyes of the young fellow himſelf, afterwards I would break his neck.
I would ruſh upon the reſt, I would drive them before me, I would knock them, I would throw them under my feet. but do I forbear,
line 20 To aequaint my miſtris with this miſchief ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Let us call him back. Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: How now!
Whoſoever you are, let me alone.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It is I Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Where is ſhe?
I am ſeeking for you, I am looking for you, you came very fitly to meet me,
Miſtris.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What is the matter, why do you quake?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Woe is me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Why do you make ſo much haſte
My Geta? take breath.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Utterly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What meaneth that utterly?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: We are undone;
line 25 It is paſt recovery.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I pray you, what is it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What
Now, Geta?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Aeſchinus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What hath he done then?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He is eſtranged from our family.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Alas, I am undone; wherefore?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He hath begun to love another.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Woe is me poor woman.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Neither did he it cloſely: he himſelf took her away from the bawd openly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Is this certain enough?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It is certain, I ſaw it my ſelf with theſe eyes, Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 30 Woe is me poor woman! what can you now believe, or whom can you truſt? that our Aeſchinus,
The life of us all, in whom all our hope and wealth did conſiſt,
Who ſwore that he would never live one day without her, who ſaid
That he would lay the childe on his fathers lap, and ſo beſeech him
That he might marry her.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Miſtris, forbear weeping,
line 35 And rather conſult further what is requiſite about this matter, whether we ſhould put it up,
Or tell it to any body?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Whiſht, whiſht, man, are you well in your wits?
Do you think this is to be told anywhere?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Truly, I doe not like it,
Firſt now the matter it ſelf ſheweth that his minde is eſtranged from us.
Now if we tell this abroad, I know very well, he will deny it:
line 40 Your good name and your daughters life will come in danger; and beſides if be confeſs it
Never ſo much, it is not good to give her him to wife, ſeeing he is in love with another;
Wherefore it is neceſſarie to concea'e it by any means.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ah, I will in no wiſe do it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What do you do?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I will tell it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ah Soſtrata, conſider what you do.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: The matter cannot be in worſe caſe then now it is; firſt, ſhe hath no portion,
line 45 And beſides, that which was her ſecond dowrie, is laſt; ſhe cannot be given in marriage
For a maid; this onely remaineth, if he deny it, I have the ring with me for a witneſs,
Which he loſt. Laſtlie, ſeeing I am privie to my ſelf, that I am far from this fault,
And that there was neither hire nor any thing betwixt, unbeſeeming her or me, Geta,
I will try what can be done.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What is that? I come nearer that you may better tell me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Go you,
line 50 As faſt as you can, and tell his kinſman Hegio all this matter in order;
For he was an eſpecial friend to our Similus, and reſpected us very much.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: For indeed
No body elſe regardeth us.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Make haſte, my Canthara, run,
Fetch the mid-wife, that we may not ſtay of her, when need is.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: NUnc illud eſt; quòd ſi omnes omnia ſua conſilia conferant, atque
Huic malo ſalutem quaerant, auxilii nihil adferant,
Quod mihique, heraeque, filiaeque herili eſt: vae miſero mihi! tot res repentè
Circumvallant, unde emergi non poteſt; vis, egeſtas,
line 5 Injuſtitia, ſolitudo, infamia. Hoccine eſſe ſeculum? O ſcelera!
O genera ſacrilega! O hominem impium!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Me miſeram,
Quidnam eſt, quòd ſic video timidum & properantem Getam?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quem neque fides,
Neque juſjurandum, neque ulla miſericordia repreſſit, neque reflexit, neque
Quòd partus inſtabat propè; cui miſerae indignè vitium per vim obtulerat.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 10 Non intelligo ſatis, quaeloquitur.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Propiùs, obſecro,
Accedamus, Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ah, me miſerum! vix ſum compos animi,
Ita ardeo iracundiâ. Nihil eſt, quod malim, quàm totam illam familiam
Dari mihi obviam, ut iram hanc in eos evomam omnes, dum aegritudo eſt haec
Recens, ſatis mihi id habeam ſupplicii, dum illos ulciſcar modó.
line 15 Seni primùm animam extinguerem ipſi, qui illud perduxit ſcelus;
Tum autem Syrum impulſorem, vah, quibus illum ulciſcar modis!
Sublimem medium arriperem, & capite primùm in terra ſtatuerem,
Ut cerebro diſpergat viam: adoleſcenti ipſi eriperem oculos, poſt haec praecipitem darem:
Caeteros ruerem, agerem, raperem, tunderem, proſternerem; ſed ceſſo
line 20 Hoc malo heram impertiri properè.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Revocemus Geta,

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hem,
Quiſquis es, ſine me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ego ſum Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ubi ea eſt!
Teipſam quaerito, te expecto, oppidò opportunè te obtuliſti mihi
Obviam hera.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid eſt? quid trepidas?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Hei mihi!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid feſtinas, mi
Geta? animum recipe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Prorſus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc prorſus ergo eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Periimus.
line 25 Actum eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Obſecro te quid ſit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Jam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid
Jam, Geta?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Aeſchinus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid is ergo?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Alienus eſt ab noſtrâ familiâ.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hem, perii, quare?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Amare occoepit aliam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Vae miſerae mihi!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Neque id occultè fert: ab lenone ipſus etipuit palàm.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Satin' hoc certum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Certum: hiſce oculis egomet vidi, Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 30 Me miſeram! quid jam credas? aut cui credas? noſtrúmne Aeſchinum,
Noſtram vitam omnium, in quo noſtrae ſpes opeſque omnes ſitae erant,
Qui ſine hac jurabat ſe unum nunquam victurum diem, qui in ſui
Gremio poſiturum puerum dicebat patris, ita obſecraturum,
Ut liceret hanc ſibi uxorem ducere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hera, lachrymas mitte,
line 35 Ac potiùs quod ad hanc rem opus eſt, porrò conſule; patiamúrne,
An narremus cuipiam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Au, Au, mi homo, ſanu' • ' es?
An proferendum hoc tibi videtur eſſe uſquam?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Mihi quidem non placet.
Jam primum, illum alieno animo à nobis eſſe res ipſa indicat.
Nunc ſi hoc palàm proferemus, ille inficias ibit, ſat ſcio,
line 40 Tua fama & guatae vita in dubium veniet; tum ſi maxumè
Fateatur, cùm amat aliam, non eſt utile hanc illi dare; quapropter,
Quoque pacto celato eſt opus.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ah, minimè gentium; non faci • m.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quidagis?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Proferarr.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hem, mea Soſtrata, vide quam rem agas.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Pejore res loco non poteſt eſſe, quàm in quo nunc ſita eſt; primùm indotata eſt;
line 45 Tum praeterea, quae ſecunda ei dos erat, periit; pro virgine dari nuptum
Non poteſt; hoc reliquum eſt, ſi inficias ibit, teſtis mecum eſt annulus
Quem ipſe amiſerat; poſtremò, quando ego conſcia mihi ſum, à me culpam eſſe hanc procul,

Neque pretium, neque rem ullam interceſſiſſe, illâ aut me indignam, Geta,
Experiar.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc? accedo, ut meliùs dicas.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Tu quantum potes,
line 50 Abi, atque Hegioni cognato hujus rem enarrato omnem ordine;
Nam is noſtro Simulo fuit ſummus, & nos coluit maximé.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nam he • cle
Alius nemo reſpicit nos.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Propera tu, mea Canthara, curre,
Obſtetricem accerſe, ut, cùm opus ſit, ne in morâ nobis ſiet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I Am quite undone, I have heard that my ſon Cteſipho was with Aeſchinus
In the taking the wench away. This evil remains to make me miſerable, if he can alſo dra • him to lewdneſs,
Who is for any employment. Where ſhould I ſeek him?
I think he is drawn away into a ſtew ſomewhither, I am ſure that diſhoneſt fellow hath perſwaded him.
line 5 But loe, I ſee Syrus going; I ſhall know of him, where he is, and truly he
Is one of that crue? if he perceive that I am looking for him; the hang man
Will never tell me, I will not let him ſee that I deſire that.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: We have told the old-man erewhile all the matter in order how it is,
I never ſaw one more merry.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Iupiter, to ſee the folly of the man.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He commended
line 10 His ſon, he thanked me that had counſelled him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am ready to burſt aſunder.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He told the money forthwith: he gave us half a piece beſides towards the charges;
That was laid out indeed as we would have it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ho, you ſhould commit it to this fellow,
If you would have any thing well looked unto.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ho, Demea, I did not ſee you.
How goeth all?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How goeth all? I cannot ſufficien • lie wonder at your courſe of life.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 15 Truly it is fond, and that I may ſpeak in earneſt, abſurd, Dromo, dreſſe thoſe other
Fiſhes: let that great conger play in the water
A little while: it ſhall be garbaged when I come, I will not have it done before.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: That theſe
Lewde pranks ſhould be done!

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Trulie they do not like me, and I often cry out,
Stephanio, ſee that theſe ſalt-meats be well watered.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O ſtrange?
line 20 Whether hath he any pleaſure to do it, or doth he think it will be for his credit, if he ſhall undoe
My ſon? woe is mee poor man; me thinks I n • w ſee that day, when
He being in want ſhall run herehence ſomewhither to be a ſouldier;

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: O Demea,
That is wiſedom, not only to ſee what is preſent, but alſo
To foreſee thoſe things which are to come.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What? is that ſinging wench now at the houſe?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 25 Look where ſhe is within.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whoo, will he have her at home?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I think ſo, he is ſo mad.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: That theſe lewd pranks ſhould be done!

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: The fooliſh lenity of his father, and his naughtie
Gentleneſs.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Trulie I am aſhamed, and it irketh me that he is my brother.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: There is too much difference betwixt you,
Demea, and I do not ſay this becauſe you are here preſent, there is too too much.
You, how great ſoever you are, are all wiſedom; he is become otherwiſe,
line 30 A mere ſot: but would you ſuffer that ſon of yours to do theſe things?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Would I ſuffer him?
Or would not I have ſmelt it out full ſix months before he had attempted any thing?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Do you tell me of your vigilant care?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Let him now be as he is, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: As a father would have his ſon to be, ſo he is.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What have you ſeen him to day?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Your
Son? (I will ſet him packing hence into the countrey) I think he is doing ſomething in the countrey a good while ago.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 35 Are you ſure he is there?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Who my ſelf went a gate-ward with him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: It is very well.
I was afraid leſt he ſhould have been hankering here.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And very angrie too.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And why ſo?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He fell a chiding his brother at the market for this ſinging wench.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Say you ſo indeed?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Whoo, he lained nothing; for by chance as the money was paying,
The fellow came upon him at unawares, he began to cry out, Aeſchinus,
line 40 Is it fit for you to play theſe mad pranks? for you to commit theſe things unbecoming
Our pedigree?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O, I weep for joy.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Thou doeſt not loſe
This money, but thy life.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: God bleſſe him, I hope, he is like
His anceſtors.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Whoo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Syrus, he is full of theſe documents.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He had one at home, of whom he might learn.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: A great deal of pains is taken in it.
line 45 I omit nothing, I wont him to it; brieflie, I bid him to look into other mens lives
As into a looking glaſſe, and to take to himſelf example by others. Do this.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Well indeed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Avoid this.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Wiſelie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: This is for your commendation.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: There is the cream of the matter.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: This is for your diſcredit.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And furthermore.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Trulie I have no leiſure now
To hearken to you; I have gotten fiſh according to my deſire; I muſt have a care
line 50 They be not ſpoiled; for this is as heinous a deed for us, as for you, Demea,
Not to do thoſe things you ſpoke on erewhile; and, as far forth as I am able,
I inſtruct my fellow-ſervants after that ſame manner; this is ſalt, this is burnt,
This is not well waſhed; that is well, remember to do ſo again. I adviſe them diligentlie
All I can as far as my skill reacheth. Finallie, I bid them, Demea,
line 55 To look into the platters as into a looking glaſſe, and tell them what is needful
To be done. I think theſe are fond things which we do. But what ſhould one do?
As a man is, ſo you muſt humour him. Would you had any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I wiſh you have more wit

l.hi: Given you.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Are you going hence into the countrey?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Straightway.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: For what ſhould you do here?
line 60 Where if you give any good commands, no bodie doth obey you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But I am going hence,
Seing he for whoſe ſake I came hither, is gone into the countrey: I care for him
Onely, he pertaineth to me. Seeing my brother will have it ſo, let him look to
That other. But who is yond, that I ſee a good way off? Is not this Hegio,
One of our kindred? if my ſight fail me not, it is he verily. Ha, a man
line 65 That hath been a friend to us even from our childhood. Good God! verily we have great ſcarcitie
Of ſuch citizens now-a-daies; a down-right honeſt and faithfull man.
I know not of any harm that ever he did to the Common-wealth.
How glad am I when I ſee any remnants of this ſtock?
Ha, now I joy to live I will tarrie for the man here,
line 70 That I may ſalute him, and talk with him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: DIſperii, Cteſiphonem audivi filium unà affuiſſe in raptione
Cum Aeſchino. Id miſero reſtat mihi mali, ſi illum poteſt, qui • alicui
Rei eſt, etiam ad nequitiam eum adducere. Ubi ego illum quaetam?
Credo abductum in ganeum, aliquó; perſuaſit ille impurus ſat ſcio.
line 5 Sed eccum Syrum ire video; hinc ſcibo jam, ubi ſiet. Atque hercle hic
De grego illo eſt: ſi me ſenſerit cum quaeritare, nunquam dicet
Carnuſex; non oſtendam id me velle.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Omnem rem modò ſeni, quo pacto haberet, enarramus ordine,
Nihil vidi quicquam laetius.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Proh Jupiter, hominis ſtultitiam!

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Collaudavit
line 10 Filium; mihi, qui dediſſem conſilium, egit gratias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Diſrumpor.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Argentum adnumeravit illi • ó; dedit praeterea in ſumptum dimidium
Minae. Id diſtributum ſanè ex ſententiâ eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, huic mandes,
Si quid rectè curatum velis.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ehem, Demea, haud aſpexeram
Te; quid agitur?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid agatur? voſtram nequeo mirari ſatis rationem.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 15 Eſt hercle inepta, ne dicam dolo, atque abſurda. Piſces caeteros
Purga, Dromo: congrum iſtum maximum in aqua ſinito luder •
Pauliſper: ubi ego venero exoſſabitur; priùs nolo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Haeccine
Flagitia!

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Mihi quidem non placent, & clamo ſaepe;
Salſamenta haec, Stephanio, fac macerentur pulchrè.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dii veſtram fidem!
line 20 Utrum ſtudióne id ſibi habet, an laudi putat fore, ſi perdiderit
Guatum? vae miſero mihi! videre videor jam diem illum, cùm
Hinc egens profugiet aliquò militatum.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: O Demea,
Iſtuc ſapere eſt, non quod ante pedes modò eſt videre, ſed etiam illa
Quae futura ſunt, proſpicere.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid? iſtaec jam penes vos Pſaltria eſt?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 25 Ellam intus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eho, an domi eſt habiturus?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Credo, ut eſt dementia.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Haec • ine fieri flagitia?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Inepta lenitas patris, & facilitas
Prava.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fra • ris me quidem pudet, pigétque.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Nimium inter vos,
Demea, ac non quia ades praeſens dico hoc, pernimium;
Intereſt. Tu quantus, quantus, nihil niſi ſapientia es: ille fit aliter,
line 30 Somnium; ſineres verò illum tu tuum facerehaec?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sinerem illum?
Aut non ſex totis menſibus priùs olfeciſſem, quàm illc quicquam ceperit?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Vigilantiam tuam tu mihi narras?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sic ſiet modò, ut nunc, quaeſo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ut quiſque ſuum vult eſſe, ita eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid? eum vidiſtin' hodie.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Tuumne
Filium. (Abigam hinc rus,) jam dudum aliquid ruri agere arbitror.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 35 Satin'ſcis tibi eſſe?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid egomet produxi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Optumè eſt,
Metui, ne haereret hîc.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Atque iratum admodum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid autem?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Adortus eſt jurgio fratrem apud forum de pſaltriâ hâc.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ain'verò?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Vah, nihil reticuit; nam ut numerabatur forte argentum,
Intervenit homo de improviſo, coepit clamare, Aeſchine,
line 40 Haeccine flagitia facere te? haec te admittere indigna
Genere noſtro?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Oh, lacrymo gaudio.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nō tu hoc
Argentum perdis, ſed vitam tuam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Salvus ſit; ſpero, eſt ſimilis
Majorum ſuorum.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hui.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Syre, praeceptorum plenus eſt iſtorum
Ille.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Domi habuit, unde diſceret.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fit ſeduló.
line 45 Nihil praetermitto, conſuefacio: denique, inſpicere tanquam
In ſpeculum vitas omnium jubeo, atque ex aliis ſumere
Exemplum ſibi. Hoc facito.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Rectè ſané.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hoc fugito.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Callidé.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hoc laudi eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Iſtaec res eſt

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hoc vitio datur:

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Probiſſimé.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Porró autem.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non hercle otium eſt nunc mihi
line 50 Auſcultandi; piſces ex ſententia nactus ſum; hi mihi nè
Corrumpantur cautio eſt. Nam id nobis tam flagitium eſt, quàm illa
Demea, non facere vobis, quae modo dixti, &, quod queo,
Conſervis ad eundem iſtunc praecipio modum: hoc ſalſum eſt, hoc aduſtum eſt,
Hoc lautum eſt parùm: illud rectè, iterum memento. Seduló
line 55 Monco quae poſſum pro meâ ſententiâ. Poſtremó, tanquam in ſpeculum,
In patinas, Demea, inſpicere jubeo, & moneo quid ſacto
Uſus ſiet. Inepta haec eſſe nos quae facimus ſentio. Verùm, quid facias?
Ut homo eſt, ita morem geras. Numquid vis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mentem vobis meliorem
Dari.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: In rus hinc abis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Rectâ.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Num quid tu hîc agas?
line 60 Ubi ſi quid bene praecipias, nemo obtemperet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ego verò hinc
Abeo, quando is, quamobrem huc veneram, rus abiit; illum curo
Unum, ille ad me attinet. Quando ita vult frater, de iſtoc
Ipſe viderit. Sed quis illic eſt, procul quem video? Eſtne hic Hegio,
Tribūlis noſter? ſi ſatis cerno, is hercle eſt. Vah, homo
line 65 Amicus nobis jam inde à puero. Dii boni! nae iſtiuſmodi jam
Magna nobis civium penuria eſt; homo antiquâ virtute
Ac fide: Haud ſcio mali quid ortum ex hoc ſit publicé.
Quàm gaudeo, ubi hujus generis reliquias reſtare
Video? Vah, vivere etiam nunc lubet. Opperiar hominem
line 70 Hîc, ut ſalutem, & colloquar.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: OStrange: a baſe unworthy fact, Geta,
What is this thou telleſt me?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It is ſo as I ſay.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: That ſuch an un-gentlemanly prank
Should be committed by one of that familie? O Aeſchinus,
Truly you have not learned this of your father.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Surely
line 5 He hath heard of this ſinging-wench; that now grieveth him.
Being but a ſtranger; his father makes nothing of it: woe is me,
I wiſh he were ſomewhere here by, and might hear theſe things.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Vnleſſe they doe, what things its fit they ſhould doe, they ſhall not carry it away thus.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: All our hope doth relie upon you, Hegio.
line 10 We have you our only friend; you are our defender, you are our father;
That old-man when he died, bequeathed us to you,
If you forſake us we are undone.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: See you ſay not ſo;
Neither will I do it, neither do I think I can do it with anie ſhew of honeſtie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will go to him; I bid you moſt heartilie good morrow Hegio.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: line 15 Oh, you are the man I looked for; good morrow, Demea.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Your elder ſon Aeſchinus,
Whom you gave to your brother to be adopted, hath neither done the part
Of an honeſt man nor a gentleman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Did you know Simulus a friend of ours,
line 20 And one much like us?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: what elſe?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: He hath defloured
His daughter being a maid.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Tarrie Demea, you have not yet heard
That which is the worſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Is there anie thing more yet?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Yes indeed more: for this is in ſome way to be born withall,
For the night, love, wine, and youth perſwaded thereto;
line 25 It is but a man's frailtie: after he knew it was done, he came himſelf
Of his own accord to the maids mother, weeping, entreating, beſeeching,
Promiſing, and ſwearing, that he would marrie her and take her home to him.
It was unknown, it was kept ſilent, it was believed; the maid
Came to be great with child upon that deflourment: this is the tenth month.
line 30 This honeſt man, forſooth, hath provided us a ſinging—wench,
That he may live withall, and forſake her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you tell me theſe things for a certaintie?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: The maid's mother
Is readie to witneſſe it, the maid her ſelf, the matter it ſelf; This Geta
Beſides, as the condition of the ſervant is, no bad one,
line 35 Nor ſlothfull, finds them all things, he alone maintaineth
The whole familie: take him aſide, tie him neck and heels, enquire the matter out of him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nay indeed rack me, if it be not ſo done, Demea;
Laſtly he will not himſelf denie it, let me have him face to face.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I am aſhamed, neither do I know what to do, nor what to anſwer this man:

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 40 Ah me poor woman I am riven aſunder wich pains. Juno Lucina,
Help me, ſave me, I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: What now, I pray thee, is ſhe crying five loaves a pennie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Yes Hegio.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: She craveth your aid, Demea,
That ſhe may obtain that by good-will, which the law compelleth you to;
I pray God, that theſe things may firſt be done, as it becometh you:
line 45 But if your minde be otherwiſe bent▪ Demea, I will defend her
To the utmoſt of my power, and him that is deceaſed.
He was my kinſman: we were brought up together being little ones
Even ſince we were children, we have been alwaies together in the warres
And at home; we have endured a great deal of penurie together.
line 50 Wherefore I will ſtrive, I will do what I can, I will trie: laſtlie,
I will loſe my life rather then I will forſake them.
What anſwer do you give me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will talk with my brother, Hegio;
What advice he ſhall give me in this matter, that I will ſollow.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: But, Demea, ſee you conſider this with your ſelf,
line 55 As you live verie eaſie lives, as you are verie potent men,
Rich, fortunate, gallant,
So much the more it behooveth you to underſtand with an even minde
The things that are equal, if you will have your ſelves be accounted honeſt men.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Come back again: all things ſhall be done, which it is fitting ſhould be done.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: line 60 It becometh you to do it. Geta, lead me the way to Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Theſe things are not done but by conſent; I wiſh this might be onely
The laſt prank, but that too much libertie
Will certainly come to ſome great miſchef or other.
I will go, I will ſeek out my brother, that I may eaſe my ſtomach of theſe things upon him.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: PRoh Dii immortales! facinus indignum, Geta,
Quid narras?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sic eſt.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Ex illâ familiâ
Tam illiberale facinus eſſe ortum? O Aeſchine,
Pol haud paternum iſtuc dediſti.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Videlicet,
line 5 De pſalteriâ hâc audivit; id illi nunc dolet
Alieno: pater is nihili pen et; hei mihi,
Utinam hîc propè adeſſet alicubi, atque audiret haec.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Niſi facient, quae illos aequum eſt, haud ſic auferent.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: In te ſpes omnis, Hegio, nobis ſita eſt:
line 10 Te ſolum habemus; tu es patronus, tu es pater.
Ille tibi moriens nos commendavit ſ • nex,
Si deſeris tu, periimus.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Cave dixeris,
Neque faciam, neque me ſatis piè poſſe arbitror.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Adibo? jubeo ſalvere Hegionem plurimúm.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: line 15 O te quaerebam ipſum; Salve, Demea,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid autem?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Major filius tuus Aeſchinus
Quem fratri adoptandum dediſti, neque boni
Neque liberalis functus officium eſt viri.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Noſtrum amicum nôras Simulum,
line 20 Atque aequalem?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ni?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Filiam ejus virginem
Vitiavit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem!

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Mane, nondum audiſti, Demea,
Quod eſt graviſſimum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: An quidquam etiam amplius?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Verq amplius; nam hoc quidem ferendum aliquo modo eſt,
Perſuaſit nox, amor, vinum, adoleſcentia;
line 25 Humanum eſt; ubi ſit factum, ad matrem virginis
Venit ipſus ultrò, lachrymans, orans, obſecrans,
Fidem dans, jurans ſe illam ducturum domum.
Ignotum eſt, tacitum eſt, creditum eſt; virgo ex eo
Compreſſu gravida facta eſt; menſis hic decin us eſt.
line 30 Ille bonus vir nobis pſaltriam, ſi Diis placet,
Paravit, quicum vivat, illam & deſerat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Pro certon' tu iſtaec dicis?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Mater virginis
In medio eſt, ipſa virgo, res ipſ • ; hic Geta
Praeterea, ut captus eſt ſervulorum, non malus▪
line 35 Neque iners, alit illas, ſolus omnem familiam
Suſtentat; hunc abduce, vinci, quaere rem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Immò hercle extorque, niſi ita factum eſt, Demea,
Poſtremò nou negabit, coràm ipſum cedo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Pudet, neque quid agam, neque quid huic reſpondeam, ſcio.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 40 Miſcram me! differor doloribus, Iuno▪ Lucina,
Fer opem, ſerva me, obſecro.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Hem! numnam illa, quaeſo, parturit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Certè Hegio.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Illaec fidem noſtram implorat, Demea,
Quod vos jus cogit, id voluntate ut impetret;
Haec primùm ut fiant, deos quaeſo, ut vobis decet:
line 45 Sin aliter animus veſter eſt, ego, Demea.
Summâ vi defendam hanc, atque illum mortuum.
Cognatus mihi erat; unà à pueris pa • vuli
Sumus educti: unà ſemper militiae & domi
Fuimus; paupertatem una pertulimus gravem.
line 50 Quapropter nitar, faciam, experiar; denique
Animam relinquam potiùs quàm illas deſeram.
Quid mihi reſpondes?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fratrem conveniam, Hegio,
Is quod mihi de hac re dederit conſilium, id ſequar.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Sed, Demea, hoc tu facito tecum animo cogites,
line 55 Quàm vos facillimè agitis, quàm eſtis maximè
Potentes, dites, fortunati, nobiles,
Tam maximè vos aequo animo aequa noſcere
Oportet, ſi vos vultis perhiberi probos.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Redito; fient, quae fieri aequum eſt, omnia.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: line 60 Decet te facere. Geta, duc me ad Soſtratam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non, me indicente, haec fiunt; utinam hoc ſit modò
Defunctum, verùm nimia illa licentia
Profectò evadet in aliquod magnum malum.
Ibo, requiram fratrem, ut in eum haec evomam.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: SOſtrata, ſee you have a good heart, and ſee you clear up that Daughter of yours
As well as you can; I will go talk with Mitio, if he be at the market,
And tell him orderlie how the matter ſtandeth.
If it be, that he will do that which he ought to doe,
line 5 Let him do it: but if his reſolution be otherwiſe aboun this matter,
Let him give me an anſwer, that I may know as ſoon as may be what I ſhould do.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: BOno animo fac ſis, Soſtraia, & iſtam quàm potes
Fac conſolêres ego Mitionem ſi apud forum eſt,
Conveniam, atque ut res geſta eſt, narrabo ordine
Si eſt facturus ut ſiet officium ſuum,
Faciat; ſin aliter de hac • re eſt ejus ſententia,

Reſpondeat mihi, ut, quid agam, quamprimù •
▪ ſciam.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: DO you ſay my father is gone hence into the countrey?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Long agoe.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I pray thee tell me truly:

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He is at his farm-houſe. And I believe he is verie hard now at ſome work.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I wiſh indeed, ſo it may be with his ſafetie, that he may ſo weary himſelf,
As that he may not be able at all to riſe out of his bed for theſe three dayes together.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 5 I wiſh it may be ſo, and anie thing that he can do more commodious then that.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Ey! for
I earneſtly deſire to ſpend all this day in merriment, as I have begun; and I utterly diſlike
That countrie-farm for no reaſon ſo much, as becauſe it is neer-hand; but if it were
Further off, the night would overtake him there, before he could return hither
Again. Now when he ſhall not ſee me there, he will come running hither again by and by,
line 10 I am certain. He will ask me where I have been, becauſe I have not ſeen him to day
All the day long. What ſhould I ſay?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Is no excuſe come into your minde?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: No nothing at all.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: You are ſo much the worſe. Have you no client, friend, or gueſt?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I have; what then?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Tell him, you attended on theſe.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Which attendance was not given;
This cannot be done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It may.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: On the day time. But if I tarrie here all night,
line 15 What excuſe ſhall I make▪ Syrus?

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: Oh, how heartilie I could wiſh it were a cuſtome

sp.l: To attend our friends alſo by night. But do you reſt your ſelf ſecure,
I know his pulſe very well. When he is as hot as a roſte, I make him
As quiet as a lamb.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He delighteth to hear you commended,
I ſet you out as a little God to him, I tell him of all your good qualities.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Mine?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Yours: the man will weep like a childe for joy.
Oh but ſee yonder for you?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Here's the man we talk of.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Is my father here?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It is juſt he.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Syrus, what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Get you but in now,
I will look to it.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: If he ask you any thing concerning me, ſay you ſaw me no where. Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Can you commaud your ſelf to give over your prate?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: A In' patrem hinc abiiſſe rus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Jam dudum.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Dic ſodes,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Apud villam eſt. Nunc autem maximè operis aliquid facere
Credo.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Utinum quidem, quod cum ſalute ejus fiat, ita ſe defatigârit;
Velim, ut triduo hoc perpetuo è lecto prorſus nequeat ſurgere.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 5 Ita fiat, & iſtoc ſi quid potis eſt rectius.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Ita; nam hunc diem
•… ſerè cupio, ut cepi, perpetuum in laetitiâ degere; & illud rus
Nullá al â cauſâ tam malè odi, niſi quia prope eſt; quod ſi abeſſet
Longiùs, priùs nox oppreſſiſſet illic, quàm huc reverti poſſet
Iterum. Nunc ubi me illic non videbit, jam huc recurret,
line 10 Sat ſcio. Rogabit me ubi fuerim, quem ego hodie toto non
Vidi die, quid dicam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nihilne in mentem?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Nunquam quidquam:

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Tantò nequiores. Cliens, amicus, hoſpes nemo eſt vobis?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Sunt, quid poſtea?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Hiſce opera ut data ſit.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Quae non
Data ſit? non poteſt fieri.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Poteſt.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Interdiu; ſed ſi hîc
line 15 Pernocto, cauſae quid dicam, Syre?

sp.speaker: S.

l.hi: Vah, quàm vellem etiam

sp.l: Noctu amicis operam mos eſſet dari. Quin tu otioſus es, ego
Illius ſenſum pulchrè calleo. Cum fervet maximè, tam placidum
Quàm ovem reddo.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Quo modo?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Laudarier te audit
Lubenter, facio te apud illum Deum, virtutes narro:

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Meas?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l:
line 20 Tuas: homini cadunt lachrymae, quaſi puero pr ••
• audio.
Hem tibi autem?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Quidnam?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Lupus eſt in fabula.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Pater adeſt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ipſus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Syre, quid agimus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Fuge modò intró.
Ego videro.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Si quid rogabit, nuſquam tu me: audiſtin'?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Potin' es, ut deſinas?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: VErilie I am an unfortunate man; firſt I can finde my brother no where
In all the world. And beſides, as I was looking for him, ſaw a day tale man
Coming from my farm, he ſaith my ſon is not in the countrey; and I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Syrus,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Is he looking for me?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But be of good chear.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 What unfortunateneſs is this, with a miſchief? I cannot ſufficientlie judge,
But that I think I am born to this thing, to ſuffer miſeries.
I am the firſt that perceive our miſhaps, I am the firſt that know all things,
And I am the firſt that carrie the news of them; I am the onely man that am grieved at it, if any thing be done amiſs.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I cannot but laugh as this man, he ſaith he is the firſt that knoweth and he alone is ignorant of all things.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Now I am come again, and am going to ſee, if my brother by chance be returned.

sp.speaker: Ct.

l.hi: Syrus,

sp.l: I pray thee have a care that he ruſh not himſelf quite in hither.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What can you hold your peace?
I will have a care.

sp.speaker: Ct.

l.hi: Truly I will never to day adventure that thing with you:

sp.l: For I will pen up my ſelf with her in ſome cloſe room: that is the ſafeſt courſe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do it, yet I will ſet this man packing.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But loe where your roguiſh Syrus is?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: line 15 Trulie there is not any body can abide here, if things be carried thus.
Verilie I would faign know, how many maſters I have: what a miſery is this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is he yelping like a fox? what would he have? what ſay you you honeſt man? Is my brother at home?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What do you ſay honeſt man to me, with a miſchief? verilie I am an undone man.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What aileth you?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Do you ask? Cteſipho hath quite kild me poor man, and that ſinging wench
With buffeting.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha, what ſtory you tell?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Oh, do you ſee how he hath cut my lip?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He ſaith, ſhe was bought by perſwaſion.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Did not you ſay
You went agateward with him latelie into the countrey from hence?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: So I did, but he came afterwards
Like a mad-man, he made no ſpare of any thing. Should not he have been aſhamed to beate
line 25 An old man; whom I latelie carried in my arms, being but a little boy thus big.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I commend thee Cteſipho, thou doſt follow thy fathers ſteps; go thy way, I take thee to be a man.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do you commend him? he will hold his hands hereafter, if he be wiſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Valiantlie done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Very valiantlie, becauſe he hath overcome a poor woman, and me
A poor ſlave, that durſt not ſtrike again: Whoo, it was very valiantlie done.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 He could not have done better, he thought as I think, that you are the ring-leader in this matter.
But is my brother within?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He is not.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I muſe, where I may ſeek him.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I know where he is,
But I will not tell you to day.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will be ſure to beat out thy brains now.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But I know not the name
Of that man, but I know the place where he is.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tell me the place then.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 35 Do you know the porch by the ſhambles this way down the ſtreet?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why ſhould 1
But know it?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Go ſtraight along this ſtreet to the upper end; when you come there,
There is a down-hill towards the lower end; haſte your ſelf this way; afterwards there is
A chappel on this hand, there is a by-corner hard by.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What one?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: There where
There is alſo a great wilde fig-tree; do you know it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Go on this way.
line 40 Indeed that by-corner is no thorow-gate.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: True indeed, ah,
Indeed you will go a great deal nearer this way, & it is not ſo ill to hit.
Do you know this rich man Cratinus's houſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: You are gone paſt it,
Go on the left hand ſtraight along this ſtreet; when you come at Diana's temple,
line 45 Go on the right hand; before you come at the gate, at the very great poole,
There is a mil-houſe, and over againſt it there is a joyners ſhop; there he is.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What doth he there?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He hath put out ſome tables to be made with holm feer,
Whereon you may drink in the ſun-ſhine.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Very well indeed: but do I m • ke no more haſte to go to him?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Get you gone for ſooth; I will ſet you on work to day, as you deſerve, you old dotard.
line 50 Aeſchinus loytereth tediouſlie; the dinner is ſpoiled;
Cteſipho is in love up to the ears: I will now look to my ſelf.
For I will now go, and take everie thing that is the moſt tooth ſome,
And tippling off the pots by little and little, I will draw this day to an end.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: NAe ego homo ſum infaelix; primùm fratrem nuſquam invenio
Gentium. Praeterea autem dum illum quaero, à villâ mercenarium
Vidi; is filium negat eſſe ruri: nec quid agam ſcio.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Syre,

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Men' quaerit?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Verum.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Perii.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quin tu animo bono es.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Quid hoc, malùm, infelicitatis? nequeo ſatis diſcernere,
Niſi me credo huic eſſe natum rei, ferendis miſeriis.
Primus ſentio mala noſtra, primus reſciſco omnia,
Primus porrò obnuncio: aegré ſolus, ſi quid fit, fero.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Rideo hunc, primum ait ſe ſcire, is ſolus neſcit omnia.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Nunc redeo, ſi fortè frater redierit, viſo.

sp.speaker: Ct.

l.hi: Syre,

sp.l: Obſecro, vide ne ille huc prorſus ſe irruat.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Etiam taces?
Ego cavebo.

sp.speaker: Ct.
sp.l: Nunquam hercle ego hodie iſtuc committam tibi.
Nam me in cellam aliquam cum illâ concludam; id tutiſſimum eſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Age, tamen ego hunc amovebo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sed eccum ſceleratum Syrum!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 15 Non hercle hic quidem durare quiſquam, ſi ſic fit, poteſt.
Scire equidem volo, quot mihi ſint domini: quae eſt haec miſeria!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ille gannit? quid vult? quid ais bone vir? eſt frater domii?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid, malum, bone vir, mihi narras? equidem perii.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid tibi eſt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Rogitas? Cteſipho me pugnis miſerum, & iſtam pſaltriam
Uſque occidit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, quid narras?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hem, vides, ut diſcidit labrum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quamobr • m?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Me impulſore hanc emptam eſſe ait.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non tu eum
Rus hinc modò produxe aiebas?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Factum; verùm venit pòſt
Inſaniens, nihil pepercit; non puduiſſe verberare hominem
line 25 Senem; quem ego modò puerum tantillùm in manibus geſtavi meis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Laudo, Cteſipho, patriſſas; abi, virum te judico.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Laudáſne? ille continebit poſthac, ſi ſapiet, manus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fortiter.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Perquam, quia miſeram mulierem, & me ſervolum
Qui referire non audebam, vicit; hui, perfortiter.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Non potuit melius; idem quod ego ſenfit, te eſſe huic rei caput.
Sed eſtne frater intus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ubi illum quaeram, cogito.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Scio ubi ſit,
Verùm hodie nunquam monſtrabo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, quid ais?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Diminuetur tibi quidem jam cerebrum.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: At nomen neſcio
Illius hominis; ſed locum novi ubi ſit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dic ergo locum.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 35 Noſtin' porticum apud macellum hâc deorſum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ni
Noverim?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Praeterito hâc rectâ plateâ ſurſum; ubi eò veneris,

l.hi: Clivos deorſum verſus eſt, hâc te praecipitato; poſtea eſt ad hanc
Manum ſacellum, ibi angiportum propter eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quodnam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Illic ubi
Etiam caprificus magna eſt; noſtin'?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Novi.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hâ • pergito •

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 40 Id quidem angiportum non eſt pervium.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Verum hercle, vah,
Cenſen' hominem me eſſe? erravi; in porticum rurſum redi,
Sanè hâc multo propiùs ibis, & minor eſt erratio.
Scin' Cratini hujus ditis aedes?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ubi eas praeterieris,
Ad finiſtram hâc rectà plateâ: ubi ad Dianae veneris,
line 45 Ito ad dextram; priùs, quàm ad portum venias, apud ipſum lacum
Eſt piſtrilla, & ex adverſo fabrica, ibi eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ibi facit?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Lectulos in ſole ilignis pedibus faciundos dedit,
Ubi potetis vos.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Bene ſanè; ſed ceſſo ad eum pergere?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I ſanè, ego te exercebo hodie, ut dignus es, ſilicernium;
line 50 Aeſchinus odioſè ceſſat: prandium corrumpitur:
Cteſipho autem in amore eſt totus: ego jam proſpiciam mihi.

Nam jam adibo, at
que unumquod
que quod quidem erit belliſſimū,
Carpam, & cyathos ſorbillans paulatim, hunc producam diem

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I Finde nothing in this matter, Hegio, why I ſhould be ſo much c • mended,
I do but my duty, I amend what we have done a •• ſſe.
Vnleſſe you think me to be one of thoſe men, who think thus
That they have an injurie done them, if they have done one themſelves wilfullie, they themſelves complain,

line 5
And cry whore firſt, becauſe I have not done ſo, you give me thanks.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: Ah no, I never thought you to be otherwiſe then you are:
But, I pray you, Mitio, go with me to the maids mother,
And tell the woman your ſelf thoſe very ſame things which you told me;
That this ſuſpition is for his brother and the ſinging wench.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 10 If you think fitting ſo, or if it be needful to be done, let us go.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.l: You do well:
For you will both eaſe her heart, who waſteth away with grief
And miſerie, and you will diſcharge the dutie of an honeſt man as you are; but if you be minded otherwiſe,
I my ſelf will tell her, what you have told me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nay, I will go.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: You do well.
All people, with whom the world goeth not very well, are more ſupitious; I know not how,
line 15 They take all things the rather as affronts done to them;
They always think they are neglected for their infirmitie
Wherefore it is more pacifying for you to excuſe your ſelf to her face to face.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You ſay well, and trulie.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Follow me in then this way.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: EGo in hac re nihil reperio, quam ob rem lauder tantopere,
Hegio. Meum officium facio, quod peccatum à nobis eſt, corrigo.
Niſi ſi me in illo credidiſti eſſe homi • u • numero, qui ita putant
Sibi fieri injuriam, ultrò ſiquam fecêre, ipſi expoſtulant;

line 5
Et ultrò accuſant: id quia non eſt à me factum, agis gratias.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l:
Ah, minimè; nunquam te aliter at
que es, in animū induxi meū.
Sed quaeſo, ut unà mecum ad matrem virginis eas, Mitio.
Atque iſtaec eadem, quae mihi dixti, tute dicas mulieri:
Suſpicionē hanc propter fratrē ejus eſſe, & illam pſalteriam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 10 Si ita aequum cenſes, aut ſi ita opus eſt facto, eamus.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Bene facis:
Nam & illi animum jam revelabis, quae dolore ac miſeriâ
Tabeſcit, & tuo officio fueris functus; ſed ſi aliter putas,
Egomet narrabo quae mihi dixti.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Imò ego ibo.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Bene facis.
Omnes, quibus res ſunt minus ſecundae, magis ſunt, neſcio quomodo,
line 15 Suſpicioſi; ad contumeliam omnia accipiunt magis;
Propter ſuam impotentiam, ſe ſemper credunt negligi.
Quapropter te ipſum purgare ipſi coràm, placabilius eſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Et certè, & verū dicis.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Sequere me, ego hâc intro.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Maximé.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I Am vexed in my minde, that this ſo great a miſchief ſhould be objected to me on a ſuddoin,
That I cannot be certain what do with my ſelf, nor what courſe to take.
My limbs are enfeebled with fear, my minde is aſtoniſhed through affrightment,
No counſel at all can ſtand in my heart.
line 5 How ſhould I rid my ſelf out of theſe incūbrances? ſo great a ſuſpiti • n
Hath now light upon me, and that not without cauſe. Soſtrata thinketh.
That I bought this ſinging wench for my ſelf: the old woman diſcovered that to me;
For as ſhe by chance was ſent hence to the mid-wife, as ſoon as I ſaw her,
I went preſentlie to her, I ask her how Pamphila did, whether ſhe was near her labour,
line 10 Whether ſhe went to call the mid-wife thither; ſh • cryeth out, away, away, Aeſchinus,
You have now deceived us long enough; your promiſe hath hitherto
Sufficiently fruſtrated us: Alas, quoth I, what is the matter, I pray you?
You may fare well, you may have her that liketh you. I perceived preſently, that they ſuſpected that;
Yet nevertheleſſe I with-held my ſelf, leſt I ſhould utter anie thing concerning my brother to that blab,
line 15 And it come all abroad. Now what ſhould I doe? ſhould I ſay ſhe is my brother's? which it is no need
To be uttered. Well, I let it paſs, it may come to paſſe, that it may not come out anie way.
This is the verie thing I fear, leſt they believe it, there are ſo many likeliehoods concur.
I my ſelf took her away by force; I my ſelf paied the monie; ſhe is brought away
Home to me: moreover I confeſſe theſe things were done through my default, that I told not this thing
line 20 To my father how it was done. I ſhould have intreated him, that I might marrie her.
Hitherto I have been negligent; now Aeſchinus henceforth beſtir thy ſelf.
Now this is to be done firſt and foremoſt; I will go to them, to clear my ſelf, I will come to the door.
I am undone, I alwaies tremble everie bone of me, when I begin to knock at this door, poor man that I am.
Ho ho, it is I Aeſchinus, ſome of you open the door quickly.
line 25 One cometh forth, I know not who, I will ſtep aſide hither.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: DIſcrucior animi, hoccine de improviſo mali mihi objici tantum,
Ut neque quid de me faciam, neque quid agam, certum ſiet.
Membra metu debilia ſunt; animus timore obſtupuit,
Pectore conſiſtere nihil conſilii quidquam poteſt.
line 5 Quomodo ex hac me expediam turbâ? tanta nunc

Suſpicio deme incidit, ne
que ea immeritó Soſtrata credit
Mihi me pſalteriam hanc emiſſe; id anus mihi judicium fecit;
Nam ut hinc fortè ea ad obſtetricem erat miſſa, ubi vidi eam,
Illico accedo, rogito Pamphila quid agat, jam partus adſiet,
line 10 Eóne obſtetricem acce • ſat; illa exclama • , abi, abi, jam Aeſchine,
Satis diu dediſti verba nobis, ſatis adhuc tua nos
Fruſtrata eſt ſides; hem, quid iſtuc, obſecro, inquam, eſt?
Valeas, habeas illam quae placet. Senſi illico id illas ſuſpicari:
Sed me reprehendi tamen, ne quid de fratre garrulae illi faverem,
line 15 Ac fieret palam. Nunc quid faciam? dicam fratris eſſe hanc? quod minimè
Eſt opus efferri. Age, mitto, fieri potis eſt, uti ne quâ exeat.
Ipſum id metuo ne credant, tot concurrunt veriſimilia.
Egomet rapui; ipſe egomet ſolvi argentum; ad me abducta eſt
Domum: haec adeò meâ culpâ fateor fieri, non me hanc rem patri
line 20 Ut erat geſta indicâſſe; exoraſſem ut eam ducerem.

Ceſſatum uſ
que adhuc eſt; nunc por • ò, Aeſchine, expergiſcere.
Nunc hoc eſt primum; ad illas ibo, ut purgem me, accedam ad fores,
Perii, horreſco ſemper, ubi pulſare haſce occipio fores, miſer.
Heus, heus, Aeſchinus ego ſum, aperite aliquis actutum oſtium.
line 25 Prodit neſcio quis, concedam huc.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: SOſtrata, doe as you ſaid. I will go talk with Aeſchinus,
That he may know how theſe things are carried. But who knock't at the door?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Truly it is my father, I am undone.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Aeſchinus.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: What buſineſſe hath be here?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Did you knock at this door? he ſaith never a word. Why do I not play upon a little while?
line 5 It is beſt to do ſo: becauſe he would never believe me this.
Do you make me no anſwer?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Truly I did not knock at this door, that I know of.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Say you ſo? for I wondered what buſineſſe you had here.
He bluſheth; All is well.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: I pray you tell me, father,
What buſineſſe had you here?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I had no buſineſſe truly.
line 10 A friend of mine brought me erewhile from the market,
To be a dayes-man for him here.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I will tell you.
There are certain poor women dwell here,
I ſuppoſe, and I am ſure, you do not know them;
For it is not long ſince they flitted hither.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: What more then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 15 There is a maid with her mother.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Go on.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: This maid is fatherleſſe.
This friend of mine is the next a-kin to her,
The Lawes conſtrain him to marrie her.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Nothing; well, go on.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: He is come to carrie her away with him,
For he dwelleth at Miletum.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Ah, to have the maid away with him?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 20 Yes.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: As far as Miletum I pray you?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: I am ſick at the heart.
What ſay the women?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What do you think they ſay? for they can ſay nothing.
The mother feigned that there is a child born by another man,
I cannot tell who, for ſhe doth not name him:
And that he is the firſt, and therefore that ſhe ought not to be given to this man.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: line 25 Ho, whether did not thoſe things afterwards ſeem juſt to you?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: I beſeech you, no? father, ſhall he have her away hence?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why ſhould he not have her away?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: It is harſhly done of you,
And unmercifully; and if it be lawfull for me, father,
To ſpeak more plainly, ungentlemanly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 30 Why ſo.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Ask you me? what heart at length do you think
Will that poor man have, that kept her companie before,
(Who forlorn man, I know not well, whether he love her dearly now or no)
When being by he ſhall ſee her taken from him by force before his face,
As to be had away out of his ſight? O father, it is an unworthy action.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 35 What reaſon have you to ſay that? who betrothed her, who gave her?
To whom, when was ſhe married? who is the principal contriver of theſe matters?
Why hath he married another man's ſweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ought ſuch a great maid
To ſit at home, waiting till her kinſman ſhould come
From thence hither? theſe things, father,
line 40 It was fitting you ſhould have alledged, and defended that matter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You cox-comb, ſhould I plead againſt him,
For whom I came to be an advocate? But, Aeſchinus, what are theſe things
Concerning us? or what have we to do with them? let us go hence; what is the matter?
Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Father, I beſeech you, hear me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Aeſchinus,
line 45 I have heard all things, and know every thing: for I love you; wherefore what things you doe,
Are a greater care to me.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I wiſh you may love me as one that deſerveth, your love,
Whileſt you live, father, as it heartily grieveth me, that I ſhould have taken
This fault upon me, and I am aſhamed of my ſelf for your ſake.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I believe it indeed, for I know your good nature:
line 50 But I fear you are too negligently careleſs in your buſineſſe.
In what citie I pray you do you think you live?
You have defloured a maid, which it was not lawfull for you to touch.
Now that is a very great offence, yet of humane frailtie.
Others and good men have done ſo oftentimes. But ſince this thing fell out, tell me,
line 55 Have you looked about? or have you had any foreſight to your ſelf?
What might be done? what way it might be done? if you your ſelf were aſhamed to Iell me,
Which way ſhould I know? whilſt you are at a ſtand about theſe things the ten months are gone about:
You have betrayed your ſelf, and her poor woman, and your ſon, as far as was in your power.
What? did you think that God would do this for you whileſt you were aſleep?
line 60 And that he ſhould be brought home into your chamber without any pains of yours?
I would not have you be careleſſe of other things af • tr the ſame manner.
Have a good heart, you ſhall marrie her.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Have a good heart, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Father, I pray you, do you now befool me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I be fool you? wherefore?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: I know not, becauſe I ſo greatly covet this to be true, I am therefore the more afraid.
line 65 Go your way home, and pray to God, that you may goe fetch your wife: go your way.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: What? ſhall I now marrie a wife?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Iuſt now?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Iuſt now, as faſt as you can.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: I wiſh I were dead, father, if I do not now love you more then theſe eyes of mine own.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What? better then her?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: As well.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Very kindly.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: What? where is
That Mileſian?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: He is gone, he is daſht, he hath taken ſhip. But why do you linger?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: line 70 Father, go you rather, and pray to God, for I am ſure he will rather
Grant your requeſt, becauſe you are the virtuous man far away.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I will go in, that ſuch things as are needfull may be got readie; do you as I told you,
If you be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: What buſineſse is this? is this to be a father?
Or is this this to be a ſon? If he were my brother or fellow-companion, how could be
line 75 Humor me more? is not he worthie to be beloved? i • not he worthy
To be hugd in ones boſome? Therefore hath he laid on me a great care
By his kindneſſe towards me, leſt peradventure I ſhould do anything
Vnawares, which he would not have me to do. Now I know it, I will take heed. But do I make no haſte
To get in, leſt I be a cauſe of delay to my own marriage!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: ITa ut dixiſti, Soſtrata, facite: ego Aeſchinum conveniam,
Ut quo modo acta haec ſunt, ſciat. Sed quis oſtium hoc pulſavit?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Pater hercle eſt, perii:

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Aeſchine.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Quid huic h • c negotii?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Túne has pepuliſti fores? tacet. Cur non ludo hunc aliquantiſper?
line 5 Melius eſt, quandoquidem hoc mihi ipſe nunquā voluit credere.
Nihil me reſpondes?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Non equidem iſtas, quod ſciam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ita? nam mirabar, quid hic negotii eſſet tibi.
Erubuit, ſalva res eſt.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Dic ſodes, pater,
Tibi verò quid iſtic res eſt?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nihil mihi quidem.
line 10 Amicus me à foro abduxit modò
Huc advocatum ſibi.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ego dicam tibi,
Habitant hîc quaedam mulieres pauperculae,
Ut opinor, has non nôſſe re, & certè ſcio;
Neque enim diu huc commigrârunt.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Quid tum poſtea?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 15 Virgo eſt cum matre.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Perge.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Haec virgo orba eſt patre.
Hic meus amicus illi genere eſt proximus.
Huic Leges cogunt nubere hanc.

sp.speaker: Aeſc.
sp.l: Perii.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Nihil; recté, perge.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Is venit, ut ſecum avehat,
Nam habitat Mileti.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Hem, virginem ut ſecum avehat?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 20 Sic eſt

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Miletum uſque obſecro?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Animo malè eſt.
Quid ipſae aiunt?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid iſtas cenſes? nihil enim.
Commenta mater eſt eſſe ex alio viro,
Neſcio quo, puerum natum, neque eum nominat,
Priorem eſſe illum, non oportere huic dari.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: line 25 Eho, nonne haec juſta tibi videntur poſtea?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Obſecro, non? an illam hinc abducet pater?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quidni illam abducat?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Factum a vobis duriter,
Immiſericorditérque; atque etiam ſi eſt, pater,
Dicendum magis apertè, illiberaliter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 30 Quamobrem?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Rogas me? quid illi tandem creditis
Fore animi miſero, qui cum illâ conſuevit priús,
(Qui infelix, haud ſcio, an illam miſerè nunc amat,)
Cùm hanc ſibi videbit praeſens praeſenti eripi,
Abduci ab oculis? facinus indignum pater.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 35 Quâ ratione iſtuc? quis deſpondit? quis dedit?
Cui, quando nupſit? autor his rebus quis eſt?
Cur duxit alienam?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: An ſedere oportuit
Domi virginem tam grandem, dum cognatus huc
Illinc veniret exſpectantem? haec, mi pater,
line 40 Te dicere aequum fuit, & id defendere?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ridiculum, advorſúmne illum cauſam dicerem,
Cui veneram advocatus? Sed quid iſta, Aeſchine,
Noſtrâ? aut quid nobis cum illis? abeamus: quid eſt?
Quid lachrymas?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Pater, obſecro, auſculta.

sp.speaker: M.

l.hi: Aeſchine,

sp.l: line 45 Audivi omnia, & ſcio: nam te amor quo magis
Quae agis curae ſunt mihi.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Ita velim me promerentem ames,
Dum vivas, mi pater, ut me hoc delictum admiſiſſe
In me id mihi vehementer dolet; & me tui pudet.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Credo hercle, nam ingenium novi tuum
line 50 Liberale; ſed vereor ne indiligens nimium ſies.
In qua civitate tandem te arbitrare vivere?
Virginem vitiaſti, quam te jus non fuerat tangere.
Jam id peccatum primū magnum, at humanū tamen.
Fecere item alii ſaepe boni. At poſtquam id evenit, cedò,
line 55 Nunquid circumſpexiſti? aut nunquid tute proſpexti tibi?
Quid fieret, quâ fieret? Si te ipſum mihi puduit dicere,
Quâ reſciſcerem? haec dum dubitas, menſes abiê • e decem:
Prodidiſti te, & illam miſeram, & natum, quod quidem in te fuit.
Quid? credebas dormienti haec tibi confecturos Deos?
line 60 Et illam ſine tuâ operâ in cubiculum iri deductum domum?
Nolo c •• erarum rerum te ſocordem eodem modo.
Bono animo es, duces urorem hanc.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Bono animo es, inquam.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Pater, obſecro, num ludis tu nunc me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ego te? quamobrem?

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Neſcio, quia tam miſerè hoc eſſe cupio verum, ideo vereor magis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 65 Abi domum, ac Deos comprecare, uxorem accerſas; abi.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Quid? jámne uxorem ducam?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Jam.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Jam?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Jam quantum poteſt.

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Dii me, pater, omnes oderint, ni magis te, quàm oculos nunc ego amo meos.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid? quàm illam?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Aequé.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Perbenign • .

sp.speaker: Aeſch.
sp.l: Quid? ille ubi eſt

l.hi: Mileſius?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Abiit, periit, navem aſcendit; ſed cur ceſſas?

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: line 70 Abi, pater, tu potiùs Deos comprecare, nam tibi eos certò ſcio
Quo vir melior multò es, quam ego, obtemperaturos magis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ego eo intrò, ut quae opus ſunt, parentùt; tu fac ut dixi,
Si ſapis.

sp.speaker: Aeſ.
sp.l: Quid hoc negotii? hoc eſt patrem eſſe?
Authoc eſt filium eſſe? ſi frater aut ſodalis eſſet, qui magis
line 75 Morem gereret? hic non amandus? hiccine non
Geſtandus in ſinu eſt? Hem! itaque adeò magnam mihi
Injecit ſuâ commoditate curam, ne fortè imprudens
Faciam, quod nolit; ſciens cavebo. Sed ceſſo ire
Intrò, ne mora meis nuptiis egomet ſiem!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I Am wearie with walking up and down; I wiſh great Jupiter would bring on thee
Some miſchief with that thy ſhewing me the way, Syrus.
I have gone creeping quite over all the town, to the gate, to the pool,
Whither not? neither was there anie carpenter's ſhop there, nor did a • i • man ſay
line 5 That he ſaw my brother. Now I am reſolved to ſit waiting
At his houſe till he come home again.

sp.speaker: D
sp.l: Efeſſus ſum ambulando: ut, Syre, te cum tuâ
Monſtratione magnus perdat Iupiter.
Perreptavi uſque omne oppidum, ad portum, ad lacum,
Quò non? nec fabrica illic ulla erat, nec fratrem homo
line 5 Vidiſſe ſe aiebat quiſquam. Nunc verò domi
Certum obſidere ſe uſque donec redierit.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I will go and tell them, there is no delay in us.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But lo where he is; I have been looking for you a great while, Mitio.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I bring you other great lewd pranks
Of that honeſt young-man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But loe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: New pranks,
line 5 Worthie of death.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Enough, now.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Alas, you know not what a man he is.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I do know.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ah you fool, you dream that I ſpeak of the ſinging-wench:
This offence is done againſt a maid that is a citizen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ho, do you know it, and ſuffer it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: VVhat ſhould I do but ſuffer it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tell me.
Do not you crie out? are you not out of your wits?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: No, I had rather you were.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 There is a child born.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: God bleſſe him and ſend him good luck.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: The maid hath nothing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I heard as much.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And muſt he marry one without a portion?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ye.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: VVhat will now become of it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: That forſooth which the matter affordeth.
The maid ſhall be brought over from thence hither.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Iupiter!
Muſt it be done on that faſhion?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: VVhat ſhould I do elſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Ask you what you ſhould do? if that do not grieve you in ve •… deed,
Certainly it is a wiſe man's part to make as though it did.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But I have alreadie
Betrothed the maid to him, the matter is concluded, the marriage is to be made.
I have taken away all fear; theſe things are rather belonging to a man.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But,
Doth this doing pleaſe you, Mitio?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: No; if I could tell how
line 20 To alter it; now that I cannot, I take it patiently.
Man's life is ſo, as when you play at tables,
If that fall not, which is moſt needfull to be caſt,
You muſt amend that by skill, which fell out by chance.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You an amender! for ſooth twentie pounds are loſt by your skill
line 25 For this ſinging-wench; who is to be packt away ſomewhither,
As ſoon as may be, if not for a piece of money, yet for nothing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Neither is ſhe to be ſold, nor indeed doth he deſire to ſell her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What will you do then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: She ſhall be at my houſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O ſtrange!
A whore, and a good-wife of the houſe under one roof?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 30 Why not?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you think you are well in your wits?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Truly I think ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I ſwear, as far as I underſtand your follie,
I think you will do this, that you may have one to ſing with you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Why not?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And the new married woman ſhall learn theſe ſame things?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And you ſhall dance among them leading the ring.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Verie well.
line 35 And if need be, you ſhall dance with us' too.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Woe is me.
Are you not aſhamed of theſe things?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But now, Demea, forbear
That peeviſhneſſe of yours, and make your ſelf blithe and buxome at your ſon's marriage.
I will go talk with theſe, and come hither again afterwards.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Jupiter!
Is this a life fit to be led? are theſe manners to be uſed? is this madneſſe to be ſhewn?
line 40 A wife ſhall come without a portion; a ſinging-wench is withindoor;
A coſtly houſe is to be maintained; a young-man is undone by riot;
An old man is turned dotard. Salus her ſelf if ſhe ſhould deſire it,
Cannot at all be able to preſerve this familie from ruine.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: IBo, illis dicam, nullam eſſe in nobis moram.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sed eccum ipſum; te jam dudum quaero, Mitio.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quidnam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fero alia flagitia ad te ingentia
Boni illius adoleſcentis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ecce autem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nova,
line 5 Capitalia.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Ohe, jam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ah, neſcis qui vir ſier.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ah ſtulte, tu de pſaltriâ me ſomnias
Agerè: hoc peccatum in virginem eſt civem.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eho, ſcis & patere?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid ni patiar?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dic mihi,
Non clamas? non infanis?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Non, malim quidem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Puer natus eſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Dii bene vertant.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Virgo nihil habet.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Audivi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Et ducenda indotata eſt?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: S ilicet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid nunc futurum eſt?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Id enim quod res ipſa fert.
Illinc huc transferetur virgo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Iupiter!
Iſtoccine pacto oportet?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quid faciam amplius?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Quid facias rogitas? ſi non ipſâ re tibi iſtuc dolet,

l.hi: Simulare certè eſt hominis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Quin jam virginem
Deſpondi, res compoſita eſt, fiunt nuptiae.
Dempſi metum omnem; haec magis ſunt hominis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Caeterum,
Placet tibi factum, Mitio?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Non; ſi queam
line 20 Mutare; nunc cùm non queo, aequo animo fero.
Ita vita eſt hominum, quafi cùm ludas teſſeris,
Si illud, quod maximè opus eſt jactu, non cadit,
Illud quod cecidit fortè, id arte ut corrigas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Corrector! nempe tuâ arte viginti minae
line 25 Pro pſaltriâ periêre: quae quantum poteſt
Aliquò abjicienda eſt, ſi non pretio, gratis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Neque eſt, neque illam ſa •• è ſtudet vendere.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid igitur facies?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Domi erit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Proh Deû n fidem!
Meretrix, & mater familias unâ in domo?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 30 Cur non?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sanum te credis eſſe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Equidem arbitror.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ita me Dii ament, ut video tuam ego ineptiam,
Facturum credo, ut habeas, quîcum cantites.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Cur non?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Et nova nupta eadem haec diſcet?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Scilicet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tu inter eas reſtim ductans ſaltabis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Probé.
line 35 Et tu nobiſcum unà, ſi opus ſit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hei mihi.
Non te haec pudent?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Jam verò omitte, Demea,
Tuam iſtanc iracundiam: atque ira, uti decet;
Hilarem ac lubentem fac te in nati nuptiis.
Ego hos conveniam, pòſt huc redeo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Iuppiter!
line 40 Hanccine vitam? hoſcine mores? hanc dementiam?
Uxor ſine dote veniet: intus pſaltria eſt:
Domus ſumptuoſa: adoleſcens luxu praeditus:
Senex delirans. Ipſa, ſi cupiat, Salus,
Servare prorſus non poteſt hanc familiam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: TRuly, little Syrus, you have lookt to your ſelf nicely,
And performed your office daintily.
Go thy way, but after I am ſtuff • full of all things within,
It is my pleaſure to walk out abroad hither.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: See and obſerve
line 5 That example of the good order they keep.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But behold here is
Our old maſter. What is done? why are you ſad?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Oh you rogue!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: So, good-man wiſe-aker, are you now waſting your words here?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: If you were my ſervant.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Trulie, Demea, you would have been a rich-man,
And you would have bettered your eſtate.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I would have made thee to be
line 10 An example to all others.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Why ſo? what have I done?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Doſt tho • ask?
In the verie buſtle, and in a verie great offence,
Which is ſcarcely ended well enough, you have been tipling, you rogue,
As it were in matter well done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Truly I wiſh I had not come forth.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: AEDipol, Syriſce, te curaſti molliter,
Lautéque munus adminiſtrâſti tuum.
Abi, ſed poſtquam intus ſum omnium rerum ſatur,
Prodeambulare huc libitum eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Illud ſis vide
line 5 Exemplum diſciplinae.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ecce autem hic adeſt
Senex noſter. Quid ſit? quid tu es triſtis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Oh ſcelus!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ohe, jam tu verba fundis hîc ſapientia?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tu ſi meus eſſes.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Dis quidem eſſes, Demea,
Ac tuam rem conſtabiliſſes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Exemplum omnibus
line 10 Curarem ut eſſes.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Quamobrem? quid feci?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Rogas?
In ipſâ turbâ atque in peccato maxumo,
Quod vix ſedatum ſatis eſt, potaſti, ſcelus,
Quaſi re bene geſtâ.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sanè, nollem nunc exitum.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.l: HO Syrus, Cteſipho intreats you to come back again.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Go your way.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why doth this fellow mention Cteſipho?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ho, you hang-man,
Is Cteſipho within?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He is not.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why doth this fellow name him?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: There is another certain little paraſite.
〈◊〉 . Do you know him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will know by and by.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What do you? whither go you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do not, I ſay.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Will you not hold off your hands, you whipt rogue?
Or had you rather have your brains daſht out?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: He is gone.
Truly I think him no fit fellow-reveller,
Eſpecially for Cteſipho. What ſhould I do now?
line 10 But whileſt theſe buſtles are over, I will go ſomewhither
Into a corner, and ſleep out this wine. I will do ſo.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: HEus Syre, rogat te Cteſipho, ut redeas.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Abi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid Cteſiphonem hic narrat?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nihil.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eho carnifex,
Eſt Cteſipho intus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Non eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cur hic nominat?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Eſt alius quidam paraſitaſter parvolus.
line 5 Noſtin'?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Jam ſcibo.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid agis? quò abis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mitte me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Noli, inquam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non manum abſtines, maſtigia?
An tibi mavis cerebrum diſpergi hîc?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Abiit.

l.hi: Aedipol commeſſatorem haud ſanè commodum,

sp.l: Praeſertim Cteſiphoni. Quid ego nunc agam?

l.label: line 10
l.hi: Niſi dum hae ſileſcunt turbae, interea in angulum
Aliquò abeam, atque edormiſcam hoc vini. Sic agam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: WE have made things readie, ſo as you ſaid, Soſtrata,
When you pleaſe. Who is that that knockt ſo hard at my door?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Woe is me, what ſhould I do? what ſhould I cry out on, or complain?
O heaven! O earth! O Neptune's ſeas!

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: See thee yonder:
〈◊〉 . He hath known all the matter; he now cryeth out on it, without doubt.
He is diſpoſed to brabble, I muſt help.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Lohere he is,
The common undoer of his children.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: At the length repreſſe your anger, and come again to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I have repreſsed it, I am come again to my ſelf, I forbear all illlanguage.
line 10 Let us conſider of the matter: this was a bargain betwixt us,
Moreover it was of your own making, that you ſhould not look after my ſon,
Nor I after your's; anſwer me this.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: It was ſo, I do not deny it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why is he tipling at your houſe? why do you entertain my ſon?
Why do you buy him a ſweetheart, Mitio? is it not fit that I ſhould have
line 15 The ſame right to meddle with you, that you have to meddle with me?
Seeing I do not look to your ſon, do not you look to mine.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You do not ſay right.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: For indeed this is an old-ſaying,
That all things are common amongſt friends.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Wittily ſaid, this proverb is but now ſprung up at laſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: line 20 Hearken a word or two, except it be troubleſome, Demea;
Firſt and formoſt if this vex you, what charges your ſons
Are at, I pray you conſider with your ſelf theſe things:
You brought up them two according to your eſtate;
Becauſe you thought your means would be ſufficient for them both:
And then you believed forſooth that I would marrie:
Keep on that ſame old wont;
Save, ſeek, ſpare, ſee you leave them as much
As poſsiblie may be, do you get that credit to your ſelf,
Let them make uſe of my means, which have happened beyond your hope.
line 30 The main ſtock ſhall not be leſſened; what ſhall be added hence ever and above,
Account that for a vantage; if you would, Demea
Rightlie conſider all theſe things in your minde,
You would rid both me and your ſelf, and them alſo of trouble.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I forbear the eſtate, I ſpeak of their haunt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Tarrie;
