From his endeavours, and make the man to ſit idle,
He goeth about by ill-words to affright him, that he may not write.
Who often ſaith thus; that the Comedies which he made heretofore
Becauſe he nowhere writ that a diſtracted young-man
Saw the hinde in chace, and the dogs to be in purſuit;
And that ſhe made moan, and intreated ſome bodie to help her.
But if he underſtood, that when that Comedie being now long ago pleaſed,
line 10 It rather pleaſed by the actor's means, then his own,
He would be far leſs bold to cenſure, then he is now to cenſure,
And what comedies he made would pleaſe better.
Now if there be anie one, who ſaith or thinketh thus,
If the old Poet had not provoked him firſt,
line 15 The new one could not have invented anie Prologue
To ſay, unleſſe he had ſome bodie to rail on:
Let him take this for an anſwer to him; that the prize
Is publickly propounded to all that profeſſe Poetrie.
He ſtrove to drive this man from his ſtudie to ſtarve;
line 20 This man was willing to anſwer him, not to provoke him.
If he had ſtriven in better words, he had had good words:
Let him conſider, that what he brought is paid him again.
I will now make an end of ſpeaking of him,
Seeing he makes no end of offending concerning himſelf.
line 25 Now I pray you conſider what I deſire: I bring you
A new Comedie, which the Greeks call Epidicazomenos,
And the Latines name Phormio:
Becauſe that he ſhall act the chiefeſt parts, will be Phormio
The Paraſite, by whom the matter will eſpecially be carried on.
line 30 If you bear anie good will towards our Poet,
Do your endeavour, attend patientlie in ſilence;
That we may not have ſuch fortune as we had
When our companie was driven from their ſtanding by a tumult,
Which ſtanding our actors excellencie, and your goodneſs
line 35 And favour aſsiſting hath reſtored unto us.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: POſtquam Poeta vetus Poetam non poteſt
Retrahere à ſtudio, & tradere hominem in otiū,
Maledictis deterrere, ne ſcribat, parat:
Qui ita dictitat; quas antehac fecit fabulas,
line 5 Tenui eſſe oratione, & ſcripturâ levi;
Quia nuſquam inſanum ſcripſit adoleſcentulum
Cervam videre fugere, & ſectari canes;
Et eam plorare, orare ut ſubveniat ſibi.
Quod ſi intelligeret, cùm ſtetit olim nova,
line 10 Actoris operâ magis ſtetiſſe quàm ſuâ,
Minus multò audacter, quàm nunc laedit, laederet,
Et magis placerent quas feciſſet fabulas.
Nunc ſi quis eſt qui hoc dicat, aut ſic cogitat,
Vetus ſi poeta non laceſſiſſet prior,
line 15 Nullum invenire Prologum potuiſſet novus,
Quem diceret, niſi haberet cui malediceret:
Is ſibi reſponſum hoc habeat; in medio omnibus
Palmam eſſe poſitam, qui a • tem tractant muſicam.
Ille ad famem hunc ab ſtudio ſtuduit rejicere;
line 20 Hic reſpondere voluit, non laceſſere.
Benedictis ſi certâſſet, audiſſet bene:
Quod ab ipſo allatum eſt, ſibi eſſe id relatum pute • .
De illo jam finem faciam dicundi mihi,
Peccandi cùm ipſe de ſe finem non facit.
line 25 Nunc quid velim, animū advortite: adporto novā
Epidicazomenon quam vocant Comoediam
Graeci; Latini Phormionem nominant;
Quia primas partes qui aget, is erit Phormio
Paraſitus, per quem res geretur maximé.
line 30 Voluntas veſtra ſi ad Poetam acceſſerit,
Date operam, adeſte aequo animo per ſilentium;
Ne ſimili utamur fortunâ atque uſi ſumus,
Cùm per tumultum noſter grex motus à loco eſt;
Quem actoris virtus nobis reſtituit lo • um,
line 35 Bonitásque veſtra adjutans atque aequanimitas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: MY ſpecial friend and countrie-man Geta
Came to me yeſterday; there remained to him
A verie little monie of a ſmall reckoning with me
A good while agoe, that I might get it up; I have got it up, I bring it him.
line 5 For I hear his maſter's ſon hath married
A wife; I believe this preſent is ſcraped together for him.
How ill it is ordered, that they who have leſſe,
Should alwaies add ſomething to them that are richer?
For that which he poor man ſpared with much adoe inchmoal
line 10 From his own allowance, pinching his own bellie,
She will ſnatch it all away, not conſidering
With what great pains it was gotten: and beſides Geta
Shall be charged with another preſent, when his miſtreſs is brought to bed,
And then with another, when the childe's birth-day ſhall be kept,
line 15 When they ſhall initiate him: the mother ſhall carrie all this away:
The childe ſhall be the cauſe of ſending. But do I not ſee Geta?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: AMicus ſummus meus & popularis Geta
Heri ad me venit; erat ei de ratiunculâ
Jampridem apud me reliquum pauxillulum
Nummorum; id ut conficerem, confeci; affero.
line 5 Nam herilem filium ejus duxiſſe audio
Uxorem, ei credo munus hoc conraditur.
Quàm iniquè comparatum eſt; hi qui minus habent,
Ut ſemper aliquid addant ditioribus!
Quod ille nunciatim vix de demenſo ſuo,
line 10 Suum defraudans genium comparſit miſer,
Id illa univerſum abripiet, haud exiſtumans
Quanto labore partum: porrò autem Geta
Ferietur alio munere, ubi hera pepererit,
Porrò alio autem, ubi erit puero natalis dies,
line 15 Ubi initiabunt: omne h •… ter aufert:
Puer cauſa erit mittundi. Sed videon' Getam?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: IF anie red-haired man ſhall ſeek me—

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: He is here at hand, ſay no more.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Oh?
But Davus I endeavoured to meet you:

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Take it, here;
It is pickt monie, there is the full ſumme, as much as I ought you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I like you, and give you thanks that you have not neglected.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.l: line 5 Eſpeciallie as the world goeth now; the matter is come to this,
If one reſtore a thing, he muſt have great thanks given him.
But why are you ſad?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What I? You wot in what fear,
And in how great peril we are.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You ſhall know,
So that you can keep it cloſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Go your way, you fool,
line 10 Are you afraid to credit him with words, whoſe truſt
You have ſeen in monie? wherein, what advantage is it for me
To deceive you?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nearken then.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will do ſo much for you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Davus, do you know Chremes our old man's elder brother?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What elſe?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What? do you know his ſon Phaedria?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 As well as I know you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It fell out that both the old men had a journie
At one time, he into Lemnus, and our maſter into Sicily,
To an old acquaintance; he allured the old man by letters
Promiſing him almoſt golden mountains.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: To him that had ſo much, and more then enough?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Say no more,
line 20 Such is his diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Oh, I ſhould have been a King.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Then both the old men departing hence left me
As it were a tutor to their ſons.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Geta, you undertook
A heavie charge.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I am uſed to this, I know.
I remember I was left, becauſe my God was diſpleaſed with me.
line 25 At the firſt I began to croſs them; what need manie words?
Whilſt I am faithfull to the old man, I have loſt the uſe of my armes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I conſidered thoſe things; for it is a follie
To hit ones heels againſt the Prick.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I began to do everie thing
For them, to humor them in what they would have.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You know how to make your market.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 30 Ours at the firſt did no harm. This Phaedria
Out of hand got a certain minſtrelleſs: he began to be deep in love with her;
She was ſervant to a moſt filthie hawd;
Neither had their fathers taken order, that they ſhould have anie thing to give.
There was nothing elſe for them to do, but to feed their eyes,
line 35 To follow her, to lead her to the ſchool, and fetch her back again.
We having little to do attended upon Phaedria.
In this ſchool where ſhe learned, over againſt the place
Was a kinde of barber's ſhop; here commonly we uſed
For the moſt part to tarrie for her, till ſhe came home thence;

line 40
In the mean time, as we ſate there, there came upon us
A young-man weeping, we wondered;
We ask • him what the matter was; Never did poverty, ſaith he,
Seem to me ſuch a miſerable and beavie burden;
I ſaw even now in this ſtreet a poor maid
line 45 Lamenting for her mother that was dead:
She was ſet over-againſt her; neither was there any body with her,
Neither one that wiſhed her well, nor acquaintance, nor kinſman,
Except a ſilly old woman, that might help the burial; I pitied her;
The maid her ſelf is very fair; what needeth many words?
line 50 He had moved us all. Then ſaith Antipho preſentlie,
Are you willing we ſhould go ſee her? I think it meet, ſaith another.
Let us go, bring us thither we pray you; we go, we come,
We ſee; the maid was fair, and that you may the rather ſay it,
She had nothing to help her beautie,
line 55 Her hair hung looſe, ſhe was bare-footed, ſhe her ſelf was undreſſed;
She was all tears, her clothes were foul, ſo that unleſſe there had been a force of grace
In her beautie, theſe things would have extinguiſhed it by force.
He that loved the ſinging-wench, ſaid onlie,
She is prettie enough. But our youngſter.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know already;
line 60 He began to fall in love with her.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Do you know with whom? minde what it may come to;
The day after he goes on ſtraight to the old-woman, he beſeecheth her;
That ſhe would grant him the libertie on her; but ſhe ſaid ſhe would not,
Neither did ſhe do what was fitting; that ſhe was a citizen of Athens,
A good women, born of good parents; If he would marry her,
He might do it by law, but if otherwiſe, ſhe ſaid nay.
line 65 Our young-man knew not what to do, be had both a minde
To marry her, and be was afraid of his father that was abſent.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Would his father, if he had returned, have given him leave?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What he? would he beſtow on him a maid that had no portion, and
line 70 One that was meanly born? he would never do it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What became of it at laſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What ſhould come of it? There is one Phormio a paraſite,
An audacious fellow, who, a miſchief take him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What did he?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He gave this advice which I will tell you.
There is a law, that the fatherleſſe & motherleſſe maids ſhould be married

line 75
To them that are next a-kin, and the ſame law enjoyneth the 〈◊〉 to marrie them.
I will ſay you are her kinſ-man, and will entertain an action againſt you;
I will feign that I am the maid's father's friend,
We will come before the judges; I will deviſe all theſe things,

Who was her father, who who was her mother, how ſhe is a-ki •
〈◊〉 you,
line 80 Which will be good and profitable for me.
When you ſhall gainſay none of theſe things, I ſhall overcome to be ſure.
Your father will be here, ſuits ſhall be commenced againſt me. What is that to me?
She ſhall be ours indeed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: A merrie bold-trick!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He perſwaded the man, it is done; we come, we are caſt;
line 85 He hath married her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: That which you hear.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Geta,
What will become of you?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Trulie I know not; this one thing I know,
What fortune ſhall afford, we will take patientlie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Content.
Oh that is the dutie of a man.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: All my hope is in my ſelf.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I commend you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I think I muſt go to ſome ſpoke •… n that may
line 90 Thus intercede for me; now let him go I pray you, but hereafter
If he ſhall do anie thing, I will not intreat for him; onely
Let him not add; when I am gon hence, even kill him quite out.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What doth that Vſher that loveth the minſtrelleſs?
What doth he?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thus, poorly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: He hath not much.
line 95 To give her perchance.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: No nothing, but mere hope.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Is his father returned, or no?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What?
How long do you look for the old-man?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I know not certainlie,
But I hear that a letter was brought us lately from him,
And that it was carried to the cuſtome-houſe men; I will goe fetch it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 100 Will you have anie thing elſe with me, Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: That you may do well.
Boy, he, doth no bodie come forth hither? Take it, give this to Dorcius.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: SI quis me quaeret rufus—

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Praeſtò eſt, define.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Oh!
At ego obviàm conabar tibi,

sp.speaker: Dave.
sp.l: D. Accipe, hem▪
Lectum eſt, conveniet numerus, quantum debui.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Amo te, & non neglexiſſe, gratiam habeo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Praeſertim, ut nunc ſunt mores; adeò nunc ſunt res,
Si quis quid reddit, magna habenda gratia eſt.
Sed quid tu es triſtis?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Egóne? ſcis quo in metu, &
Quanto in periculo nos ſumus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Scies,
Modò ut tacere poſſis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Abi ſis, inſciens,
line 10 Cujus tu fidem in pecuniâ proſpexe •…
Verere ei verba credere? ubi quid mihi lucri eſt
Te fallere?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ergo auſculta.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hanc operam tibi dico.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Senis noſtri, Dave, fratrem majorem Chremem
Noſtin'?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quidni?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid? Ejus gnatum Phaedriam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Tanquam te.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Evenit ſenibus ambobus ſimul
Iter, illi in Lemnum, ut eſſet, noſtro in Siciliam,
Ad hoſpitem antiquum; is ſenem per epiſtolas
Pellerit; modò non montes auri pollicens.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cui tanta erat res, & ſuperaret?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Deſinas.
line 20 Sic eſt ingenium.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O, regem me eſſe oportuit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Abeuntes ambo hinc tum ſenes, me filiis
Relinquunt quaſi magiſtrum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Geta,
Provinciam cepiſti duram.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Mihi uſu venit hoc, ſcio.
Memini relinqui me Deo irato meo.
line 25 Cepi adverſari primô; quid •… bis opus eſt?
Seni fidelis dum ſum, ſcapulas perdidi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Venêre in mentem mihi iſthaec; namque inſcitia eſt
Advorſum ſtimulum calces.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Cepi his omnia
Facere, obſequi quae vellent.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sciſti uti foro.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 30 Noſter mali nihil quicquàm primó. Hic Phaedria
Continuò quandam nactus eſt puellulam
Ci hariſtriam; hanc amare cepit perdité;
Ea ſerviebat lenoni impuriſſimo;
Neque, quod daretur quicquam, id cu • â •… tres:
Reſtabat aliud nihil, niſi oculos paſcere;
line 35 Sectari, in ludum ducere, & • educere,
Nos otioſi operam dabamus Phaedriae.
In quo haec diſcebat ludo, ex adverſo ei loco▪
Tonſtrina erat quaedam; hic ſolebamus 〈…〉

line 75
Iiis nubant, & illos ducere eadem lex haec jubet.
Ego te cognatum dicam, & tibi ſcribam dicam,
Paternum amicum me aſſimilabo virginis;
Ad judices veniemus qui fuerit pater,
Quae mater, qui cognata tibi ſit, omnia haec
line 80 Confingam; quod erit mihi bonum atque cominodum.
Cùm tu horum nihil refelles, vincam ſcilicet.
Pater aderit, mihi paratae lites. Quid meâ?
Illa quidem noſtra erit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Joculam audaciam!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Perſuaſit homini; factum eſt; ventum eſt; vincimur;
line 85 Duxit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid narras?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hoc quod audis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O Geta,
Quid te defuturum eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Neſcio hercle, unum hoc ſcio,
Quod fors feret. feremus aequo animo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Placet.
Ehem iſtuc viri eſt officium?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: In me omnis mihi ſpes eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Laudo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ad precatorem abeam credo, qui mihi
line 90 Sic oret; nunc omitte, quaeſo, hunc; caeterum
Poſthac ſi quicquam, nihil precor; tantummodo
Non addat; ubi ego hinc abiero, vel occidito.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid paedagogus ille qui cithariſtriam?
Quid rei gerit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sic, tenuiter.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non multum habet
line 95 Quod det fortaſſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Immo nihil, niſi ſpem meram.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Pater ejus rediit an non?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nondum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid? ſenem
Quoad exſpectatis voſtrum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non certum ſcio;
Sed epiſtolam ab eo allatam eſſe audivi modò,
Et ad portitores eſſe latam: hanc petam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 100 Nunquid, Geta, aliud me vis?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ut bene ſit tibi.
Puer, heus, nemón' huc prodit? Cape, da hoc Dorcio.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: THat the matter ſhould come to this paſſe, Phaedria, that I ſhould be afraid of my father,
Who would have me verie well provided for, when I think of his coming?
Whereas, if I had not been ſo inconſiderate, I might have expected him, as it was meet.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do you aske, that art privie with me to ſo bold a prank?
line 5 Which I wiſh it had never come into Phormio's minde to perſwade me to it,
And that he had not forced me being deſirous thitherward, which is the beginning of miſchief;
Had I not obtained her, then it had gon heavily with me for ſome daies,
But this daily care would not have troubled my minde.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I heare you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Whilſt I expect how quickly he may come, that may take ſrom me this familiaritie with her.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 10 It grieveth others, becauſe what they love is wanting; it grieveth you, becauſe you have too much.
Antipho, you are glutted with love; for trulie this kinde of life of yours
Is to be deſired and wiſhed; I wiſh I were ſo fairly bleſſed,
As that I might enjoy that which I love ſo long.
Now I deſire to die; do you ſuppoſe the reſt:
line 15 What I now get by this want, or what you get by that abundance.
That I may not add that you have without coſt got one that is honeſt and well-favoured,
That you have as you deſired, a wife of no ill report abroad,
You are happie, except this one thing be wanting, a minde that may bear theſe things-moderatelie,
But if you had to do with that bawd that I have to deal with, then you would perceive it.
line 20 We are all for the moſt part of that diſpoſition, that we are not contented with our ſelves.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: But you, Phaedri • , on the contrarie me thinks are fortunate,
That have power yet in your hand to adviſe what you deſire;
To hold her, to love her, or let her go, I unhappie man am fallen int • that condition,
That I have neither power to let her go, nor libertie to keep her.
line 25 But what is this? do not I ſee Ge •• come running hither?
It is juſt he, I am affraid poor man what thing he now comes to tell me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: ADeo • ' rem rediiſſe, qui mihi conſultum optimè velit eſſe,
Phaedria, patrem ut extimeſcam, ubi in mentem ejus adventus venit?
Quod ni fuiſſem incogitans, ita • um exſpectarem, ut par fuit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc eſt?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Rogitas, qui tam audacis facinoris mihi conſcius ſis?
line 5 Quod utinam ne Phormioni id ſuadere in mentem incidiſſet,
Neu me cupidum eò impuliſſet, quod mihi principium eſt mali.
Non potitus eſſem, fuiſſet tum illos mihi aegrè aliquot dies:
At non quotidiana haec cura angeret animum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Audio.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Dum expecto, quàm mox veniat, qui hanc mihi adimat conſuetudinem.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 10 Aliis, quia defit quod amant, aegrè eſt; tibi, quia ſupereſt, dolet;
Amore abundas, Antipho; nam tua quidem hercle certò
Vita haec expetenda optandaque eſt. Ita me Diibene ament,
Ut mihi liceat tam diu quod amo frui.
line 15 Quid ego ex hac inopiâ nunc capiam, & quid tu ex iſtâ copiâ.
Ut ne addam, quòd ſine ſumptu, ingenuam, liberalem nactus es;
Quòd habes ut voluiſti, uxorem ſine malâ famâ palàm,
Quod ſi tibi res cum eo lenone ſit, quocum mihi eſt, tum ſentias.
line 20 Ita plerique ingenio ſumus omnes, noſtri noſmet paenitet.
At tu mihi contrà nune videre fortunatus, Phaedria,
Cui de integro eſt poteſtas etiam conſulendi quid velis:
Retinere, amare, amittere: ego in cum incidi infaelix locum,
Ut neque mihi vis ſit amittendi, nec retinendi copia.
line 25 Sed quid hoc eſt? videon' ego Getam currentem huc adve • ire?
Is eſt ipſus: timeo miſer quam hic mihi nunc nunciet rem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: YOu are undone, Geta, except you can quicklie finde out ſome ſhift for you,
So manie miſchiefs on a ſuddain hang over you being unprovided,
Which I neither know how to avoid, nor how to get my ſelf out of them;
For our boldneſs can be concealed no longer,
line 5 Which evils if they be not wiſelie prevented, will ruine me or my maſter.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why comes he in a chafe?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I have but a moment of time
For this matter. Here is my maſter.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What miſchief is that?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Which when he ſhall hear, what remedie ſhall I finde for his anger?
Should I ſpeak? I ſhall incenſe him; ſhould I hold my peace? I ſhould ſet him on: ſhould I clear my ſelf? I ſhould loſe my labour.
I pittie him, I am affraid for him: he now holds me, for but for him,
I would have looked well to my ſelf, and would have been revenged of the old-mans anger,
I would have packed up ſomething, and betaken my ſelf hence to my heels forthwith,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What running away or theeving doth he provide for?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But where ſhall I finde Antipho?
line 15 Or which way ſhould I go to ſeek him?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He nameth you.

sp.speaker: An
sp.l: I know not
What great miſchief I expect by this meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Are you in your wits?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will go on homeward,
There he is the moſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Let us call the fellow back.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Stand preſentlie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ho, imperiouſlie enough ſpoken, whoſoever you are.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Geta, it is he himſelf
Whom I would meet with.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Tell me, I pray you, what news you bring, and if you can, diſpatch in a word.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 20 I will do it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Speak out.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I ſaw your father juſt now at the port.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What mine?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Have you underſtood me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What ſhould I do?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: That I ſaw this mans father your uncle.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: For what remedie can I poor man finde on a ſuddain for this undoing?
But if my fortunes come to this Phanium, that I be parted from you,
I ſhall deſire to live no longer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Seing then theſe things are ſo, Antipho,
line 25 It is ſo much more fit for you to look about you. Fortune aideth ſtout men.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I am not my ſelf.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But now Antipho it is verie needful you ſhould be;
For if your father perceive you to be fearful, he will think
You have deſerved blame.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: This is true.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I cannot be altered.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What would you do, if you were to do ſome weightier matter?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: line 30 Seeing I cannot do this, I ſhould leſse do that.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O Phaedria, this is nothing; you may be gone.
Why do we ſpend our labour in vain? but I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And ſo muſt I trulie.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I pray you, what if I counterfeit? is this enough?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You prate.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Look me in the face,
Is it enough thus?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What if I look thus?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It is almoſt well enough.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What if I look thus?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: That is enough.
Ho, hold you there: and be ſure you anſwer word for word, like for like,
line 35 Leſt being angry he baffle you with his fierce ſpoken words.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tell him you were conſtrained by force againſt your will, by Law, by judgement; do you underſtand me?
But what old man is this that I ſee in the further end of the ſtreat?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It is he himſelf.
I cannot abide to be by.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Alas, what ſay you? whither go you, Antipho?
Tarrie, tarrie, I ſay.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I know my ſelf, and my own offence;
line 40 I commend Phanium and my life unto you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Geta, what ſhall we do now?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You ſhall now hear his chiding, I ſhall be hanged, unleſs I be miſtaken.
But that which erewhile we adviſed Antipho here, we muſt do it our ſelves,
Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Away with this Muſt, and rather do you will me what I ſhall do.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Do you not remember what your ſpeech was heretofore in beginning the matter,
line 45 For the defending the fault? that that excuſe was juſt, eaſie,
Able to overcome, verie good.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I remember it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Lo, now

We have need of it, or if you can do anie thing, a better and more tra •
tie one.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: It ſhall be done
With all dillgence.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Now do you go firſt to him; I will be here in ambuſh
Readie to make a ſupply, if you ſhall fail in any thing.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go to then.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: NUllus es, Geta, niſi • am aliquid tibi conſilium c • l •• è reppereris,
Ita nunc imparatum ſubitò tanta te impendent mala:
Quae neque uti devitem ſcio, neque quo modo me indè extraham;
Nam non poteſt celari noſtra diutius audacia;
line 5 Quae ſi non aſtu providentur, me aut herum peſſum dabunt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Quidnam ille commotus venit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tunc • emporis mihi punctū
Ad hanc rem eſt. Herus adeſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Quid illud mali eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quod cùm audierit, quod ejus remedium inveniam īracundiae?
Loquárne? incendam; taceam? inſtigem; purgem me? laterem lavem.
line 10 Heu me miſerum! tum mihi paveo, tum Antipho me excruciat animi;
Ejus me miſcret, ei nunc timeo; is nunc me retinet; namque abſque eo eſſet,
Rectè ego mihi vidiſſem, & ſenis eſſem ultus iracundiam:
Aliquid convaſiſſem, atque hinc me conjicerem protinus in pedes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Quam hic fugam, aut furtum parat?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sed ubi Antiphonem reperiam?
line 25 Aut quâ quaerere inſiſtam via?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Te nominat.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Neſcio quod
Magnum hoc nuncio expecto malum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Sanus es?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Domum ire pergam:
Ibi plurimùm eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Revocemus hominem.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sta illico.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hem, ſatis pro imperio, quiſquis es.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ipſe eſt quem volui
Obviam.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Cedò, quid portas, obſecro? atque id ſi potes verbo expedi:

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 20 Faciam.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Eloquere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Modò apud portum patrem.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Meúmne?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Intellex • in'.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Occidi.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Quid agam?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hujus patrem vidiſſe me patruum tuum.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Nam quod ego huic nunc ſubitò exitio remedium inveniam miſer?
Quod ſi eò meae fortunae redeunt, Phanium, abs te ut abſtrahar,
Nulla eſt mihi vita expetenda.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ergo iſtaec cùm ita ſint, Antipho,
line 25 Tantò magis te advigilare aequum eſt. Fortes fortuna adjuvat.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Non ſum apud me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Atqui opus eſt nunc cùm maxumè ut ſis, Antipho:
Nam ſi ſenſerit te timidum pater eſſe, arbitrabitur
Commeruiſſe culpam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hoc verum eſt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Non poſſum immutarier.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid faceres, ſi aliud quid gravius tibi nunc faciendum foret?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: line 30 Cùm hoc non poſſum, illud minus poſſum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hoc nihil eſt Phaedria, ilicet.
Quid conterimus operam fruſtrà? quin abeo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Et quidem ego.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Obſecro, quid ſi aſſimulabo? ſatin' eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Garris.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Vultum contemplamini;
Satin' ſic eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Quid ſi ſic?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Propemodum.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Quid ſi ſic?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sat eſt.
Hem iſtuc ſerva: & verbum verbo, par pari ut reſpondeas,
line 35 Ne te iratus ſuis ſaevidicis dictis protelet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Vi coactum eſſe te invitum, lege, judicio: tenes?
Sed quis hic eſt ſenex quem video in ultimâ plateâ.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Ipſus eſt.
〈◊〉 poſſum adeſſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ah, quid ais? quò a • is, Antipho?
Mane, mane, inquam.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Egomet me novi & peccatum meum;
line 40 Vobis commendo Phanium, & vitam meam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Geta. Quid nunc fiet?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tu jam lites audies; ego plectar pendens, niſi quid me fefellerit.
Sed quod modò h • c nos Antiphonem monuimus, id noſmetipſos facere
Oportet, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Aufer mihi Oportet; quin tu quid faciam
Impera.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Meminiſtin' olim ut • uerit voſtra oratio in re
line 45 Incipiundâ ad defendendam noxiam? juſtam illam cauſam, facilem,
Vincibilem, optumam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Memini.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hem, nunc
Ipſâ eſt opus, aut ſi quid potes, meliore & callidiore.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Fiet
Sedulò.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nunc prior adito tu; ego in inſidiis hîc ero
Succenturiatus, ſi quid deficies.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Age.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Is it ſo at laſt, hath Antipho married a wife without my bidding?
And did he not fear my authoritie? well, I let authority go; did he not fear my diſpleaſure
At the leaſt, was he not aſhamed? O bold attempt, O Geta
The prompter on.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: With much ado at laſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What will they ſay to me, or what excuſe will they finde?
I wonder.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But I have found one alreadie, care you for ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Will they ſay this to me?
I did it againſt my will, the law conſtrained me, I hear and I confeſs it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: It liketh me well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But that he ſhould wittinglie and holding his peace betray his cauſe to his adverſaries,
What did the law force him to that?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: That is a hard thing to anſwer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will help you out with it, let him alone.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know not what to do, becauſe this hath befallen me beſides what I looked for, and as a thing not to be believed,
line 10 I am ſo cha • ed that I cannot bring my minde to think of anie thing.
Wherefore it behooveth all when they are moſt in proſperity, to think verie much
With themſelves, how they can endure the miſerie of adverſitie;
Let him that returneth from a ſtrange countrey, always conſider of dangers, baniſhments, loſſes,
Or his ſons miſdemeanour, or his wives death, or his daughters ſickneſſe,
line 15 That theſe things are common, and may fall out: that nothing may be new to his minde.
That he reckon all that as gained, whatſoever happeneth beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O Phaedria, it is a thing not to be believed, how far I exceed my maſter in wiſedom,
I have thought on all the diſcommodities that may come to me; that if my maſter return,
I muſt grinde continuallie in the bake-houſe; I muſt be beaten; I muſt have ſhackles on;
line 20 I muſt do work in the countrey: none of theſe things ſhall happen now to my minde.
I will reckon all that as gained, whatſoever ſhall happen beyond my expectation.
But why do you forbear to go to the man, and at firſt to ſalute him kindelie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I ſee my brothers ſon Phaedria coming to meet me,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O my uncle, God ſave you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: God ſave you. But where is Antipho?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 25 I am glad you are come ſafe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I believe you; anſwer me this.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He is well, he is here. But are all things ſufficientlie according to your minde?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I wiſh indeed they were.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you ask, Phaedria?
You have made a good marriage here, whileſt I was away.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Why, are you angrie with him for that now?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O gallant craftsman!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Should I not be angry at him, I beartilie wiſh
I had him brought me into my ſight, that he may know now, that through his own default
That gentle father of his is become a verie ſharpe man.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But he hath done nothing, uncle, for which you ſhould be angry.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But • o all things are alike, they are all of a • eather,
line 35 Know one, and you may know all.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: It is not ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: This my ſon is in the fault, and he is here to defend his cauſe,
When he is in the fault, this my ſon is readie at hand; they help one another.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: The old-man at unawares hath finelie painted out their doings.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: For except theſe things were ſo, you would not take his part, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 If it be, uncle, that Antipho hath committed a fault againſt himſelf,
Whereby he might be leſſe reſpectful of an eſtate or good name,
I do not plead his cauſe, but let him ſuffer what he hath deſerved.
But if anie one perhaps preſuming on his own naughtie ſi b • ilitie,
Hath laid waite for our youth,
line 45 And hath got the better, is that our fault or the judges,
Who do often through envie take away from a rich man,
Or for pittie give to a poor man?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But that I know the cauſe, I ſhould think this man ſpake true.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Is there anie judge, that can kn • w your juſt matters,
line 50 When you your ſelf do not anſwer a word,
So as he hath done?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He hath done the dutie
Of an ingenuous man, after he came to the judges,
He could not utter what he thought,
Baſhfulneſs did ſo daunt him being fearful.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 55 I commend this man; but do I forbear to go to the old-man as ſoon as can be?
Maſter, God ſave you: I am glad you are come ſafe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O, good keeper, God ſave you, the main ſtay indeed of our houſe,
To whom I committed my ſon at my going hence.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I heard erewhile that you accuſe us all
line 60 Vndeſervedlie, and me of all theſe that have leſt deſerved it.
For what would you have me to do for you in this buſineſs?
The laws permit not a man that is a ſervant to plead.
Neither hath he libertie to bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I let all thoſe things paſs,
Put in this too; the indiſcreet young man was affraid, I grant it:
line 65 You are a ſervant; but though ſhe be never ſo near a kin,
It was not neceſſarie for him to have her, but that which the law commandeth,
You ſhould have given her a portion, ſhe ſhould have ſought another husband.
For what reaſon did he rather marrie a woman that had nothing, and bring her home?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: A reaſon was not wanting, but money.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: He ſhould have taken it up
line 70 Somewhere or other.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Somewhere or other? There is nothing more eaſie to be ſaid.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At laſt, if by no other means, yet upon uſurie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Whoo.
You have ſpoken finelie, if ſo be anie bodie would truſt him,
Whileſt you are alive.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: No. It is not like to be thus: it cannot be.
Should I ſuffer her being married with him one day?
line 75 She hath deſerved no courteſie: I would have that fellow
Beſhewed to me, or that it be ſhown me where he dwelleth.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You mean Phormio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: That the womans defendant.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will cauſe that he ſhall be here by and by.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Where is Antipho now?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Abroad.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Go your way, Phaedria, ſeek for him, and bring him hither.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I go,
line 80 Straight way indeed thither.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You mean to Pamphila.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And I will ſtep aſide home hence to pray to my houſhold-Gods.
Thence will I go to the market, and call ſome
Friends to me, who may be by at the handling this matter,
That I may not be unprovided when Phormio cometh.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: ITáne tandem uxorem duxit Antipho injuſſ •… meo?
Nec meum imperium? age, mitto imperium, non ſimultatem meam
Revereri ſaltem, non pudere? O facinus audax, O Geta
Monitor.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Vix tandem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Quid mihi dicem, aut quam cauſam reperient,
Demiror.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Atqui repperi jam, aliud cura.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: A •… hoc dicent mihi?
Invitus feci, lex coegit'; audio, & fateor.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Placet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Verùm ſcientem, tacitum cauſam tradere adverſariis,
Etiámne id lex coegit?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Illud durum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ego expediam, ſine.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Incertum eſt quid agam, quia praeter ſpem atque incredibile hoc mihi obtigit,
line 10 Ita ſum irritatus animum, ut nequeam ad cogitandum inſtituere,
Quamobrem omnes, cum ſecundae res ſunt maxumè, tum maxumè
Meditari ſecum oportet, quo pacto advorſam aerumnam ſerant:
Pericula, exilia, damna, peregrè redien • ſemper cogit • t,
Aut filii peccatum, aut uxoris mortem, aut morbum filiae;
line 15 Communia eſſe haec, fieri poſſe; ut ne quid animo ſit novum:
Quidquid praeter ſpem evenit, omne id deputare eſſe in lucro.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O Phaedria, incredile eſt, quantâ herum anteo ſapientiâ,
Meditata ſunt mihi omnia mea incommoda: herus ſi redierit,
Molendum eſſe uſque in piſtrino; vapulandum: habendae compedes:
line 20 Opus ruri faciendum; horum nihil quidquam accidet animo novum.
Quicquid praeter ſpem evenie • , omne id deputabo eſſe in lucro.
Sed quid ceſſas hominem adire, & blandè in principio alloqui?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Phaedriam mei fratris video filium mihi ire obviám.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Mi patrue, ſalve.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Salve; ſed ubi eſt Antipho?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 25 Salvum te advenire.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Credo: reſponde hoc mihi.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Valet; hîc eſt. Sed ſatin' omnia ex ſententiâ?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Vellem quidem.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc eſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Rogitas, Phaedria? Bo •… s, me abſente, hîc confeciſtis nuptias.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Eho, an id ſuccenſes nunc illi?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O artificem probum!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Egon' illi non ſucenſeam? ipſum geſtio
Dari mihi in conſpectum, nunc ſuâ culpâ ut ſciat
Lenem patrem illum factum eſſe acerrimum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Atqui nihil fecit, patrue, quod ſuccenſeas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ecce autem ſimilia omnia, omnes congruunt,
line 35 Unum cognôris, omnes nôris.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Haud ita eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hic in noxia eſt, ille ad defendendam cauſam adeſt.
Cùm ille eſt, hic praeſtò eſt; tradunt operas mutuas.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Probè horum facta imprudens depinxit ſenex.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nam ni haec ita eſſent, cum illo haud ſtares, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 Si eſt, patrue, culpam ut Antipho in ſe admiſerit,
Ex quâ re minus rei foret aut famae temperans,
Non cauſam dico, quin quod meritus ſit, ferat.
Sed ſi quis fortè, malitiâ fretus ſuâ,
Inſidias noſtrae fe • it adoleſcentiae,
line 45 Ac vicit, noſtran' culpa ea eſt an judicum?
Qui ſaepe propter invidiam adimunt diviti,
Aut propter miſericordiam addunt pauperi?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ni nôſſem cauſam crederem vera hunc loqui,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: An quiſquam judex eſt, qui poſſit noſcere
line 50 Tua juſta, ubi tute verbum non reſpondeas,
Ita ut ille fecit?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Functus adoleſcentuli eſt
Officium liberalis, poſtquam ad judices
Ventum eſt, non potuit cogitata proloqui.
Ita eum tum timidum obſtupefecit pudor.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 55 Laudo hunc; ſed ceſſo adire quamprimum ſenem?
Here, ſalve: ſalvum te adveniſſe gaudeo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Oh, bono cuſtos, ſalve, columen verò familiae.
Cui commendavi filium hinc abiens meum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Jamdudum te omnes nos accuſare audio
line 60 Immeritò, & me omnium horum immeritiſſimum.
Nam quid me in hac re facere voluiſt • tibi?
Servum hominem cauſam dicere leges non ſinunt,
Neque teſtimonii dictio eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Mitto omnia.
Adde iſtuc, imprudens timuit adoleſcens, ſino:
line 65 Tu ſervus; verùm ſi cognata eſt maxumè,
Non fuit neceſſe habere, ſed id quod lex jubet,
Dotem daretis, quaereret alium virum.
Quâ ratione inopem potiùs ducebat ad domum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non ratio, verùm argentum deerat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sumeret
line 70 Alicunde.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Alicunde? nihil eſt dictu facilius.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Poſtremò, ſi nullo alio pacto, vel faenore.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hui,
Dixti pulcrè, ſiquidem quiſquam crederet
Te vivo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non, non ſic futurum eſt, non poteſt.
Egóne illam cum illo ut patiar nuptam unum diem?
line 75 Nihil ſuave meritum eſt. Hominem cōmonſtrarier
Mihi iſtum volo, aut ubi habitat demonſtrarier.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nempe Phormionem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Iſtum patronum mulieris.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Jam faxo aderit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Antipho ubi nunc eſt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Foris.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l:
Abi, Phaedria, eum require, at
que adduce huc.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Eo,
line 80 Rectâ viâ equidem illuc.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nempe ad Pamphilam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At ego Deos penates hinc ſalutatum domum divortar.
Indè ibo ad forum, atque aliquot mihi
Amicos advocabo, ad h • nc rem qui adſient,
Ut ne imparatus ſim cùm adveniat Phormio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: SAy you ſo, that • e being affraid of the ſight of his father, went hence away?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He was verie much affraid.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And that Phanium was left alone.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And that the old man was angry?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Verie greatlie.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: The weight of the buſineſs is laid upon thee onlie, Phormio,
Thou thy ſelf haſt ſtamped this, you muſt eat it up: buckle to thy work.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 5 I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: If he ſhall ask?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: My hope is in thee.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Behold the matter,
What if he ſhall reſtore her?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You forced him to her.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: So I think.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Help us.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Give me the old man, now all my deviſes are fitted in my minde.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What would you have me to do, but that Phanium may tarrie, and that I may acquit
Antipho of this fault, and derive all his fathers anger upon my ſelf.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 10 O valiant man and our friend! but Phormio, I am often in fear of this,
Leſt this ſtrengh of your ſinews break at laſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Tuſh,
It is not ſo, I have made trial: I know which way to ſhift alreadie,
How many m • n do you think now I have beaten almoſt to death,
Strangers? then Citizens? the better I knew them, ſo much the oftner I beat them.
line 15 Tell me now; did you ever hear any action of treſpaſs was laid againſt me?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Why that?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Becauſe the net is not laid for the hawk, and the kite,
That do harm to us, but it is ſpread for thoſe that do us no harm;
Becauſe in theſe there is profit, in thoſe we fool away our pains.
Others are in danger from others, from whom ſomething may be gotten:
line 20 They know that I have nothing; you will ſay, they will have you home being caſt;
They will not maintain a greedie fellow: and they are wiſe in my judgement,
If they will not do a main good turn for an ill turn.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thanks can never be given ſufficientlie according to your deſert.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nay indeed no man requites his King ſufficientlie according to his deſerts.
line 25 That you ſhould come to the club from the bath an •… ted and trim,
Whileſt you have what delighteth you, he is fretted; you may laugh,
You may drink firſt, you may ſit down firſt; a doubtful ſupper is ſet before you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What word is that?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Where you may doubt, what you ſhould take firſt.
line 30 When you reckon how delectable theſe things are, and how dear they are:
To him that beſtoweth them, would not you account him altogether? God at hand.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: The old man is here; have a care what you do; the firſt brunt is verie ſharpe,
If you can abide it, after it, you may play as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: ITáne patris ais conſpectum veritum hinc abiiſſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Admodum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Phanium relictam ſolam?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sic.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Et iratum ſenem?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Oppidò.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ad te ſumma ſolum Phormio rerum redit.
Tute hoc intriſti, tibi omne eſt exedendum: accingere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 5 Obſecro te.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Si rogitabit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: In te ſpes eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Eccere.
Quid ſi reddet?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tu impuliſti.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Sic opinor.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Subveni.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Cedò ſenem: jam mihi inſtructa ſunt corde conſilia omnia.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid ages?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid vis? niſi ut maneat Phanium, atque à crimine hoc
Antiphonem eripiam, atque omnem in me iram derivem patris?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 10 O vir fortis, atque amicus! verùm hoc ſaepe, Phormio.
Vereor, ne iſthaec fortitudo nervorum erumpat denique.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ah,
Non ita eſt, factum eſt periculum; jam pedum viſa eſt via.
Quot me cenſes homines jam deverberâſſe uſque ad necem,
Hoſpites? tum cives? quò magis novi, tantò ſaepius.
line 15 Cedò dum, an unquam injuriarum audiſti mihi ſcriptum dicam?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid iſthuc?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quia non rete accipitri tenditur, neque milvo,
Qui malè faciunt nobis, illis qui nihil faciunt tenditur.
Quia enim in illis fructus eſt, in illis opera luditur.
Aliis aliunde eſt periculum, unde aliquid abradi poteſt:
line 20 Mihi ſciunt nihil eſſe, dices, ducent damnatum domum:
Alere nolunt hominem adacem: & ſapiunt meâ quidem ſententiâ,
Pro maleficio ſi beneficium ſummum nolunt reddere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non poteſt ſatis pro merito ab illo tibi referri gratia.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Imò enim nemo ſatis pro merito gratiam regi refert.
line 25 Tene ad ſymbolam venire unctum atque lautum è balneis,
Otioſum ab animo, cum ille & curâ & ſumptu abſumitur;
Dum tibi ſit quod placeat, ille ringitur; tu rideas,
Prior bibas, prior decumbas: coena dubia adponitur.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc verbi eſt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ubi tu dubites quid ſumas potiſſimum.
line 30 Haec cùm rationem ineas, quam ſint ſuavia, & quàm cara ſint:
Ea qui praebeat, num tu hunc habeas planè praeſentem Deum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l:
Senex adeſt, vide quid agas: prima coitio eſt acer
• ima.
Si eam ſuſtinueris, poſt illam, jam ut lubet, ludas licet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: LOe! have you ever heard, that an injurie was ever done
More deſpitefullie to anie man, then is done to me?
Come ye hither, I pray you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He is angry.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But will you minde this buſineſs.
I will vex him by and by. O monſtrous ſtrange!
line 5 Doth Demipho denie Phanium to be a kin to him?
Doth Demipho denie this woman to be a kin to him?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He doth deny it

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And doth he ſay that he knew not her father, who he was?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He ſaith, not.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I think this is he, of whom I ſpake, follow ye me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And doth he ſay, he knew not Stilpho, who he was?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He ſaith, not.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 10 Because the poor woman is left in want, her father is unknown,
She is neglected; See, what covetouſneſs doth.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: If you ſhall accuſe my maſter of that is naught, I will tell you your name.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O the boldneſs of a fellow, what doth he come of his own accord to accuſe me?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: For now there is no cauſe why I ſhould be angry with the young man,
line 15 If he knew him not, becauſe he being now an elderlie man,
And poor; one that got his living by his labour, he kept himſelf
Commonlie in the countrey, there he had ground of my father
To till; in the meantime the old man did oftentimes
Tell me, that his kinſman neglected him:
line 20 But what a man did he neglect? the beſt man that ever I ſaw in my life.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: See how you commend him and your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Get you gone and be hanged.
For unleſſe I thought him to be ſuch a one, I would never procure ſuch heavie diſpleaſure
For this woman's ſake againſt our familie,
Which he now ſcorneth ſo diſhoneſtlie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 25 You baſe knave, do you go on to rail on him, when my maſter is abſent.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But he deſerveth this.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Say you ſo, you goal-bird.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You extortioner of goods, you wreſter of lawes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Geta.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Anſwer him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What man is this, ho?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: G.

l.hi: Demipho,

sp.l: He hath never ceaſed to give out railing ſpeeches,
line 30 Such as you have not deſerved, and ſuch as he hath deſerved himſelf,
Againſt you when you were abſent.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Give over.
Young-man, firſt of all I deſire this of you by your good leave,
If it may pleaſe you to make me an anſwer.
What friend of yours do you ſay that man was? make it plain to me.
line 35 And how did he ſay that I was his kinſman?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You fiſh it out ſo, as if you did not know him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Did I know him?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But I ſay I did not: do you that ſay I knew him, bring him to my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ho! did not you know your couſin-german?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You kill me quite out.
Tell me his name.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: His name? yes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why do you now hold your peace?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 Trulie I am undone, I have quite forgot his name.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ho. what do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Ph.

l.hi: Geta,

sp.l: If you remember that which I once told you, put me in minde. Ho,
I will not tell you, as though you did not know you come to pump me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do I pump you?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Stilpho.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And indeed what is it to me?
It is Stilpho.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whom did you mention?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I ſay, did not you know Stilpho?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 45 I neither knew him, nor was anie man of that name
A kin to me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What ſo? are you not aſhamed of theſe things?
But if he had left an eſtate of ten talents.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: A miſchief light on thee.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You would be the firſt man
To reckon your pedigree by heart as far as your grandfather and greatgrandfather.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 50 Yes as you ſay; if I had come then I could have told
How ſhe had been my kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ho! our maſter, well done; ho you! look to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I made it clear to the judges, to whom I ought,
If then it had been falſe, why did not your fon
Refute it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do you tell me of my ſon?
line 55 Concerning whoſe follie one cannot ſpeak as it deſerveth.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But you, that are a wiſe man, go to the magiſtrates;
That they may give you a ſentence again of the ſame matter.
Foraſmuch as you alone bear ſway, and it is lawfull for you onely,
To get a judgement twice here concerning the ſame caſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 60 Though an injurie be done me, yet nevertheleſſe
Rather then I would follow ſuiters, or rather then I would hear you,
Iuſt as ſhe were my kinſwoman, becauſe the law enjoineth,
To give her a portion, have her away, and take five pounds.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he, a merrie world!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is the matter? do I deſire anie thing that is not fair?
line 65 Should not I indeed obtain this; which is mine by common law?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Is it ſo forſooth I pray you, when you have abuſed her, like a whore,
Doth the law bid you give her a reward and let her go?
Or, that being a citizen ſhe might not commit anie lewdneſſe
Through want of means, is ſhe commanded to be given to her next kinſman,
line 70 That ſhe might live with one man? which you forbid.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Yes indeed, to the next kinſman: but whence are we? or wherefore?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Enough.
Do not try a ſuit, they ſay, when a judgement is paſsed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Should I not try? nay, I will not give over,
Till I have brought this matter to an end.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You play the fool.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Do but let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Laſtly Demipho, we have nothing to do with you,
line 75 It is your ſon that is caſt, not you, for your age
For marrying was paſt alreadie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Suppoſe him
To ſay all theſe things that I have now ſaid;
Or elſe trulie I will forbid him my houſe with this wife of his.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He is angrie.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You your ſelf will do better then ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 80 Are you ſo provided to do everie thing againſt use,
You unhappie wretch.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He is afraid of us, although he diſſembleth it
All that he can.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You have made a good beginning.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But you muſt ſuffer
What is to be ſuffered; you ſhould do as is meet for you to do,
That we may be friends betwixt our ſelves.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Should I crave
line 85 Your friendſhip; or ſhould I be willing to ſee or hear you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: If you will agree with her, you ſhall have one
To delight your old age: conſider your own age.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Let her delight you: have her to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Aſſwage your anger.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Minde this.
There have been now words enough; unleſſe you make haſte
line 90 To take away the woman; I will pack her out. I have told you my minde, Phormio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: If you lay a hand on her, otherwiſe then is fitting for a free-born woman,
I will bring a huge action againſt you, I have told you my minde, Demipho.
If there ſhall be anie need, ho, you ſhall finde me at home.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: EN! unquam cuiquam contumelioſius
Audiſtis factam injuriam, quàm eſt mihi?
Adeſte, quaeſo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Iratus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quin tu hoc ages?
Jam ego hunc agitabo. Proh Deûm immortaliū fidē!
line 5 Negat Phanium hanc ſibi eſſe cognatam Demipho!
Hanc Demipho negat eſſe cognatam?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Negat.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Neque ejus patrem ſe ſcite, qui fuerit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Negat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ipſum eſſe opinor de quo agebam, ſequimini.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Neque Stilphonem ſcire, qui fuerit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Negat.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 10 Quia egens relicta eſt miſera, ignoratur parens,
Negligitur ipſa; vide avaritia quid facit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Si herum inſimulabis malitiae, malè audies.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O audaciam! etiámne ultro accuſatum ad • enit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nam iam adoleſcenti nihil eſt quod ſuccenſeam,
line 15 Si illum minus nôrat, quippe homo jam grandior,
Pauper, cui in opere vita erat, ruri ferè
Se continebat: ibi agrum de noſtro parente
Colendum habebat: ſaepe interea mihi ſenex
Narrabat, ſe hunc negligere cognatum ſuum.
line 20 At quem virum? quem ego videro in vita optumum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Videas te atque illum ut narras.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Abi hinc in malam crucem.
Nam ni ita eum exiſtumaſſem, nunquam tam graves
Ob hanc inimicitias caperem in noſtram familiam,
Quam is aſpernatur nunc tam inliberaliter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 25 Pergin', hero abſente, malè loqui, impuriſſime?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Dignum autem hoc illo eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ain' tandem, carcer?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Bonorum extortor, legum contortor.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Geta.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Reſponde.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quis homo eſt? ehem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tace.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Abſenti tibi
Te indignas, ſéque dignas contumelias
line 30 Nunquam ceſſavit dicere, Demipho.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Deſine.
Adoleſcens, primùm abs te hoc bonâ veniâ expeto,
Si tibi placere potis eſt, mihi ut reſpondeas.
Quem amicum tuum ais fuiſſe iſtum? explana mihi?
line 35 Et qui cognatum me ſibi eſſe diceret.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Proinde expiſcare, quaſi non nôſſes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nôſſem?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ergo me nego; tu qui ais redige in memoriam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Eho tu ſobrinum tuum non nôras?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Enecas.
Dic nomen.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nomen? maxumé.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid nunc taces?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 40 Perii hercle; nomen perdidi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, quid ais?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Geta,
Si memiuiſti id quod olim dictum eſt, ſubjice. Hem,
Non dico, quaſi non noris, tentatum advenis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Egon' autem tento?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Stilpho.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Atque adeò quid meâ?
Stilpho eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quem dixti?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Stilphonem, inquam, non nôras

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 45 Neque ego illum nôram, neque mihi cognatus fuit
Quiſquam iſto nomine.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Itáne? non te horum pudet?
At ſi talentum rem reliquiſſet decem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dii tibi malè faciant.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Primus eſſes memoriter
Progeniem veſtram uſque ab avo atque atavo proferens.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 50 Ita ut dicis; ego tum ſi adveniſſem, quî mihi
Cognata eſſet ea dicerem: itidem tu face.
Cedò, qui eſt cognata?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Heus noſter rectè; heus tu, cave.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Dilucidè expedivi, quibus me oportuit
Judicibus; tum id ſi falſum fuerat, filius
line 55 Cur non refellit?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Filium narras mihi?
Cujus de ſtultitia dici, ut dignum eſt, non poteſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: At tu, qui ſapiens es, magiſtratus adi:
Judicium de eadem cauſa reddant tibi.
Quandoquidem ſolus regnas, & ſoli licet
Hîc de eadem cauſa bis judicium adipiſcier.
line 60 Etſi mihi facta injuria eſt, veruntamen,
Potiùs quàm lites ſecter, aut quàm te audiam,
Itidem ut cognata ſi ſit, id quod lex jubet
Dotem dare, abduce hanc, minas quinque accipe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he, homo ſuavis!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid eſt? num iniquum poſtulo?
line 65 Anne hoc quidem ego adipiſcar, quod jus publicum eſt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Itáne tandem, quaeſo, item meretricem ubi abuſus ſis illam,
Mercedem dare lex jubet ei, atque amittere;
An, ut ne quid civis turpe in ſe admitteret,
Propter egeſtatem, proximo juſſa eſt, dari,
line 70 Ut cum uno aetatem degeret? quod tu vetas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ita proxumo quidem; at nos unde, aut quamobrem:

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ohe,
Actum, aiunt, ne agas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non agam? immo haud deſinam,
Donec perfecero hoc.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ineptis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sine modó.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Poſtremò tecum nihil rei nobis, Demipho, eſt,
line 75 Tuus eſt damnatus natus, non tu; nam tua
Praeterierat jam ad ducendum aetas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Omnia haec
Illum putato quae ego nunc dico dicere:
Aut quidem cum uxore hac ipſum prohibebo domo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Iratus eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Tute idem melius feceris.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 80 Itáne es paratus facere me advorſum omnia
Infelix.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Metuit hic nos tametſi ſedulò
Diffimulat.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Bene habent tibi principia.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quin quod eſt
Ferendum feras: tuis dignum factis feceris,
Ut amici inter nos ſimus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Egon' tuam expetam
line 85 Amicitiam? aut te viſum aut auditum velim?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Si concordabis cum illa, habebis quae tuam
Senectutem oblectet; reſpice aetatem tuam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Te oblectet: tibi habe.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Minue verò iram.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hoc age.
Satis jam verborum eſt: niſi tu properes mulierem
line 90 Abducere, ego illam ejiciam. Dixi, Phormio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Si illam attigeris ſecus quàm dignum eſt, liberam:
Dicam tibiimpingam grandem. Dixi, Demipho.
Si quid opus fuerit, heus domi me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Intelligo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: WHat care and trouble hath my ſon brought upon me?
Who hath entangled me and himſelf by this marriage?
Neither doth he come forth into my ſight, that I may know at leaſt,
What he can ſay concerning this matter, or what his minde is.
line 5 Do you go and ſee, whether he be returned home or not:

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ye ſee in what ſtate this matter ſtandeth.
What ſhould I do? tell me, Hegio.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I think Cratinus had beſt tell you,
If you think good.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tell me, Cratinus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Would you have me tell you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Yes you.
I would have you do thoſe things, which may be for your own good▪ this is
line 10 My opinion, it is both right and honeſt, that what your ſon hath done,
Whilſt you was away, be reſtored to it's former eſtate,
And this you will obtain. I have ſpoken my minde.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Now ſpeak you, Hegio.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I think he hath trulie ſpoken his minde: but thus it is,
So manie men, ſo manie mindes: everie one hath his own way.
line 15 I do not think, that what is done by law
Can be revoked; and it is an uglie thing to go about it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Speak, Crito.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: I think it is to be deliberated more on.
It is a weightie matter.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Will you have anie thing elſe with us?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ye have done verie well,
I am much more uncertain, then I was erewhile.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: They ſay he is not
line 20 Returned.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I muſt wait for my brother;
What advice he ſhall give me, I will follow it.
I will go ask for him at the port, until he come back.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But I ſeek Antipho, that he may know, what things are done here.
But behold I ſee him coming hither in good time.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: QUantâ me curâ & ſollicitudine affecit
Gnatus, qui me & ſe hiſce impedivit nuptiis?
Neque mihi in conſpectum prodit, ut ſaltem ſciam,
Quid de hac re dicat, quidve ſit ſententiâ.
line 5 Abi tu, viſe redieritne jam, an nondum, domum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Eo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Videtis quo in loco res haecſict.
Quid ago? dic, Hegio,

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Ego Cratinum cenſeo,
Si tibi videtur.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dic, Cratine.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Mene vis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Te.
Ego quae in rem tuam ſint, ea velim facias: mihi
line 10 Sic hoc videtur; quod te abſente hic filius
Egit; reſtitui in integrum aequum ac bonum eſt.
Et id impetrabis. Dixi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dic nunc Hegio.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Ego ſedulò hunc dixiſſe credo; verum ita eſt,
Quot homines▪ tot ſententiae; ſuus cuique mos eſt.
line 15 Mihi non videtur, quod ſit factum legibus
Reſcindi poſſe, & turpe inceptum eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dic Crito.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Ego amplius deliberandum cenſeo,
Res magna eſt.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Numquid nos vis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Feciſtis probè,
Incertior ſum multò quàm dudum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Negant
line 20 Rediſſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Frater eſt expectandus mihi;
Is quod mihi dederit de hac reconſilium id exſequar.
Percontatum ibo ad portum, quoad ſefe recipiat.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Atque Antiphonem quaeram, ut quae acta hîc ſint, ſciat.
Sed eccum ipſum video in tempore huc ſe recipere.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: TRulie, Antipho, you are much to be diſcommended with that faint heart,
That you ſhould thus go away hence, and commit your life to others to be preſerved?
Did you think other men would better minde your buſineſſe then your ſelf?
For however other things were, you might ſurely have conſulted for her, who is now at your houſe,
line 5 Leſt ſhe being deceived becauſe of your aid ſhould endure ſome ill;
Which poor woman's hopes and riches do all depend upon you alone.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Trulie, maſter, we blamed you here even now, in your abſence, becauſe you went away.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I was looking for you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But we failed never the more for that reaſon.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Speak, I pray you, in what ſtate do my matters and fortunes ſtand?
line 10 Doth my father perceive anie thing of the matter?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Is there anie further hope?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Alas.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But that Phaedria did not ceaſe to labour for you.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: He hath no new thing.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Beſides Phormio in this, as in other matters,
Shewed himſelf a ſtout man.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What did he?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He confuted
Your father that was verie angrie with words.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: O brave Phormio!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 15 And I did what I could too.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: O my Geta, I love you all.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thus the entrance is made, as I tell you: the matter is yet in quiet;
And your father will tarrie for your uncle, until he come hither.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Why will he tarrie for him?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: As he ſaid, he would do according to his advice in that which
Belongeth this buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Geta, How greatlie am I afraid that my uncle
line 20 Will now come hither ſafe! For, as far as I hear, I muſt either live
Or die according to his ſentence.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Here is Phaedria for you.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Look where he is, he comes forth out of his own wreſtling-ſchool doors.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: ENimvero, Antipho, multis modis, cum iſtoc animo vituperandus es,
Itáne te hinc abiiſſe, & vitam tuam tutandam aliis dediſſe?
Alios tuam rem credidiſti, magis quàm tete animadverſuros?
Nam utut erant alia, illi certè, quae nunc tuae domi eſt, conſuleres.
line 5 Ne quid propter tuam fidem decepta pateretur mali,
Cujus nunc miſerae ſpes opéſque ſunt in te uno omnes ſitae.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Equidem, here, nos jam dudum hic te abſentem incuſamus, qui abieris.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Teipſum quaerebam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sed eâ cauſâ nihilo magis defecimus.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Loquere, obſecro, quonam in loco ſint res & fortunae meae?
line 10 Nunquid patri ſubolet?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nihil etiam.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ecquid ſp • i porrò eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Neſcio.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Niſi Phaedria haud ceſſavit pro te eniti.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Nihil ſecit novi.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tum Phormio itidem hac re, ut in aliis,
Strenuum hominem praebuit.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quid is fecit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Confutavit
Verbis admodum iratum patrem.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Eheu Phormio!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 15 Ego, quod potui, feci porró.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Mi Geta, omnes vos amo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sic habent principia ſeſe, ut dico: adhuc tranquilla res eſt;
Manſurúſque patruum eſt pater, dum huc adveniat.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quid eum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ut aiebant, de ejus conſilio ſeſe velle facere quod ad hanc
Rem attinet.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quantus metus eſt mihi, venire huc nunc
line 20 Salvum patruum, Geta! Nam per ejus unā, ut audio, aut vi • ā
Aut moria • , ſententiam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Phaedria tibi adeſt.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ubinan •…

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Eccum, ab ſuâ paleſtrâ exit foras.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: DOrio, I pray you, hear me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I do not hear you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: A litle while.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hear what I will ſay.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But it irketh me now to hear the ſame things a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But now I will ſay what you will willingly hear.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Speak, I hear you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Cannot I intreat you to tarrie this three daies? whither go you now?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 I wondered that you ſhould bring me anie news.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Alas I fear the bawd ſhould deviſe ſome miſchief to his overthrow.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I fear the ſame.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Doſt thou not believe me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Gueſſe.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But if I pawn my credit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Theſe are but tales.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You will ſay that you got well by that good turn.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Theſe are but words.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Believe me, you will be glad when it is done: verilie this is true.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Theſe are but dreames.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 10 Trie, it is not long.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You ſing the ſame ſong.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You ſhall be my couſin, you my parent, you my friend.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Prate▪ on now.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: That you ſhould be of ſuch a hard and inexorable a nature,
That you can neither be ſoftned by pittie, or praiers!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: That you ſhould be ſo inconſiderate and indiſcreet, Phaedria,
line 15 That you ſhould lead me with gaudywords, and lead mine away for nothing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: He pitties him.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Alas, I am confuted with your words.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: How like either partie is to himſelf!

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: And that this evil ſhould then befall me,
When Antipho was buſied with ſome other care.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Aias, but what is that, Phaedria?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O moſt fortunate Antipho!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What I?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Who have that at home, which you love.
line 20 Neither had you ever need to have to do with ſuch a bad fellow as this.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Have I at home? nay, as they ſay, I hold a wolf by the eares,
For neither can I deviſe, how to ſend her away, nor do I know how to keep her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: My caſe is the verie ſame about this man.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Soft, be not too cheap a bawd.
Hath he done anie thing for you?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What he? that which a moſt diſcourteous fellow would do.
line 25 He hath ſold my Pamphila.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What hath he ſold her?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Say, you, he hath ſold her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He hath ſold her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What an unworthie act was it, to ſell a maid that was bought with his own monie?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I cannot intreat him that he would tarrie, and alter his promiſe with the man,
This three daies, whilſt I get the monie which is promiſed by my friends.
If I give it you not then, do not ſtay for me one hour longer.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 You deaf me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: That which he intreateth, Dorio, is not long: let him over-intreat you.
He ſhall doubly requite you this, which you ſhall well deſerve.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Theſe are but words.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Will you ſuffer Pamphila to be deprived of this citie?
And beſides can you be able to endure their love to be pull'd aſunder?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Neither can I nor you ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: God reward you according to your deſerts.
line 35 I have ſuffered you contrarie to my nature theſe manie monthes,
Promiſing, and bringing nothing, lamenting; now on the other ſide,
I have found one that will give all things, and not weep; give place to your betters.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: In verie truth, if I well remember, there was heretofore a day,
On which being the ſet day you ſhould have given him the monie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: It was ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do I deny that?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: line 40 Is it alreadie paſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: No, but this day is come before it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Are you not aſhamed
Of your lightneſſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: No, ſo it be for my profit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You dughillraskal.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Dorio,
Ought you to do ſo I pray you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: This is my qualitie, if you pleaſe, make uſe of me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do you ſo deceive this man?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nay rather, Antip • o, this man deceiveth me.
For he knew I was ſuch a one. I thought him to be otherwiſe;
line 45 He hath beguiled me; I am no otherwiſe to him then I was.
But however theſe things are, yet this will I do; to morrow morning the ſouldier ſaid
He would give me the monie; if you Phaedria, will bring it me the firſt,
I will make uſe of my own law, that he ſhall be the better chapman that payeth me the firſt. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: DOrio, audi, obſecro.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non audio.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Patumper.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quin omitte n e.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Audi quid dicam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Atenim taedet jam audire eadem millies.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: At nunc dicam quod lubenter audias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Loquere, audio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Nequeo orare, ut maneas triduum hoc▪ quo nunc abis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Mirabar ſi tu mihi quicquam adferres novi.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Hei metuo lenonem, ne aliquid ſuo ſuat capiti.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Idem metuo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Non mihi credis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hariolare.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Sin fidem do.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Fabulae.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Foeneratum iſtuc beneficium pulchrè tibi dices.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Logi.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Crede mihi, gaudebis facto: verum hercle hoc eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Somnia.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 10 Experire, non eſt longum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cantilenam eandem canis.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Tu mihi cognatus, tu mihi parens, tu amicus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Garri modó.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Adeon' ingenio te eſſe duro atque inexorabili
Ut neque miſericordiâ neque precibus molliri queas▪

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Adeon' te eſſe incogitantem atque impudentem, Phaedria,
line 15 Ut phaleratis dictis ducas me, & meam ducas gratis.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Miſeritum eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hei, verbis vincor.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quam uterque eſt ſimilis ſui▪

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Neque Antipho aliâ cùm occupatus eſſet follicitudine,
Tum hoc mihi eſſe objectum malum.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ah, quid iſtuc autem eſt, Phaedria?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: O fortunatiſſime Antipho!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Egóne?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Cui, quod amas, domi eſt.
line 20 Nec cum hujuſmodi unquam tibi uſus venit ut conflictares malo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Mihin' domi eſt? immo, quod aiunt, auribus teneo lupum.
Nam neque quomodo amittam invenio, neque uti retineam ſcio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ipſum iſtuc mihi in hoc eſt.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Eja, ne parum leno ſies.
Numquid hic confecit?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hiccine? quod homo inhumaniſſimus,
line 25 Pamphilam meam vendidit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid? vendidit?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: A • n', vendi it?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Vendidit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quod indignum facinus, ancill m •… emptam ſuo.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Neque exorare, ut maneat, & cum illo ut mutet fidem,
Triduum hoc, dum id quod eſt promiſſum ab amicis argentum aufero;
Si non tum dedero, unam praeterea horam ne opertus ſ • es.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 30 Obtundis.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Haud longum eſt id quod orat, Dorio: exoret, ſine.
Idem hoc, tibi, quod bene promericus fueris, conduplicabit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Verba iſtaec ſunt.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Pamphulámne hac urbe privati ſines?
Tum praeterea horum amorem diſtrahi poterin' pati?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Neque ego, neque tu.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dii tibi id quod dignum duint.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 35 Ego te complures adverſum ingenium meum menſes tuli
Pollicitantem, nihil ſerentem, flentem; nunc contrà, omnia
Repperi qui det, neque lachrymet; da locum melioribus.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Certè hercle, ego ſi ſatis memini, tibi eſt olim dies
Quam ad dares huic, praeſtitutam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Factum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Num ego iſtuc nego?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: line 40 Jamne ea praeteriit?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non, verùm haec ei anteceſſit.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Non pudet
Vanitatis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Minimé, dum ob rem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sterquilinium.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Dorio,
Itáne tandem facere oportet?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sic ſum, ſi placet, utere.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Siccine hunc decipis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Immo enimvero, Antipho, hic me decipit;
Nam hic me hujuſmodi eſſe ſciebat. Ego hunc eſſe aliter credidi;
line 45 Is me fefellit; ego iſti nihilo ſum aliter ac fui.
Sed ut haec ſunt, tamen hoc faciam: cras mane argentum mihi
Miles dare ſe dixit: ſi mihi prior tu attuleris, Phaedria,
Meâ lege utar, ut potior ſit qui prior ad dandum eſt. Vale.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: WHat ſhould I do? whence ſhould I poor man get monie for him on ſuch a ſudd • in,
Who have leſſe then nothing? But if he could now have tarried
This three daies, it was promiſed me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Should we ſuffer this man, Geta,
To become miſerable, who of late, as you told me, helped me kindlie?
line 5 But rather, ſeeing there is need, let us try how to requite this benefit again.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I know indeed this is but reaſonable.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Go to then, you alone are able to ſave him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What ſhould I doe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: You muſt get the monie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I deſire that; but whence, teach me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: My father is hereby.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I know that, but what them?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Ah, a word is enough to a wiſe-man.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Is it ſo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes. Trulie you perſwade me finelie: and do you go hence too?
line 10 Do not I rejoice if I get no harm by your marriage,
Except you alſo now command me to ſeek my death in doing miſchief for this man's ſake?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: He ſpeaks truth.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What? am I, Geta, a ſtranger to you?

sp.speaker: G. I.
sp.l: do not think it,
But is it a ſmall matter, that the old man is now angrie with us all,
Except we provoke him further, that there may be no place left for intreatie?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 15 Should another have her away hence in an unknown place out of my ſight? Ha,
Therefore whilſt you may, and whilſt I am here, ſpeak with me, Antipho,
Look upon me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why ſo? or what are you about to doe? tell me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Into what part of the earth ſoever ſhe ſhall be carried hence, I am reſolved to follow her, or to die.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: God proſper what you are to doe, yet go fair and ſoftlie.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: See,
line 20 If you can afford him anie help.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: If I can, I will, what?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Deviſe I pray you,
Leſt he ſhould deviſe anie thing more or leſſe, which may afterwards grieve us, O Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I am deviſing;
He is well enough, as I ſuppoſe, but indeed I fear the miſchief.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do not fear.
We will bear the good and bad with you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: How much have you need of?
Speak.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But thirtie pounds.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thirtie! whoo! Phaedria, ſhe it verie dear.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 25 But ſhe is cheap indeed.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Well, well, I will get them and give you them.

sp.speaker: Ph.
