sp.l: Oh,
Merrie fellow.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Get you away hence.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I have now need.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You ſhall carrie
The money by and by; but I have need of Phormio to help in this matter.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: He is at hand, be verie bold to lay anie burden on him, and he will bear it; he is the onlie man
That is a friend.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Let us go to him then quicklie.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go, bid him be readie at home.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: line 30 Is there anie thing wherein you may need my help?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nothing, but go your way home,
And comfort that poor woman, whom I know to be within aſtoniſhed with fear.
Do you loiter?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: There is nothing that I will do ſo willinglie.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What way will you do that?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will tell you by the way; onelie get you aſide hence.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: QUid faciam? unde ego tam ſubitò huic argentum inveniam, miſer,
Cui •… us nihil eſt? Quod hic ſi potuiſſet nunc ex •… ier
Triduum hoc, promiſſum fuerat.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Itáne hunc patiemur, Geta,
Fieri miſerum, qui me dudum, ut dixti, adjuverit comiter?
line 5 Quin, cùm opus eſt, beneficium rutſus experiamur reddere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Scio equidem hoc eſſe aequum.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Age ergo, ſolus ſervare hunc potes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid faciam?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Invenias argentum.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Cupio; ſed id unde, edoce.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Pater adeſt hic.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Scio; ſed quid tum?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ah. Dictum fapienti ſat eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Itáne?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ita.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Sanè hercle, pulcrè ſuades: etiam tu hinc abis?
line 10 Non triumpho ex nuptiis tuis, ſi nihil nanciſcor mali,
Ni etiam nunc me hujus cauſâ quaerere in malo jubeas crucem?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Verum hic dicit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid? ego vobis, Geta, alienus ſum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Haud puto.
Sed parúmne eſt, quod omnibus nunc nobis ſuccenſeat ſenex,
Ni inſtigemus etiam ut nullus locus relinquatur preci?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 15 Alius ab oculis meis illam in ignotum hinc abducet locum? ehem,
Dum igitur licet, dumque adſum, loquimini mecum, Antipbo.
Contemplamini me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quamobrem? aut quidnam es facturus? cedò.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quoquo hinc aſportabitur terrarum, certum eſt perſequi illam aut perire.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Dii bene vortant quod agas: pederentim tan en.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Vide
line 20 Si quid opis potes afferre huic.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Si poſſum faciam; quid?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quaere, obſecro,
Ne quid plus minúſve faxit, quod nos pòſt pigeat, O Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quaero.
Salvus eſt, ut opinor: verùm enim metuo malum.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Noli metuere:
Unâ tecum bona malaque tolerabimus.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quantū opus eſt tibi?
Loquere.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Solae triginta minae.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Triginta 〈◊〉 hui perchara eſt, Phaedria▪

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: line 25 I ſta verò vilis eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Age, age: inventas reddam.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Oh,
Lepidum caput.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Aufer te hinc.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Jam opus eſt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Jam jam
Feres; ſed opus eſt mihi Phormionem ad hanc rem adjutorem dari.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Praeſtò eſt, audaciſſimè quidvis oneris impone & feret; ſolus eſt homo
Amicus.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Eamus ergo ad eum ocyús.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Abi, dic praeſtò ut ſit domi.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: line 30 Numquid eſt quod meâ operâ vobis opus ſit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nihil, verùm abi domum,
Et illam miſeram, quam ego nunc intus ſcio eſſe exanimatam metu,
Conſolare. Ceſſas?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Nihil eſt aeque quod faciam lubens.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quâ viâ iſtuc facies?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Dicam in itinere: modò te hinc amove.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: WHat? For what reaſon did you go hence to Lemnus, Chremes?
Have you brought your daughter with you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why have you not done ſo?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: After her mother ſaw that I tarried here ſomewhat too long,
And withall that the maids age did not tarrie for
line 5 My negligence, they ſaid that ſhe made a journey to me
With her whole familie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why then I pray you,
Did you tarrie there ſo long, after you had heard that?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: In truth ſickneſs held me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whence, or what was it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Do you ask?
Old age it ſelf is a diſeaſe: but I heard by the ſea-man
line 10 That carried them, that they are ſafe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Have you heard, Chremes, what hath happened to my ſon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Which deed verilie makes me uncertain what to reſolve;
For if I ſhould make this profer to anie f • rainer,
I muſt tell him in order, how, and whence ſhe is my daughter.
line 15 I knew you to be as faithful to me as I am to my ſelf.
If that ſtranger be willing to have me his kinſman,
But if he ſlight me, he ſhall know more then is requiſite to be known.
And I am affraid leſt my wife ſhould know this ſome way or other,
line 20 But if ſhe do know, that is my onelie remedie, that I ſhake my ſelf out of all,
And go forth of my houſe: for I alone am my own of all that I have.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know it is ſo, and therefore that matter is a trouble to me.
Neither will I ceaſe anie time to try all wayes,
Vntil I have effected for you that which I have promiſed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: QUid? quâ profectus cauſâ hinc es Lemmum, Chremes?
Adduxtin' tecum filiam?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Non.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ita non?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Poſtquam vidit me ejus mater eſſe hîc diutius,
Simul autem non manebat aetas virginis
line 5 Meam negligentiam; ipſam cum omni famil â Ad me profectam eſſe aiebant.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid illic tamdiu Quaeſo igitur commorabare, ubi id audiveras?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Pol me detinuit morbus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Unde, aut qui?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Rogas?
Senectus ipſa morbus eſt; ſed veniſſe eas
line 10 Salvas audivi ex nautâ qui illas vexerat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid gnato obtigerit audiſtin' Chreme?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quod quidem me factum conſilii incertum facit;
Nam hanc conditionem ſi cui tulero extrario,
Quo pacto aut unde mihi ſic, dicendum ordine eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 15 Te mihi fidelem atque ego ſum mihi
Sciebam, ille ſime alienus affinem volet,
Tacebit, dum intercedit familiaritas;
Sin ſpreverit me, plus quàm opus eſt ſcito, ſciet.
Vereorque ne uxor aliquâ hoc reſciſcat mea.
line 20 Quod ſi ſcit, uti me excutiam atque egrediar domo,
Idreſtat; nam ego meorum ſolus ſum meus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Scio ita eſſe, & ideo iſtaec res mihi ſollicitudini eſt,
Neque defetiſcar unquam ego experitier
Donec tibi id quod pollicitus ſum effecero.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I Never knew a man more crafty
Then Phormio: I come to the man to tell him
We had need of money, and how that might be done,
I had ſcarce ſpoken the half, but he underſtood me.
line 5 He was glad: he commended me; he ſought for the old man.
He thanked God that a time was offered him,
Wherein he might ſhew himſelf to be no leſse
A friend to Phaedria, then he was to Antipho. I bade the man
To tarrie for me at the market, and ſaid, I would bring the old-man thither.
line 10 But lo where he is! who is the other beyond him? a • ah, Phaedria's
Father cometh: but why did I fear, a beaſt that I am?
Was it becauſe two are offered me, whom I may deceive in ſtead of one?
I think it more profitable to make uſe of a double hope.
I will ask of him of whom I reſolved from the beginning: if he give, it is ſufficient.
If nothing can be done from him, then I will ſet upon this ſtranger.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: EGo hominem callidiorum vidi neminem
Quàm Phormionem; venio ad hominem ut dicerem
Argento opus eſſe, & id quo pacto fieret,
Vixdum dimidium dixeram, intellexerat.
Gaudebat: me laudabat: quaerebat ſenem:
Diis gratias agebat, tempus ſibi dari,
Ubi Phaedriae ſe oſtenderit nihilominus
Amicum eſſe, quam Antiphoni. Hominem ad forum
Juſſi operiri, eò me eſſe adducturum ſenem.
Sed eccum ipſum: quis eſt ulterior? atat, Phaedriae
Pater venit: ſed quid pertimui autem bellua?
An quia quos fallam pro uno duo ſunt mihi dati?
Commodius eſſe duco duplici ſpe utier.
Petam hinc unde à primo inſtitui: ſi is dat, ſat eſt.
Si ab hoc nihil fiet, tum hunc adoriar hoſpitem.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I Tarrie to ſee how quicklie Geta. returns hither.
But I ſee my uncle ſtanding with my father: woe is me,
How I am affraid whither his coming may drive my father.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will go to these men, O our Chremes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: God ſave you, Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 5 It is a joy to me that you come ſafe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I believe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What is done?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Many things are new to me at my coming home, as it falleth out, here are a great manie new matters.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Yes, Have you heard concerning Antipho what was done?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I have heard all.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Had you jtold him? it is an unworthy trick, Chremes,
To be thus coſened.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I talked convenientlie about it with my brother.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 10 For indeed I alſo beating my head verie buſilie about it,
Have found a remedie for this matter, as I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What Geta?
What remedie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: As I departed from you, Phormio. by chance
Met me.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What Phormio?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He who pack'd this woman upon us.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I know him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I thought good to try his minde,
line 15 I caught the fellow alone; why do you not ſee, Phormio, quoth I
That theſe things be compoſed betwixt you
With good will, rather then with ill will?
My maſter is a free-hearted man, and one that avoids ſuites in law:
For trulie all the reſt of our friends erewhile
line 20 With one conſent perſwaded him, that he would throw her head-long.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What doth this fellow begin, or what will he come to to day?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Will you ſay
That he ſhall be puniſhed according to law, if he caſt her out?
That is certainlie known alreadie: ſoft, you shall finde worke enough,
If you begin with the man, he hath ſuch a fine deliverie.
line 25 But ſuppoſe he be caſt; yet nevertheleſs
The matter in queſtion is not concerning his life, but his money.
After I perceived the fellow was ſoftened with theſe words,
We are now here alone, ſay I; he, tell me what would you have
To be given you in hand, that my maſter may let this ſuite fall,

line 30
That ſhe may go away hence, and that you may not be troubleſome.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Doth God proſper him ſufficientlie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: For I know verie well,
If you will but ſpeak any piece of right and reaſon,
He is ſo good a man, you will not make three words
Today betwixt you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Who commanded you to ſay thoſe words?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 35 Verilie we could not better come
Thither whither we deſire.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Go on to tell out your tale.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But at firſt the fellow plaid the mad-man.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tell me, what doth he demand?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What? too much, as much as he liſted.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tell me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: If anie bodie would give it,
A great talent (i. e. fourſcore and three pounds.)

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l:
Yea indeed a ha •
ter, how he is aſhamed of nothing:

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 40 Which I told him too; what if he would beſtow his own onelie daughter? it was little advantage;
Not to have begot another; there one found, that can deſire a portion.
That I may be ſhort, and let go his fooleries,
This in fine was his laſt ſpeech;
〈◊〉 , quoth he, now from the beginning deſired to marry
line 45 My friends daughter, as it was meet.
For I conſidered of her diſcommoditie,
That a poor woman ſhould be given to a rich man to be made a drudge:
But I ſtood in need (that I may tell you the plain ſtorie)
Of one that might bring me ſomewhat, whereby I might pay
line 50 What I owe; If Demipho will juſt now give me as much
As I am to receive of her, which is eſpouſed to me,
I ſhould deſire no woman to be given me to wife, ſooner then her.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I am uncertain whether I ſhould ſay this fellow doth theſe things
Through follie, or miſchievouſneſs, witting or unadviſed.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 55 What if he owe his life?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: His ground, he ſaith, is mortgaged
For ten pounds.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Go to, go to, let him marrie her now, I will give it him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: His little houſe is mortgaged for other ten.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hui!
It is too much.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Do not cry out, fetch theſe ten from me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He muſt buy a little maid for his wife, beſides he ſtand • in need
line 60 Of a little more houſhold-ſtuffe, and charges for the marriage.
Suppoſe indeed for theſe things (ſaith he) ten pounds.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Let him now likewiſe rather enter ſix hundred actions againſt me,
I will give him never a penni • ; that the naughtie knave ſhould alſo mock me?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I pray you be content, I will give it: do but you make your ſon
line 65 To marrie her, whom we would have him.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Woe is me, Geta,
You have quite undone me with your fallacies.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: She is packt out for my ſake,
It is but reaſon that I ſhould loſe this.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Let me know from you, ſaith he,
As ſoon as you can, if they will give me her;
That I may let this go, leſt I be held in uncertainties.
line 70 For they have reſolved to give me now a portion.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Let him take his money by and by; let him ſignifie to them the divorcement,
Let him marry her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Which thing indeed may it never proſper with him.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I have now very fitlie brought money with me,
The rent, which my wives farms at Lemnos yield me;
line 75 I will take it; I ſhall tell my wife, you have need of it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: EXſpecto quàm mox recipiat ſeſe huc Geta.
Sed patruum video cum patre aſtantem: hei mihi,
Quàm timeo adventus hujus quo impellat patrem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: A dibo hoſce. O noſter Chremes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Salve, Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 5 Venite ſalvum volupe eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Credo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid agitur?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Multa advenienti, ut fit, nova hîc compluria.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ita. de Antiphone audiſti quae facta?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Omnia.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Tun' dixeras huic? ſacinus indignum, Chreme,
Sic circumiri.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Id cum hoc agebam commodúm.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 10 Nam hercle ego quoque id quidem agitans mecum ſedulo,
Inveni ut opinor remedium huic rei.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid Geta?
Quod remedium?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ut abii abs te, fit mihi fortè obviam

l.hi: Phormio.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Qui Phormio?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Is qui iſtam.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Scio.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Viſum eſt mihi, ut ejus tentarem ſententiam.
line 15 Prêndo hominem ſolum: cur non, inquam, Phormio,
Vides, inter vos haec potiùs cum bonâ
Ut componantur gratiâ, quàm cum ma • â?
Herus liberalis eſt, & fugitans litium;
Nam caeteri quidem hercle amici omnes modò
line 20 Uno ore anctores fuêre, ut praecipi • em hanc daret.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quid hic caeptat, aut quò evadet hodie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: An legibus
Daturum poenas dices, ſi illam ejecerit?
Jam id exploratum eſt; eja, ſudabis ſatis,
Si cum illo inceptas homine, eâ eloquentiâ eſt.
line 25 Verùm pone eſſe victum eum: at tandem tamen
Non capitis ejus res agitur, ſed pecuniae.
Poſtquam hominem his verbis ſentio mollirier,
Soli ſumus nunc, inquam, hic; eho, dic quid velis
Dari tibi in manum, ut herus his deſiſtat litibus;
〈◊〉 . Haec hinc faceſſat, tu moleſtus n • ſies.
Satin' illi Dii ſunt propitii?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nam ſat ſcio,
Situ aliquam partem aequi bonique dixeris,
Ut eſt ille bonus vir, tria non commutabitis
Verba hodie inter vos.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quis te iſthaec juſſit loqui;

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 35 Immo non potuit melius pervenirier,
Eò quo nos volumus.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Occidi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Perge cloqui.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: At primò homo inſanibat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cedò, quid poſtulat?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid; nimium, quantum libuit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dic.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Si quis daret,
Talentum magnum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Immo malum hercle, ut nihil pudet.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 40 Quod dixi adeò ei: quid ſi filiam ſuam unicam locaret? parvi rettulit,
Non ſuſcepiſſe; inventa eſt, quae dotem petat.
Ut ad pauca redeam, ac omittam illius ineptias;
Haec denique ejus fuit poſtrema oratio;
Ego, inquit, jam à principio amici filiam
line 45 Ita ut aequum fuerat, volui uxorem ducere;
Nam mihi veniebat in mentem ejus incommodum,
In ſervitutem pauperem ad ditem dari:
Sed mihi opus erat, ut apertè tibi nune fabuler,
Aliquantulum quae afferret, quî diſſolverem
line 50 Quae debeo: etiam nunc ſi vult Demipho
Dare quantum ab hac accipio, quae ſponſa eſt mihi,
Nullam mihi malim, quàm iſtanc uxorem dari.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Utrum ſtultitiâ facere ego hunc an malitiâ
Dicam, ſcientem an imprudentem, incertus ſum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 55 Quid ſi animam debet?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ager oppoſitus eſt pignori ob
Decem minas, inquit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Age, age, jam ducat, dabo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Aediculae item ſunt ob decem alias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hui,
Nimium eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ne clama, petiſto haſce à me decem.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Uxori emunda ancillula eſt, tum autem pluſculâ
line 60 Supellectile opus eſt, ſumptu ad nuptias,
• is rebus pone ſanè decem, inquit, minas.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Sexcentas perinde potiùs ſcribi • o mihi jam dicas:
Nihil do; impuratus me ille ut etiam irrideat?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quaeſo, ego dabo, quieſce: tu modò filius
line 65 Fac ut illam ducat, nos quam volumus.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: H •… mihi, Geta,
Occidiſti me tuis fallaciis:

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Meâ cauſâ ejicitur.
Me hoc eſt aequum amittere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quantum potes,
Me certiorem, inquit, face, ſi illam dant;
Hanc ut mittam, ne incertus ſiem:
line 70 Nam illi mihi dotem jam conſtituerunt dare.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Jam accipiat: illis repudium r • nunciet.
Hanc ducat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quae quidem illi res vortat malè.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Opportunè adeò nunc argentum mecum attuli;
Fructum, quem Lemni uxoris reddunt praedia:
line 75 Id ſumam; uxori, tibi opus eſſe, dixero.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: GEta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What have you done?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I have wiped the old men of the money.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Is that ſufficient?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Trulie I know not, thus much I was bidden to do.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Oh you whipt-raſcal; you anſwer me another thing then I ask you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What then do you ſay?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What ſhould I ſay? by your means
line 5 My ſtate is brought to a halter altogether.
I wiſh ſome heavie judgment may light on you
For example to others: Ho, if you would anie thing,
Which you would have well done, you may commit it to this fellow,
Who may bring you out of a calm place to daſh againſt a rock.
line 10 What was leſſe advantagious, then to touch this ſore,
Or to mention a wife? my father is put in hope
That ſhe may be thruſt out. Tell me now beſides if Phormio
Shall receive the portion, he muſt marrie his wife home to him.
What ſhall be done?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But he ſhall not marrie her.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I know it. But,
line 15 When they ſhall demand the money again, for our ſake for ſooth
He will rather go to the goal.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: There is nothing, Antipho,
But it may be corrupted by wrong telling.
You pick out that which is good, and ſpeak that which is naught.
Hear now on the other ſide; if he receive the money,
line 20 He muſt marrie a wife, as you ſay; I yield to you,
A little ſpace at laſt will indeed be granted
In preparing for the wedding to invite folks, and to ſacrifice:
In the mean time friends will give the money which they promiſed,
And he ſhall reſtore it to them.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Wherefore? or what ſhall he ſay?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Do you ask?
line 25 How many things after theſe prodigies have hapned to me?
A ſtrange black dog came into the houſe,
A ſnake fell from the tyles through the ſquare place where the rain falls in.
A hen crew, the wizzard foreſpake it;
The deviner forbad to begin anie ne • buſineſs
line 30 Before the deep of winter: which is a very lawfull excuſe.
Theſe things ſhall be done, I warrant you.
Your father cometh forth, go your way, tell Phaedria that I have money for him.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: GEta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quid egiſti?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Emunxi argento ſenes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Satin' eſt id?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Neſcio hercle; tantùm juſſus ſum.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Eho verbero, aliud mihi reſpondes ac rogo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quid ergo narras?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quid ego narrem? operâtuâ
line 5 Ad reſtim mihi quidem res redit planiſſimé.
Utte quidem omnes Dii, Deaeque, ſuperi, inferi,
Malis exemplis perduint: Hem ſi quid velis
Huic mandes, quod quidem rectè curatum velis,
Qui te ad ſcopuſum è tranquillo inferat.
line 10 Quid minus utile fuit, quàm hoc ulcus tangere,
Aut nominare uxorem? injecta eſt ſpes patri
Poſſe illam extrudi: cedò, nunc porrò Phormio
Dotem ſi accipiet, uxor ducenda eſt domum.
Quid fiet?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non enim ducer.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No • i. Caeterùm
line 15 Cùm argentum repetent, noſtrâ cauſâ ſcilicet
In nervum potiùs ibit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nihil eſt, Antipho,
Quin malè narrando poſſit depravarier:
Tu id quod boni eſt excerpis: dicis quod mali eſt.
Audi nunc contrà jam; ſi argentum acceperit,
line 20 Ducenda eſt uxor, ut ais, concedo tibi.
Spatium quidem tandem apparandis nuptiis
Vocandi, ſacrificandi, dabitur paululum.
Interea amici quod polliciti ſunt argentum dabunt,
Idille iſtis reddet,

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quamobrem? aut quid dicet?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Rogitas?
line 25 Quot res poſt illa monſtra evenerunt mihi?
Introiit in aedes ater alienus canis,
Anguis per impluvium decidit de tegulis,
Gallina cecinit, interdixit hariolus,
Haruſpex vetuit ante brumam aliquid novi
line 30 Negotii incipere: quae cauſa eſt juſtiſſima.
Haec fient.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ut modò fiant.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Fient, me vide.
Pater exit, abi, dic, eſſe argentum, Phaedriae.

l.hi: BE quiet, I ſay, I will have a care they do not cozen us;
I will never let this go from me raſhlie, but I will take witneſſes to me,
I will ſet down a memorandum to whom I give, and wherefore I give.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: How warie he is, where there is no need!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: But he hath need to do ſo; but make haſte, whileſt he is in the ſame minde.
line 5 For if that other woman ſhall be more urgent upon him, perhaps he will caſt us off.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You have thought as the matter is.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Bring me to him then.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I make no delay.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: When you have done this,
Step over to my wife, that ſhe may ſpeak with her, before ſhe go hence;
Let her tell her that we will give her in marriage to Phormio, that ſhe be not angry.
And that he 〈◊〉 a more fit match, who may be more familiar with her.
line 10 That we have not neglected our dutie a whit, that as much portion is given her,
As he deſired.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What doth this concern you, with a miſchief!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Much, Demipho.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Is it not enough for you to have done your dutie, if fame approve it not?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I would have this done alſo with her good will, leſt ſhe ſhould report that ſhe was caſt out.

sp.speaker: D:
sp.l: I my ſelf can do that.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: A woman will agree better with a woman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 I will intreat her.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I am thinking where I may finde theſe women.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: QUietus eſto, inquam: ego curabo ne quid verborum duit.
Hoc temerè nunquam amittam ego à me, quin mihi teſtes adhibeam,

l.hi: Cui dem, & quamobrom dem comemorabo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ut cautus eſt, ubi nihil eſt opus!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Atqui ita opus eſt facto; at matura, dum libido eadem haec manet.
line 5 Nam ſi altera illa magis inſtabit, forſitan nos rejiciet.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Rem ipſam putâſti.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Duc me ad eum ergó.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Non moror.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ubi hoc egeris,
Tranſito ad uxorem meam, ut conveniat hanc priùs quàm hinc abeat.
Dicat eam nos dare Phormioni nuptum: nè ſuccenſeat,
Et magis eſſe illum idoneum, qui ipſi ſit familiarior.
line 10 Nos noſtro officio nihil egr • ſſo • ; quantum is voluerit,
Datum eſſe dotis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid tuâ, malùm, id reſert?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Magni Demipho.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non ſat tuum officium feciſſe, ſi non id • ama approbat?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Volo ipſius quoque voluntate hoc fieri, ne ſe ejectum praedicet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Idem ego iſtuc facere poſſum.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Mulier mulieti magis congruet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Rogabo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ubi ego illas repperire poſſim, cogito.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: WHat ſhould I do? whom ſhall I finde to be my friend poor woman, or to whom
Shall I impart theſe purpoſes? or of whom ſhould I deſire help?
For I am affraid leſt my miſtris through my perſwaſion ſhould be unworthilie wronged.

I h • a • the young mans father takes theſe things that are done ſo paſ •…
• atelie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 5 But what diſmaied old-woman is this, which is come out from my brothers?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Which poverty forced me to do, when I know this was an uncertain
Marriage; that I might take that courſe, that our life might be preſerved in the mean time.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Verilie, except I be miſtaken, or my eyes fail me,
I ſee my daughters nurſe.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Neither is he to be traced out.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What ſhould I do?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 10 Who is her father?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Had I beſt go to her or tarrie, till I better know what ſhe ſaith?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: But if I could but now finde him, there would be nothing that I ſhould fear.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: It is juſt ſhe,
I will ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Who ſpeaks here?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sophrona.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: And doth he name my name too?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Look back to me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O ſtrange, is this Stilpho?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Do you ſay no?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Go aſide hence from the door a little this way I pray you, Sophrona.
line 15 See you do not call me by this name hereafter.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What I pray you, are not you he,
Whom you have alwayes uſed to ſay you were?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Whiſht.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: What, are you affraid of this door?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I have a curſt wife pent up; but concerning that name,
I have told you wrong heretofore to that end, left you peradventure being indiſcreet
Should blab it out, and my wife alſo ſhould come to know it one way or other.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Alas, by this means we poor women could never be able to finde you here.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Come on, tell me, what have you to do with this familie whence you come? or where are
Thoſe women?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Woe is me.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ha, what is the matter? are they living?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Your daughter is alive:
But death hath ſeiſed upon the mother for very grief.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: This is ill done.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: And I who was a forlorn old woman, being in want, and unknown,
line 25 Have beſtowed the maid in marriage as well as I could to this young man, that is the maſter
Of this houſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: To Antipho?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ah, to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What?
Hath be two wives?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Soft, I pray you, he hath indeed this one alone.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What is that other woman, which is ſaid to be his kinſwoman?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: This is then ſhe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It was done on purpoſe, how he being in love might have her
line 30 Without a portion.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O ſtrange! how often do theſe things fall out by chance unadviſedlie,
Which one dare not wiſh! at my coming I have found my daughter
Placed with him that I deſired, and as I deſired.
That which we both endeavoured with a great deal of pains, that it might be done,
This woman alone hath effected without anie great care of ours.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 35 Now ſee what is needfull to be done; here comes the young-man's father,
And they ſay he takes it verie impatientlie.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: There is no danger:
But for God's ſake and man's, take heed that no bodie kno • w this is my daughter.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: No bodie ſhall know it from me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Follow me, you ſhall hear the reſt within.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: QUid agam? quem mihi amicum inveniam miſera? aut cui
Conſilia haec referam? aut unde auxilium petam?
N • m vereor •… a ne ob meum ſuaſum indignè injuriâ afficiatur.
Ita patrem adoleſcentis facta haec tolerare audio violenter.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 5 Nam quae haec anus eſt exanimata, à fratre quae egreſſa eſt meo?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quod ut facerē egeſtas me impulit, cùm ſcirē infirmas nuptias
Haſce eſſe: ut id conſulerem, interea vita ut in tuto 〈◊〉 foret.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Certè aedipol ni • i me animus fallit, aut parùm proſpiciūt oculi,
Meae nutricem gnatae video.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Neque ille inveſtigatur.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid agam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 10 Qui eſt pater ejus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Adeón' an maneo dum ea quae loquitur, magis cognoſcam?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quod ſi eum nunc repperire poſſim, nihil ſit, quod verear.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ea ipſa eſt.
Colloquar.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quis hîc loquitur?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sophrona.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Et meum nomen nominat?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Reſpice and me.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Dii, obſecro vos, éſtne hic Stilpho?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Non:

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Negas?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Concede hinc à foribus paululum iſtorſum ſodes, Sophrona.
line 15 Ne me iſtoc poſthac nomine apelles ſis.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid? nones, obſecro,
Quem ſemper te eſſe dictitaſti?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: St.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Quid has metuis fores?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Concluſam hîc habeo uxorem ſaevam: verum iſtoc de nomine,
Eo perperam olim dixi, ne vos forte imprudentes foris
Effutiretis, atque id porrò aliquâ uxor me reſciſceret.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 20 Hem iſtoc pol nos te hic invenire miſerae nunquam potuimus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Eho dic mihi, quid rei tibi eſt cum familiâ hac unde exis? aut ubi
Illae ſunt?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Miſeram me!

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hem quid eſt, vivú •• ne?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Vivit gnata.
Matrem ipſam ex aegritudine miſeram mors conſecuta eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Malè factum.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ego autem quae eſſem anus deſerta, egens, ignota,
Ut potui nuptum virginem locavi huic adoleſcenti, harum
Qui eſt dominus aedium.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Antiphonine?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Hem, iſti ipſi.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid.
Duaſne is uxores habet?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: A • obſecro, unā ille quidē hanc ſolā.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid illa altera, quae dicitur cognata?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Haec ergò eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid ais?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Compoſitò factum eſt, quo modo hanc amans habere poſſet
line 10 Sine dote.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Dii voſtram fidem, quàm ſaepe fortè temerè
Eveniunt, quae non au • e; soptare! offendi adveniens,
Quicum volebam, atque ut volebam collocatam filiam.
Quod nos ambo, opere maxumo, dabamus operam, ut fieret,
Sine noſtrâ cur? maximâ ſuâ curâ haec ſola fecit.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: line 35 Nunc quid opus facto eſt, vide; pater adoleſcentis venit,
Eúmque animo iniquo oppidò ſerre aiunt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nihil per •• li eſt.
Sed per Deos atque homines, meam eſſe hanc, cave reſ • iſcat quiſquam.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nemo ex me ſcibit.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sequere me; caetera intus audies.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: THrough our default we cauſe, that it is better to be evil,
Whilſt we ſtrive too much that we may be reputed good and kinde.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: One muſt ſo • lie, as they ſay, that he run not beyond his cottage.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Was not that enough,
To take wrong at his hands, but we muſt offer him monie of cur own accord?
line 5 That he may have whereon to live, 'till he diſpatch ſome other villanie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Verie clearlie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: They are now rewarded, that make right things wrong.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Verie trulie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How fooliſhlie now have we handled the matter with him:

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Onelie I wiſh we could come off with this device, that he may marrie her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is there anie doubt of that?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Trulie I know not, ſuch afellow as he is, how he may alter his minde.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 H • , change his minde indeed?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I hope not, but if by chance he do, I ſay.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I will do, as my brother adviſed, that I may bring his wife hither,
That ſhe may ſpeak with her. O you Geta, go your way, tell her before-hand that ſhe is coming.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: We have got monie for Phaedria; not a word of the chiding.
We have provided that ſhe may not go hence for the preſent; and what further?
line 15 What ſhall be done? you ſtick in the ſame mire: you ſhall but borrow a greater ſumme to pay a leſſe,
Geta; the miſchief which was preſent, is but prolonged to another day; your ſtripes increaſe,
Vnleſſe you look to it before-hand. Now will I go home hence, and inſtruct Phanium.
That ſhe may not anie whit be afraid of Phormio, or his diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: D
sp.l: NOſtrâpte culpâ facimus, ut malos expediat eſſe,
D • m nimiùm dici no • bonos ſtudemus & benignes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ita fugias ne praeter ca •… quod aiunt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nonne id ſaterat,
Accipere ab illo injuriam? etiam argentum eſt ultro objectum,
line 5 Ut ſit qui vivat, aliquid aliud flagitii conficiat?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Planiſſimé.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: His nunc praemium eſt, qui recta praya faciunt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Veriſſimé.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ut ſtultiſſimè equidem illi rem geſſerimus.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Modo ut hoc conſilio poſſit diſcedi, ut iſtam ducat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Etiamne id dubium eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Haud ſcio hercle, ut homo eſt, an mutet animum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 10 Hem mutet animum?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Neſcio, verùm ſi fortè, dico.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ita faciam ut frater cenſuit, ut uxorem huc ejus adducam,
Cum iſta ut loquatur. O tu Geta, abi: praenuntia hanc venturam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Argentum inventum eſt Phaedriae: de jurgio ſiletur:
Proviſum eſt ne in praeſentiâ haec hinc abeat; quid verò porró?
line 15 Quid fiet? in eodem luto haeſitas; vorſuram ſolves,
Geta; praeſens quod fuerat malum, in diem abiit: plagae creſcunt,
Niſi proſpicis. Nunc hinc domum ibo, ac Phanium edocebo,
Ne quid vereatur Phormionem, aut ejus orationem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: That ſhe may do that which muſt be done, of her own good will.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I will do it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Now help me with your paines, like as heretofore you help't me with the eſtate.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I am willing to do it, and indeed I am able to do leſſe through my husband's fault, then is becomming me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 And why?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Becauſe indeed he negligently looks after the means
Which my father got honeſtly. For he conſtantly got two talents
Of ſilver by the farmes. Ha, how one man exceeds another!

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Two talents, I pray you?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: And when things were much cheaper, yet two talents.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Whoo!

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What do theſe ſeem a wonder to you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I wiſh I had been born a man,
line 10 I would have ſhown you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know verie well.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Forbear I pray you,
That you may be able to talk with her; leſt the young-woman wearie you quite out.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I will do as you bid me, but I ſee my husband come from your houſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ho Demipho,
Is the monie given him alreadie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I took order preſentlie.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I would it had not been given. Alas, I ſee my wife; I had almoſt ſaid more then was enough.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Why would you not, Chtemes?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Now all is well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What ſay you? have you ſpoken with her,
Why we bring this woman?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I have diſpatched.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What ſaith ſhe at laſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: She cannot be got away.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why can ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Becauſe they both love one another dearly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What doth that concern us?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Verie much.
Beſides theſe things, I have found her to be our kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What? do you do • t?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No.
line 20 So it will prove, I do not ſpeak raſhlie; bethink your ſelf as I do.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Are you
Well in your wits?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Soft, I pray you, take heed you do nothing againſt our kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: She is not our kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Do not denie it. Her father is called by another name, herein you have been miſtaken.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Did not ſhe
Know her father?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: She knew him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Why did ſhe call him by another name?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You will never
Yeild to me to day, neither do you underſtand.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: If you tell me nothing.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 25 Do you go on?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I wonder what this is.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Trulie I know not.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Would you fain know? verilie, there is no bodie neerer a-kin to her
Then I am and you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: O ſtrange! let all us go together to her,
I will know this off, or on.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ah, ah.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That I ſhould have ſo little belief with you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Would you have me believe this?
Will you have that to be ſufficientlie enquired by me? well, be it ſo: what, ſhe our friend's

line 20
Daughter, what will become of it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Should 〈…〉 ſend this woman away?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What elſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Muſt that ot • er tarrie?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You may go, Nauſiſtrata.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I think indeed it is more convenient for all parties that ſhe tarrie,
Then to do as you began. For ſhe ſeemed to me of a verie good diſpoſition, when I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What buſineſſe is here?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hath he ſhut the doors alreadie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Alreadie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: O ſtrange! we roſe 〈◊〉 our right ſide.
line 25 I have found my daughter married with your ſon.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha, how could that be?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: This place is not ſafe enough for me to tell you in.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But go your way in.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ho. Let not our ſonues know this; I am unwilling they ſhould.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: AGedum, ut ſoles, Nauſiſtrata; fac illa ut placetur nobis;
Ut ſuâ voluntate id, quod eſt faciendum, faciat.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Faciam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Pariter nunc operâ me adjuves, ac dudum re opitulata es.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Factum volo, ac pol minus queo viri culpâ, quam me dignum eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 5 Quid autem?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quia pol mei patris bene parta indiligenter
Tutatur. Nam ex praediis talenta argenti bina
Statim capiebat. Hem, vir viro quid praeſtat?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Bina, quaeſo?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Ac rebus vilioribus multò, tamen duo talenta.

sp.speaker: D,
sp.l: Hui!

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid haec videntur?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Scilicet.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Virum me na •… vellem,
line 10 Ego oſtenderem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Certò ſcio.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quo pacto?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Parce ſodes,

Ut poſſis cum illâ: ne te adoleſcens mulier aff •
• iget.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Faciam ut jubes, ſedmeum virum abs te exire video.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ehem Demipho,
Jam illi datum eſt argentum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Curavi illico.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nollem datum. H •• , video uxorem; penè plus quàm ſat erat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 15 Cur nolles, Chreme?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Jam recté.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid tu? ecquid loquutus
Cum iſtâ • s, quamobrem hanc ducimus?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Tranſegi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid ait tandem?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Abduci non poteſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid non poteſt?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quia uterque utrique eſt cordi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc noſtrâ?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Magni.
Praeter haec, cognatam comperi eſſe nobis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid? deliras?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Non.
line 20 Sic erit: non temerè dico: redi mecum in memoriam.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Satin'
Sanus es?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Au, obſecro, cave in cognatam pecces.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ne nega. Patris nomen aliud dictum eſt, hoc tu • rraſti.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non nôrat
Patrem?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nôrat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cur aliud dixit?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nunquámne hodie
Concedes mihi, neque intelligis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Si tu nihil narres.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 25 Pergis?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Miror quid eſt hoc.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Equidem hercle neſcio.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Vin' ſcire? at, ita me ſervet Jupiter, ut proprior illi, quàm ego ſum
Ac • u, nemo eſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Dii voſtrā fidē! • amus ad ipſā unà omnes no • ,
Aut ſcire, aut neſcire hoc volo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Aha.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Itáne parùm mihi fidem eſſe apud te?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Vis me hoc credere?
Vin' ſatis quaeſitum mihi iſtuc eſſe? age, fiat: quid, illa filia

line 20
Amici noſtri, quid futurum eſt?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Rectè.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hanc igitur mittimus?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid • i?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Illa maneat?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sic.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ireigitur tibi licet, Nauſiſtrata.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Sic pol commodius eſſe in omnes arbitror, quàm ut coeperas, manere
Hanc. Nam perliberalis viſa eſt, cùm vidi, mihi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc negotii eſt?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Jámne operuit oſtium?

sp.speaker: D
sp.l: Jam.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: O Jupiter! Dii nos reſpiciunt.
line 25 Gnatam inveni nuptam cum tuo filio.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem, quo pacto
Id potuit?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Non ſatis tutus eſt ad narrandum hic locus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At tu intrò abi.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Heus. Ne filii quidem noſtri hoc reſciſcunt: nolo.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: IAm glad, howſoever my own matters go, that my brother hath ſped well.
What a fine thing it is to furniſh the minde with ſuch deſires,
As, when adverſitie comes, you may remedie them a little!
As ſoon as he got monie, he rid himſelf of his care.
〈◊〉 I cau by no means winde my ſ • lf out of theſe turmo •… s.
But, if this be concealed, I am in fear; if it be diſcovered, I am disgraced.
Neither would I betake my ſelf home now, unleſſe hope was ſhewed me
Of having her. But where can I finde Geta,
That I may aske him what time he will appoint me to meet with my father?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: LAetus ſum, ut ut •… eae res ſeſe habent, ſratri obtigiſſe quod vult.
Quàm ſcitū eſt, ejuſmodi parare in animo cupiditates,
Quas cum res adverſae ſient, paulo mederi poſſis!
Hit ſimul argentum repperit, curâ ſe expedivit.
Quin, ſi hoc celetur, in metu; ſin patefit, in ptobro ſiem.
Neque me domum nunc reciperem, ni mihi eſſet ſpes oſtenſa
Hujuſce habendae. Sed ubinam Getam invenire poſſum,
Ut rogem quod tempus conveniendi patris capere me jubeat?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: II have received the monie; I have delivered it to the bawd, I have brought away the woman:
I have taken order that Phaedria may enjoy her as his own: for ſhe is ſet free.
Now there is yet one thing behinde for me, which I muſt alſo diſpatch; that I may get
Leiſure of the old men to drink: for I will ſpend theſe few daies.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: line 5 But here is Phormio; what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What doth Phaedria now mean to do?
How doth he ſay he will have his fill of love?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He will now on the other ſide act your part.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: To out-run his father.
He intreated you that you would plead his cauſe again, and ſpeak for him,
For he is going to tipple at my houſe: I will tell the old men,
line 10 That I am going to Sunium to the Mart, to buy a little maid, which Geta ſpake of a while agoe,
Leſt when they ſee me not here, they may think I am ſpending their monie.
But your door creek't.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: See who comes forth.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: It is Geta.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: ARgentum accepi; tradidi lenoni; abduxi mulierem;
Curavi propriâ ea Phaedria ut potiretur; nam emiſſa eſt manu.
Nune una res reſtat mihi, quae eſt etiam conficiunda; otium
A ſenibus ad potandum ut habeā: nam aliquot hos conſumā dies.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: line 5 Sed Phormio eſt; quid ais?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quidnam nunc facturus eſt Phaedria?
Quo pacto ſatietatem amoris ait ſe velle ſumere?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Viciſſim partes tuas acturus eſt.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quas?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ut fugitet patrem.
Te ſuam rogavit rurſum ut ageres cauſam, ut pro ſe diceres,
Nam potaturus eſt apud me: ego me ire ſenibus Sunium
line 10 Dicam ad mercatum, ancillulam emptum, dudum quam dixit Geta,
Ne, cùm hîc non videant me, conficere credant argentum ſuum.
Sed oſtium concrepuit abs te.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Vide quis egrediatur.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Geta eſt.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.l: O Fortune! O luckie fortune! with how great commodities
On what ſuddain have you loded this day to my maſter Ansipho through your aſsiſtance!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What doth he mean?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: And you disburdened us his friends of our fear.
But do I loiter with my ſelf, who do not load his ſhoulder with my cloak,
line 5 And make haſte to ſeek the man, that he may know theſe things' which have happened.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Doe you underſtand what he ſaith?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do you?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: No more do I.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will go onward hence to the bawd's; there they are now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Ho Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Loe there's for you. Is it anie wonder or ſtrange thing for you
To be called back again, when you have begun the race?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 10 He holds on trulie, you ſhall never overcome with your wearying.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do you not tarrie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You ſhall be beaten: he is ſome little Beadle of the ward that calls me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That ſhall be done to you by and by, except you ſtay, you whipt raskal.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: This muſt be ſome bodie that is more acquainted with me; he threatneth harm.
But is it he whom I am ſeeking or no? it is he.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go talk with him preſentlie.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 15 O the moſt honoured man of all men living, as much as can be,
For without controverſie, you are the onely happie man, Antipho.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I wiſh I were: but I would have it told me, why I ſhould believe it is ſo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Is it not enough, if I make you beſmeared with joy?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You quite kill me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: But do you away with theſe promiſes, & tel me what you bring.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Oh,
line 20 Were you here too, Phormio?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I was here. But do you forbear?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hearken, ha,
As ſoon as I had given you the monie even now at the market: we went home.
Straightway. In the mean time my maſter ſent me to your wife.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I forbear to utter it, for it is nothing to this matter, Antipho.
When I began to go into the nurſerie, the boy, Mida came running to me,
line 25 He pull' • me behind by the cloak, he pull'd me backward, I looked back, I askt him,
Why he held me: he ſaith, that it was forbidden anie bodie to go in to his miſtreſs.
Onely Sophrona ſaith he brought in Chremes hither the old-man's brother.
And he is now within with them; when I heard this, I went on to go to the door.
Vpon my tip-toes ſoftlie; I came to it; I ſtood,
line 30 I held my breath, and laid mine ear to, ſo I began to minde
Catching at her ſpeech on this faſhion.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: O brave Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Here I heard
A moſt fine prank, ſo as trulie I almoſt cryed out for joy.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What was it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What do you think?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: But it is a moſt wonderfull thing.
Your uncle is found to be the father of your wife Phanium.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ha,
line 35 What ſay you?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: He kept companie with her mother long ago in Lemnus.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: This is but a dream: is it likely that ſhe ſhould be ignorant of her own father?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Pho • mio,
Believe there is ſome reaſon; but do you think that I could underſtand all things
Without the door, which they did within amongſt themſelves?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And indeed I have alſo heard that tale.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nay indeed I will tell you ſomewhat,
line 40 Whereby you may the rather believe it. Your uncle in the mean time came thence hither out of doors:
Not long after hewent in again with your father;
They both ſaid they gave you leave to have her.
At the laſt, I am ſent to ſeek you and bring you to them.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ho, but then carrie me; why do you leiter?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will do it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: line 45 O my Pho • mio, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Farewell Antipho.
I ſwear, it is well done, and I am glad
That they had ſo great fortune;
I have now an eſpeciall occaſion to cozen the old-men,
And to take away from Phaedrſa his care concerning the monie,
line 50 That he may not be beholding to anie of his equals.
For as this monie was given with an ill-will,
It ſhall be beſtowed on theſe: I have found out a way indeed, how I can enforce this.
Now I muſt take a new geſture and countenance;
But I will ſtep aſide into this next by-corner:
line 55 From thence I will ſhew my ſelf to theſe men, when they ſhall come forth a-doors.
Whither I pretended to go to the Mart. I do not goe.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.l: O Fortuna! O fors fortuna! quantis commoditatibus
Quàm ſubitò hero meo Antiphoni ope veſtra hunc o • erâſtis diem?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quidnam hic ſibi vult?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nóſque amicos ejus exone • aſtis metu.
Sed mihi nunc ego ceſſo, qui non humetu hunc onero pallio,
line 5 Atque hominem propero invenire, ut haec quae contigerint, ſciat?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Num tu intelligis quid hic narret?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Num tu?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Nihil.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Tantundem ego.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Ad lenonem hinc ire pergam; ibi nunc ſunt.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Heus Geta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hem tibi. Num mirum tibi aut novum eſt
Revocari, curſum cùm inſtitueris?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Geta

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 10 Pergit hercle; nunquam odio tuo me vinces.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Non manes?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Vapulabis; curialis vernula eſt, qui me vocat.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Id quidem tibi jam fiet, niſi reſiſtis, verbero.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Familiarior • m oportet eſſe hunc, minitatur malum.
Sed iſne eſt quem quaero an non? ipſe eſt.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Congredere actutum.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: line 15 Omnium, quantum eſt, qui vivunt hominum bo no honoratiſſime,
Nam ſine controverſiâ ab Diis ſolus diligere, Antipho.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Ita velim; ſed quî iſtuc credam ita eſſe dici mihi velim.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Satin' eſt, ſi te delibutum gaudio reddo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Enecas.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quin tu hinc pollicitationes aufer, & quod fers cedo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Oh,
line 20 Tu quoque hîc aderas, Phormio?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Aderam. Sed ceſſas?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Accipe, hem,
Ut modò argentum tibi dedimus apud forum: rectá ad domum
Sumus profecti. Interea mittit me herus ad uxorem tuam.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Quamobrem?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Omitto proloqui, nam nihil ad hanc rem eſt, Antipho.
Ubi in gyneceum ire occipio, puer ad me occurrit Mida,
line 25 Pone me apprehendit pallio; reſupinat; reſpicio; rogo,
Quamobrem detineret me: ait eſſe vetitum intrò ad he am accedere.
Sophrona modô fatrem huc, inquit, ſenis introduxit Chremem,
Eúmque nunc eſſe intus cum illis; hoc ubi ego audivi, ad fores
Suſpenſo gradu placidè ire perrexi, acceſſi, ſteti:
line 30 Animam compreſſi, aurem admovi; ita animū cepi attendere
Hoc modo ſermonem captans.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Euge Geta!

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Hic pulcherrimum
Facinus audivi, ita penè hercle exclamavi gaudio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Quid?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Quidnam arbitrare?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Neſcio.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Atqui mirificiſſimum.
Patruus tuus pater eſt inventus Phanio uxori tuae.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Hem,
line 35 Quid ais?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Cum ejus conſuevit olim matre in Lemno clanculúm.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Somnium: ut haec ignoraret ſuum patrem?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Aliquid credito
Phormio, eſſe cauſae: ſed me cenſen' potuiſſe omnia
Intelligere extra oſtium, intus quae inter ſeſe ipſi egerunt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Atque hercle ego quoque illam audivi ſabulam.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Immo etiam dabo,
line 40 Quo magis credas; patruus interea inde huc egreditur foras.
Haud multò pòſt cum patre idem ſe recipit intrò denuo:
Ait uterque tibi poteſtatem ejus habendae ſe dare;
Denique ego miſſus ſum, te ut requirerem atque adducerem.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Hem, quin ergo, rape me; quid ceſſas?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Fecero.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: line 45 O mi Phormio, vale.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Vale Antipho.
Bene ita me Dii ament f • ctum, gaudeo
Tantam fortunam de improviſo eſſe his datam.
Summa eludendi occaſio eſt mihi nunc ſenes,
Et Phaedriae curam adimere argentariam,
line 50 Ne cuiquam ſuorum aequalium ſupplex ſiet.
Nam idem hoc argentum ita ut datum eſt ingratis, his
Datum erit; hoc quî cogam, re ipſâ repperi.
Nunc geſtus mihi, vultúſque eſt capiundus novus:
Sed hinc concedam in angiportum hunc proxumum,
line 55 Inde hiſce oſtendam me, ubi erunt egreſſi foras.
Quò me aſſimulāram ire ad mercatum, non eo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I Have cauſe to give God great thanks, and I do t •• nk him,
Seeing theſe things, brother, have fallen out well • or us.
Now, Phormio is to be met with all as ſoon as may be,
Before he waſtfully ſpend our thirt • e pounds,
line 5 That we may take it from him.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I will go ſee,
If Demipho be at home, that what—

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But we were going to you, Phormio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: About this ſame errand perhaps.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Yes indeed.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I thought ſo.
Why were you going to me? that is a jeſt; are you afraid
Leſt I ſhould not do that, which I had once undertaken?
line 10 Ho, ho, as poor a man as I am.
I have hither to • ad a care of this one thing indeed, that I ſhould be truſted.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Is ſhe, as I ſaid, of a good diſpoſition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Therefore I come to you to te •• you, Demipho,
That I am readie, when you will; give me my wife.
line 15 For I ſet all my buſineſſe aſide, as it was meet,
After I had obſerved that you were ſo very willing to it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But this man hath diſſ • aded me, from giving her to you.
For what a rumor will it be, ſaith he, among the people, if you do it?
Heretoſ • re when it might be honeſtly done, then ſhe was not giv •• him;
line 20 Now it is a • ugly thing for a widdow t • be thruſt out of door: and almoſt all the ſame things,
Which you your ſelf ere •• ile blamed before my face.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You b •• ool me ſtately enough.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do you ask▪
Becauſe indeed I cannot marrie that other.
For with what face ſhall I return to he • again, whom I have ſlighted?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: line 25 And beſides I ſee Antipho dot • let her go from him
With • n ill will, ſay▪

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: And beſides I perceive my ſo •
But ſtep over to the market, I pray you, and give order
That that money be paid me again by a bill, Phormio▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 30 That which I afterwards paid by a bill to thoſe to whom I ought it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What ſhall we do then?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: If you will give me my wife,
Which you have betrothed, I will marrie her; but if it be ſo that you would
Have her to tarrie with you, let all the portion tarrie here with me, Demipho.
For it is not reaſonable that I ſhould be deceived becauſe of you,
line 35 Seing I for your honours ſake have ſent back a divo • cement
To another, which gave me as big a portion.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Get you hence and be hanged with that greatneſs,
You runnagate; do you think I do not even now know you,
Or you doings withal?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I am provoked.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Would you marrie this woman,
line 40 If ſhe were given you?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Do but try.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: That my ſon
May dwell with her at your • ouſe, this was your plot.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I pray you, what do you ſay?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But do you give me my money.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nay indeed, do you give me my wife.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Walk with me before a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Before a Iuſtice? trulie if you go on to be fur • her troubleſome▪

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 45 What will you do?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What I? you think that I perhaps
Patro • ize onelie them that have no portions:
I uſe alſo to do it to them that have portions.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What is that to us?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nothing.
Here I knew a woman, whoſe husband another—

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: What is the matter?
Wife • ad at Lemnus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I am quite undone.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: By whom he • ad
line 50 A daughter, and he bringeth her up privatelie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I am buried.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I will now go tell her theſe things too.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I pray you,
Do not do it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Oh! was you be?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How he plaies upon us?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: We diſmiſse you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Theſe are but tales.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What will you have?
We forgive you the money which you have.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I hear you.
line 55 Why then, with a miſchief, do ye thus befool me
With your • ond childiſh ſaying?
I will not, I will: I will, I will not: give me it again, take it.
What was ſaid is unſaid; what was before confirmed, is now made void.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: How, or whence did he know theſe things?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know not;
line 60 But I am ſure I told it to no bodie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: This is ſtrange, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I have gravelled them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ha,
Is it fit that he ſhould carrie away this ſo much money from us
Jeering us thus openlie! trulie we had better dye.
Therefore prepare to be of a manlie and readie courage.
line 65 Conſider that your fault is carried abroad,
And that-you cannot now conceal it from your wife.
Now, Chremes, what ſhe is likelie to bear from others,
It is more pacifying for us to tell it our ſelves;
Then we may be able to be revenged of this filthy fellow
line 70 After our own faſhion.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Alas, unleſs I look to my ſelf, I am at a ſtay.
Theſe men endeavour to come towards me with a minde to kill or be killed.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: But I am afraid ſhe cannot be pacified.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Have a • ood heart,
I will make you friends again; preſuming upon this, Chremes,
Seeing ſhe is dead, by whom you had this daughter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 75 Do ye deal thus with me? ye ſet upon me verie craftilie;
Trulie, Demipho, you have provoked me not for his good.
Do you ſay at laſt, after you have done what you liſt in another countrey,
And have had no regard to this worthy gentlewoman,
But have offered her diſgrace after a new faſhion;
line 80 That you now come to me to waſh away your fault with intreatie?
I will make her ſo incenſed againſt you with theſe ſayings,
That you ſhall not quench her, though you melt into tears.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: A miſchief which I wiſh might light upon him;
That anie man ſhould be ſo verie a • dacious?
line 85 Should not this rogue by common conſent be baniſhed hence
Into ſome ſolitarie countrie?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: I am now brought to that paſs,
That I know not at all what I ſhould do with him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I kn • w,
Let us go before a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Before a Iuſtice! hither, if you have anie • iſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: But follow him, and hold him, whilſt I call out the ſervants hence.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 90 Trulie I cannot alone; come run hither.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Here is one action Againſt you.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Proſecute it by law then.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I have another againſt you, Chremes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Carrie this fellow away.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Do you do ſo? trulie I have need 〈◊〉 my voice.
Nauſiſtrata, come • orth.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Stop his mouth.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Look you, this baſe knave
How much he is able to do.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nauſiſtrata, I ſay.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Do you not hold your peace?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 95 Should I hold my peace?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Except he follow, thump him on the belly with your fiſts,
Or put out his eye.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: There is a place, where I will be revenged on you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: DIis meritò magnas gratias habeo, atque ago,
Quand • evenê • e hae • nobis frater proſpe • è.
Quantum poteſt nunc conveniendus Phormio eſt,
Priuſquam dilapidet n • ſtras triginta minas,
line 5 Ut auferamus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Demiphonem ſi d • mi eſt,
Viſam; ut quod—

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At nos ad te ibamus, Phormi • .

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: De eâdem hac fortaſſe cauſâ.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ita hercle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Credidi.
Quid ad me ibatis? ridiculum; an veremini,
Ne non id facerem, quod recepîſſem ſe •… l?
line 10 Heus, heus, quanta haec mea paupertas eſt,
Adhuc curavi unum hoc quidem, ut mihi eſſe • fides.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Eſtne ita, ut dixi, liberalis?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Oppidó.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Itaque ad vos venio nunciatum, Demipho.
Paratum me eſſe, ubi vultis▪ uxorem date.
line 15 Nam omnes poſthabui mihi res, ita ut par • uit,
Po • tquam tantopere id vos velle animum advorteram.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At hic de • ortatus eſt me, ne illam tibi darem,
Nam qui erit rumor populi, inquit, ſi id feceris?
Olim cùm honeſte potuit, tunc non eſt data:
line 20 Nunc viduam ex ••• di turpe eſt; •• rme eadem omnia,
Quae • ute dudum coram me incuſaveras.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Satis ſuperbè illuditis me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Qui?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Rogas▪
Qui • ne alteram quidem illam potero ducere.
Nam quo redibo o • e ad eam, quam co •• empſerim?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 25 Tu •… autem Antipbonem video ab ſ • amittere
Invitum eam, inque.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tum autem video fi •• um
Invitum ſanè mulie • em ab ſe • mittere.
Sed tranſi ſodes ad forum, atque illud mihi
Argentum rurſum jube reſc • ibi, Phormi • .

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 30 Quodne ego perſcripſi po •… ipſis quibus debui?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid igitur fiet?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Si vis mihi uxorem dare,
Quam deſpondiſti, ducam; ſin eſt, ut velis,
Manere illam apud te, dos hîc omnis maneat, Demipho.
Nam non eſt aequum me propter vos decipi,
line 35 Cùm ego veſtri honoris cauſâ repudium alteri
Remiſerim, quae dotis tantundem dabat.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I in malam rem hi • c cum iſtac magnificentiâ▪
Fugitive; etiam nunc credis te ignorarier,
Aut tua facta ade • ?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Irritor.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Tu hanc duceres,
line 40 Si tibi data eſſet?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Fac periculum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ut filius Cum illâ habitet apud te? hoc veſtrum conſilium fuit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Quaeſo quid narras?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quin tu argentum cedó.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Immo • e ò tu uxorem cedó.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: In jus ambula.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: In jus? enimverò ſi porrò eſſe odioſi pergitis.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 45 Quid facies?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Egóne? vos me indotatis modò
Patrocinari fortaſſe arbitramini▪
Etiam dotatis ſoleo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid id noſtrâ?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nihil.
H • c quandam nôram, cujus vir uxorem—

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Quid eſt?
Lemni habuit aliam▪

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nullus ſum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ex quâ filiam
line 50 Suſcepit; & eam clam educat.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Sepultus ſum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Haec adeò ego illi jam denarrabo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Obſecro,
Ne facias.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Oh, tun▪ is eras?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ut ludos • acit?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Miſſum te facimus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Fabulae.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid vis • ibi?
Argentum quod habes, condonamus te.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Audio:
line 55 Quid vos, malùm, ergo ſic ludificami • i
I •• ptâ veſtrâ puerili ſententia?
Nolo, volo: volo, nolo: • urſum cedò, cape:
Quod dictum, indictum eſt; quod modò erat ratum, irritum eſt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quo pacto, aut unde haec hic reſcivit?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Neſcio,
line 60 Niſi me dixiſſe id nemini certò ſcio.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Monſtri, ita me Dii ament, ſimile.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Injeci ſcrupulum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Hem.
Hiccine ut à nobis tantum hoc argenti auferat
Tam apertè irridens? emori hercle ſatius eſt.
Animo virili praeſentique ut ſis para.
line 65 Vide tuum peccatum eſſe elatum foràs,
Neque id jam celare poſſe te uxorem tuam;
Nunc quod ipſa ex aliis auditura ſit, Chreme,
Id noſmetipſos indicare placabilius eſt,
Tum hunc impuratum poterimus noſtro modo
line 70 Ulciſci.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Atat, niſi mihi proſpicio, haereo.
Hi gladiatorio animo ad me affectant viam.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: At vereor ut placa • i poſſit.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Bono animo es.
Ego redigam vos in gratiam; hoc ſretus, Chreme,
Cùm è medio exceſſit, unde haec ſuſcepta eſt tibi.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 75 Itáne agitis mecum? ſatis aſtuti aggredimini:
Non hercle ex re iftius me inſtigâſti, Demipho.
Ain' tu tandem, ubi peregrè tibi quod libitum fuit feceris,
Neque hujus ſis veritus faeminae primariae,
Quin novo modo eifaceres contumelias;
line 80 Venias nunc mihi precibus lautum peccatum tuum?
His ego illam dictis ita tibi incenſam dabo,
Ut ne reſtinguas, lachrymis ſi exſtillaveris.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Malum, quod iſti Dii Deaeque omnes duint,
Tantáne affectum hominem quenquam eſſe audaciâ?
line 85 Nonne hoc publicitus ſcelus hinc deportarier
In ſolas terras?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: In id redactus ſum loci,
Ut quid agam ex illo neſciam prorſus.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Ego ſcio,
In jus eamus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: In jus? huc, ſi quid lubet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: At ſequere, ac retine, dum ego hinc ſervos evóco.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 90 Enim ſolus nequeo: ac curre huc.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Una injuria eſt
Tecum.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Lege agito ergo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Altera eſt tecum, Chreme.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Rap • hunc.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Itáne agitis 〈◊〉 enimvero voce eſt opus.
Nauſiſtrata, exi.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Os opprime.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Impurum vide,
Quantum valet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nauſiſtrata, inquam.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Non taces?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 95 Taceam?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Niſi ſequitur, pugnos in ventrem ingere,
Vel oculum exclude.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Eſt, ubi vos ulciſcar, locus.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: WHo names me?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What a ſtir is there, I pray you,
My husband?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: How now, why have you now held your peace?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What fellow is this?
Do you not anſwer me?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Would you have him to anſwer you,
Who indeed knoweth not where he is?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Take heed how you believe this fellow in anie thing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 5 Go your way, touch him, if he be not all cold, kill me quite.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: It is nothing.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What is it then that he ſaith?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: You ſhall know by and by:
Hark you.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Do you go on to believe him?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What, I pray you,
Should I believe him who hath ſaid nothing?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: The poor man dotes For fear.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Trulie it is not for nothing that you are ſo affraid.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 10 Am I affraid?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Verie well indeed: if you be not affraid,
And this be nothing that I ſay, do you tell.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You rogue! Should he tell you?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: O you Sir, you have taken verie great pains
For you brother.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: My husband, do not you tell me?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: But.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What but?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: It is not needful to tell it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: For you, but it is needful for her to know it.
line 15 In Lemnus.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Ah, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Do not you hold your peace?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Vnknown to you.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Woe is me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: He married a wife.

sp.speaker: N
sp.l: My husband, God ſent better news.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: It is done ſo.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I am undone poor woman.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: And by her he hath
One daughter alreadie, whileſt you was aſleep.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: What do we?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: O ſtrange, an unworthie and naughtie prank.

sp.speaker: D
sp.l: line 20 This is done and paſt.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Was anie thing done to day more unworthilie?
Who when they come to have more wives, then become old men.
Demipho, I appeal to you, for it quite irks me to ſpeak with this man himſelf.
Were theſe things your often journeyings, and long tarryings
At Lemnus? was this the cheapneſs, that leſſened our rent?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 25 Nauſiſtrata, I do not denie but here is blame deſerved in this matter:
But ſuch as may be pardoned.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: You talk to one that is dead.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: For he neither did it through neglect, or diſlike of you,
Being full of wine almoſt above fifteen years ago, he got
Her with childe, of whom this daughter is born, and he never touched her afterwards.
line 30 She is dead, ſhe is gone out of the world, who was to be ſcrupled at in this matter.
Wherefore I intreat you, as your other doings are, that you would take it moderatelie.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What I take it moderatelie? I deſire poor woman to be ſhut of this buſineſs.
But what ſhould I hope? ſhould I think he will leſſe offend further hereafter through age?
He was then alreadie an old man; if old age maketh men baſhful.
line 35 Is my beautie and my age now rather to be deſired, Demipho?
What do you now alledge to me, why I ſhould expect or hope that it be no more ſo?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: For them that have leaſure to go to the burial of Chremes, hoe, it is time.
I will tell them thus? go to now, go to; let who will provoke Phormio;
I will make him be ſlain with ſuch a misfortune, as this man is.
line 40 Let him indeed come into her favour again: I have now puniſhed him enough.
She hath that, which ſhe may ring in his ear to him, as long as he lives.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Do I think this was done through my deſert? why ſhould I now mention thoſe things, Demipho,
Severally, what a wife I have been towards him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I know all things
As well as you.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: This ſeems not to be done through my deſert.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: No in no wiſe.
line 45 But ſeeing it cannot be now undone by accuſing him,
Pardon him: he increateth; he confeſſeth; he cleareth himſelf; what would you have more?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: But indeed before ſhe give him his pardon, I will provide for my ſelf, and Phaedtia.
Ho Nauſiſtrata, before you be too haſty to anſwer him, bear me.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I have got thirtie pounds from him by a trick▪
line 50 I have given it to your ſon: and he hath given it to the bawd for his ſweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Ha, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Do you think it ſuch an unworthy thing, if your ſon
A young man have one ſweet heart, when you have two wives?
Are you aſhamed of nothing? with what face can you chide him? anſwer me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: You ſhall do as you will.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Nay that you may now know my minde,
line 55 Neither do I pardon, nor promiſe any thing, nor make any anſwer,
Before I ſee my ſon; I leave all to his judgement.
What he ſhall command, I will do.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You are a wiſe woman, Nauſiſtrata.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Is this ſufficient for you?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Yea truly Ico me off gallantly and and finely, and beyond my hope.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Do you tell me your name, what it is.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Mine? Phormio,
Truly a friend to your family, and moſt to your Phaedria.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: line 60 Phormio, truly but I will do and ſay for you hereafter any thing I ſhall be able,
And what you ſhall deſire.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: You ſpeak bountifully.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Indeed it is your deſert.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Will you do one thing firſt to day, which I may be glad on, Nauſiſtrata,
And which your husband may not abide to ſee?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I deſire to do it.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Invite me to ſupper.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: line 65 Truly I do invite you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Let us go in hence.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: But where is Phaedria
Our Umpire?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I will cauſe that he ſhall be here by and by. Fare ye well, and clap your hands.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: QUis nominat me?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid iſtuc turbae eſt, obſecro,
Mi vir?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ehem, quid nunc obticuiſti?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quis hic homo eſt?
Non mihi reſpondes?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Hiccine ut tibi reſpondeat,
Qui hercle ubi ſit, neſcit?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Cave iſti quicquam credas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: line 5 Abi, tange, ſi non totus • riget, me eneca.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nihil eſt.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid ergo eſt, quod iſtic narrat?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Jam ſcies;
Auſculta.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Pergin' credere?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid ego, obſecro,
Huic credam qui nihil dixit?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Delirat miſer Timore.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Non pol temerè eſt, quod tu tam times.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: line 10 Egon' timeo?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Rectè ſanè; quando nihil times,
Et hoc nihil eſt, quod dico ego, tu narra.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Scelus! Tibi narret?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Eho tu, factum eſt abs te ſedulò Pro fratre.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Mi vir, non mihi narras?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: At.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid at?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Non opus eſt dicto.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Tibi quidem; at ſcito huic opus eſt.
In Lemno.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hem; quid ais?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Non taces?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Clam te.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hei mihi.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Uxorem duxit.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Mihomo, Dii melius duint.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Sic factum eſt.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Perii miſera.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Et inde filiam
Suſcepit jam unam, dum tu dormis.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Quid agimus?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Pro Dii immortales, facinus indignum & malum?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: line 20 Hoc actum eſt.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: An quicquam hodie eſt factum indignius?
Qui mihi, ubi ad uxoros ventum eſt, tum fiunt ſenes.
Demipho, te appello, nam me cum hoc ipſo diſtaedet loqui;
Haeccine erant itiones crebrae, & manſiones diutinae
Lemni? haeccine erat, quae noſtros fructus minucbat, vilitas?

sp.speaker: D
sp.l: line 25 Ego, Nauſiſtrata, eſſe in hac re culpam meritam non nego,
Sed ea quae ſit ignoſcenda.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Verba fiunt mortuo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Nam neque negligentiâ tuâ, neque odio id fecit tuo.
Vinolentus ferè abhinc annos quindecim mulierculam
Eam compreſſit, unde haec nata eſt, neque poſt illam unquam attigit.
line 30 Ea mortem obiit; è medio abiit; qui fuit in re hac ſcrupulus.
Quam ob rem te oro, ut alia facta tua ſunt, aequo animo hoc feras.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid? ego aequo animo? cupio miſera in hac re jam deſungier.
Sed quid ſperem? aetate porrò minus peccaturum putem?
Jam tum erat ſenex, ſenectus ſiquidem verecundos facit.
line 35 An mea forma atque mea aetas nunc magis expetenda eſt, Demipho?
Quid mihi nunc affers, quamobrem exſpectem aut ſperem porrò non fore?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Exequias Chremeti, quibus eſt commodum ire, hem tempus eſt.
Sic dabo; age nunc, age, Phormionem, qui volet, laceſſito.
Faxo tali cum mactatum, atque hic eſt, infortunio.
line 40 Redeat ſanè in gratiam; jam ſupplicii ſatis eſt mihi.
Habet haec, ei quod dum vivat uſque ad aurem obganniat▪

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: An meo merito credo? quid nunc ea comme norem, Demipho.
Singillatim, qualis ego in hunc fue •…

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Novi aequè omni •
Tecum.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Merito non hoc meo videtur factum.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Minime gentium.
line 45 Verùm quando jam accuſando fieri inf • ctum non poteſt,
Ignoſce: orat, confitetur, purgat: quid vis amplius?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Enimvero priùs quàm haec dat veniam, mihi proſpiciam, & Phaedriae.
Heus Nauſiſtrata, priùs quàm huic reſpondes temerè, audi.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Quid eſt?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ego minas triginta per fallaciam ab illo abſtuli;
line 50 Eas dedi tno gnato: is pro ſua amica lenoni dedit.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Hem quid ais?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Adeon' indignum tibi videtur, filius
Homo adoleſcens unam ſi habet amicam? tu uxores duas.
Nihil pudere? quo ore illum objurgabis? reſponde mihi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Facies ut voles.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Immo, utjam meam ſcias ſententiam,

line 55 Neque ego ignoſco, ne
que promitto quicquam, ne
que reſpondeo,
Priùs quàm gnatum videro; ejus judicio permitto omnia.
Quod is jubebit faciam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Mulier ſapiens es, Nauſiſtrata.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Satin' eſt tibi?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Immo verò pulchrè diſcedo, & probè, & praeter ſpem.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Tu tuum nomen dic, quod eſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Mihin'? Phormio,
line 60 Veſtrae familiae herele amicus, & tuo ſummus Phaedriae.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Phormio, at ego ecaſtor poſtliac tibi quod potero, & qu • voles,
Faciam & dicam.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Benignè dicis.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Pol meritum eſt tuum.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Vin' primum hodie facere, quod ego gaudeam Nauſiſtrata,
Et quod tuo viro oculi doleant?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Cupio.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Me ad coenam voca.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: line 65 Pol verò voco.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Eamus int • ò hinc.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Fiat; ſed ubi eſt Phaedria
Judex noſter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Jam hic faxo aderit. Vos valete, & plaudite.
